headline: Biden Defends Afghan Pullout and Declares an End to Nation-Building
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: The president offered a glimpse of a different American foreign policy in the post-9/11 world, one that he said would be guided more by competition with China and Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday forcefully rejected criticism of his decision to end America’s 20-year war in Afghanistan, hailing what he called the “extraordinary success” of the evacuation of Kabul and declaring the end of an era in which the United States uses military power “to remake other countries.”

headline: An Afghan Left Behind Tells His Story
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Rasheed worked with the U.S. in Afghanistan. Now he is facing threats from the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: This article will also appear in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: What Is Stefanos Tsitsipas Doing in the Bathroom During His Matches?
abstract: Andy Murray says his Monday opponent employs stall tactics too often. Reilly Opelka says Tsitsipas is probably changing his socks.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t his opponent’s dazzling foot speed or the velocity of his serve that Andy Murray was still dwelling on a day after his match. The statistic that stuck with Murray, the 2012 U.S. Open champion, was how long his opponent, Stefanos Tsitsipas, took during his off-court breaks.

headline: Goalball Teammates Set Paralympic Record for Longevity
keywords: ['Goalball', 'Olympic Games (2020)', 'Disabilities', 'Blindness', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Paralympic Games', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: Asya Miller and Lisa Czechowski, who have won three Paralympic medals as teammates, first competed together at the Sydney Games in 2000.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Asya Miller and Lisa Czechowski can’t quite remember when they met, probably because it happened half a lifetime ago. In separate interviews this summer, one guessed that they met at a regional track and field meet. The other thought it happened at a goalball tournament.

headline: Developer Charged in Scheme to Bilk Matt Gaetz’s Family
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: The Justice Department arrested the man for seeking $25 million for a presidential pardon that would have purportedly ended a sex trafficking investigation into Mr. Gaetz.
lead_paragraph: A Florida real estate developer was arrested on Tuesday by the Justice Department for his role in a scheme to bilk $25 million from the family of Representative Matt Gaetz in exchange for a purported presidential pardon that would have ended a sex trafficking investigation into Mr. Gaetz.

headline: Black Surfers Refuse to Be Excluded: ‘I Have a Right to Be on This Wave’
abstract: A new generation of surfers and activists are building on the efforts and achievements of those who came before — and carving out a space for themselves.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of surfers and activists are building on the efforts and achievements of those who came before — and carving out a space for themselves.

headline: Biden Plays the Long Game as He Justifies the End of the ‘Forever War’
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: President Biden is banking on the assumption that he will be remembered for finally extricating the country from the war in Afghanistan, not for how he did it.
lead_paragraph: The forever war is over, but the forever debate may be only beginning. As he presided over the end of a lost 20-year mission in Afghanistan, President Biden on Tuesday touched off a prolonged argument for history over his decision to get out, how he handled it and what it means for the future of America.

headline: Wowza!
abstract: Sean Yamada-Hunter’s debut is a hypothetical masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Administrivial alert: In an earlier version of this puzzle, the clue at 35-Across read “This, in Spanish” for the answer ESO. The word ESO means “that.” The clue has been corrected online.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 01, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 1, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about college students stranded in Afghanistan misstated comments by the president of the American University of Afghanistan about attempts to evacuate students. He said that the university had shared the students’ names with the U.S. military, and that the military’s protocol was to share that information with the Taliban to coordinate access to the airport. He did not say the U.S. military had shared with the Taliban a list of students trying to leave Afghanistan.

headline: Novak Djokovic holds off Holger Rune in his first U.S. Open match.
abstract: Djokovic, who is chasing the Grand Slam, dropped the second set, but his night got easier when the teenager Rune began suffering from cramps in his legs.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, the No. 1-ranked men’s tennis player, began his bid for the final leg of the Grand Slam with a 6-1, 6-7 (5), 6-2, 6-1 victory over Holger Rune in the first round of the U.S. Open on Tuesday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Spurning Critics, Biden Calls Exit Notable Success
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 1, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “I was not going to extend this forever war.”

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: An upcoming change-of-plea hearing for Alexanda Kotey suggests he is cooperating with prosecutors and could provide details about victims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A notorious British member of the Islamic State who is facing federal charges over accusations that he helped jail and tortured Western hostages is preparing to plead guilty, according to a court notice filed late Tuesday.

headline: U.S.A. Gymnastics and Abuse Survivors Propose a $425 Million Payout
keywords: ['Gymnastics', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']

Nassar, the former national team doctor, filed a joint plan on Tuesday that would allow the federation to emerge from bankruptcy and would include a $425 million settlement with those in the sport who were victims of abuse.

headline: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Wednesday

lead_paragraph: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN; 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app. In Canada on TSN from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; and streaming on TSN.ca and the TSN app.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: President Biden’s comments on the Afghanistan withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: Speaking from the White House a day after the final U.S. military plane left Kabul, President Biden vehemently defended the decision to end the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Europe, Afghanistan Is Your Wake-Up Call
abstract: To strengthen the alliance with America, Europe must step up.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban’s takeover in Afghanistan is, first and foremost, a tragedy for Afghans. The world’s attention is rightly focused on trying to help those desperately trying to flee the country and worrying about those left behind, notably women and girls.

headline: Supreme Court, Breaking Silence, Won’t Block Texas Abortion Law
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', "Women's Rights", 'State Legislatures', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The law, which prohibits most abortions after six weeks and went into effect on Wednesday, was drafted by Texas lawmakers with the goal of frustrating efforts to challenge it in federal court.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court refused just before midnight on Wednesday to block a Texas law prohibiting most abortions, less than a day after it took effect and became the most restrictive abortion measure in the nation.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Sustainability Advocates Ask: Why Demolish When You Can Deconstruct?
abstract: More cities are adopting deconstruction ordinances that require older homes to be taken down for salvageable parts, but they face challenges in trying to expand their efforts.
lead_paragraph: As the green building movement evolves beyond energy efficiency into new areas of sustainability, one promising effort focuses on finding new life for used building materials, though advocates say they are struggling with how to expand this niche market.

headline: Japan Needs a Lot More Tech Workers. Can It Find a Place for Women?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Shortages', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The country is pushing to digitally modernize itself, but one of the developed world’s starkest gender gaps is holding it back.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — If Anna Matsumoto had listened to her teachers, she would have kept her inquisitive mind to herself — asking questions, they told her, interrupted class. And when, at age 15, she had to choose a course of study in her Japanese high school, she would have avoided science, a track that her male teachers said was difficult for girls.

headline: Why New York Lawmakers Are Holding a Special Session on Evictions
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul called lawmakers back to Albany to consider extending New York's eviction moratorium.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: An Impossible Task? New Zealand Tries to Eliminate Delta.
abstract: The country is holding fast to a lockdown to contain an outbreak that began in mid-August. But it’s also acknowledging that lockdowns can’t go on forever.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — When New Zealand, for the first time in months, reported a case of community spread of the coronavirus on Aug. 17, residents sprang into action. They stripped supermarket shelves of pasta and toilet paper, dug masks out of drawers and fled to vacation homes in the mountains or at the beach.

headline: Little Simz’s Big Moment
abstract: The British rapper’s laser focus has been trained on fame since she was a child. Now, she’s ready to take it to the next level.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Long before she was famous here as the rapper Little Simz, Simbiatu Abisola Abiola Ajikawo, known as Simbi, made her debut performance at a local youth club showcase. Ten years old and wearing a red Ecko tracksuit, her hair parted in two bunches, she lunged to the edge of the stage, almost collapsing into her classmates in the front row, and rapped: “In 10 years, I want to be a performer that can entertain, and still remain, to do good things in life.”

headline: What to Read: 4 Graphic Works
abstract: From a comics biography of a Spanish surrealist to retro drawings of female pro wrestlers.
lead_paragraph: From a comics biography of a Spanish surrealist to retro drawings of female pro wrestlers.

headline: Newly Published, From Water Statues to the Supreme Court
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: CHASING ME TO MY GRAVE: An Artist’s Memoir of the Jim Crow South, by Winfred Rembert, as told to Erin I. Kelly. (Bloomsbury, $30.) A man recounts surviving a near-lynching in rural Georgia and spending seven years on chain gangs in the late 1960s and early ’70s before creating a successful career of turning painful memories into art.

headline: OPEC and other producers decide to keep adding to oil output.
abstract: The cartel led by Saudi Arabia, along with Russia, will keep to modest production increase negotiated in July.
lead_paragraph: Officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil-producing countries decided on Wednesday to stick with their hard-won July agreement of increasing production each month by 400,000 barrels a day, a modest amount equivalent to less than 1 percent of global supply.

headline: The Secret to Raising a Resilient Kid
abstract: The ability to bounce back is more important now than ever; here’s how to impart it
lead_paragraph: In my early teens, my dad took myself, my best friend and our neighbor on a grueling backpacking trip connecting California’s Yosemite Valley to Half Dome to nearby Clouds Rest mountain and back again.

headline: How Far Can You Go to Resist Being the Subject of a Viral Video?
abstract: One boy’s violent act of retribution raises uncomfortable questions about the world we’ve made for children.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, one of my plans was to appear on some kind of candid video show. I was dimly aware of “Candid Camera” as a phenomenon of my parents’ or possibly my grandparents’ generation, but I fantasized about “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” or even just a spot on the local news. In addition to making me famous, this appearance would capture my insouciant charm. As an unusually self-conscious child — one who used the word “insouciant” a lot, if that gives you a sense of the problem — I hoped a candid video might show me as I really was: likable, quick-thinking, maybe possessed of some undiscovered athletic ability. The best part of this plan was that I could do nothing to advance it; by definition, I had to wait for the camera to discover me. I knew the odds of such a thing happening were astronomical. In the 1990s, people did not just roll up and shoot video of children on the street.

headline: A Holy-Grail, One-Pot Roast Chicken
abstract: It’s the simplest recipe: a little bit braised and a little bit roasted in a covered Dutch oven.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in my early 20s, I went to Paris to strengthen my French and my character. I’m not sure what prompted this — probably something I read — but I woke up one morning and realized that I’d never lived alone. I’d lived with my parents, had roommates briefly and then married when I was 19. All of a sudden this seemed like a shortcoming in need of immediate attention. And so I took all the vacation time I had coming to me from work, booked the cheapest flight I could find, got a tiny top-floor room in a small hotel and enrolled in a course at the Sorbonne. It didn’t take long to discover that going to the movies was a better way to learn a language than sitting in a classroom, and that for me, living alone made me lonely. I’m certain that’s why I followed a stranger home for dinner.

headline: I Never Knew How Golden My Summers Were
abstract: Sometimes, what’s most important becomes clear only with the passage of time.
lead_paragraph: Our order was ready. I headed to the counter and retrieved the fried seafood platter for two, a pornographic avalanche of crispy calamari, shrimp, scallops. There were whole belly clams. There were oysters and codfish, and a mountain of onion rings. There were French fries and homemade coleslaw, and ketchup. There was tartar sauce.

headline: In the Eyes of God, Does a State Have the Right to Kill a Man?
abstract: The state of Texas will execute a death row inmate next week. Is capital punishment as it exists in the United States contrary to religious teachings?
lead_paragraph: The death penalty — and the morality behind it — has long divided America. Joe Biden is the first sitting president in our nation’s history to openly oppose capital punishment. By comparison, his predecessor oversaw the executions of 13 people between July 2020 and the end of his tenure.

headline: College Football Looks to Fundamentals to Combat a 2020 Hangover
abstract: More than one-third of Power 5 teams played eight games or fewer last season. Now coaches are preaching the basics more than usual.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The football coaches talked for days about the basics: how to carry the ball, how to handle a block, how to tackle. As they dissected their position groups, the men professed what they had come to most deeply believe about their game.

headline: How Rollers Became 2021’s Most Unexpected Hair Tool
abstract: With the return of really big hair, a new generation is discovering rollers. Here’s how to master the look.
lead_paragraph: First, they showed up on social media, where this spring a new generation began discovering them in a TikTok hair flip challenge to recreate Farrah Fawcett’s bouncy curls. Then they became the secret weapon for celebrity hairstylists as big volume returned as a thing after years of lived-in looks that erred more on the side of shaggy than bombshell. Take Dove Cameron, Michelle Obama, Laura Dern, Jennifer Lopez and SZA, for example.

headline: Airport Lounges: 7 Questions About Getting Back to Business
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airports', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Credit Cards', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: The majority of airport lounges serving international passengers remain closed, but domestic locations are reopening — offering varying experiences, that is. Here’s what air travelers need to know.
lead_paragraph: Airport lounges, the flier’s respite for unlimited food, drink and Wi-Fi, closed when Covid-19 hit, an early casualty of the pandemic. Now they are reopening in the United States, but experiences vary — many have returned to full capacity while others remain shuttered or lack full service.

headline: We Need to Start Traveling Again. Here’s How.
keywords: ['Vaccination Proof and Immunization Records', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Travel Warnings', 'Quarantines', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: We need a global vaccine certification system to ease international trade and trips.
lead_paragraph: Travel restrictions are disrupting international trade and holding back recovery from the trillions of dollars the pandemic has added to world debt. To stem the damage and open up the world safely, we need a global vaccine certification system — an undertaking that would require the political leadership that only the Group of 20 can provide.

headline: How Strong Is America’s Multiracial Democracy?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Whites', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Recent research on racism, prejudice and politics suggests a broad range of possibilities.
lead_paragraph: The issue cutting across every aspect of American politics today is whether — and how — the nation can survive as a multiracial democracy.

headline: Summer Days, Drifting Away
keywords: ['Summer (Season)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Alcoholic Beverages']
abstract: It’s not over just yet, but we’re getting ready to bid the season farewell. (Plus, cocktail and ice cream recommendations!)
lead_paragraph: It’s almost Labor Day, which means that our time together is coming to an end. We laughed, we cried, we snacked, we island hopped, we … assessed infection risks. After a long summer of mixed vibes, my newsletter partner Michael Gold and I decided to (virtually) sit down and reflect on all of the strangeness that this season brought upon us. (And instead of our usual suggested activities, scroll down for picks on two types of late-summer refreshers: ice cream and cocktails.)

headline: Naomi Osaka on Tennis and Childhood: ‘Home Is Queens and These Courts’
abstract: The defending U.S. Open champion got her start playing with her family in a city park in Jamaica, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Just a few days before Naomi Osaka, the defending champion of the United States Open, stepped onto the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium in Flushing, Queens, for her first match of the 2021 tournament, the four-time Grand Slam title winner made another stop in Queens: to an unassuming public park in Jamaica.

headline: She’s the Investor Guru for Online Creators
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Social Media', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Li Jin, 31, began backing creators years ago. She has raised her own fund to invest in influencer-related start-ups.
lead_paragraph: Cody Ko, a YouTube star with 5.7 million subscribers, found himself in a pickle in May. Two different start-ups wanted to give him stock, and he was concerned that they were potentially competitive deals.

headline: Is Brooklyn Leading New York City Out of the Pandemic?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Small Business']
abstract: The emptying of Manhattan’s office districts has benefited Brooklyn neighborhoods where residents worked from home, testing the balance of power between the city’s boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan has long anchored New York City’s economy, attracting workers and travelers from around the world to its vibrant commercial districts and renowned cultural institutions.

headline: The Downtown Decade: U.S. Population Density Rose in the 2010s
abstract: Outer suburbs still grew the fastest, but many downtowns and central districts also grew rapidly.
lead_paragraph: The recent 2020 census data confirmed earlier estimates that urban counties grew slower than suburban ones over the past decade. But more detailed neighborhood census counts reveal that U.S. population density actually rose in the past decade after falling in the previous two decades, a result of faster growth in the most concentrated parts of urban counties.

headline: It’s Election Season in Germany. No Charisma, Please!
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Debates (Political)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The race to replace Chancellor Angela Merkel after 16 years in office is the tightest in years. But the two leading candidates are anything but exciting, and that’s how Germans like it.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The most popular politician who would like to be chancellor isn’t on the ballot. The leading candidate is so boring people compare him to a machine. Instead of “Yes, We Can!” voters are being fired up with promises of “Stability.”

headline: Covert Evacuations and Planned Demolitions: How the C.I.A. Left Its Last Base in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Demolition', 'your-feed-visual-investigations']
abstract: A compound outside Kabul was one of the most secretive — and notorious — in Afghanistan. Our visual analysis shows how the spy agency shut down its operations there — and how the Taliban then entered the site.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks leading up to President Biden’s Aug. 31 deadline to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan, a secretive and highly secure compound used by the Central Intelligence Agency became a hub for clandestine evacuations before parts of it were deliberately destroyed, an investigation by The New York Times found.

headline: Living In ... Rye Brook, N.Y.
abstract: In this southeastern Westchester community, ‘you don’t have the showiness that you do in some of the nearby towns.’
lead_paragraph: In this southeastern Westchester community, ‘you don’t have the showiness that you do in some of the nearby towns.’

headline: Refugees Are Suffering. This Novelist Won’t Look Away.
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Books and Literature', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Rabih Alameddine writes about topics many would rather forget. In his new book, “The Wrong End of the Telescope,” he tells the story of a transgender doctor attempting to care for people fleeing war-torn Syria.
lead_paragraph: About nine years ago, as thousands of Syrians fled the violence in their country for neighboring Lebanon, the novelist Rabih Alameddine visited some of the refugee camps to speak with them. He didn’t know what would come of it, but he had experience listening to people in extremis — including dying friends during the AIDS epidemic in San Francisco — and he knew the power of the act. At the very least, he thought, he could talk to the kids about soccer.

headline: Rye Brook, N.Y.: A ‘Low-Profile’ Village With Good Schools
abstract: In this southeastern Westchester community, ‘you don’t have the showiness that you do in some of the nearby towns.’
lead_paragraph: Lee Freund likes to say that his family’s house came with a dog. That’s because, two days after he and his wife, Jackie Freund, moved in with their children, Jordan, now 16, and Brooke, 13, Ms. Freund surprised them with an Australian labradoodle puppy. They named him Teddy.

headline: Arizona Banned School Mask Mandates. Now Some Kids Are Sick and Parents Are Angry.
abstract: Gov. Doug Ducey, a Republican who is not allowing schools to impose mask mandates but is a vocal supporter of Covid vaccinations, has been battered from all political sides.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Only weeks after Arizona’s students went back to school, coronavirus infections are forcing thousands of children and teachers into quarantine. Outbreaks around Phoenix are surging. In one suburban district, so many drivers are sick that school buses are running 90 minutes late.

headline: G.O.P. Election Reviews Create a New Kind of Security Threat
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'State Legislatures', 'Computer Security', 'Voting Machines', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Republicans continue to challenge the 2020 results, voting equipment is being compromised when partisan insiders and unvetted operatives gain access.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in May, after surveillance cameras had inexplicably been turned off, three people entered the secure area of a warehouse in Mesa County, Colo., where crucial election equipment was stored. They copied hard drives and election-management software from voting machines, the authorities said, and then fled.

headline: An Artist Who Brings Order to Chaos
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Art', 'Movies', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: John Akomfrah’s films have shaken up official narratives around Black identity and imperialism. His latest tries to make sense of life in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shortly before the artist and filmmaker John Akomfrah left Ghana for Britain after a 1966 coup, the nine-year-old-boy had a final encounter with his grandfather, the High Priest of the Akomfrah clan. The venerated old man wore a ring that had passed down through generations, representing the power to bring order to life’s chaos. It seemed like a perfect parting gift for his eldest grandson.

headline: ‘I Helped Destroy People’
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Terrorism', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Muslim Americans', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Terry Albury, an idealistic F.B.I. agent, grew so disillusioned by the war on terror that he was willing to leak classified documents — and go to prison for doing it.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of Aug. 29, 2017, Terry Albury awoke with a nagging sense of foreboding. It was not yet dawn in Shakopee, Minn., the Minneapolis suburb where Albury, an F.B.I. special agent, lived with his wife and two young children, and he lay in bed for a few minutes, running through the mental checklist of cases and meetings and phone calls, the things that generally made him feel as if his life was in order. He was a 16-year veteran of the F.B.I.: 38, tall and powerfully built, with buzzed black hair and a black goatee. Most of his career he had spent in counterterrorism, investigating sleeper cells and racking up commendations signed by the F.B.I. directors Robert Mueller and James Comey, which praised his “outstanding” work recruiting confidential sources and exposing terrorist financing networks. He was a careful investigator and a keen observer. “Something is going on behind the scenes that I’m not aware of,” he told his wife the night before. She told him to stop worrying. “You always think there’s something going on.” She was right. But this time he had reason to be apprehensive, even though he’d been careful. The memory card was buried in his closet, tucked into a shirt pocket under a pile of clothes. “Stop being so paranoid,” he told himself. Then he left for work.

headline: Joining Plastic, Glass and Metal on the Recycle List: Fake Art
abstract: Experts say discredited works of art often resurface on the market again and again, in part because their owners just won’t take no for an answer.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who thinks works of art declared to be fake simply disappear in disgrace or are destroyed should talk to Jane Kallir, the author of the catalog raisonné for Egon Schiele, the Austrian painter. She was offered the same fake Schiele watercolor for authentication, she said, 10 times by 10 different collectors.

headline: Afghanistan Before the Fall
abstract: It all happened so fast.
lead_paragraph: A FACADE OF NORMALITY

headline: The Taliban are poised to name a supreme leader and map out their government.
abstract: The Taliban are preparing to set out their new Islamic government imminently, naming Sheikh Haibatullah Akhundzada, the insurgency’s top religious leader, as the country’s supreme authority, according to a Taliban official.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban are preparing to set out their new Islamic government imminently, naming Sheikh Haibatullah Akhundzada, the insurgency’s top religious leader, as the country’s supreme authority, according to a Taliban official.

headline: Hurricane Larry Brings Snow to Parts of Greenland
abstract: The storm stayed out to sea but brought a hurricane season oddity to some parts of the island: snow caused by the remnants of a tropical storm.
lead_paragraph: After striking Canada as a Category 1 hurricane and causing widespread power outages in Newfoundland, Larry moved north toward Greenland, where the storm stayed out to sea but brought a hurricane season oddity to some parts of the island: snow caused by the remnants of a tropical storm.

headline: Pandemics Get Forgotten. But Not at This Museum.
keywords: ['Museums', 'Medicine and Health', 'Epidemics', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The collection of the German Hygiene Museum shows that the same debates recur whenever disease breaks out, even if we don’t remember them.
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — In a display case at the German Hygiene Museum here is a pretty, blue glass bottle whose daintiness belies its purpose. Manufactured in 1904, it is a flask for tuberculosis patients to wear at the hip, so they could spit up infectious phlegm with relative discretion. (In Thomas Mann’s 1924 novel “The Magic Mountain,” residents of a sanitarium nickname this device Blue Heinrich.)

headline: New Zealand struggles as it tries to eliminate the Delta variant.
abstract: Two weeks later, New Zealand is still in lockdown, one that will last at least another 14 days.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — When New Zealand, for the first time in months, reported a case of community spread of the coronavirus on Aug. 17, residents sprang into action. They stripped supermarket shelves of pasta and toilet paper, dug socked-away masks out of drawers and fled to vacation homes in the mountains or at the beach.

headline: Kenny Malone, a premier drummer for top Nashville names, dies of Covid.
abstract: Kenny Malone, a prolific Nashville session drummer whose skittering snare rhythms haunted Dolly Parton’s No. 1 country hit “Jolene” in 1973 and whose cocktail-jazz groove anchored Crystal Gayle’s crossover smash “Don’t It Make My Brown Eyes Blue” in 1977, died on Thursday from Covid-19. He was 83.

That news induced nausea in abortion-rights advocates around the country, as they waited to see what the court’s newly turbocharged conservative majority would do after oral arguments in the case expected to be heard this fall.

headline: Gail Omvedt, 80, Dies; India Became Her Home, the Caste System Her Cause

lead_paragraph: Gail Omvedt, an anti-caste crusader, scholar and prolific author who championed the cause of India’s marginalized communities and was a leader in the country’s feminist movement, died on Aug. 25 at her home in the western state of Maharashtra. She was 80.

headline: Julian Schnabel Revisits van Gogh, and Paints Oscar Isaac’s Severed Head
abstract: In a new exhibition, the artist returns to the subject of his latest movie and explores the connections between two seemingly separate parts of his career.
lead_paragraph: Painting and filmmaking are related mediums, but there is a relatively small canon of good films about painters. These are, by my own, probably highly debatable, count: Kenji Mizoguchi’s “Utamaro and His Five Women” (1946), Vincente Minnelli’s “Lust for Life” (1956), John Huston’s “Moulin Rouge” (1952), Andrei Tarkovsky’s “Andrei Rublev” (1969), Peter Greenaway’s “The Draughtsman’s Contract” (1982), Jacque Rivette’s “La Belle Noiseuse” (1990), Ed Harris’s “Pollock” (2000), Julie Taymor’s “Frida” (2002), Mike Leigh’s “Mr. Turner” (2014), Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck’s “Never Look Away” (2018) — and two movies by Julian Schnabel, who is the only director on the list who can also claim to have made a pretty decent living as a painter. His first film, 1996’s “Basquiat,” is about his former contemporary Jean-Michel Basquiat, and is part biopic (the title character is played by the great Jeffrey Wright), part artistic treatise and almost as much about Schnabel, who actually painted the imitations of Basquiat works that appear in the film himself (he refers to them now as “props”) and shot various scenes inside his own New York City home. His second and superior film about a painter, 2018’s “At Eternity’s Gate,” is an existential portrait of Vincent van Gogh — played by Willem Dafoe — that illustrates the contrast between his pained final days and his outsize influence.

headline: Three Officers and Two Paramedics Are Charged in Elijah McClain’s Death

headline: Sally Rooney and Love in the Time of General Systems Collapse
abstract: In “Beautiful World, Where Are You,” the novelist and her stand-ins chew over questions about fame, sex, idealism and other subjects.
lead_paragraph: It’s very Gen X to complain about stardom, to make a show of resisting it. A bit ironic then, if understandable, that the Irish novelist Sally Rooney is chafing at her fame. If you read only glancingly about literary culture, you could be forgiven for thinking that she is less a writer than a piece of $20 avocado toast, an excuse for people to express bafflement at the very idea of millennials and what they might be after or up to. Generational profiles often have broad truths to offer, but Rooney’s youth (the author of “Conversations With Friends” and “Normal People” is just now 30) seems to have short-circuited many observers. The discussion around her can feel so extraliterary that it’s easy to lose sight of what she does well on the page, which is quite a bit.

headline: ‘Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings’ Review: House of Hidden Dragons
abstract: A millennial slacker reckons with his past — and his family of warriors.
lead_paragraph: Home is where the heart is. Unless you’re Shang-Chi. Then home is where your mother’s mystical secret village — and its dragon guardian — is. That’s the case in Marvel’s unsteady “Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings,” directed by Destin Daniel Cretton with an obliging eye toward kung fu cinema, but not much else.

headline: Weddings for Rent

abstract: These days, everything but the spouse is available on loan.
lead_paragraph: A dramatic multi-tier cake, Chanel pearls, $800 Christian Louboutins — maybe the financial hardship of the pandemic has made all of these big-day splurges seem a little less appealing than they once did. Or maybe (probably also because of the pandemic) you’re having last-minute nuptials and simply don’t have time to shop for these investments. Or maybe you’d just really like an extra bridesmaid to pitch in for the celebration. Whatever your wedding need, there’s likely a rental service for it. keywords: ['Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Football', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']

headline: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Radical feminist futures at the Bronx Museum; February James’s excellent New York debut; and sculptures from Argentine Concrete artists.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Museum of the Arts, which turned 50 this year, was founded partly as a way of bringing mainstream art from Manhattan to the borough. Its debut exhibition in 1971 featured loans from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In the decades since, the programming has been increasingly responsive to global consciousness and its South Bronx neighborhood, making the museum — which is admission free — one of the most adventurous art spaces in the city.

headline: Gauff-Stephens U.S. Open Matchup Another Sign of the Williams Legacy
abstract: Neither Venus nor Serena Williams entered the U.S. Open this year. But their influence in the women’s singles tournament is clear.
lead_paragraph: When Sloane Stephens and Coco Gauff face off on Wednesday night at the U.S. Open, their drawing power as young Black women in Arthur Ashe Stadium will be just the latest showcase of the legacy of the sisters Venus and Serena Williams.

abstract: About a fifth of all people evacuated from Kabul were brought to Ramstein Air Base in Germany, where they await the next leg of their journey, to the United States.
lead_paragraph: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — As the workday drew to a close at the U.S. air base in southwest Germany, “The Star-Spangled Banner” rang out from speakers set up across the vast facility.

headline: Robert Middlekauff, Historian of Washington and His War, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: He wrote what many believe to be the best single-volume history of the Revolutionary War and another work seeing the war through the eyes of George Washington.
lead_paragraph: Robert Middlekauff, a distinguished historian who wrote what is considered one of the best one-volume histories of the American Revolution as well as a study of George Washington’s experience of the War of Independence, died on March 10 at a retirement community in Pleasanton, Calif. He was 91.

headline: N.Y.C.’s mayor directs city employees to return to the office full-time soon.
abstract: There are more than 300,000 city workers overall, but many of them are essential employees who have already been reporting to job sites.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City has directed all of the city employees who are currently working from home to return to the office full-time starting in less than two weeks, a signal that he is intent on resurrecting the city’s office-dependent central business district despite the Delta variant of the coronavirus.

headline: Modern Monetary Theory Has a New Friend in Congress
abstract: John Yarmuth is a big fiscal deal. He says we should be open to deficit spending.
lead_paragraph: The influence of Modern Monetary Theory in Congress is growing faster than most people realize. M.M.T., as it’s known, is an economic theory that says government budget deficits don’t matter unless they overwhelm the economy’s productive capacity and cause high inflation. That message appeals to Democrats in Congress who want to raise spending without having to worry about the resulting red ink. It could even appeal to Republicans who want to cut taxes.

headline: 13 Delicious, Original Ways to Eat Eggs for Dinner
abstract: Dinner can be inspired with these inventive takes on a world-class protein.
lead_paragraph: When searching for a meatless dinner idea that’s still rich in protein, eggs are underrated. Sure, having breakfast for dinner is always a solid option, but eggs are good for more than being a side to pancakes and hash browns. Below are recipes for pasta, curry, sandwiches and scrambles that are decidedly dinner-appropriate. If you’re looking for more vegetarian dinner ideas, sign up for The Veggie, New York Times Cooking’s new weekly newsletter.

headline: How Should I Respond to Creepy Questions About My Friend’s Race?
keywords: ['Asian-Americans', 'Friendship', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: You can’t assume you know how your friend will feel about these questions. Your first step should be to find out.
lead_paragraph: On several occasions, I’ve been at a bar or party with an Asian American friend and when my friend is getting a drink or off to the bathroom, a man (it’s always a man) will ask me, “Where is she from” or “What type of Asian is she?” I usually try to deflect the former question with “She’s from [hometown]” and with the latter I’ll pretend not to know or ask, “Why does it matter?” They either roll their eyes or ask again another way. I really don’t know how to deal with this situation productively as an ally. I usually don’t mention it to my friend both because I feel it’s my responsibility to deal with it and because we’ll probably never see the offending person again. I don’t even really know if it’s something that would upset her, but I know nobody’s ever waited for me to walk away so that they could ask my friend what kind of white I am. How should I handle these sorts of perpetual-foreigner questions? Should I tell my friend when it happens?

headline: The Minimum Voting Age Should Be Zero
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Youth', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Parenting']
abstract: When kids are babies, parents should vote for them. As they grow up, they should take on more autonomy, until they finally vote on their own.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 presidential election saw the highest vote total in any American election ever, driven by a historic increase in turnout among eligible voters. Even so, the total number of voters amounted to just 48 percent of the population measured in the 2020 census. Most people living in America either could not or did not cast a vote.For each group of people prohibited from casting a vote, there is some rationale. Noncitizens are not formally part of the body politic; democracies since Athens have included franchise restrictions as punishment for criminals; children can’t make well-informed rational choices. Many people may disagree with one or several of these choices. Maybe denying the franchise to felons is unjust, given bias in the criminal justice system, or perhaps permanent residents should be allowed to vote, as they often could in the 19th century.

headline: Shifting to Governing, Taliban Will Name Supreme Afghan Leader
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Food Insecurity', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Shortages']
abstract: Facing immense challenges in a devastated country, and a hard transition from war to administration, the Islamist movement is preparing to name a new, theocratic government.
lead_paragraph: On the second full day with no U.S. troops on Afghan soil, the Taliban moved Wednesday to form a new Islamic government, preparing to appoint the movement’s leading religious figure, Sheikh Haibatullah Akhundzada, as the nation’s supreme authority, Taliban officials said.

headline: Coming to Terms With the Legacy of Rick James
keywords: ['Music', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: For a new documentary, the director and the star’s daughter examine both his pioneering work and his misogyny, as well as a sexual assault conviction.
lead_paragraph: It’s no question that Rick James is a legend for helping bring “punk-funk” to the mainstream with classics like “Mary Jane” and “Super Freak”; for breaking down the color barrier in rock ’n’ roll; and for confronting the whiteness of MTV in the ’80s. But how do you reckon with the man who is just as famous for committing sexual assault and perpetuating misogyny in the music industry? To Sacha Jenkins, director of the fascinating new documentary, “Bitchin’: The Sound and Fury of Rick James,” the answer is complicated.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Photo No No’s’ and More
abstract: I'm a photo editor for the Arts section. Here are five things I've been watching and reading lately.
lead_paragraph: I'm a photo editor for the Arts section. Here are five things I've been watching and reading lately.

headline: Robert Kennedy Was My Dad. His Assassin Doesn’t Deserve Parole.
abstract: Sirhan Sirhan killed the father I never knew. Why should he go free?
lead_paragraph: I never met my father. When Sirhan Sirhan murdered him in the kitchen hallway of the Ambassador Hotel in front of scores of witnesses, my mother was three months pregnant with me. Of my 10 older brothers and sisters, Kathleen, the eldest, was 16, and Douglas, the youngest, was little more than 1. I was born six months after my father’s death. My mother and the majority of my siblings agree with what I now write, although a couple do not. But I will say, for myself, while that night of terrible loss has not defined my life, it has had impact beyond measure.

headline: Afghan siblings recount the perils of the first day of Taliban rule.

headline: Ida’s Heavy Rains Send Louisiana Residents on a Hunt for Clean Water
keywords: ['Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Water', 'Shortages', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Levees and Dams', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Nearly everyone in Jefferson Parish, next to New Orleans, was experiencing problems with their water service after the power went out. Lines for bottled water were growing.
lead_paragraph: KENNER, La. — In one of the many lines snaking into gas stations, out of groceries and around hardware stores in Jefferson Parish, La., on Wednesday sat Jeanne DiLeo, in her car, waiting. The simplest of necessities required hours of effort in the world that Hurricane Ida left behind. She had driven to Mississippi to buy fuel to keep her car running and her generator going, and was now sitting in a caravan of vehicles in front of a church to get food and — most important — water.

abstract: President Biden’s climate envoy ended talks in China with a pledge to continue negotiations. But Beijing warned that broader U.S.-China tensions hurt cooperation.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 2, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Sept. 2, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about lawmakers who sought to help the U.S. evacuation effort in Afghanistan misstated the circumstances of the evacuation from Kabul of a pair of Afghan orphans. A contact of Senator Jon Ossoff called an ex-military officer to help them at the airport, not Mr. Ossoff himself. The orphans had encountered difficulties getting on a U.S. government plane, but were not lost.

Beneath that was a portrait of Lil Nas X and, just below it, an assemblage of stories about Aaliyah’s personal style.

headline: Mikis Theodorakis, ‘Zorba’ Composer and Marxist Rebel, Dies at 96
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Music', 'Political Prisoners', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Politics and Government', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Movies']
abstract: Known for his film music, he also waged a war of words and music against a military junta that banned his work and imprisoned him during its rule of Greece.
lead_paragraph: Mikis Theodorakis, the renowned Greek composer and Marxist firebrand who waged a war of words and music against an infamous military junta that imprisoned and exiled him as a revolutionary and banned his work a half century ago, died on Thursday at his home in central Athens. He was 96.

headline: The Best-Seller List Welcomes Oprah’s Latest Pick and an Eyebrow-Raising Gadget
abstract: September is a brisk month for big books. This week’s standouts include “The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois” and “Dopamine Nation.”
lead_paragraph: OPRAH’S FAVORITE On Aug. 24, clad in beige athleisure wear and brandishing an iPad, Oprah announced her latest book club selection: “The Love Songs of W. E. B. Du Bois,” by Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, a poet whose first work of fiction clocks in at 816 pages. (On Instagram, she refers to it as “my Big Chubby Baby of a novel.”) One would be hard-pressed to locate a review that doesn’t describe this multigenerational epic, exploring Black history and family legacy through a young woman’s eyes, as “sprawling” or “sweeping.” On Page 9 of this issue, our reviewer writes, “‘The Love Songs of W. E. B. Du Bois’ is quite simply the best book that I have read in a very, very long time.” It enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4, almost 25 years to the day after Oprah announced her very first book club pick: Jacqueline Mitchard’s “The Deep End of the Ocean,” another debut novel that went on to be a best seller (for 16 months). In 1996, when Oprah announced the choice on her talk show, she said: “I want to get the whole country reading again. Those of you who haven’t been reading, I think books are important!” She explained how the club would work: Readers who wanted to have dinner with Mitchard could send a letter to a Chicago P.O. box or “write us at America Online, those of us who know how to do that.” The studio audience smiled politely and clapped.

headline: Exploring Manhattan’s Junior Fours. Which Apartment Would You Choose?

headline: Poem: Flight
abstract: Sometimes the poem sings when you say it, and then sings more when you say it again.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the poem sings when you say it, and then sings more when you say it again. Take these lines: “Forget the years that only grow harder/as the soul recedes in what the years bring.” I hear it and say, “Yes, I’ve been there.” And you feel a bit of sorrow at how you’ve changed. You wonder why the poem has taken you to such sadness. But the singing keeps going, and you’re now like Lenny Williams, crying, “Oh, I love you, baby,” into some night. And saying: “Touch me. As I am. As you can./My heart a bird’s heart just beyond your hand.” Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Dog Moms
abstract: Is the owner of an animal its parent?
lead_paragraph: Holly writes: We recently got a puppy from my sister-in-law, whose dogs had a litter. She’s a self proclaimed “dog mom,” so she calls herself our puppy’s grandma. Please order her to stop this, at least in my presence.

headline: Apple Has New Tools to Protect Children. But at What Cost?
keywords: ['audio-negative-tragedy', 'audio-neutral-informative', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Social Media', 'Sex Crimes', 'Privacy']

lead_paragraph: Apple has long been a pioneer on privacy, and has made that a central part of its marketing. So it was surprising to see privacy groups complain last month when it announced new features meant to combat child sexual abuse.

headline: Most N.Y. Colleges Require Vaccination. Students Are Fine With That.

headline: Asian Americans Are Finally Getting the Heroes We Deserve
abstract: The release of “Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings” is a meaningful moment for Asian American representation.
lead_paragraph: When I and many of my Asian American peers were growing up, we were so hungry to see ourselves represented that we’d scream and call the family to join us in the living room when an Asian guest star wandered into a scene on TV or a commercial came on featuring an Asian family. We’d scour celebrities’ biographies to surface “undercover Asians,” those with trace evidence of Asian heritage. Phoebe Cates, yes! Joseph Gordon-Levitt, no.

headline: Maggie Nelson Wants to Redefine ‘Freedom’
keywords: ['Art', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: In her new essay collection, the writer wants to enunciate all the meanings and manifestations of the word that our current conversation obscures.
lead_paragraph: It was June when I arrived in Northeast Los Angeles, right in the middle of Pride Month, though there wasn’t much evidence of it. In the Bay Area, where I arrived from, rainbow flags, storefront decorations and clumsy attempts at inclusive marketing were ubiquitous. But here, in Southern California’s stupefying sunlight, there were, thankfully, no billboards equating the freedom to date whom you want to the freedom to order weed via an app. Driving along Colorado Boulevard, I encountered only the confusing jumble of gentrification: mom-and-pop doughnut shops next to high-concept pet day cares. In the light, the entire city seemed to be shrugging at me.

headline: The Truth Is That You Can’t Protect Everything From Every Hurricane
keywords: ['Coast Erosion', 'Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Coastal Areas', 'Beaches', 'Wetlands', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Floods']

The first is the hardest to acknowledge: No matter what you spend in vulnerable coastal areas, you can’t protect everything from every storm.

headline: Flameouts and Flimflammery in Four Just-Published Mysteries
abstract: Nail-biting new crime fiction from Amy Stewart, Craig Nova, Catherine Dang and Karen Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: In her ongoing historical mystery series, now seven books strong, Amy Stewart has embellished the lives of the real Kopp sisters, Constance, Norma and Fleurette. The first book, “Girl Waits With Gun,” drew on an actual crime (and Constance’s role as one of the country’s first female deputy sheriffs), but Stewart has since let her imagination roam. MISS KOPP INVESTIGATES (Mariner, 295 pp., paper, $15.99) — set in 1919 — sees Norma returned from overseas wartime duty, Constance about to embark on a new career with the Bureau of Investigation, as the F.B.I. was then called, and Fleurette, her theater dreams dashed after a case of scarlet fever, finding new ways to employ her talents.

headline: Several industrialized nations are beginning to give booster shots this month.

lead_paragraph: This month, several countries have begun or will start giving booster shots to people already vaccinated against the coronavirus, in an effort to bolster immunity in the face of the fast-spreading Delta variant and the change to a cooler season that is likely to bring more people together indoors.

headline: Hawaii is facing an oxygen shortage amid a record surge in virus cases.
abstract: The state medical authorities have also warned of a dwindling number of I.C.U. beds and are asking people to postpone elective surgeries.

headline: This Theater Brings Nature Right Into the Drama
abstract: A lush forest makes a spectacular backdrop for the stage of the Théâtre du Peuple, in eastern France.
lead_paragraph: BUSSANG, France — Hundreds of productions have been performed at the Théâtre du Peuple, a 126-year-old playhouse in this village 45 miles from the border with Germany. Yet no matter how good the actors, they are often upstaged by the theater’s unusual backdrop: a steep forest, visible right behind the stage.

headline: Newark airport temporarily halts flights after severe flooding across New Jersey.

lead_paragraph: Torrential rain brought by remnants of Hurricane Ida caused severe flooding across parts of Newark on Wednesday night and into Thursday, rendering streets impassable and prompting Newark Liberty International Airport to temporarily suspend flights.

abstract: Sixteen years after Katrina, the latest hurricane was a test of how prepared cities like New Orleans are for extreme weather.

lead_paragraph: Austin-Healey’s Mark I Sprite, a little racer known as a Bugeye, is perhaps not the first car you’d consider for a cross-country drive. For one thing, there’s no trunk lid (access is from behind the seats), nor external door handles or actual glass windows — there are removable “side curtains” instead.

headline: Taiwan receives its first batch of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines after a monthslong delay.
abstract: The first batch of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines arrived in Taiwan on Thursday morning, health officials said. The delivery of the 930,000 doses came after a monthslong struggle to acquire BioNTech’s vaccines on the island.
lead_paragraph: The first batch of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines arrived in Taiwan on Thursday morning, health officials said. The delivery of the 930,000 doses came after a monthslong struggle to acquire BioNTech’s vaccines on the island.

headline: Here’s how much rain fell across the New York City area.
abstract: Record rain was recorded across the area, including 7.19 inches in Central Park during a 24-hour period.
lead_paragraph: Record levels of rain fell across the New York City area on Wednesday as the remains of Hurricane Ida moved through. Here are the total amounts measured by the National Weather Service between 4 a.m. Wednesday and 4 a.m. Thursday at locations across the region.

headline: Climate Bankruptcy
abstract: Remnants of Hurricane Ida barreled into the New York City region. And what happens when climate change comes to a small Southern town.
lead_paragraph: Fair Bluff is a small North Carolina town in an idyllic setting, amid cornfields and tobacco fields and alongside the verdant Lumber River. But Fair Bluff’s setting may also be dooming the town.

headline: ‘Memory House’ Review: Seeking a Niche Between Present and Past
abstract: An Indigenous worker in Brazil finds a surreal portal of sorts to the culture of his forebears.
lead_paragraph: While I don’t exactly agree that the worst of times generate the most compelling art, political turmoil can certainly inspire some of the angriest work. Case in point: the recent surge of class-conscious films by a number of Brazilian directors, such as Kleber Mendonça Filho (“Bacurau”), responding to the government’s austerity policies and its willful neglect of the country’s cultural heritage.

headline: ‘Zone 414’ Review: Dreaming of Electric Sheep, Again
abstract: A blatant “Blade Runner” rip-off, this perfunctory techno-noir sees a brooding detective team up with an emotional android.
lead_paragraph: “Zone 414” doesn’t bother with subtlety. It’s a blatant “Blade Runner” rip-off complete with brooding bounty hunters, psychotic billionaires playing God, and doe-eyed androids searching for love. The folks responsible for this copycat must be banking on the mix-up.

headline: House Panel Requests McCarthy’s Phone Records Be Preserved in Jan. 6 Inquiry
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Social Media', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the top House Republican, has threatened to punish any company that agrees to preserve records for the congressional committee investigating the attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot included Representative Kevin McCarthy, the Republican leader, this week on a list of hundreds of people whose records it instructed social media and telecommunications companies to preserve for possible use in the inquiry.

headline: ‘Mogul Mowgli’ Review: Rapping for Dear Life
abstract: Riz Ahmed plays a hip-hop artist who faces illness and identity crises in Bassam Tariq’s electrifying new film.
lead_paragraph: We first meet Zaheen, whose rap moniker is Zed, onstage at a club in New York. Wiry and wired, with a whispery intensity and a quick sense of humor — and played by Riz Ahmed with everything he has — Zed is on the verge of a career breakthrough after years of almost-stardom. He’s also about to break up with his girlfriend, Bina (Aiysha Hart), and face an illness that will precipitate a wrenching identity crisis.

headline: ‘Happier Than Ever’ Review: Modern Pop Meets Classic Hollywood
abstract: In the Disney+ concert film “Happier Than Ever: A Love Letter to Los Angeles,” the pop star Billie Eilish pays tribute to the star-struck hauntedness of that city.
lead_paragraph: The concert film “Happier Than Ever: A Love Letter to Los Angeles” finds the pop musician Billie Eilish performing in her hometown, and taking her place in the long lineage of stars who have been shaped by the mythology of Los Angeles.

headline: ‘We Need to Do Something’ Review: I Think I’ll Stay In
abstract: A family rides out a diabolical storm by holing up in a bathroom in this slice of confinement horror.
lead_paragraph: As if timed to hurricane season, “We Need to Do Something” kicks off with a family of four riding out a storm in a big suburban bathroom. Then it turns out that the weather forecast is not the issue: the family’s antsy teenager, Melissa (Sierra McCormick), may have sort of unleashed the forces of hellfire through black magic high jinks with a schoolmate.

headline: ‘Faya Dayi’ Review: A Dream State
abstract: Jessica Beshir’s debut feature settles into a trance-like flow.
lead_paragraph: Shot in a rural Ethiopian town, the tone poem “Faya Dayi” settles into a trance-like flow. We watch men and occasionally women musing to one another — about their dreams for the future or about distant lovers, mothers and fathers — but the feel is dreamlike, like a falling dusk, even when the concerns are concrete.

headline: ‘Yakuza Princess’ Review: Crime, Amnesia and Ancient Swords
abstract: This mayhem-filled film from Brazil has no higher function beyond its beheadings.
lead_paragraph: You know this movie isn’t kidding around from its opening scene. Set in Osaka “20 years ago,” the blue-tinted sequence depicts a solemn ceremony broken up by bloody gun assassinations, culminating with a young boy taking a bullet in the back of his neck. So when I say “isn’t kidding around,” what I mean is “wants to impress you with the crass opportunism of its violence.”

headline: ‘Bitchin’: The Sound and Fury of Rick James’ Review: A Very Kinky Guy
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: A new documentary explores the serious artistry behind this “punk-funk” legend’s outlandish persona.
lead_paragraph: The main title of this Sacha Jenkins-directed documentary derives from a sketch on Dave Chappelle’s still-mourned former show on Comedy Central. He regularly reenacted anecdotes told by the comic Charlie Murphy; in one of these, the funk renegade Rick James did some obscene blustering at a bar before announcing “I’m Rick James, bitch!” The sketch resulted in new visibility for James while also making him a cartoon.

headline: ‘The Year of the Everlasting Storm’ Review: Home Movies
abstract: Seven directors present their views of the year of pandemic lockdown, but most fall into predictable territory.
lead_paragraph: You can’t blame filmmakers for keeping busy during lockdown. The omnibus film “The Year of the Everlasting Storm” assembles pandemic-made shorts from around the globe. But with just two decent segments out of seven, this anthology uncannily replicates the sensation of feeling trapped.

headline: ‘Worth’ Review: Appraising Lives
abstract: Starring Michael Keaton, this is a surprisingly effective movie about a tricky subject — the creation of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund.
lead_paragraph: The central question of “Worth” is whether it’s possible to reduce a life to a dollar value. The film, directed by Sara Colangelo (the American remake of “The Kindergarten Teacher”), dramatizes the creation of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, which the federal government established after the attacks to limit lawsuits against the airlines. The lawsuits’ downstream effects, the reasoning went, could sink the United States economy.

headline: After pummeling the New York area, Ida soaks New England.
abstract: A tornado hit Cape Cod and a Connecticut State Police sergeant died after his vehicle was swept away in floodwaters, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Hurricane Ida swept across parts of southern New England on Thursday, flooding streets and homes while not causing the catastrophic damage that just hours earlier had paralyzed the New York City area and led to the deaths of dozens of people.

headline: The Business of Voting in Texas
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPAC)', 'Voting Rights, Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A new bill overhauling election laws is putting corporate pledges on ballot access to the test.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-controlled Texas Legislature this week passed a major bill overhauling election laws in the state, the latest of many to tighten voting rules this year. In Texas, as elsewhere, many businesses and industry groups have spoken out against the move, arguing that it is bad for the economy.

headline: Facebook’s WhatsApp is fined for breaking the E.U.’s data privacy law.
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Social Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)']
abstract: Regulators in Ireland, where many tech giants have their European headquarters, have been criticized for not enforcing Europe’s data-protection law, once heralded as a global standard.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s WhatsApp messaging service was fined nearly $270 million by Irish authorities on Thursday for not being transparent about how it uses data collected from people on the service, in a case that represents a big test of Europe’s ability to enforce its landmark data privacy law.

headline: Videos Show Flooded N.Y.C. Transit System
abstract: Across the city, New Yorkers documented the scene as flood waters overwhelmed buses and subways. Nearly every subway line in the city was shut down.
lead_paragraph: Across the city, New Yorkers documented the scene as flood waters overwhelmed buses and subways. Nearly every subway line in the city was shut down.

headline: ‘Wild Indian’ Review: Reckoning With the Past to Save the Present
abstract: This drama from Lyle Mitchell Corbine Jr. captures the various wounds of individual, familial and generational trauma.
lead_paragraph: “Some time ago, there was an Ojibwe man, who got a little sick and wandered West,” the intertitle at the start of “Wild Indian” states. The camera finds a man stooped and slowly making his way through the woods and follows him for a spell. “Little” is an understatement: His face is covered with pox blisters. This more-than-cautionary note sets the tone for the First Nations writer-director Lyle Mitchell Corbine Jr.’s symbolically rich and subtle thriller focused on two cousins who share a secret about a rending act of violence.

headline: Texas businesses take the fight over voting rights to Washington.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Voting Rights, Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Community leaders are planning to approach the Biden administration and congressional lawmakers to press for passage of two federal voting rights laws.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-controlled Texas Legislature this week passed a major bill overhauling election laws in the state, the latest of many to tighten voting rules this year. In Texas, as elsewhere, many businesses and industry groups have spoken out against the move, arguing that it is bad for the economy.

headline: Texas? Idaho? Where Californians Are Moving.
abstract: The recall election has resurfaced talk of a “California exodus.”
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing the candidates vying to replace Gov. Gavin Newsom can agree on, it’s that too many Californians are fleeing the state.

headline: The T List: Six Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Home décor from Dolce & Gabbana, a Brutalist eatery — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Cobble Hill, Lenox Hill and on the Grand Concourse.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Cobble Hill, Lenox Hill and on the Grand Concourse.

headline: Thomas Nozkowski’s Final Statement
abstract: In the face of terminal cancer, an artist focused and refined his singular style of abstract painting right till the end.
lead_paragraph: With a farmer’s diligence and a detective’s ingenuity, the painter Thomas Nozkowski marked out and cultivated a deceptively modest territory for nearly five decades. His harvest was inexhaustibly bountiful. “What I most respect about Nozkowski’s work is its endless inventiveness,” the sculptor Martin Puryear, who was his upstate New York neighbor and close friend, said in a phone interview. “Each of his paintings is its own story, and the story of the painting is in the painting.”

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Cobble Hill, Lenox Hill and on the Grand Concourse.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Easton, Conn., and a six-bedroom in Huntington Bay, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Easton, Conn., and a six-bedroom in Huntington Bay, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom house in Easton, Conn., and a six-bedroom house in Huntington Bay, N.Y.
