headline: My Ex Risked Our Daughter’s Health for … a Photo Op?
abstract: A reader asks for permission to scold her former husband (and his current wife).
lead_paragraph: My ex-husband invited our 19-year-old daughter to spend a long weekend in Las Vegas with him, his wife and their children. She was excited to go. She asked him how to pack, in case she needed dressy clothes. He told her to pack for hot weather and outdoor activities. After arriving, she discovered they weren’t going to Las Vegas at all. They drove to Zion National Park for several days of hiking. But my daughter has heat-induced asthma, and her father knows this! Hiking in 107-degree heat is a health risk for her. When she asked to stop, they refused and she was raised not to argue with them. So she overused her rescue inhaler. Later, she discovered they intentionally misled her about the trip because they feared she wouldn’t come, and they wanted a family picture for their Christmas card. Please tell me I can call them out?

headline: Venice, Day 1: See the Almodóvar, Free the Nipple
abstract: The director was the toast of a glamorous dinner with Penélope Cruz, Isabelle Huppert and Denis Villeneuve, who talked about “Dune” as if he were a proud parent.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Denis Villeneuve, the director of “Dune,” wanted to apologize in advance.

headline: Ready for October, the Yankees Have to Get Through September
abstract: As the team returns from a disappointing road trip, and hits the stretch run of September, its margin for error is still “razor-thin.”
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — One final time this summer, the Yankees’ charter crossed the Continental Divide, traveling eastbound overnight Wednesday to deliver the players home snugly into the stretch run of September.

headline: This Season’s Vital College Football Statistic: Vaccination Rates
abstract: With forfeits possible this year, teams see vaccinations as competitive advantages, prompting locker room campaigns to drive rates higher.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — PJ Mustipher, a defensive tackle for Penn State, peered around Lucas Oil Stadium this summer and let himself imagine the Nittany Lions returning in December to play for a Big Ten title.

headline: Can You Still Afford a Mortgage?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Rising home prices have increased income requirements for mortgage qualification.
lead_paragraph: With the quick escalation of home prices during the pandemic, it’s become increasingly difficult to qualify for a typical mortgage. This week we return to the quarterly report from HSH.com, which breaks down the annual income required to qualify for a mortgage in the country’s 50 largest metropolitan areas.

headline: Four nursing home residents have died at an evacuation facility, Louisiana officials say.
abstract: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. Follow here for news on Hurricane Ida, wildfires, floods and more.
lead_paragraph: Four Louisiana nursing home residents who were evacuated ahead of Hurricane Ida have died at facility where state inspectors were prevented from conducting a full assessment this week, state officials said on Thursday.

headline: The Caldor fire is menacing Lake Tahoe.
abstract: Firefighters hope an area they cleared about eight miles south of the lake’s shores will keep the flames from advancing much further.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif. — There were several flare-ups during a dynamic 24 hours along the far-flung fire lines of the Caldor fire. Giant funnels of smoke poured from forested hillsides. But despite the ominous scene, the authorities on Thursday morning said the wind was working in their favor, and that for now, they hoped to keep the blaze from reaching Lake Tahoe.

headline: Ida Leaves New York City Area Drenched
abstract: The New York area was under a state of emergency on Thursday after the remnants of Hurricane Ida led to at least eight deaths and disrupted subway service.
lead_paragraph: The New York area was under a state of emergency on Thursday after the remnants of Hurricane Ida led to at least eight deaths and disrupted subway service.

headline: Overlapping Disasters Expose Harsh Climate Reality: The U.S. Is Not Ready
abstract: The deadly flooding in the Northeast, on the heels of destruction from Louisiana to California, shows the limits of adapting to climate change. Experts say it will only get worse.
lead_paragraph: In Louisiana and Mississippi, nearly one million people lack electricity and drinking water after a hurricane obliterated power lines. In California, wildfire menaces Lake Tahoe, forcing tens of thousands to flee. In Tennessee, flash floods killed at least 20; hundreds more perished in a heat wave in the Northwest. And in New York City, 7 inches of rain fell in just hours Wednesday, drowning people in their basements.

headline: Streaks, Injuries and Virus Outbreaks Muddle Wild-Card Races
abstract: With about a month left in the baseball season, a crowded field is contending for wild-card spots. Each has its own challenges, Boston’s coronavirus issues chief among them.
lead_paragraph: The beginning of September is often a good time to take stock of the six-month Major League Baseball regular season. Rosters expand. The playoffs are a month away. It’s crunchtime in the pennant races.

headline: For a Thriving U.S. Soccer Team, Challenges Create Opportunities
abstract: Ahead of World Cup qualifying, a young team with a fresh attitude says it is unburdened by the failure of its predecessors to qualify for the tournament.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — As drama goes, at least by recent United States World Cup qualifying standards, the news rated a raised eyebrow, not a blaring alarm.

headline: Moving Over: A Powerhouse of Black Dance Is Retiring (Mostly)
abstract: Joan Myers Brown, the founder of Philadanco, is stepping back if not quite away from her duties. She still goes to the office every day.
lead_paragraph: Rushing to our Zoom interview from an in-person audition at the Philadanco studios, Joan Myers Brown opened the conversation by making me laugh. She asked for a reminder of what we were doing and then said, “What an honor, you want to talk about me — only thing I usually talk about is Philadanco.”

headline: The 1970s Brought Change to the Beach Boys. A New Boxed Set Celebrates It.
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: “Feel Flows: The Sunflower and Surf’s Up Sessions, 1969-1971” explores a time of experimentation and reinvention for the band.
lead_paragraph: As the 1970s dawned, the Beach Boys were in crisis.

headline: Soccer’s New Rich Leave the Old Guard Looking Beleaguered
abstract: European soccer’s summer trading window closed this week, with teams backed by nation states and the super rich cementing their dominance.
lead_paragraph: Last season’s Champions League final was one sign. The outcome of European soccer’s summer trading window — which closed earlier this week — was yet another. The continent’s old guard is in retreat, and in their place a new cash-rich elite has fully arrived.

headline: Inside Broadway’s Reopening: A Times Virtual Event
abstract: We visit “Hadestown,” “Girl From the North Country” and a new playwright, with backstage encounters and songs, in our series finale of “Offstage.”
lead_paragraph: Information on our upcoming subscriber-only virtual events can be found here.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, the courtyard at MoMA PS1 became the main venue for “Warm Up,” a summer event that mingled art, music and design in order to draw new audiences. But things change. “Warm Up” certainly hasn’t gone away, but last fall, the institution began “PS1 Courtyard: an experiment in creative ecologies,” a program testing out ways to use the outdoor space that encourage community engagement.

headline: ‘The Big Scary ‘S’ Word’ Review: Socialism for Beginners
abstract: This documentary serves up the merits of socialism with a stuffed compendium of formulations from experts, historical precedents and just-folks testimonials.
lead_paragraph: The word “socialism” is often used as a boogeyman to scare voters, with little or no reference to actual substance. Enter Yael Bridge’s “Big Scary ‘S’ Word,” a stuffed compendium of formulations from experts, historical precedents and just-folks testimonials. Hope is not a policy, as the saying goes, so Bridge gamely tries to provide both, fleshing out ideals with examples.

headline: America Desperately Needs a Much Better F.D.A.
abstract: The agency that regulates drug safety has become too cozy with the industry it’s supposed to oversee.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, an unflappable Food and Drug Administration scientist named Frances Kelsey spared the nation from the horrors of thalidomide. The drug had become popular around the world as a remedy for a variety of ailments, including morning sickness in pregnant women. Although there had not been many studies of its safety, thalidomide’s manufacturers marketed it as exceedingly safe. Regulators in many countries, including Canada and across much of Europe, approved its sale.

headline: House Committees Demand F.D.A. Records on Alzheimer’s Drug Approval
abstract: The agency approved Biogen’s Aduhelm “despite concerns raised by experts,” committee leaders said in a letter.
lead_paragraph: Two powerful congressional committees investigating the controversial federal approval of Biogen’s Alzheimer’s drug, Aduhelm, demanded extensive information and documents from the Food and Drug Administration in a letter released on Thursday, making it clear that the committees’ leaders are troubled by unusual actions the agency took in the course of evaluating and approving the drug.

headline: Beautiful Merch, Where Are You?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Advertising and Marketing', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Hats and Caps', 'audio-positive-escape']
abstract: Ahead of the release of Sally Rooney’s third novel, bucket hats, tote bags and “status galleys” are the talk of the literary internet.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Syed Ali Geelani, Separatist Leader in Kashmir, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Territorial Disputes', 'Secession and Independence Movements', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Geelani was an uncompromising opponent of the Indian government’s control of the Kashmir valley and favored Pakistani sovereignty over the mostly Muslim region.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — Syed Ali Geelani, an influential and uncompromising leader of the separatist movement in Kashmir who refused to engage with India over the future of that troubled Himalayan region, died on  Wednesday while under house arrest in Srinagar, Kashmir’s biggest city. He was 91.

headline: G.M. will idle more factories this month as a chip shortage drags on.
abstract: The automaker is suspending production of some of its most profitable vehicles.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Thursday that it would idle six North American plants for two weeks this month and two others for a week each as the global shortage of computer chips continues to stymie carmakers.

headline: Kolkata’s ‘Fairy Tale’ Trams, Once Essential, Are Now a Neglected Relic
abstract: The few riders left say the 140-year-old system makes sense for a city of 15 million struggling with pollution and overcrowding. But many trips now are more nostalgic than necessary.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — The tram rattled along College Street, passing dozens of book stalls, and announcing itself with the quaint chime of a bell. A gentle breeze from its open windows and antique ceiling fans cut the humid summer heat.

headline: More Than 80 Percent of Seniors Are Vaccinated. That’s ‘Not Safe Enough.’
abstract: The older cohort had a head start on getting immunized against Covid-19, but too many remain unprotected, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Won Lee began her initial visit to a new homebound patient, Almeta Trotter, last month by asking about her life, her health and how she was managing in her apartment in the Dorchester neighborhood of Boston, shared with her longtime partner and a parakeet.

headline: Can American Democracy Survive Another Pandemic?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Adam Tooze’s “Shutdown” warns that we are ill equipped to deal with another health crisis or other immense problems that may challenge us.
lead_paragraph: SHUTDOWN How Covid Shook the World’s Economy

headline: Why This Covid Chapter Might Be the Hardest of All
abstract: All the rules are fluid, and all the answers have asterisks.
lead_paragraph: Anecdotally and scientifically, there’s reason to believe that the most successful dieters — the ones who truly change their habits and keep the most weight off for the longest time — don’t commit themselves to one of those faddish regimens that draw bold red lines through categories of food to be avoided entirely and bright green circles around categories to be embraced. They muddle through meal by meal. They make a series of smart, tailored judgment calls. They traffic in subtlety, nutritionwise.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’ Returns, With New Rules for Children
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant']
abstract: The surge of the Delta variant has prompted many dance companies to retool the holiday favorite. At New York City Ballet, there will be no performers under 12.
lead_paragraph: There will be dancing snowflakes, spirited sword fights and a visit to the Land of Sweets.

headline: Eric Adams, New York’s likely next mayor, says he has ‘never witnessed something like this.’
abstract: Currently serving his last months as Brooklyn borough president, Mr. Adams called the city’s devastation “a wake-up call” on climate change and spoke about the need for “new solutions.”
lead_paragraph: Eric Adams, who as the Democratic nominee is the likely next mayor of New York City, expressed alarm over the devastation he saw in hard-struck areas from the remnants of Hurricane Ida.

headline: Confusion in Texas as ‘Unprecedented’ Abortion Law Takes Effect
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Abortion', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: No lawsuits appeared to have been filed, but call centers for abortion services turned into help lines crowded with crying women. Some began seeking services by crossing state lines.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When the Supreme Court decided this week that Texas could carry out and enforce the nation’s most restrictive anti-abortion law, even some staunch abortion opponents were surprised.

headline: On Mars, NASA’s Perseverance Rover Drilled the Rocks It Came For
abstract: After an earlier drilling attempt failed to collect anything, the rover appeared to gather its first sample. But mission managers need to take another look before sealing the tube.
lead_paragraph: The rock appeared right where it should have been — captured within the drill bit of NASA’s latest Mars rover, Perseverance.

headline: Waves of Joy: Capturing Black Surfers in Action
abstract: A photographer and a water cinematographer combined their talents to document skills, thrills and a sense of solidarity.
lead_paragraph: To get the perfect shot of a surfer in the ocean you need at least four things: an expert who is equally comfortable working on a surfboard and swimming in open water; a camera, covered in waterproof material; a comprehensive safety plan; and a lot of luck.

headline: Adult Swim: How an Animation Experiment Conquered Late-Night TV
abstract: Cartoon Network’s nighttime adult programming block, which turns 20 this week, was built on lo-fi animation techniques that were as much a no-budget necessity as an aesthetic choice.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, it was a minor miracle that Adult Swim ever made it off the drawing board 20 years ago. Money was next to nonexistent. The editor of Cartoon Network’s first original series worked from a closet. A celebrity guest on that series, unaware of the weirdness he had signed up for, walked out mid-taping.

headline: How 88rising Crafted an Evocative Soundtrack for Marvel’s ‘Shang-Chi’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Asian-Americans', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The Asian arts collective worked closely with the director Destin Daniel Cretton to put its imprint on the anticipated movie.
lead_paragraph: One concert was all it took to spark the idea of the Asian arts collective 88rising overseeing the soundtrack for one of the most hotly watched action movies of the year.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Risky Drinking, Hearing Aids and Sleep Advice
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: The Roots of Joan Mitchell’s Greatness
abstract: A retrospective at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art tracks how the painter’s signature style extended the contours of Abstract Expressionism.
lead_paragraph: In 1948, Joan Mitchell was a 23-year-old artist living in a drafty apartment in Paris. She had arrived in France in the aftermath of World War II to a nation that was still reeling from rations and riots. A newly minted graduate of the Art Institute of Chicago, Mitchell had come to Paris to study the history of French painting and learn the techniques of the masters but found that her workaholism had frayed her nerves and rendered her too anxious to take part in the bustling social life of the city. Mitchell spent her nights awake, feverishly trying to improve her craft, huddling around her stove for warmth.

headline: The Final Days at the World’s Oldest Bank
abstract: For over eight years, I’ve been reporting on struggles at the world’s oldest bank, Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena in Siena, Italy, where I am from.
lead_paragraph: For over eight years, I’ve been reporting on struggles at the world’s oldest bank, Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena in Siena, Italy, where I am from.

headline: A Second Life for Stale Bread
abstract: These panzanella recipes don’t require much cooking, but you’d never know it from the complexity of flavors.
lead_paragraph: Some of my favorite recipes in the world were developed by cooks who refused to waste stale bread — or roti, or sangak — repurposing tough, old crusts into unexpectedly delicious meals.

headline: Afghans Who Worked for The Times Arrive in the U.S.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The group, 124 people including families, flew to Houston from Mexico City after their escape from Kabul. One Afghan journalist in the group has not been cleared by U.S. border officials.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after escaping from Taliban-controlled Afghanistan, and after intricate negotiations involving government officials in multiple nations, a group of Afghans who worked for The New York Times, along with their families, have reached the United States.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: August 2021
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the August edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.

headline: A jury is selected for the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
keywords: ['Jury System', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: For two days, a judge, federal prosecutors and defense lawyers questioned roughly 100 potential jurors before whittling the list down to 12 jurors and five alternates.
lead_paragraph: A jury of 12 residents of Northern California and five alternates was sworn in on Thursday for the fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the disgraced founder of blood testing start-up Theranos, which is set to begin next week.

headline: ‘Who You Think I Am’ Review: A Woman of Feeling, in Bed and Out
abstract: Juliette Binoche plays an academic with a turbulent inner life that makes her complicated romantic life all the more difficult.
lead_paragraph: Juliette Binoche moves through the French drama “Who You Think I Am” as if possessed. From moment to moment, her character — an academic with a turbulent inner life — looks tense or wildly happy. Emotion, by turns, lightens and darkens her translucent face, and changes her body, gait and gestures. She laughs, she cries, expands, contracts. At times, she all but floats down the street, buoyed by the love of a younger man. Then again, she may be less high on him, per se, than on how he makes her feel.

headline: Biden Vows to Protect Abortion Rights in Face of ‘Extreme’ Texas Law
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Biden directed a gender-focused policy council in the White House and other agencies to “launch of a whole-of-government effort” to respond.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday excoriated the Supreme Court’s refusal to block a Texas law that prohibits abortion after six weeks, saying that it “unleashes unconstitutional chaos” against women and vowing that his administration would investigate how the federal government could protect existing constitutional abortion rights.

headline: ‘Anne at 13,000 Ft’ Review: A Woman Adrift
abstract: A young day-care employee struggles to live and love in a world that, much like her, remains a blur.
lead_paragraph: For much of the wispy drama “Anne at 13,000 Ft,” you wait for it to expand on its title and maybe even coalesce into something more than its nebulous parts. The title character is one of those difficult women that the movies just can’t quit and rarely prove as interesting as filmmakers seem to think. Anne obviously has issues — psychological, behavioral, familial — but the movie isn’t big on specifics. It’s a pretty, uninvolving blur.

headline: The Poetic Justice of Amanda Gorman’s Estée Lauder Contract
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Women and Girls', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Met Gala', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: The inside story of how it happened and why it matters.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment, starting on Jan. 20, 2021, as the 23-year-old poet Amanda Gorman stood on the steps of the Capitol in her sunny yellow coat, reading her work “The Hill We Climb” at President Biden’s inauguration, when the viewing country seemed to go into a collective swoon.

headline: In ‘Back to The Future: The Musical,’ the Car Is the Star of the Show
abstract: A devoted fan of the 1985 movie helped the London production’s creative team recreate the iconic time-traveling DeLorean, down to the last detail.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — During a recent performance of “Back to the Future: The Musical,” at the Adelphi Theater here, the audience couldn’t stop cheering.

headline: Finding a Globe’s Worth of Art Treasures Close to Home
abstract: It took a pandemic to get our critic to explore the exquisite art in his own backyard. Here’s what he discovered.
lead_paragraph: There are many flavors of obnoxious New Yorkers. My own: the well-traveled provincial. Before the pandemic I tallied up alarming carbon emissions in search of art, thought nothing of jetting to East Asia or South Africa for a single exhibition or performance — and then neglected institutions just a time zone or two away. When the lockdown came and my passport’s power shriveled, I made the embarrassing calculation that I’d been to four times as many foreign countries as I have U.S. states.

headline: New Yorkers tried to save neighbors from Ida’s floods. Sometimes they couldn’t.
abstract: “It’s so hard when someone asks for help and you can’t help them,” said a woman who listened as a man’s screams for help from a basement bedroom suddenly stopped.
lead_paragraph: The torrents from Ida’s waters cascaded through New York City basement doors and windows, turning everyday spaces into death traps.

headline: Ida Paralyzes the New York City Area
abstract: The remnants of Hurricane Ida caused flash flooding and a number of deaths and disrupted transit across parts of New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Hurricane Ida caused flash flooding and a number of deaths and disrupted transit across parts of New York and New Jersey.

headline: The French Left Is in Disarray, but Here Comes Anne Hidalgo

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to fall into the habit of seeing the Book Review and The Times’s daily book critics as a monolithic bloc of infallible and irreproachable literary opinions — heck, with lists like this one, we sometimes even encourage it. In truth, though, we’re more like the affectionate cranks who make up your local reading group: We’re passionate and knowledgeable, and we disagree all the time. Editors disagree with other editors, our reviewers love books that we hated or hate books that we loved, and subscribers don’t hesitate to let us know when we’ve done an injustice to their favorites. It’s raucous and healthy and wonderful, and ideally it will expand your horizons or at least get you thinking about the contours of your reading life. That’s what we’re here for.

headline: The U.S. Open Is Alex Molcan’s Proving Ground
abstract: After seeing one of his junior opponents soar in the rankings while he floundered, Molcan has regained confidence and is in the third round of his first Grand Slam event.
lead_paragraph: Alex Molcan had usually played Andrey Rublev evenly when they competed in junior tournaments for players age 14 and under. Sometimes Rublev won, sometimes it was Molcan.

headline: Married Kremlin Spies, a Shadowy Mission to Moscow and Unrest in Catalonia
keywords: ['Secession and Independence Movements', 'Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Referendums', 'Fugitives']
abstract: Intelligence files suggest an aide to a top Catalan separatist sought help from Russia in the struggle to break with Spain. A fierce new protest group emerged shortly afterward.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — In the spring of 2019, an emissary of Catalonia’s top separatist leader traveled to Moscow in search of a political lifeline.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A lethal storm in the northeastern U.S.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Hurricane Ida killed at least 43 people in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut and left more than 150,000 homes without power. States of emergency were still in effect as of midday yesterday, as officials sought to get a handle on the damage. Here are the latest updates and photos from the storm.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Cornered in Rooms or Cars by Torrents of Water, Dozens Are Found Dead
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 3, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “I tried to hold on to my wife and she was trying to hold on to me. But the water pushed me away and I couldn’t feel her hand anymore.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 3, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 3, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a rise in demand for the drug ivermectin misattributed a quote from an author of an ivermectin study. She is Maria Popp, not Maria-Inti Metzendorf.

headline: United States Ties El Salvador to Open World Cup Qualifying
abstract: As a youthful American team took its first step toward the 2022 World Cup, it rued a few missed opportunities.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — The formula for success in World Cup qualifying is written in years of hard lessons, hard games and hard nights: Win your home games. Pick up points on the road. Survive and advance.

headline: New Zealand Police Kill ‘Extremist’ Who Stabbed 6 in ISIS-Inspired Attack
abstract: The man was under surveillance when he injured six people at a West Auckland supermarket on Friday, officials said. The prime minister called it a “terrorist attack.”
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Six people were injured in a knife attack at a supermarket in New Zealand on Friday, an outburst of violence that the prime minister labeled a “terrorist attack” that had been carried out by a “violent extremist” inspired by the Islamic State.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Work-From-Home Economy and the Urban Job Outlook
keywords: ['Service Industries', 'Telecommuting', 'Workplace Environment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Urban Areas', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Offices are unlikely to be as full after the pandemic as they were before. Service businesses and their employees will have to adapt.
lead_paragraph: Restaurant Associates is not the company it used to be. It has long operated restaurants, catered events and run corporate dining rooms for clients including Google and the Smithsonian Institution. Now it employs about half of the 10,000 or so people it had on staff before the pandemic.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in September
abstract: Our picks for September, including ‘Billions,’ ‘Goliath’ and ‘Worth’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for September.

headline: ‘We’re Like Athletes Here’: The Maestro With a Gym Habit
abstract: Lorenzo Viotti’s sporty social media posts don’t fit the image of an opera conductor. But they help classical music reach a new audience, he says.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Lorenzo Viotti stood before the orchestra, without a baton, conducting with both hands. As the music swelled, his arms swayed. Three fingers plucked the air, then he swept forward to guide the sound to a crescendo.

headline: Disabled Japanese Are Often Invisible. Will Paralympics Bring Lasting Light?
abstract: Tokyo improved its infrastructure before the Games, but activists wonder how long the focus will continue in a country with a long history of excluding people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Before ushering in the Paralympic Games, Tokyo undertook a wave of projects to make itself more accessible to people with disabilities. Nearly all train stations now have elevators, and some have safety barriers along platform edges to protect the visually impaired. About 3,200 newly built hotel rooms are wheelchair accessible, as are stalls in many public bathrooms.

headline: Looking Longingly Out Someone Else’s Window
abstract: Most of our worlds have narrowed down to a single view, but a crowdsourcing website lets us borrow a different one, for a little while.
lead_paragraph: This week, I’ve looked out of the window of a high-rise apartment in Tyumen, Russia, through a skylight in Trorod, Denmark, and out a balcony in Toulouse, France.

abstract: At least 43 died, and 150,000 homes were left without power.

abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 3, 2021
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘What You Are Going Through,’ ‘Finding Freedom’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE CRUELTIES, by Liz Nugent. (Gallery/Scout Press, 352 pp., $16.99.) Sarah Lyall found this Irish thriller about the extremely unpleasant, possibly homicidal Drumm brothers “clever,” adding, “One of the delights, if that is the right word, of this book is how thoroughly the author delves into the details of the family’s world-class dysfunction.”

headline: The Navy SEAL Who Went Rogue
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: David Philipps’s “Alpha” tells the story of an out-of-control Navy officer who won the protection of Donald Trump and escaped a murder charge.
lead_paragraph: ALPHAEddie Gallagher and the War for the Soul of the Navy SEALsBy David Philipps

headline: Bitcoin Uses More Electricity Than Many Countries. How Is That Possible?
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Virtual Currency', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments']
abstract: The most popular cryptocurrency wastes energy by design. Why is that, and could it ever be greener?
lead_paragraph: The most popular cryptocurrency wastes energy by design. Why is that, and could it ever be greener?

headline: Why Not Offer a Remote Option for School?
abstract: Vaccine hesitancy remains strong, while students under 12 are still vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: At the outset of the pandemic last year, two of Ruth Horry’s three children got sick with Covid — one of them, just 5, frighteningly so, with a fever that raged for days and required hospitalization. “It got to the point where she was at 105 and shaking and we couldn’t even get in a cab,’’ Ms. Horry told me. “They wouldn’t take us. She was coughing and people were scared; this was a time when everyone was basically wearing garbage bags.”

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2, Episode 7: What’s the Matter With Ted?
abstract: Also: Nate seems headed to a dark place, and Keeley and Roy explore whether there can be too much of a good thing.
lead_paragraph: At last: A clear vision of the trajectory of this season — hinted at last week — has come into focus. It’s not about wins and losses. We still have no idea of AFC Richmond’s chances of rejoining the Premier League. We don’t even know their next opponent in the FA Cup, following last week’s shocking upset of Tottenham Hotspur.

headline: Is It the Weekend? Not Until He Says So.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The 18-year-old behind the viral Twitter account @CraigWeekend has offered people a routine reminder to take a load off.
lead_paragraph: In a scene from “Saturday Night Live,” the English actor Daniel Craig stares into the camera and flops his arms halfheartedly, as if he meant to raise them above his head but got tired halfway.

headline: He Melted Her Heart on the Ice. Twice.
abstract: Max Fruchter told Natalie Dicker all the reasons he liked her while they went ice skating. Two years later, at a rink with rose petals, he proposed.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Rose Dicker ran out to greet Max Elliot Fruchter with a friendly hug in July 2019 as he walked up the path to her parents’ front door in Great Neck, N.Y.,  for their first date.

headline: This Isn’t Your Grandpa’s Joe Biden
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'audio-neutral-informative']
abstract: The subtle radicalism of Biden’s economic vision.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s economic policy isn’t what you would have expected from his long career. That’s true in the legislation he’s backing, which is bigger and bolder than anything we’ve seen from him before, but it’s even truer in the appointments he’s making and the theories he’s embracing. On everything from antitrust to inflation to employment to power, Biden is reflecting a new strain of progressive economic thought — one that wants to direct markets, not just correct them.

headline: In the Dead of Night, the Supreme Court Proved It Has Too Much Power
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Law and Legislation', "Women's Rights", 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The conservative majority essentially nullified the constitutional rights of millions of American women without so much as an argument.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s recent reliance on the so-called shadow docket to make major rulings — on display, this week, in its decision to let Texas end legal abortion after six weeks, at least for now — throws the problem of judicial power in a representative democracy into sharp relief.

headline: Dread, War and Ambivalence: Literature Since the Towers Fell
abstract: The Times’s book critics reflect on how 9/11 has influenced writers and readers.
lead_paragraph: The events of 9/11 irrevocably changed the course of global affairs. They also changed culture. It will likely be easier to say how a century from now. But with 20 years’ hindsight, The Times’s book critics reflect below on some of the influence of that day on the writing that has followed.

headline: A Very Successful Matchmaking Mission
abstract: Valerie Persinger and Michael Webster were set up by her sister and brother-in-law, who also happened to be the groom’s Navy commander at the time.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Persinger and Michael Webster were targets of an unlikely matchmaking pair: her sister and his former boss, who happened to be married to one another.

headline: Biden Tours Hurricane Ida Damage in New Orleans
abstract: The president has taken pains to show his commitment to the storm response even as his administration deals with the Afghanistan pullout and other critical issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden flew to the New Orleans area on Friday to tour the damage wrought by Hurricane Ida, part of an effort to demonstrate his commitment to the federal government’s storm response even as his administration remains enmeshed in other pressing matters from the coronavirus surge to the aftermath of his Afghanistan withdrawal.

headline: Manhattan-Centric No More, at Least Online
abstract: Tiana Idoni-Matthews met Nate Koppel, from Woodside, Queens, on JSwipe after extending her dating radius from five to 25 miles.
lead_paragraph: Tiana Ehinome Idoni-Matthews, who lived on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, connected with Nathaniel Wagner Koppel, who lived in Woodside, Queens, on the dating app JSwipe in January 2017 after she extended her Manhattan-centric dating radius from five to 25 miles.

headline: From Training Buddies to Life Partners
abstract: Laura Siegle and A.J. Cephus met through CrossFit. When she left for a monthlong break, he realized that he wanted to take their relationship beyond the gym.
lead_paragraph: Laura Siegle and Ahmaed Cephus Jr. had trained at the same CrossFit gym in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, for about a year, engaging in friendly competition and getting to know cursory details about each other’s lives, when Ms. Siegle left for a month in the summer of 2016 on a trip.

headline: ‘The Battery’s Dead’: Burnout Looks Different in Autistic Adults
keywords: ['Autism', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Sleep', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Insomnia', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Though little studied, exhaustion among people with autism has become its own pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Tyla Grant, 24, holds down a full-time advertising job, is trying to get a nonprofit off the ground and creates regular content for her podcast, YouTube channel and Instagram. Occasionally, she winds up so fried she can’t speak or get out of bed for days.

headline: Goodbye to the ‘Office Mom’
abstract: If cultivating a certain kind of workplace culture is important, it shouldn’t be extra work that goes uncompensated, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: In May, the chief executive of Washingtonian Media, which publishes a D.C.-area magazine, wrote an opinion essay in which she fretted over “the erosion of office culture” because of remote work.

headline: America Is Giving the World a Disturbing New Kind of War
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The withdrawal from Afghanistan is a final step in the transformation of American warfare into something sanitized and edited out of view.
lead_paragraph: In a speech on Tuesday, President Biden identified his decision to withdraw from Afghanistan with his desire to end the “forever war.” But he also promised that America will “maintain the fight against terrorism in Afghanistan and in other countries.” The reality today, he said, is that “we don’t need to fight a ground war to do it.”

headline: How Lady Gaga’s Mother and the Head of Her Foundation Spends Sundays
abstract: If someone secretly pays for your coffee this month, it might be Cynthia Germanotta.
lead_paragraph: Born This Way Foundation, founded by Lady Gaga and her mother, Cynthia Germanotta, who is its president, focuses on mental health initiatives for young people. Its annual #BeKind21 campaign, which encourages participants to perform a daily act of kindness, either toward themselves or to others, started on the first of the month and is running through Sept. 21. “One young woman wrote in and thanked us because she chose those 21 days not to harm herself,” Ms. Germanotta said. “That was courageous and amazing.”

headline: Fall Travel Trends: Have You Heard of ‘Trip Stacking’? (You Will.)
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Travel Warnings', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Road Trips', 'Autumn (Season)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Uncertainty remains the new normal in travel this autumn driven by the rise in cases and ever-changing travel restrictions, but here are eight things you can expect.
lead_paragraph: After a summer in which travel accelerated rapidly, nearly reaching prepandemic numbers, fall is looking like the season of uncertainty. Increasing concern about the Delta variant, as well as a seasonal travel dip, have slowed bookings. Fear of the variant and the potential of changing regulations have prompted travelers to plan more cautiously.

headline: How Shang-Chi, Master of Kung Fu, Knocked Down Stereotypes
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Movies', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Asian-Americans', 'Actors and Actresses', 'Martial Arts', 'audio-positive-nostalgic', 'audio-positive-happy']
abstract: The Marvel superhero originated in comics filled with racist tropes. The creators of the new film made a list of the preconceptions they were up against and set out to conquer them.
lead_paragraph: In the pantheon of Marvel superheroes, there’s Spider-Man and Iron Man and Captain America and … Shang-Chi?

headline: Let Your Fridge Go Off for an Hour to Save Our Power Grids
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Air Conditioning', 'Home Appliances']
abstract: Empowering consumers to control their electric consumption would free up power to meet demand elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: In Oregon, some residents are begging electric companies to shut off their power in high winds to prevent the lines from sparking dangerous fires. Power companies that refuse can expect to get sued for keeping the lights on.

headline: Why Does New York State Sue Its College Students?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Tuition', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Debt Collection', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: Thousands of SUNY students have been taken to court by the attorney general’s office over tuition debt. And through a quirk in the law, the only way they can defend themselves is by appearing before a judge in Albany.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Belony was rushing to work when she saw a fat yellow envelope left for her on her mother’s kitchen table. She opened it and immediately noticed the New York attorney general’s official seal sitting ominously at the top of the page. The state had filed a lawsuit against her for unpaid college tuition.

headline: Upstate Motels Make a Comeback, With an Aim to Captivate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Once a convenience of the American road trip, these classic motor hotels are being restored as vacation destinations by a new generation of owners.
lead_paragraph: Dana Bowen and her husband, Lindsay Bowen, both 49, initially had been looking to buy a roomy outpost away from New York City that could double as a vacation rental. The couple have a Brooklyn apartment, and a small house in the quaint village of Athens, in Greene County, and habitually scouted Catskill and Hudson Valley property listings looking for “the one” — something big enough to host family and friends, and rent out the rest of the time.

headline: A Love Worth the Phone Bill
abstract: As teens, Jody Prendergast and Lancelot Ferguson spoke so much on the phone — she in Rosedale, Queens, he in St. Mary Parish, Jamaica — that her father cut the cord. Their connection persisted.
lead_paragraph: Jody Prendergast and Lancelot Ferguson were teenagers when they met in their native St. Mary Parish, Jamaica, in the summer of 2004. Both had jobs at a local medical clinic: Mr. Ferguson was interning in the dental department. Ms. Prendergast was filing papers and filling out immunization cards alongside her best friend, Tara Jo Ferguson (no relation to Mr. Ferguson). Though the girls had spent previous summers playing soccer in the streets and dancing, Ms. Ferguson’s mother was a nurse, and that year she put them to work.

headline: The Storm Warnings Were Dire. Why Couldn’t New York Be Protected?
abstract: New York City and state officials knew heavy rains were coming, but their preparations couldn’t save the city from death and destruction.
lead_paragraph: The warnings and maps seemed clear.

headline: Louisiana High School Sports Meet a Mighty Opponent: Climate Change
keywords: ['Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Interscholastic Athletics', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Repeated hurricanes have devastated the state’s schools, teams and athletic fields. Ida was the latest reminder of the challenges facing the Sportsman’s Paradise.
lead_paragraph: GRAND ISLE, La. — Ida was not yet a hurricane when high school coaches across southern Louisiana began preparing for what had become all too familiar, even inevitable.

headline: A region assesses the damage from a sudden and deadly storm.
abstract: Additional deaths were announced on Friday, raising the region’s death toll from Ida to at least 46.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from the remnants of Hurricane Ida grew on Friday with the announcement of two more deaths in New Jersey, bringing the total number of lives lost to 46 across four states hit that were hit by the storm Wednesday evening.

headline: President Biden pledges investment in vaccine components, but will that help the world?
abstract: President Biden plans to invest $2.7 billion to ramp up U.S. production of critical vaccine components, saying the investment would help make the United States the “arsenal of vaccines for the world.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden plans to invest $2.7 billion to ramp up U.S. production of critical vaccine components, saying the investment would help make the United States the “arsenal of vaccines for the world.”

headline: Weak Job Gains Leave Washington on High Alert
abstract: The Federal Reserve and White House had hoped for strong job gains, and the August report did not deliver. That makes coming numbers critical.
lead_paragraph: Disappointing August jobs numbers intensified the economic uncertainty caused by the Delta variant, putting pressure on the Federal Reserve as it considers when to reduce its policy support and on the White House as it tries to get more Americans vaccinated.

headline: Hiring Slowdown in August Shows Delta Variant’s Impact
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Employers added 235,000 jobs, one of the weakest showings of the past year. Work involving in-person contact with customers was particularly affected.
lead_paragraph: The American economy stumbled in August as the latest coronavirus wave forced employers to curtail hiring in the sectors that had spearheaded the job market’s recent resurgence.

headline: What Is Labor Day? A History of the Workers’ Holiday.
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Labor Day', 'Parades']
abstract: President Grover Cleveland made it a national holiday in 1894, during a crisis over federal efforts to end a strike by railroad workers.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1800s, many Americans toiled 12 hours a day, seven days a week, often in physically demanding, low-paying jobs. Children worked too, on farms and in factories and mines. Conditions were often harsh and unsafe.

headline: The Shadow of Elizabeth Holmes and an M.L.B. Team’s History-Making Lineup of Color: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Here’s the current state of transit in the New York region.
abstract: Most of the city’s airports, subway lines and commuter rails were largely back to normal by Friday  evening.
lead_paragraph: Two days after the remnants of Hurricane Ida brought torrential flooding and deadly downpours to New York, much of the region’s transit system was back up and running Friday evening.

headline: How Texas Banned Almost All Abortions
abstract: Legislation banning most terminations has gone into effect in Texas. How did it avoid being immediately struck down like so many previous anti-abortion laws?
lead_paragraph: In a way, the new Texas law that has effectively banned abortions after six weeks is typical — many other Republican-led states have sought to ban abortions after six, 10 or 15 weeks.

headline: An Upper East Side Triplex for $60 Million, or $20 Million Over Ask
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The penthouse, overlooking the Central Park reservoir, was sold by the Swiss financier Jacqui Safra. The closing was the second largest so far this year.
lead_paragraph: One of New York City’s most expensive co-ops has closed, with the sale of a palatial triplex overlooking the Central Park reservoir that was owned by Jacqui Safra, a Swiss financier and producer of several Woody Allen films. At $60 million, it was the biggest transaction in August and second priciest so far this year.

headline: Japan’s Leader Is Stepping Down. Here’s Who Might Replace Him.
abstract: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga leaves his party facing its biggest crisis in years, with the coronavirus caseload at record highs and the economy struggling to recover.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election as head of Japan’s governing party, the decision created an unexpected opening to replace him.

headline: AstraZeneca settles with the E.U. over delays in vaccine deliveries.
abstract: A legal fight over undelivered doses lost steam as Europe’s inoculation program ramped up.
lead_paragraph: The European Union reached an agreement with AstraZeneca in a legal battle over delays in the company’s delivery of hundreds of millions of Covid-19 vaccine doses, ending a longstanding dispute.

headline: Rulings Without Explanations
abstract: Why is the Supreme Court using its “shadow docket” so often?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court opinion allowing Texas to ban nearly all abortions was different from most major rulings by the court.

headline: ‘Cinderella’ Review: A Girlboss in Glass Slippers
abstract: Camila Cabello stars in this musical reimagining of the fairy tale, which centers on an orphaned maiden who yearns not for true love but for corporate success as a dressmaker.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, Cinderella dreamed of owning a business. Or so the story goes in Kay Cannon’s new movie, which drags the princess tale into the 21st century with Top-40 pop songs, self-aware dialogue and a trite girlboss sensibility.

headline: I Was Euphoric in June. Look Where We Are Now.
abstract: Farewell to the heartbreaking summer of 2021.
lead_paragraph: My girlfriend and I wasted no time this spring. As soon as the Moderna vaccination fever left our bodies in May, we gleefully quadruple-booked every empty weekend left on the calendar. The itinerary swelled beyond precedent. Weddings, birthdays, family reunions and no-occasion rooftop hangs gridlocked into one another, evoking a logistical crisis every evening. I chilled in the cheap seats at Citi Field, sucked in the stale air at the Alamo Drafthouse and drove to both northern and southern Vermont in the span of three weeks. The world was in bloom, and both of us were desperate to witness it firsthand.

headline: What is Apple Thinking?
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'E-Commerce', 'Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Tax Evasion', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The company’s recent concessions over its App Store could be part of a deliberate strategy to protect more important revenue streams.
lead_paragraph: On an Apple device, the one thing you cannot do in Netflix’s app is subscribe to Netflix. A message on the app’s home screen explains this and encourages new users to return “when you’re a member.” It’s up to them to figure out how to do that.

headline: Navigating Today’s Rental Market
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Prices have bounced back since the height of the pandemic, but there are still ways to get a good deal.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, as the rental market floundered, Caleb Valentin decided that the moment had come to move out of his mother’s house in Staten Island and live in Manhattan. The options were stunningly good. He found a two-bedroom on Avenue A and East 12th Street in the East Village for $2,000, and rented it with his cousin.

headline: There’s growing hope the Caldor fire won’t reach Lake Tahoe.
abstract: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. Follow here for news on wildfires, Hurricane Ida, floods and more.
lead_paragraph: As the Caldor fire tore toward Lake Tahoe, California firefighters hacked down trees and bulldozed earth in paths up to 40 feet wide in the hopes that the fire would stop in its tracks when it reached their line of defense.

headline: Why Newsom Is Telling California Voters to Leave Half the Ballot Blank
abstract: The second question on the recall ballot is confusing and distressing many Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the sprawling forms Californians usually contend with in the voting booths, the ballots for the recall election of Gov. Gavin Newsom ask only two questions:

headline: Why Apple is suddenly giving up ground to app developers.
abstract: On an Apple device, the one thing you cannot do in Netflix’s app is subscribe to Netflix. A message on the app’s home screen explains this and encourages new users to return “when you’re a member.” It’s up to them to figure out how to do that.
lead_paragraph: On an Apple device, the one thing you cannot do in Netflix’s app is subscribe to Netflix. A message on the app’s home screen explains this and encourages new users to return “when you’re a member.” It’s up to them to figure out how to do that.

headline: Ode to the Flex Desk
abstract: As interns with this unit, a little-known team of journalists who read Times articles before you do, we learned lessons in writing we’ll never forget.
lead_paragraph: The first questions we were asked as interns at The New York Times were usually: “What do you do there? Where can I see your work?”

headline: Family’s Death in Sierra National Forest Is Shrouded in Mystery
abstract: Investigators still don’t know what caused the deaths of Jonathan Gerrish, Ellen Chung, their 1-year-old daughter, Miju, and their dog. They were found on Aug. 17.
lead_paragraph: The couple had backpacked in the Himalayas, ridden camels through the Gobi Desert and checked off Burning Man, even creating their own hashtag, an amalgamation of their first names: #jellonadventures.

headline: Tips for Victims of Unemployment Benefit Fraud
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Identity Theft', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The problem emerged early in the pandemic and shows no signs of slowing down, identity theft experts say. Here’s what to do.
lead_paragraph: Have you received an unsolicited debit card in the mail? Or a letter seeking extra details for an application for unemployment insurance that you don’t recall filing?

headline: Change May Be Coming to Your Favorite Wines
abstract: Rising temperatures and the risk of wildfires have led some wineries to grow different types of grapes. And some regions that were long overlooked are now producing notable wines.
lead_paragraph: The ill effects of climate change on many of the great wine regions in the United States and Europe have only just begun to be felt.

headline: ‘Start Flying Toward the Smoke’: A Wildland Firefighter on Battling Blazes
abstract: “I feel like our fire season has been longer and I’ve been on more fires little by little every year.”

headline: New York State urges insurance companies to expedite storm-related claims.
abstract: The Department of Financial Services said it would increase the number of people who could process claims.
lead_paragraph: New York State officials, bracing for a rush of insurance claims after record-breaking rain submerged large parts of New York City, are urging insurance companies to expedite storm-related claims.

headline: Edward J. Greenfield, Judge With a Writerly Touch, Dies at 98
abstract: He often luxuriated in the richness of the English language, going off on whimsical digressions and enlivening the law with colorful asides.
lead_paragraph: It was a minor legal case in the early 1970s. The New York City Civil Service Commission ruled that a police officer who had missed his Civil Service promotion exam because he was attending his mother-in-law’s funeral could not make up the test because “the deceased was not related.”

headline: Drake and Kanye West, Long Intertwined, Will Tangle on the Charts
abstract: The rappers’ anticipated albums, “Certified Lover Boy” and “Donda” — both potential streaming blockbusters — arrived within five days of each other, with very different rollouts.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Drake and Kanye West have been locked in a dialogue at the top of the hip-hop heap — occasional collaborators turned friendly competitors turned bitter rivals, and sometimes all three at once.

headline: Tyson Foods offers workers more paid time off — if they get vaccinated.
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Tyson will also compensate workers for “educational sessions about the benefits and risks of the Covid vaccines.”
lead_paragraph: Tyson Foods said it would provide 20 hours of paid sick time a year to fully vaccinated employees to enhance benefits for workers willing to receive coronavirus vaccinations.

headline: When Opera Livestreams Became Live Performances
keywords: ['Opera', 'Salzburg Festival', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Theater', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: This summer, three European productions, previously available to American audiences only online, were at last accessible in person.
lead_paragraph: I should start with a confession: Rarely during the pandemic have I been able to watch an entire livestream through.

headline: Apple delays the rollout of child-safety features over privacy concerns.
keywords: ['iPhone', 'Child Pornography', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: Apple had not expected the kind of backlash the new features faced.
lead_paragraph: Apple said on Friday that it would delay its rollout of child safety measures, which would have allowed it to scan users’ iPhones to detect images of child sexual abuse, after criticism from privacy groups.

headline: Venice Film Festival: How Does Kristen Stewart Play Princess Diana?
keywords: ['Movies', 'Venice International Film Festival', 'Actors and Actresses', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The star of “Spencer” may be one of the few actresses with an inkling of what it’s like to be so often hounded by the paparazzi.
lead_paragraph: While watching the new film “Spencer,” which premiered Friday at the Venice Film Festival, I kept pondering Kristen Stewart’s long, unlikely association with the fashion house Chanel.

headline: The Nigerian Activist Trying to Sell Plants to the Oil Company That Destroyed Them
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Women and Girls', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Oil Spills']
abstract: “I need to help my women to stand,” says Martha Agbani, who helped a group of women from the Niger Delta build a flourishing mangrove nursery.
lead_paragraph: YAATAAH, Nigeria — When the women arrived in the quiet, waterside village of Yaataah on an afternoon in May, some local young men hurried over to them. They offered to carry the women’s loads — old rice sacks and tin basins full of seeds, ready for planting — down to the swamp.

headline: Health Officials Advise White House to Scale Back Booster Plan for Now
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Federal regulators warned on Thursday they may not have enough data to recommend boosters for anyone except certain recipients of the Pfizer vaccine by late September.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top federal health officials have told the White House to scale back a plan to offer coronavirus booster shots to the general public this month, saying that regulators need more time to collect and review all the necessary data, according to people familiar with the discussion.

headline: How We’re Helping You See the World
abstract: Last year, as the pandemic took hold, we launched a new visual series called The World Through a Lens. Here’s a look behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: Last year, as the pandemic took hold, we launched a new visual series called The World Through a Lens. Here’s a look behind the scenes.

headline: Reuniting an Orphan Elephant and Her Mom, Perhaps, With DNA and Luck
abstract: Nania beat the odds to survive separation from her forest elephant family in Burkina Faso. Her caretakers hope DNA testing may help return her to the wild with her family.
lead_paragraph: The elephant was alone and dehydrated when villagers first found her. It was September 2017, and the motherless mammal wandering near Boromo in Burkina Faso was only 2 or 3 months old.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Kick things off with Dorie Greenspan’s age-old recipe for chicken in a pot.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Did you miss me? I spent more than two weeks not writing newsletters, not editing recipes or thinking about stories to tell, not checking in with correspondents, not clearing my inbox, not doing much of anything productive besides cooking for my family, chasing fish in the surf, chopping aged maple and reading books in the shade. It was a glorious break from a routine I generally treasure, and to which I return refreshed and excited, eager for what’s next.

headline: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks deal more with inner turmoil and isolation than space exploration.
lead_paragraph: While science fiction can explore galaxies far, far away and offer interstellar spectacles, it is often most challenging when it stays close to home and investigates what makes us human. This month’s selection of overlooked sci-fi streaming movies takes a particular interest in our bodies, ourselves, but don’t worry, the laser battles will come back soon.

headline: When Chance Encounters at the Water Cooler Are Most Useful
abstract: Research suggests that initially meeting in person is helpful, especially for people who don’t work closely.
lead_paragraph: A key scientific breakthrough that would eventually help protect millions from Covid-19 began with a chance meeting at a photocopier — in 1997, between Professor Katalin Kariko and Dr. Drew Weissman, whose work laid the foundation for the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines.

headline: ‘The Doors Didn’t Open Easily’ on Her Path to ‘Cinderella’
abstract: The choreographer JoAnn M. Hunter has quietly become an important figure in the world of musical theater, especially with her work for Andrew Lloyd Webber.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Midway through Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new “Cinderella,” the male ensemble throws itself into a thrusting, muscle-popping number that perfectly illustrates the musical’s fictional setting of Belleville, a town devoted to beauty in all its superficial forms. It’s also laugh-out-loud hilarious, a sly take on an objectification more usually embodied by a female chorus, and a witty amplification of the musical’s reimagining of the Cinderella myth.

headline: Consumers and Companies Are Buying In on Paying Later
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'E-Commerce', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Installment payment services are everywhere thanks to fresh deals with Amazon and Square. It’s a simple idea that can quickly get complicated for users.
lead_paragraph: That $128 pair of jeans can now be had for just four payments of $32. Dropping $100 on cosmetics seems less indulgent when the transaction is broken up into $25 payments. Even a pricey Dyson vacuum can be rationalized when purchased in $125 installments.

headline: Gov. Hochul: ‘We have to take action’ to avert future disasters.
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul questioned whether more could have been done to warn residents about the danger of flooding from Ida.
lead_paragraph: New York State officials were in the preliminary phases of assessing Ida’s damage on Friday, a day after President Biden approved an emergency declaration that will open up additional federal resources, including $5 million for affected counties.

headline: Abba Previews First Album in 40 Years, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Charli XCX, Bobby Shmurda, Japanese Breakfast and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: The Problem When Teams See Athletes as Assets
abstract: Chelsea and Manchester City have both found ways to monetize their army of spare signings by loaning them out. But should soccer incentivize that, or limit it?
lead_paragraph: One of the things that appealed most to Manchester City about Marlos Moreno was his flexibility. The club spotted him as a teenager, coming off the back of a breakthrough season in which he helped Atlético Nacional, his hometown club in his native Colombia, win not just a national title but the Copa Libertadores, too.

headline: What to Know: Purdue Pharma Settlement
abstract: The maker of OxyContin won bankruptcy approval on Sept. 1 as part of a far-ranging settlement that ended thousands of lawsuits against the company and its owners, the Sacklers.
lead_paragraph: The maker of OxyContin won bankruptcy approval on Sept. 1 as part of a far-ranging settlement that ended thousands of lawsuits against the company and its owners, the Sacklers.

headline: Takeaways From the August Jobs Report
abstract: Employers added just 235,000 jobs, far below economists’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: Employers added just 235,000 jobs, far below economists’ expectations.

headline: When Eggplant Meets Eggs
abstract: This silky end-of-summer dish, reminiscent in some ways of shakshuka, is run through with spiced eggplant, tomatoes and herbs.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest compromises I had to make with my husband, Daniel, back when we were dating was about eggplant. I realized he hated it, so I avoided cooking it for our together meals for years.

headline: Wonking Out: A Very Austrian Pandemic
abstract: Friedrich Hayek gave terrible policy advice.

headline: N.H.L. Players Are Set to Return to the Olympics
abstract: After missing the 2018 Winter Games, the best hockey players in the world will be able to participate in 2022 in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: After missing out on the 2018 Games, N.H.L. players will return to the Winter Olympics in Beijing in February.

headline: Venice Film Festival: ‘Dune’ Leaves Us With 3 Big Questions
abstract: After watching the world premiere, our columnist has a better idea of the risks and expectations as the film heads to the box office and awards season.
lead_paragraph: The spice must flow. But will audiences go?

headline: Kraft Heinz will pay $62 million to settle accusations of an accounting ‘scheme.’
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said the packaged foods giant inflated cost savings from the merger.
lead_paragraph: When Kraft merged with Heinz in 2015, it was meant to be another chance for the private equity firm 3G Capital to apply the same ruthless cost savings it had already introduced at Heinz and had used throughout the consumer goods industry. But at Kraft Heinz, the strategy was pushed too far, federal regulators said.

headline: Covid snapshot: Today’s case, hospitalization, death and vaccination numbers for the U.S.
abstract: Oregon, Hawaii, South Carolina and have reported more cases in the past week than in any other seven-day period. Weekly deaths in Florida are at record highs.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, an average of roughly 163,600 coronavirus cases has been reported each day in the United States, an increase of 12 percent from two weeks ago. Total cases are likely to surpass 40 million within days.

headline: In Gap Between Rich and Poor, Everton’s Women See an Opening
abstract: A series of changes, big and small, has a strengthened Everton believing it can hold its own with deep-pocketed rivals in England’s Women’s Super League.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Some of the changes have been small, so small as to be imperceptible, at least from the outside. This summer, for the first time, Everton hired someone specifically to take care of the uniforms of its women’s team. It is the sort of thing that serves as a reminder that, in women’s soccer, many little battles are still being won.

headline: Wage gains remained strong in August as hiring slowed.
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: Average hourly earnings increased rapidly, including for leisure and hospitality workers, even as job gains fell short of expectations.
lead_paragraph: Wages continued to grow briskly in August even as hiring decelerated, a surprising development that economists said was probably driven partly by continuing demand for workers in spite of coronavirus outbreaks caused by the Delta variant.

headline: De Blasio’s plan to evacuate basement apartments doesn’t do enough, critics say.
abstract: Advocates and officials questioned the mayor’s new ‘Climate-Driven Rain Response,’ which includes door-to-door evacuations and stronger flood warnings.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the deaths of 13 people in New York City from this week’s flooding, most of them in basement apartments, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Friday that the city would increase the use of evacuation orders and travel bans, issue stronger flood warnings to those living in basement apartments and send emergency responders door-to-door to help evacuate residents.

headline: Afghans With Ties to U.S. Who Could Not Get Out Now Live in Fear
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Women and Girls', 'Visas', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Thousands did not make it onto U.S. military evacuation flights. Many of them are now in hiding, worried for their safety and their future.
lead_paragraph: Armed Taliban militants were looking for Shah. They knew he worked as an interpreter for the United States government, and came to his provincial home at night. “Someone inside worked for the U.S. Army!” they shouted, threatening to shoot down the door.

headline: Capitol Rioter Known as QAnon Shaman Pleads Guilty
keywords: ['QAnon', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jacob Chansley, who stormed onto the Senate floor in face paint and a horned hat, accepted a deal under which federal prosecutors will recommend a sentence of 41 to 51 months in prison.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Chansley, a former actor and Navy sailor widely known as the QAnon Shaman, who stormed the Capitol in January in stars-and-stripes face paint and a horned fur hat, pleaded guilty on Friday to a single felony count of obstructing an official proceeding before Congress.

headline: What Does It Look Like When a City Returns to Its Senses?
abstract: The reopening of New York has created a banquet of sights, smells, flavors, textures and sounds. The New York Times asked photographers to convey how the city is nourishing each of the senses.
lead_paragraph: OK McCausland sought to capture taste. “There’s that moment everyone feels when they’re about to indulge in something they love. I was looking for that moment,” she said — like a group about to dive into a trough of popcorn at a Mets game, or a cut of meat just as it’s being devoured at Katz’s Delicatessen in Manhattan.

headline: A New Kind of Homecoming All Over College Football
abstract: After the disruptions of 2020, teams from coast to coast are playing in their own stadiums for the first time since 2019.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Normalcy, or what passes for it these days, started for Louis Trujillo when he arrived around 6 a.m. on Thursday to tailgate at the University of New Mexico. Ordinary came for Yolanda Sanchez when she began her shift in a stadium parking lot at 7 a.m., and for Andrew Erickson, a Lobos wide receiver, as he warmed up in sight of the Sandia Mountains about 10 hours later.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How Monica Lewinsky hopes to reframe her story. Also in this edition: the rescue dogs of 9/11, and an interview with Michael Keaton.
lead_paragraph: How Monica Lewinsky hopes to reframe her story. Also in this edition: the rescue dogs of 9/11, and an interview with Michael Keaton.

headline: Recipes for a Little Joy
abstract: Caramelized zucchini pasta, slow-cooker tinga chicken tacos and more meals that are as simple as they are fun to make.
lead_paragraph: What a week. How’s everyone doing out there? I’ve been thinking of those affected by Hurricane Ida (and everything else). And I hope you are doing OK. We had some flooding, lost some treasured things. But my family is safe, and we are grateful.

headline: Love Letter: Single, Yet Enjoying the View of Marriage
abstract: And: childhood sweethearts reunited.
lead_paragraph: Shubnum Khan, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, is 36 and single. Given that she was expected to be married by 25, this is not quite the future she had imagined. And yet she loves her life, and the different type of domestic contentment she has found with her parents, who still make each other — and her —  laugh a lot.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Amia Srinivasan
abstract: srinivasan transcript
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Amia Srinivasan. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
