keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The Climate Action Network said coronavirus conditions would mean many representatives would not be able to attend the annual conference, set this year for Scotland.
lead_paragraph: A global network of activists called on Tuesday for international climate talks scheduled for November in Scotland to be postponed, arguing that delegates from the most vulnerable nations would not be able to attend because of the pandemic.

headline: In ‘The Wonder Years,’ Dulé Hill Looks Forward, and Back
keywords: ['Television', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Actors and Actresses', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination']
abstract: This new version of the 1980s hit is still nostalgic, but it pushes Hill to confront themes that his previous TV parts have rarely allowed.
lead_paragraph: Dulé Hill joined “The West Wing” in 1999, not long after it debuted. He played Charlie Young, a personal aide who soon begins a relationship with the president’s youngest daughter, Zoey Bartlet (Elisabeth Moss). Charlie is Black; Zoey is white. The hate mail arrived almost immediately.

headline: 10 Hours Gives Us (Almost) All of Schumann’s Songs
abstract: Christian Gerhaher and Gerold Huber, peerless in lieder, have released an 11-disc set of Robert Schumann’s songs, many overlooked.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1988, it was hearing the lieder of Robert Schumann that convinced Christian Gerhaher, then a philosophy student in Munich, to ask a pianist he knew from school, Gerold Huber, whether they might start playing some songs together.

headline: A Heart-Rending Novel About an Intersex Teenager Forced to Live as a Boy
abstract: In her debut, “An Ordinary Wonder,” Buki Papillon explores the complex, and often painful, experiences of a Nigerian teenager forced to deny her identity.
lead_paragraph: AN ORDINARY WONDERBy Buki Papillon

headline: The lead proponent of Newsom’s recall has been sidelined with the coronavirus.
abstract: Orrin Heatlie, who along with a small group of Tea Party activists began circulating petitions for the governor’s recall in 2019, said he was recovering at home from the virus.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic-fueled campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom of California heads into its last week, its lead proponent said he has been sidelined with the coronavirus.

headline: Rachel Lindsay Has No Roses Left to Burn
abstract: I thought I could change The Bachelor franchise from within. Until I realized I was their token.
lead_paragraph: I thought I could change The Bachelor franchise from within. Until I realized I was their token.

headline: A Vaccine Success in Europe That Sinks in the East
abstract: Partly because of skepticism about shots, Bulgaria has fully inoculated only 20 percent of adults, and Romania 32 percent, well below the European Union average of 70 percent.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — More than 70 percent of the European Union’s adult population has been fully vaccinated, making it one of the world’s vaccination leaders. But some Eastern European countries are lagging far behind, exposing the bloc to new waves of infections and creating a divide that E.U. officials and experts say could hamper recovery efforts.

headline: Pro-Bolsonaro Rallies May Be Prelude to Power Grab, Critics Say
abstract: Critics see in the rhetoric of the leader, who is seeing declining poll numbers and mounting legal challenges, a parallel to former President Donald J. Trump’s.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Beleaguered by declining poll numbers, a sputtering economy and judicial investigations, President Jair Bolsonaro called on his supporters to rally across the country on Tuesday, Brazil’s Independence Day, in a show of force critics fear could be a prelude to a power grab.

headline: El Salvador’s Adoption of Bitcoin Is Off to a Rocky Start
abstract: Experts had raised concerns about making the digital token an official currency and the rapid execution of new technology on a national scale.
lead_paragraph: El Salvador faced a rocky transition in its adoption of Bitcoin as legal tender on Tuesday. The government’s app for facilitating transactions — its “digital wallet” — went offline temporarily, protesters took to the streets of the capital to denounce the move, and the price of Bitcoin dropped sharply, demonstrating the volatility of the cryptocurrency market.

headline: How the Cat Gets Its Stripes: It’s Genetics, Not a Folk Tale
abstract: Researchers took a deep dive into embryonic development to tease out the source of the tabby pattern in cats.
lead_paragraph: Folklore is full of stories about the coat patterns of cats: How the tiger got its stripes. How the leopard got its spots. And scientists ask the same questions, although not necessarily about large predators. The research may focus instead on something like the mackerel tabby pattern in domestic shorthairs.

headline: With Her Party Fading, Merkel Dips Into the Campaign Fray
abstract: Germany’s chancellor pleaded with voters to support her party, which has flagging poll numbers and a candidate who has failed to capture imaginations.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Angela Merkel has said she wanted to stay out of the election campaign for her replacement as Germany’s chancellor. But with her party polling at record lows, Ms. Merkel used a speech to Germany’s Parliament on Tuesday to plead with Germans to keep the Christian Democrats in power.

headline: Peter Singer Wins $1 Million Berggruen Prize
abstract: The philosopher, in keeping with his ideas about “effective altruism,” said he plans to donate half the prize to alleviating global poverty.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, the philosopher Peter Singer has been promoting the idea of “effective altruism,” which encourages people to have reason, rather than empathy, guide their philanthropy. It’s an idea that has sparked a movement on college campuses, in Silicon Valley and beyond.

headline: Divorce Stinks, But It Could Be Your Superpower
abstract: A divorced mother of two finds a new sense of pride in learning how to manage a home and much more, on her own.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, as I contemplated ending my marriage, I looked out my kitchen window and saw my husband mowing our lawn. I didn’t yet know if I’d be able to manage on my own, living in the New Jersey suburbs as a divorced mother of two. Yes, I had spent years alone when I was younger. As a journalist, I had even moved to Myanmar and India by myself. But this was different. Could I manage a house alone? Could I mow the lawn?

headline: Mexico City to Replace Columbus Statue With Indigenous Woman Monument
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Indigenous People', 'Columbus Day', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: “We owe it to them. We exist because of them,” the mayor of Mexico City said in a news conference.
lead_paragraph: A statue of the explorer Christopher Columbus that was removed last year in Mexico City will be replaced by a statue of an Indigenous woman to honor the country’s Native people, the mayor of Mexico City said on Sunday.

headline: The History of Dreams, From Greek Mythology to Last Night’s Sleep
abstract: In “The Oracle of Night,” Sidarta Ribeiro makes a resounding case for the mystery, beauty and cognitive importance of dreams.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1995, the Brazilian neuroscientist Sidarta Ribeiro moved to New York to pursue his Ph.D. at Rockefeller University. His arrival, he writes in his fascinating, discursive new book, “The Oracle of Night,” precipitated one of the strangest periods of his life.

headline: Nensi Dojaka Wins LVMH Prize for Young Designers
abstract: The Albanian women’s wear designer, who courts a cult following with her barely-there mesh dresses and separates, scooped the industry’s most prestigious new talent award.
lead_paragraph: Nensi Dojaka, a 28-year-old Albanian women’s wear designer known for her distinctive barely-there mesh dresses and separates, has won the 2021 LVMH Prize for emerging talent.

headline: Here Comes the Autumn of Anxiety
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'internal-sub-only', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: The pandemic hasn’t ended; the rescue programs have.
lead_paragraph: In the heady days of spring, when the United States was vaccinating 3 million people a day, President Biden predicted a “summer of joy.” But then the vaccination campaign stalled, and the Delta variant fueled a new wave of infections, hospitalizations and deaths.

headline: Ohio Judge Reverses Order Requiring Covid Patient to Be Given Ivermectin
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Hospitals', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: An intubated patient was prescribed the deworming drug by his doctor. Federal health officials have said that it has not been shown to be effective against the coronavirus and that it can be toxic in humans.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio judge on Monday reversed an earlier decision requiring a hospital to administer ivermectin, an anti-parasitic drug that is primarily used as a veterinary deworming agent, to a patient as a treatment for Covid-19.

headline: Abbott Signs Texas Election Law, Ending a Fierce Voting Rights Battle
keywords: ['Voting Rights, Registration and Requirements', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott called the law, which will sharply curtail access to the ballot in Texas, a “paradigm” for other states looking to pass election bills.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Tuesday signed a sweeping bill overhauling the state’s elections, capping a dramatic, monthslong national saga over voting rights with a new Republican-led law that will sharply restrict voting across the nation’s second-biggest state.

headline: 9/11 Reflections: We’d Like to Hear From You
abstract: We ask readers how the attack affected them.
lead_paragraph: As the 20th anniversary of 9/11 approaches, we ask readers to reflect on how the attacks affected your life directly or changed your view of the world around you.

headline: Miss the Old Kanye? Try the New Kanye.
abstract: West has always been dreaming big, speaking loudly, courting controversy and channeling all of that into music. But one thing has changed.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West’s 10th album, “Donda,” just had the biggest opening week of the year (though that mark is about to be eclipsed by Drake’s “Certified Lover Boy”). The success of “Donda” on the Billboard chart and on streaming services wasn’t guaranteed, given how West has receded from the center of hip-hop in recent years. But with an album rollout that grew increasingly rococo over several weeks, he displayed his true gift for garnering attention.

headline: Inflation Is Popping From Sydney to San Francisco. It May Be a Good Sign.
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Inflation has surged across advanced economies. The shared experience underlines that price gains come from temporary drivers — for now.
lead_paragraph: Price gains are shooting higher across many advanced economies as consumer demand, shortages and other pandemic-related factors combine to fuel a burst of inflation.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'First Ladies (US)']
abstract: Sending the first lady back into the classroom puts weight behind President Biden’s promise that his administration can get students safely back into in-person learning this fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jill Biden, the first lady, quietly started another school year as an English professor on Tuesday, returning to the physical classroom after a year of teaching remotely.

headline: To Avoid River Flooding, Go With the Flow, the Dutch Say
abstract: Extreme rainfall is causing deadly and destructive floods globally. The Netherlands averted disaster this summer by creating flood plains.
lead_paragraph: The Netherlands, accustomed to wet weather, was midway through what would become one of the wettest Julys on record, and Patrick van der Broeck was getting edgy.

headline: A Plague Is an Apocalypse. But It Can Bring a New World.
abstract: The meaning of this one is in our hands.
lead_paragraph: The meaning of this one is in our hands.

headline: Prices are Going Up. Will It Last?
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: You may have noticed that you’re paying more for lots of things. Inflation has become a hot topic, but the question is whether it will last.
lead_paragraph: You may have noticed that you’re paying more for lots of things. Inflation has become a hot topic, but the question is whether it will last.

headline: With a Mess of Fabrics, Broadway’s Costume Shops Return to Work
abstract: During the pandemic they helped by sewing cloth masks and surgical gowns. Now, they are back in a frenzy to make theater sparkle.
lead_paragraph: The work spaces at Parsons-Meares Ltd., one of New York City’s premier costume shops for Broadway shows, tend to be a spectacular confusion of satin and silk, lace and lamé, milliskin and muslin, scraps of brown paper in unique and strange shapes. Each surface seems on the verge of being inundated by leftover materials of varying hues and textures.

headline: From Afghanistan to the World Cup, Tiny, Wealthy Qatar Steps Up
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Soccer', 'World Cup 2022 (Soccer)', 'Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Airlifts', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Gulf state played a major role in the American airlift, the latest evidence of the small but gas-rich country punching above its weight on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — As chaos took over the United States’ last-minute efforts to evacuate more than 120,000 of its citizens and partners from Afghanistan last month, a tiny, wealthy country that many Americans would struggle to find on a map suddenly found itself uniquely placed to help out.

headline: Charter Flights Delayed as U.S. and Taliban Struggle to Work Together
keywords: ['Airports', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Airport Security', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With the Kabul airport closed, scores of people have tried to leave via the airport in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif. But the U.S. and the Taliban have struggled to establish an efficient system.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — With the massive United States military effort to evacuate American citizens and endangered Afghans completed, those still scrambling to find safe passage from Afghanistan are now navigating a complicated and potentially dangerous diplomatic impasse.

headline: Alec Baldwin Gets Under Trump’s Skin
keywords: ['Impersonators and Impressionists (Entertainment)', 'audio-positive-escape', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Comedy and tragedy in an age of political chaos.
lead_paragraph: Comedy and tragedy in an age of political chaos.

headline: Who Can Say Why Enya Endures? Only Time
abstract: Even at her peak, she was hugely famous but never especially cool. But maybe we’re finally ready to heed her whispered call to awaken.
lead_paragraph: On the long drives through Ireland that peppered my childhood like bouts of flu, my father played songs from a small pool of classic albums. Many of these would be familiar to any Irishman from that time. The cheerful ribaldry of the Dubliners, Christy Moore’s “Live at the Point” and the earnest, heart-tugging confessionals of Eleanor McEvoy and Mary Black all soundtracked our winding trips through the unending swatches of green that formed the Irish countryside. But none of those artists struck me like my father’s personal favorite, Enya.

headline: What Comes After the War on Terrorism? War on China?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Is conflict with China inevitable?
lead_paragraph: The U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan after a failed 20-year nation-building exercise has left many Americans and analysts saying, “If only we knew back then what we know now, we would have never gone down that path.” I am not sure that’s true, but it nevertheless raises this question: What are we doing today in foreign policy that we might look back 20 years from now and say, “If only we knew back then what we know now, we would never have gone down that path”?

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My First Love Called Me a Vacation’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Anna was the manager of the Tucson, Ariz., assisted living home where my father lived. The day father moved in, I told her I wanted to rearrange the furniture. She had already done it when I arrived. She cut his toenails, combed his hair, watched sports and “Leave It to Beaver” with him, and played his Bible audiobook as he navigated his last days on earth. I loved him. She loved him. Neither of us had been in love with a woman before. But she said, “There’s a first time for everything.” In an ending, a new beginning. — Holly Schaffer

headline: A T-Shirt Shop for the Semi-Ironic ‘Twilight’ Fan
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: BUGGIRL200 started out as an inside joke. But easy-to-use e-commerce platforms like Shopify have made it possible to turn such jokes into full-fledged businesses.
lead_paragraph: Before 2020, Madison Sinclair hadn’t seen any of the “Twilight” movies. But after watching all five during quarantine, she grew completely enamored — and inspired to express her new fandom.

headline: Mark Duplass Can’t Get Enough of ‘Rocky II’
abstract: The filmmaker and star of “Language Lessons” discusses his teenage education in indie cinema and the screenwriting lessons in “Waiting For Godot.”
lead_paragraph: It was May 2020, two months into lockdown, and Mark Duplass, an avowed workaholic, was getting itchy. So he took up some hobbies, one of which was conversational Spanish lessons with an online institute in Guatemala.

headline: Mexico’s Supreme Court Votes to Decriminalize Abortion
keywords: ['Abortion', "Women's Rights", 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'Constitutions', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling, which sets a precedent for the legalization of abortion nationwide, follows years of efforts by a growing women’s movement in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Criminalizing abortion is unconstitutional, Mexico’s Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, setting a precedent that could lead to legalization of the procedure across this conservative Catholic country of about 130 million people.

headline: Texas’ Long History of Hollowing Out Women’s Health Care
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Maternal Mortality', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: It’s a watershed moment in  a long-running war on reproductive rights in the state.
lead_paragraph: In a stunning move, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed a sweeping law to take effect in Texas last week that eradicates nearly all abortion care in the second-largest state in the country.

headline: The Medium of the Moment
abstract: Newsletters are a natural evolution of the creator-fan relationship.
lead_paragraph: This is a preview of the Kara Swisher newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.

headline: Drake, in Search of an Enemy Besides Himself
abstract: His new album “Certified Lover Boy” is full of familiar anxieties and sounds, and barbed words for Kanye West, a mentor turned nemesis.
lead_paragraph: At this point in Drake’s career, there are songs about the throne, and songs about the bed. Each milieu comes with a price. The first is about hard power: Remaining at the top means outmaneuvering enemies, building up an invulnerable enterprise. The other, in Drake’s hands at least, is about soft power — most often, the path to conquest is through humility, and sometimes awe. Rarely do the two modes meet.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: The Taliban announce acting government posts.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban chose people to fill several cabinet positions on an acting basis, stopping short of formally announcing a permanent government in Afghanistan.

headline: Frank Conversations About Making a Living in Dance
abstract: The choreographer Miguel Gutierrez’s podcast “Are You for Sale?” looks at what he calls “the ethical entanglements between art and money.”
lead_paragraph: On the first episode of his new podcast “Are You for Sale?,” the choreographer Miguel Gutierrez divulges the salary he paid himself during what he calls “one of the high points” of his career. The big reveal? Forty-eight thousand dollars a year.

headline: There’s Something About Miso
abstract: This pantry staple leads to big, umami-rich flavor in pastas, soups and vegetable dishes.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, at a New York restaurant called Nishi, I tried a cheeky, cheeseless version of cacio e pepe made with chickpea miso. I was skeptical, but the hot, slippery noodles were so satisfying, so full of salty dimension and depth, so absurdly delicious, that I didn’t miss the cheese at all.

headline: Medical Journals Call Climate Change the ‘Greatest Threat to Global Public Health’
abstract: An editorial published by more than 200 journals worldwide warned of ‘catastrophic harm to health that will be impossible to reverse.’
lead_paragraph: A collection of leading health and medical journals called this week for swift action to combat climate change, calling on governments to cooperate and invest in the environmental crisis with the degree of funding and urgency they used to confront the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Fall Restaurant Preview: A Reboot for New York
abstract: Restaurants whose plans were put on hold by the pandemic finally emerge, while global powerhouses gain footholds in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s fall restaurant season will effectively be the first in two years, and though Covid is a wild card, chefs and restaurateurs are forging ahead with openings and reopenings, often resuming projects that have been on hold. Ambitious restaurants in the heart of Manhattan from Union Square to 59th Street, like Le Pavillon and Iris, have been up and running, with new places set to join them. Prominent players like Danny Meyer, Laurent Tourondel, Ignacio Mattos and Franklin Becker are expanding their portfolios. Rick Bayless of Chicago, and Will Beckett and Huw Gott of London’s Hawksmoor are all making New York debuts. New steakhouses are still arriving, and Indian food, both fast-casual and formal, continues to get fresh attention. Despite the loss of some marquee names, there are signs of life in Hudson Yards. High-end sushi bars keep opening. And so far, despite the challenges of staffing and getting supplies delivered, the openings appear to be happening on time — a departure from past years, when many were delayed for months. That may be an index of how eager the owners are to get back to business.

headline: Igor Oistrakh, Soviet-Era Violinist (and a Son of One), Dies at 90
abstract: His father, David, was one of the 20th century’s finest violinists, but Igor more than held his own as a musician and interpreter performing throughout the West.
lead_paragraph: Igor Oistrakh, a noted violinist who was part of a violin-playing family that included his father, David, one of the 20th century’s finest exponents of the instrument, died on Aug. 14 in Moscow. He was 90.

headline: Bomba Estéreo Strives to Save the Planet and Soothe the Heart
abstract: Mixing traditions and electronics, this duo from Colombia envisions a futurism with roots.
lead_paragraph: When Bomba Estéreo, the Colombian duo of Simón Mejía and Liliana Saumet, had nearly finished recording its sixth studio album, “Deja,” the group took part in an age-old ritual: a pagamento, or payment. It’s a ceremony “to pay back what you have taken from the Earth,” Mejía explained in a video interview from his home studio in Bogotá.

headline: ‘The Big Book of Amaro’ Chronicles the World of the Bitter Spirit
abstract: Everything is covered in an encyclopedic new book by Matteo Zed, an Italian spirits expert.
lead_paragraph: In an encyclopedic new book, the Italian amari expert Matteo Zed covers the spirit, the bitter drink as old as monasteries and made new in Brooklyn. Amari are sipped as digestivos, aperitivos and in cocktails. He tells their history, describes the 50 botanicals often used when making them, gives an idea of their styles and sorts them into categories. There’s an amaro renaissance going on worldwide and he helps it along, with his favorite ways to enjoy the spirit. There are descriptions of more than 200 Italian brands, a fascinating region-by-region and bottle-by-bottle survey, followed by a handful of amari from other countries. The book supplies recipes for cocktails using amari and a few dishes made with them, all beautifully photographed.

headline: A Hole, a Tunnel, a 32-Yard Crawl: Palestinians Still Free After Jailbreak
abstract: A huge manhunt has failed to find six Palestinian prisoners who escaped an Israeli jail early on Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It was about 1:30 a.m. on Monday morning when the first prisoner poked his head up through a hole in a dirt track in northeast Israel and hauled himself above ground.

headline: Democrats and Lobbyists Gird for Battle Over Far-Reaching Tax Increases
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Income Inequality', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'American Jobs Plan (2021)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Congressional committees this week begin drafting tax increases on the wealthy and corporations to pay for a $3.5 trillion social policy bill, but the targets are putting up a fight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats always knew their battle plan for raising taxes on corporations, large inheritances and the superwealthy would not survive initial contact with the enemy.

headline: A Shop for All Your Dinner Party Needs
abstract: Katherine Lewin opened Big Night, a bright store stocked with everything you need for entertaining.
lead_paragraph: After a year of the pandemic, Katherine Lewin, the former editorial director for the restaurant platform the Infatuation, missed dinner parties. Figuring she was not alone, Ms. Lewin opened a bright shop stocked with essentials for entertaining. “People are intimidated, but it can be easy,” she said. (Ms. Lewin readily dispenses advice.) Shelves are filled with food products like tinned seafood, crackers and condiments, and there is a refrigerator stocked with cured meats and cheeses. She also sells She Wolf breads. The central counter and the wall behind it hold flatware, dishes, cake stands, linen napkins, barware and glassware, including some vintage pieces. Behind the store there is a secluded outdoor area with benches and a big picnic table; she plans to hold events with local restaurants there. E-commerce is coming.

headline: The Meadow Moves Across Town
abstract: The West Village chocolates and salts store closed a year ago, and will reopen on Mulberry Street.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Mark Bitterman closed the Meadow, his West Village shop with its unusual inventory of chocolate bars, salts and bitters. After closing down during the pandemic, he has now relocated across town. At the deep, narrow store furnished with reclaimed lumber you can buy a different chocolate bar for almost every day of the year — he has a wall of more than 350 of them. And you could easily get lost exploring the more than 100 salts from various sources, many flavored, on the shelves opposite. Other products include fresh flowers, salt blocks for cooking and grilling, and a few grocery items like condiments and spices. Among the newer chocolates he’s carrying, almost all bean-to-bar, are Honeymoon from St. Louis, Bixby from Maine and Cuna de Piedra from Monterrey, Mexico. You might also get to know the elegant Sol Cacao bars from the Bronx. Among the salts are a saffron variety, a useful seasoning that’s difficult to produce, and a very popular Guatemalan fleur de sel and ground Tellicherry pepper mix, which isn’t.

headline: 800,000 New Yorkers Just Lost Federal Unemployment Benefits
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'American Rescue Plan (2021)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: Many pandemic-era federal programs expired on Sunday, leaving jobless New Yorkers with more modest state unemployment benefits, or no aid at all.
lead_paragraph: From the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, New York City has been pummeled economically unlike any other large American city, as a sustained recovery has failed to take root and hundreds of thousands of workers have yet to find full-time jobs.

headline: Reminisce About the Restaurant Savoy
abstract: The East Village restaurant Huertas will host a conversation with the chef Peter Hoffman about restaurants and his memoir.
lead_paragraph: If you’re among those who might pass the corner of Prince and Crosby Streets in SoHo with a pang of nostalgia for the loss of the restaurant Savoy, closed in 2011, you can relive some of its moments with Peter Hoffman, the chef and a former owner, at a program at the Basque restaurant Huertas, near Mr. Hoffman’s restaurant Back Forty, which closed in 2014. On Sept. 23, Jonah Miller, the owner of Huertas, will hold a conversation with Mr. Hoffman about restaurants and his book, “What’s Good? A Memoir in 14 Ingredients,” which will be on sale. Savoy-inspired snacks and wine will be served. Proof of vaccination is required.

headline: Howard University Hit by a Ransomware Attack
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The Washington school canceled online and hybrid classes for a second day after shutting down its network.
lead_paragraph: Howard University, one of the country’s leading historically Black colleges and universities, canceled some classes for a second day after it was hit with a ransomware attack.

headline: A New Food Hall for Midtown
abstract: The Hugh, with a generous central seating area rimmed with trees, will have 17 restaurants, bars and food retailers.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Stubbins, the architect of a landmark skyscraper with an angled roof at Lexington Avenue and 53rd Street, now has his name emblazoned over the entrance to a spacious and soaring new food hall called the Hugh, which occupies the heart of the building’s ground floor. Originally the Citicorp Center and now owned by Boston Properties, the building opened in 1977 and had an atrium filled with shops and stands, an unusual feature that was described as “a U.N. of food” in The Times. That space has been renewed and refreshed. Around the perimeter of a generous central seating area rimmed with trees are 17 restaurants, bars and food retailers, an eclectic collection, all with counter service and many with bar stools. They’re opening gradually starting this week and offer a snapshot of today’s appetite. “We see a younger clientele in this neighborhood, people who go downtown or back to Brooklyn after work, so we’re trying to capture a sense of downtown,” said Anna Castellani, who created DeKalb Market Hall in Brooklyn, and this food hall with David Swinghamer in partnership with Boston Properties. She emphasized that they wanted to provide a more elegant setting than typical food halls. “We tried to be true to the building,” she said. There is also some outdoor seating.

abstract: Return to campus in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: In-person classes are returning to almost every university in the United States after more than a year of crisis and chaos — and at a particularly fraught moment. The highly contagious Delta variant is pushing cases skyward while the polarized debate around vaccines and masks has complicated campus discussions about virus safety.

headline: Who Are the Taliban’s New Government Leaders? Here’s What We Know
abstract: Many of the acting cabinet ministers appointed Tuesday have played similar roles within the Taliban for years, but there were some surprises.

headline: Man Gets 4 Years in $126 Million Printer Toner Fraud
keywords: ['Office Supplies and Equipment', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Small Business', 'Telemarketing']
abstract: Gilbert N. Michaels, of West Los Angeles, Calif., preyed on tens of thousands of small businesses and charities by overcharging them for toner they didn’t need, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The sales script went something like this, federal prosecutors say: The price of printer toner has gone up, but customers can lock in at the lower rate they’ve been paying for the office supply.

headline: The Pandemic Has Set Back the Fight Against H.I.V., TB and Malaria
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Tuberculosis', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Malaria', 'Third World and Developing Countries']

lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic has severely set back the fight against other global scourges like H.I.V., tuberculosis and malaria, according to a sobering new report released on Tuesday.

headline: Michael K. Williams Brought His Whole Life to His Characters
abstract: While Omar Little on “The Wire” is his best-known role, the actor drew upon his family and neighborhood for a slew of larger-than-life parts.
lead_paragraph: In a memorable scene in HBO’s “Lovecraft Country,” a sullen, swollen-eyed Montrose Freeman stands alone in a crowded underground ballroom as his lover, Sammy, in drag, beckons him to the dance floor. Wearing a red silk shirt, Montrose, played by Michael K. Williams, glistens as his character, a queer Black man, struggles with his sexuality and his race in 1950s Chicago.

headline: Booming Utah’s Weak Link: Surging Air Pollution
abstract: A red-hot economy, wildfire smoke from California and the shriveling of the Great Salt Lake are making Utah’s alarming pollution even worse.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Kevin Perry had just begun his morning routine, stepping outside to get the newspaper, when he noticed something was wrong with the sky.

headline: Climate Disaster Is the New Normal. Can We Save Ourselves?
abstract: There are only two options: adapt or suffer.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Where to Stream Michael K. Williams’s Best TV Performances
abstract: Starting with “The Wire,” Williams explored provocative intersections of race, crime, sexuality and masculinity. But he wasn’t afraid to poke fun at his own image.
lead_paragraph: Omar didn’t scare easily, and neither did Michael K. Williams.

lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — It was supposed to be a hearing intended to get the case against the five men accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks back on track after a long delay caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Democrats Press Biden Administration to Take On Texas Abortion Law
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Constitution (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Democrats and reproductive rights activists pressed the Biden administration on Tuesday to take more aggressive action to stop a Texas law that prohibits abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, even as administration officials and legal experts acknowledged it would be difficult to curtail the law in the coming months.

headline: Transcript of Biden’s Speech on Climate Change and Hurricane Ida

headline: Marvel’s Heroes Reflect on 9/11 in New Story
abstract: Captain America and Spider-Man remember those lost on Sept. 11 in an eight-page story that is included in some Marvel comics out Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, “The Four Fives,” an eight-page story from Marvel Entertainment in remembrance of the lives lost on Sept. 11, will publish. In the nearly dialogue-free comic, Spider-Man and Captain America are in downtown Manhattan as the Bell of Hope, in the churchyard of St. Paul’s Chapel, rings in a pattern of “four fives” (five strikes, four times): a longstanding ritual that signals a firefighter has fallen. The comic was written by Joe Quesada; drawn by John Romita Jr. and Scott Hanna; colored by ​​Marte Gracia; and lettered by Joe Caramagna.

The Giants had a 17-year playoff drought that started in the Johnson administration. The Jets have never been back to the Super Bowl after their upset victory over the Baltimore Colts in the 1968 season.

The three most popular vehicles sold in the Home of the Brave, historically, have been the Ford F-150, Chevrolet Silverado and Ram 1500, in that order. Need to drag a house off its foundation? Hand me that recovery strap and turn up Blake Shelton.

headline: If You Never Met Your Co-Workers in Person, Did You Even Work There?
abstract: As the pandemic drags on, more people are beginning and leaving new jobs without once seeing their colleagues face-to-face, leading to an easy-come, easy-go attitude toward workplaces.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Gregorio joined a nonprofit foundation in Arlington, Va., in April last year, shortly after the pandemic forced many people to work from home. One year and a zillion Zoom calls later, she had still never met any of her colleagues, aside from her boss — which made it easier to quit when a new job came along.

Letters, memoirs and diaries written by friends of Lawrence illuminate his three major crises and adversaries during the pilgrimage.

headline: Exercise for 3 Minutes, Every Half-Hour, to Counter the Ill Effects of Sitting
abstract: Climbing stairs, doing jumping jacks or even taking as few as 15 steps during mini-breaks improved blood sugar control among office workers.
lead_paragraph: Sitting for hours at a desk can play havoc with our metabolic health, contributing over time to high blood sugar and high cholesterol, even in people who otherwise seem mostly healthy. But a practical though small new study shows that standing up and moving every 30 minutes for about three minutes may lessen the health impacts of over-sitting. The study found that climbing several flights of stairs, bopping through some jumping jacks or squats or even taking as few as 15 steps during these mini-breaks improved aspects of blood sugar control among office workers, without noticeably interrupting their work flow.

headline: How Do You Get and Spend Money?
abstract: Check out this illustrated article in which 11 teenagers talk about the role of money in their lives, then tell us about your experiences.
lead_paragraph: How important is money to you? When you have it, what do you usually spend it on?

headline: Could Robots From Boston Dynamics Beat Me in a Fight?
abstract: A parkour showcase of the agile humanoids is both wondrous and unsettling.
lead_paragraph: In a vast warehouse-style room, two humanoid robots are taking on an obstacle course. Their barrel-shaped torsos, stuffed with processors and batteries, make it look as if they’ve been going to the gym a lot but have neglected leg day. They run and jump, traipsing on and off blocks and angled steps not unlike those in the qualifying round of the obstacle-​course show “American Ninja Warrior.” One runs along a beam and then, later, vaults over it. For the finale, they position themselves on opposite corners of a table and do two synchronized back flips. Feet firmly on the ground, they celebrate: One brushes off its shoulders, the other raises its arms in triumph. Neither, obviously, has broken a sweat.

headline: A Hate Group Targeted My Kid Online
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberharassment', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood', 'Content Type: Service']

headline: How to Catch a Bat
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Bats', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: An air puffer can help stop biting. Use thick leather gloves anyway.
lead_paragraph: “Treat bats the way you would unvaccinated children,” says Winifred Frick, chief scientist at Bat Conservation International. Before Covid, biologists often blew on bats’ faces to get them to stop biting and on their underbellies to confirm their reproductive status. Don’t do that; you could inadvertently give a bat coronavirus. New bat-handling protocols suggest using an air-puffing tool like one of those baby-booger nasal aspirators to puff air on a bat instead. Also, wear a mask, get vaccinated and test negative for coronavirus before going out in the field.

headline: ‘You Don’t Bring Democracy at the Point of a Gun’
abstract: Two veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom reflect on where the Sept. 11 attacks led the nation.
lead_paragraph: As the world reflects on the anniversary of Sept. 11, what does the day of the attacks — and the 20 years of war it precipitated — feel like to America’s veterans? With the Afghanistan withdrawal suddenly reclaiming attention for the “forever” wars, is the 9/11 era finally over, on the home front and in America’s foreign policy? Jane Coaston brings together Kenneth Harbaugh and Michael Washington, two friends and veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom, to discuss the pax Americana, the 9/11 roots of today’s divide in the veteran community and the political weaponization of service members’ patriotism. Harbaugh is a former Navy pilot turned veterans’ advocate and podcaster. Washington is a former Marine and firefighter who today works as a licensed therapist for veterans and emergency workers.

headline: One Thing We Can Agree On Is That We’re Becoming a Different Country
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Whites', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Social Media', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tolerance and intolerance are taking on many different guises.
lead_paragraph: A highly charged ideological transition reflecting a “massive four-decade-long shift in political values and attitudes among more educated people — a shift from concern with traditional materialist issues like redistribution to a concern for public goods like the environment and diversity” is a driving force in the battle between left and right, according to Richard Florida, an urbanologist at the University of Toronto.

headline: The Simple Perfection of Fried Eggs and White Rice
abstract: The great thing about egg rice is that it’s hardly cooking. If you can fry an egg, then you can make egg rice.
lead_paragraph: Every two weeks, Christina Dang buys a carton of 18 eggs from the Costco near her home in San Diego. Most of these eggs go into a snack she makes for herself when she comes home from work: egg rice. She fries a single egg sunny-side up and places it on a small plate of leftover jasmine rice. Then, over the yolk, she pours a little Maggi sauce, a dark, savory potion of wheat protein. For Dang, who is a pharmacist, there’s a ritual to eating this simple but potent dish, one she has upheld since she was young. She breaks the yolk and mixes the Maggi into it, creating a makeshift gravy that drapes the rice in eggy gold. She pierces her fork straight down into the food, so she has an even distribution of Maggi-tinged yolk, crisp-edged egg white and steamed white rice, fluffy as a fresh-raked pile of leaves, on her tines. “I eat this at least once a day,” she told me.

headline: What Will School Really Look Like This Fall?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Children and Childhood', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Income Inequality', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Six experts on the consequences of missed learning — and what it means for this year.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half into the pandemic, the crucial and irreplaceable role that school plays in students’ lives has never been clearer. In contrast to last fall, when school buildings in some parts of the country closed for long periods (mostly in blue cities and towns), a consensus has emerged this year in favor of bringing as many students as possible back to the classroom. But the country remains divided about which measures are required to do this safely. Infections are already forcing mass quarantines, and fear and high prevalence rates may further threaten in-person schooling once again — despite the indisputable evidence of the severe cost to kids.

headline: My Colleague Is Secretly Holding Two Jobs. Should I Expose Her?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the over employed and the under ambitious.
lead_paragraph: I recently joined a fast-growing health care company. I referred a candidate I worked with years ago, also a friend, who was a good match for an open position. My friend was offered the job, but I later learned that she intends to keep the full-time position she currently occupies while signing on for a full-time position at my company. Because each company allows for some remote work, she feels that she’ll be able to balance time for each. This arrangement is clearly against company policy, which requires, among other things, disclosure and approval of all other employment. My friend intends to keep her plans a secret from both companies.

headline: High Natural Gas Prices Strain Europeans, Weighing on Recovery
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Crimped supplies and increased demand have pushed energy prices to their highest in years, raising concerns about the winter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the world struggles to recover from the pandemic, soaring natural gas prices threaten to become a drag on the economies of Europe and elsewhere. Wholesale prices for the fuel are at their highest in years — nearly five times where they were at this time in 2019, before people started falling ill with the virus.

headline: He Had Chest Pain and Dangerously Low Blood Pressure. What Was Wrong?
abstract: Could a wayward breath mint have caused his symptoms?
lead_paragraph: The young woman was awakened by the screams of her 39-year-old husband. “Please make it stop!” he shouted, leaping from the bed. “It hurts!” He paced back and forth across the room, arms crossed over his chest as if to protect himself. Two days earlier, he had inhaled a breath mint when his wife startled him. He felt it move slowly down his throat as he swallowed repeatedly. His chest had hurt ever since. But not like this.

headline: In Turkey, a Watery Grave Becomes a Park
abstract: Off the Gallipoli Peninsula, the remains of some two dozen British, French and Australian ships — World War I relics — are memorialized in an undersea park formed during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The wind was picking up and the sea growing choppier as I rolled backward into the Aegean off the Eftelya Dina, a 33-foot dive boat based in the northwest Turkish port of Canakkale.

headline: ‘The Contender’ Lit Me on Fire. Now It’s a Cringe Factory.
abstract: A movie about a female senator navigating a sex scandal felt revolutionary when a writer saw it in 2000. But its stab at feminism feels clumsy now.
lead_paragraph: Why I revisited “The Contender” this summer is neither here nor there because it could have happened at any time, such is the real estate that movie takes up in my brain — meaning I was always revisiting it somewhere in my mind, though it had been more than 20 years since I’d seen it. But this movie has been informing me, vexing me and haunting me since. Beware the movies you watch as you crest the peak of your coming-of-age, at the exact moment when you’re sure you know everything.

headline: Virginia Removes Robert E. Lee Statue From State Capital
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The Confederate memorial was erected in 1890, the first of six monuments that became symbols of white power along the main boulevard in Richmond.

Lee, the South’s Civil War general — was hoisted off its pedestal in downtown Richmond, Va., on Wednesday, bringing to an end the era of Confederate statues in the city that is best known for them.

headline: Where L.G.B.T.Q. Migrants Find the True Meaning of Shelter
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A community in Tijuana is a model of a physically and psychologically safe place for vulnerable migrants.
lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — Steam curls off a plate overloaded with fresh tamales as refugees gather around a buffet-style dinner table, laughing together on a chilly evening here. Nearby, a pregnant woman shoos away toddlers underfoot, and one woman flips the hair of a blond wig so grand, it practically sweeps the cracked concrete floor. Across the room, a jovial young man teases a group of excited boys who are lining up to hit a rainbow-shaped pinata — a nod to the L.G.T.B.Q.-friendly space of Casa de Luz, where everyone gathered for this posada celebration in December.

headline: Seven Louisiana nursing homes lose their licenses after evacuating residents to a warehouse.

lead_paragraph: The state of Louisiana has revoked the licenses of seven nursing homes that evacuated more than 800 residents ahead of Hurricane Ida to a squalid warehouse north of New Orleans where several people died.

headline: Photographs of a Housing Crisis Worsened by Fire
abstract: The photographer Rachel Bujalski traveled to the Oregon towns burned by the Almeda fire last year even before she had an assignment.
lead_paragraph: For the past decade, Rachel Bujalski, a photographer based in San Francisco, has been documenting the inability of many people to find affordable housing in the United States. As part of this work, she has examined the devastating impact of wildfires that have left thousands of people homeless. She recently traveled to Ashland, Ore., in a region where the Almeda fire destroyed thousands of homes last September, and recorded the experiences of residents who are still displaced a year later for an article that was published Tuesday.

abstract: Afghanistan desperately needs aid. Nonprofits desperately want to provide it. But the aid groups are being tested as never before by the uncertainty that has followed the Taliban takeover.

headline: Travel restrictions are back in Europe for U.S. visitors, at least in some places.
abstract: In removing the U.S. from a list of safe countries, the European Union opened the door to a new web of bans, quarantines and testing requirements.
lead_paragraph: Italy now requires travelers from the United States to take a test before arrival, and unvaccinated American visitors must isolate for five days. Sweden is barring all nonessential U.S. visitors. The Netherlands says vaccinated travelers must isolate after arriving from the United States — and unvaccinated ones are not welcome.

headline: Extraordinary Actresses on Their Ordinary Roles in ‘Morning Sun’
abstract: Edie Falco, Blair Brown and Marin Ireland portray three generations of women sharing the same Greenwich Village walk-up in Simon Stephens’s new play.
lead_paragraph: Simon Stephens’s “Morning Sun,” Edie Falco insisted, is not a big play. It isn’t epic or tragic or especially momentous. Its characters don’t change the world. They barely cast a shadow. Which Falco likes.

headline: ‘Gender Alchemy’ Is Transforming Art for the 21st Century
keywords: ['Art', 'Museums', 'Women and Girls', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: With the growing visibility of gender-nonconforming and transgender people, the scope of feminism is fast evolving. Now two major museum shows in California explore the impact on art.
lead_paragraph: Organizing a museum survey of feminist art can be as politically fraught as organizing a women’s march, for some of the same reasons. Different women are bound to have different political goals or priorities. There are competing theoretical frameworks, from Marxist feminism, which sees capitalism as the main source of women’s oppression, to the intersectional feminism so prominent today, which highlights the impact of factors such as race and class on women’s lives. And the very notion of what it means to be a woman is fast evolving, with the growing visibility of gender-fluid, nonbinary and transgender populations.

headline: Quiz: If America Had Six Parties, Which Would You Belong To?
abstract: We can fix American politics. Just add more parties.
lead_paragraph: We can fix American politics. Just add more parties.

headline: Next Food Frontier: Fish Made From Plants, or in a Lab
abstract: Sophisticated, plant-based alternatives that mimic seafood are cropping up at restaurants and grocery stores around the world. And “cultivated” seafood, grown in labs from real cells, is on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: The chef Tsang Chiu King is preparing a subtle-but-significant change to his menu: He’s replacing the fish in some dishes with a plant-based alternative.

headline: ‘This Is the Biden Agenda’
abstract: The sprint for President Biden’s signature legislative plan has begun.
lead_paragraph: Early in Bill Clinton’s presidency, House Democrats voted to pass an energy tax, known as the B.T.U. tax, only to watch the Senate prevent the bill from becoming law. In the next midterm elections, more than 25 of the House Democrats who had voted for the bill lost re-election.

headline: Trial Begins Over November 2015 Paris Terrorist Attacks
abstract: The assaults carried out by Islamic State extremists that killed 130 people deeply rattled France and sent shock waves across Europe. The proceedings are scheduled to last at least nine months.

headline: In California, a heat advisory and a wildfire season that is ‘far from over.’

lead_paragraph: California’s wildfire season is “far from over” and the remainder of the year could be rough, a high-ranking fire official warned on Tuesday as thousands of firefighters across the state continued to battle at least a dozen large blazes threatening homes and communities.

headline: In Brazil, a House That Frames Its Landscape Like a Camera
abstract: By eliminating walls and color, the architect Marcio Kogan takes the form of a Trancoso fishing cottage to its most natural — yet elevated — ideal.

It was 1987, and he’d already completed 13 shorts, but creating a feature required choosing between what he then considered his two parallel callings.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in Minnesota, Virginia and California
abstract: An 1894 Queen Anne Victorian in St. Paul, an 1820 expanded farmhouse in Charlottesville and a 1908 Craftsman home in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: This home is on Summit Avenue, a 4.5-mile stretch containing 373 Victorian homes — the greatest concentration along a single street of any city in the United States, and the inspiration for not one but two national historic districts. F. Scott Fitzgerald, who once described the avenue as “a mausoleum of American architectural monstrosities,” lived for a time in his parents’ house on a block diagonal to this one; the writer Sinclair Lewis lived not far east of that. The restaurants and shops along Grand Avenue are a block south. Downtown St. Paul is about two miles northeast.

headline: Whether Dancing or Still, the Body in ‘Ema’ Tells the Story

lead_paragraph: Ema is the oddest of things: a dancer with a passion for setting things on fire. In “Ema,” Pablo Larraín’s film, the title character has a particular look, too: bleached hair slicked back so severely that it appears to be shellacked to her head. That hairstyle, hard and impenetrable, is like a coat of armor, which makes sense. Ema is made of ice. Until she dances.

headline: Review: In ‘Return the Moon,’ Theater Between Phases
abstract: While insubstantial, this immersive online performance gathers people virtually until they can get together more safely in person.
lead_paragraph: A quirk of astronomy: The phases of the moon appear the same no matter where you stand on Earth. If it’s gibbous in Greenland, it’s gibbous in Argentina; a crescent is a crescent from New Zealand to Uzbekistan. As I write this, a new moon approaches, and all over the world stars shine brighter now. Over the past year and a half, there have been fewer opportunities to watch the same thing at the same time in person, so what a miracle that if any of us were to stand outside, we might, for a moment, see the same bright thing.

headline: Theater to Stream: ‘Hamlet’ and a Tracy Letts Triptych

headline: The New Image Makers

headline: Where to Stream Jean-Paul Belmondo’s Best Performances
abstract: Whether he was doing his own stunts in action films or being nonchalant in literary adaptations, the actor was magnetic.
lead_paragraph: One word often comes up when reading about Jean-Paul Belmondo: cool. The French actor, who died on Monday at 88, never appeared to try hard, bringing a nonchalant effortlessness to all his roles. Belmondo did not look like a typical leading man — The New York Times described him as “hypnotically ugly” in 1961 — but he had charm and the unbothered casualness that the French call “désinvolture.”

headline: The U.S. Is Not Ready for Climate Reality
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A shocking summer keeps illustrating the limits of adapting to climate change. Experts say it will only get worse.
lead_paragraph: The climate disasters have been relentless this summer. Hurricane Ida took down the power grid in New Orleans, where more than 300,000 households remain without electricity as of Wednesday. A few days later, Ida dumped 7 inches of rain on New York City, drowning people in their basements and paralyzing the subways. Deadly heat waves scorched the Pacific Northwest, a massive wildfire spurred residents to evacuate South Lake Tahoe and flash floods devastated Tennessee.

lead_paragraph: This Lesson of the Day will help prepare students to participate in our live panel on Sept. 30 at 1 p.m. Eastern about how Sept. 11 shaped the generation that grew up in its aftermath.
