headline: Live Panel for Students: The Post-9/11 Generation
abstract: How did 9/11 shape the generation that grew up in its aftermath? Register for our panel on Sept. 30 and invite your students to share their perspectives.
lead_paragraph: Today’s middle and high school students were born after Sept. 11, 2001, yet they grew up in a world shaped by the attacks and their aftermath. What does Sept. 11 mean to the post-9/11 generation?

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The Taliban’s governance issues.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Taliban named an acting cabinet to lead Afghanistan, the dizzying challenges that accompanied the group’s victory were coming into sharp relief, including growing dissent, a humanitarian crisis and foreign policy woes.

headline: Canada’s Felix Auger-Aliassime and Leylah Fernandez Arrive at U.S. Open
abstract: The semifinalists are part of a new wave of Canadian tennis stars who are changing the image of the game in their country and reflecting its increased diversity.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s tennis success story continues to add chapters at breakneck pace with Felix Auger-Aliassime and Leylah Fernandez having advanced to the semifinals of the U.S. Open for the first time in their short careers.

headline: At U.S. Open, Novak Djokovic Moves One Step Closer to Grand Slam
abstract: After dropping the first set, the world No. 1 smoothly beat sixth-seeded Matteo Berrettini, 5-7, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3, to advance to the semifinals against Alexander Zverev.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open has waited 52 years for a man to have a chance at winning the Grand Slam, so what’s a few extra hours?

headline: Word of the Day: languid
abstract: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Dings and Pings
abstract: What do you think this GIF is saying?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this GIF is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Can a Man Wear Mules to Work?
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: For many men, gussied-up slippers are becoming a shoe for (almost) all occasions.
lead_paragraph: While some folks have sprinted out of lockdown keen to make up for lost time, a number of men have, er, shuffled back onto the streets. They are ambling, dawdling and slouching to lunches, drinks and work meetings, powered by insouciance rather than haste.

headline: What Is ‘American Fashion’ Now?
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Met Gala', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Museums', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: As New York Fashion Week begins and the Met Gala returns, it’s time to confront the question of who gets to define a nation’s style — and whether anyone can.
lead_paragraph: In less than a week, on Sept. 13, as the sun sets over Central Park, the great and the good and the very, very glamorous will sweep up the marble steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the party of the year, otherwise known as the Met Gala, for the first time since the pandemic began.

headline: Kehinde Wiley Portrait Inspired by ‘The Blue Boy’ Will Be Unveiled in October
abstract: The Huntington commissioned the artist, best known for his portrait of Barack Obama, to create a large-scale painting in response to the Thomas Gainsborough masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Los Angeles, the artist Kehinde Wiley was inspired by the beauty, wealth, glory and power of the Grand Manner portraits of men in regal poses at the Huntington in San Marino, Calif., though he was struck by one frustrating omission: Where were the subjects of color?

headline: Incendiary Essay Ignites Guessing Over Xi’s Plans for China
abstract: After Communist Party websites shared Li Guangman’s fierce denunciation of private corporations, contention broke out over whether leaders share his views.
lead_paragraph: For years, Li Guangman, a retired Chinese newspaper editor, wrote in obscurity, firing off attack after attack at chic celebrities and celebrated tycoons whom he accused of betraying the sturdy socialist values of Mao. Few outside of China’s fervent but narrow world of Maoist leftists read them.

headline: Samantha Bee Blasts Supreme Court for Allowing the Texas Abortion Ban
abstract: The “Full Frontal” host wasn’t happy about the state’s law, which outlaws abortion after six weeks, or the high court’s decision not to block it.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: On London Stages, High Ambitions and Mixed Results
abstract: In “Rockets and Blue Lights” and “Once Upon a Time in Nazi Occupied Tunisia,” British playwrights make grand gestures. Sometimes too grand.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It seems reasonable to expect fireworks from a play called “Rockets and Blue Lights,” a vivid title for an overstuffed, if intriguing, drama with no shortage of things to say.

headline: A Qatari jet carries more than 100 foreigners from Kabul.
abstract: Thursday’s flight to Doha was a major step in resolving an impasse that has left scores of foreigners stranded in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The first passenger flight to leave Afghanistan since the frenzied U.S. military evacuation ended late last month arrived in Doha, the Qatari capital, on Thursday with more than 100 foreigners, including Americans, aboard, and Biden administration officials said they expected more such flights in coming days.

headline: ​North Korea Forgoes the Usual Muscle-Flexing in a Military Parade
keywords: ['Parades', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The parade, which marked the government’s 73rd anniversary, was seen as a celebration of those who have borne the brunt of the regime’s effort to rebuild the economy amid sanctions and the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — ​North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, attended a national predawn military parade on Thursday, but skipped the opportunity to raise tensions with the United States through a fiery speech or the display of long-range ballistic missiles.

headline: Least Vaccinated States Lead Spike in Children’s Cases, Leaving Some Hospitals Stretched
abstract: Though serious illness in young people remains uncommon, more children are now being hospitalized for Covid-19 than ever before — especially in states where fewer residents have been vaccinated.
lead_paragraph: Though serious illness in young people remains uncommon, more children are now being hospitalized for Covid-19 than ever before — especially in states where fewer residents have been vaccinated.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Coffee, Dorm Rooms and Exercise
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Gabrielle Union Likes to Read in the Bathroom
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: “It’s quiet, I am left alone, it’s optimal temperature, I feel like I’m killing a couple birds with one stone, and I can retain what I’ve read.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s quiet, I am left alone, it’s optimal temperature, I feel like I’m killing a couple birds with one stone, and I can retain what I’ve read,” says the actress and activist Gabrielle Union, whose new memoir is “You Got Anything Stronger?”

headline: What Has One Eye and 1,200 Heads? An Old English Riddle, That’s What!
abstract: Riddles are as old as the English language and, as Adrienne Raphel explains, can tell us a lot about Anglo-Saxon culture — as long as we are able to solve them.
lead_paragraph: There’s a certain state of mind I call crossword brain: It’s both intuitive and counterintuitive, knowing when to turn away from the seemingly obvious solution, but also knowing when to trust your instincts and go with the answer that feels good. Crossword brain requires you to bend and sometimes entirely break the way you think you should make connections. Crosswords tug all sides of your mind, requiring you to dart from straightforward definitions to narrative logic to free association to bad dad puns, all in the same space.

headline: Inside the Abandoned Kabul Mansion Taliban Soldiers Call Home
abstract: More than 150 fighters have taken over the residence of a notorious Afghan warlord. Many are adjusting to a new lifestyle while awaiting orders from the new government.
lead_paragraph: More than 150 fighters have taken over the residence of a notorious Afghan warlord. Many are adjusting to a new lifestyle while awaiting orders from the new government.

headline: What Did Best-Selling Illustrators Doodle While Daydreaming in School?
abstract: Three artists open up about the influences that led them to pick up pen, pencil and paintbrush.
lead_paragraph: O.G. INFLUENCERS We all know how illustrations from iconic picture books can imprint themselves on our imaginations with the indelibility of an important memory. Close your eyes and you might be able to see a gaggle of girls in yellow coats swarming Miss Clavel in Ludwig Bemelmans’s “Madeline,” or amphibious buddies lounging on a log on the cover of Arnold Lobel’s “Frog and Toad Are Friends.” Who are the artists behind the latest generation of much-loved, well-thumbed stories, and what shapes their work? I checked in with three best-selling illustrators to find out.

headline: With Plans for a Baby, They Wanted a Place With a Second Bedroom and Lots of Amenities. Which Would You Choose?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Condominiums']
abstract: A couple from Mexico City knew that if they were going to buy, ‘it had to be now’ — before interest rates went up. Here’s what they found in Brooklyn for less than $2 million.
lead_paragraph: A couple from Mexico City knew that if they were going to buy, ‘it had to be now’ — before interest rates went up. Here’s what they found in Brooklyn for less than $2 million.

headline: The European Central Bank will slow its crisis-era bond buying.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Interest Rates', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: The central bank also slightly raised its forecasts for inflation and economic growth.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank said on Thursday that it would slow down its pandemic-era bond-buying program, one of the main tools it has used to support the eurozone economy through lockdowns, citing “favorable financing conditions” and the inflation outlook.

headline: Riz Ahmed Is Breaking Hollywood’s ‘Ethnicity Handcuffs’
abstract: The actor and musician has broken out past Hollywood’s stereotypical portrayals of Muslims. But does it matter if he’s the exception to the rule?
lead_paragraph: Since 9/11, and even before, Hollywood’s portrayal of Muslims has emboldened inaccurate stereotypes of dangerous villains or jihadist terrorists. In addition to misrepresenting Muslims, the industry has also arguably underrepresented this population — one U.S.C. study found Muslims represented 1.6 percent of speaking roles in recent major films. Actor, musician and activist Riz Ahmed is challenging this status quo in a career that has included playing a guileless assistant struggling to make ends meet in “Nightcrawler” and a drummer who loses his hearing in the film “Sound of Metal.” In 2021, he became the first Muslim to be nominated for a best actor Oscar — an accolade he found “bittersweet.”

headline: Texas’ Abortion Law Should Force America to Change Its Ways
abstract: A law preserving the life of a human being at any stage can be considered “extreme” only within a distorted social context.
lead_paragraph: Abortion is a failure for every woman and her unborn child — a failure of love, justice and mercy. Texas’ new abortion law is far from perfect, but I hope it can move us closer to these ideals.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the King-Size Bed
abstract: A husband wants to convert the living room so he and his wife can sleep on a bigger mattress.
lead_paragraph: Alan writes: My wife and I share a one-bedroom apartment in Vancouver. She has always wanted a king-size bed, but our bedroom is too narrow. I suggested we convert our large living room. She says that’s unnatural. But I’d like to treat my queen to a king.

headline: Poem: I came to you
abstract: From a poet who was always looking for and singing the names of others.
lead_paragraph: When Jean Valentine died on Dec. 29, 2020, America lost one of its most generous poets. Just days ago I was going through the many letters my friends from prison have sent me. And somehow within the mix was a letter from Jean. She wondered if I had the names of some young poets she should be checking for. I wish I remembered whose name I gave her, if anyone’s. But maybe it doesn’t matter; maybe for us poets, it only matters that someone is asking if we exist. Jean Valentine was a poet always looking for and singing the names of others. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

headline: California’s Recall Election Is Broken
keywords: ['Elections, California Gubernatorial Recall (2021)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Voters should choose “no” on the recall question and the state should look to reform the process.
lead_paragraph: California’s process for recalling its governor is so broken, some Democratic strategists are encouraging a vote for a Republican former San Diego mayor because “he’s not insane.” Millions of mail-in ballots were already cast before the state even released a list of qualified write-in candidates to potentially replace the sitting governor, Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, leaving voters to choose from a list of 46 mostly gadflies and wannabes.

headline: Men Fall Behind in College Enrollment. Women Still Play Catch-Up at Work.
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Admissions Standards', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Community Colleges']
abstract: Women are overrepresented in low-paying professions that require college credentials.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus upended the lives of millions of college students. The Wall Street Journal reported this week that men have been hit particularly hard — accounting for roughly three-fourths of pandemic-driven dropouts — and depicted an accelerating crisis in male enrollment.

headline: How the Mayor’s Big Decision Could Upend N.Y.C. School Admissions
abstract: New York City’s highly competitive gifted and talented programs could be overhauled in one of the last major policy moves from Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after he took office eight years ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed to tackle inequality in New York City’s public schools. But as the mayor enters his final months in office, the city’s schools remain among the most racially segregated in America.

headline: God Has No Place in Supreme Court Opinions
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: Republican officeholders are no longer coy about their religion-driven mission to stop abortion.
lead_paragraph: One hundred and fifty years ago, a woman named Myra Bradwell brought a U.S. Supreme Court case claiming a constitutional right to be admitted to the Illinois bar. She had passed the state’s bar exam with high honors, but the Illinois Supreme Court refused her application, saying that when the state General Assembly gave the court the power to grant law licenses, “it was with not the slightest expectation that this privilege would be extended to women.”

headline: Skilled Workers Are Scarce, Posing a Challenge for Biden’s Infrastructure Plan
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Shortages', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'American Jobs Plan (2021)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: One estimate says the bill would add $1.4 trillion to the U.S. economy over eight years, but without enough workers, efforts to strengthen roads and public transit could be set back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The infrastructure bill that President Biden hopes to get through Congress is supposed to create jobs and spur projects for companies like Anchor Construction, which specializes in repairing aging bridges and roadways in the nation’s capital.

headline: These Jennifer Aniston Fans Weren’t Born When ‘Friends’ Aired
abstract: Young stans also flock to the “Friends House” in Manhattan’s West Village to pay homage to the 52-year-old actress.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Bartol, 17, a high school senior in Manhattan, can recite like a catechism Jennifer Aniston’s lifetime trajectory, from her television debut as Rachel on “Friends,” to her string of failed romances and recent turn as a flinty but flappable network anchor on “The Morning Show.”

headline: As a Daytime Host, Kelly Clarkson Has No Fear of Being Vocal
abstract: After its first two seasons were disrupted by the pandemic, “The Kelly Clarkson Show” has big expectations to fulfill. But its host is ready to come back better and, yes, stronger.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Clarkson had just come striding through an aisle of the Appel Room one afternoon in late August, accompanied by Kristin Chenoweth and a troupe of dancers as they sang the final bars of the uplifting Imagine Dragons ballad “On Top of the World.”

headline: Proponents of Post-Trump Curbs on Executive Power Prepare New Push
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: House Democrats are framing their efforts as a rebuke of Donald J. Trump’s record as would-be reformers seek Senate Republican support.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Donald J. Trump’s norm-busting presidency careened through two impeachments, his departure set the stage for lawmakers to impose new limits on executive power like the period after Watergate and the Vietnam War.

headline: Impersonation? Yes. But With the Right Star, Something Richer.
abstract: In new musicals about Princess Diana, Cary Grant and Michael Jackson actors get a chance to embody icons while spotlighting their individual talents.
lead_paragraph: Just before the pandemic I ambivalently attended a performance of “Tina: The Tina Turner Musical.” I knew some Tina Turner songs, and I was vaguely aware of her marriage to the abusive Ike Turner. I was only barely acquainted with her global celebrity, and skeptical about the depth a biographical jukebox musical could offer.

headline: Why Art Struggled to Address the Horrors of 9/11
abstract: After the attacks, American culture became one of prohibitions. Then the Iraq War made it difficult to address Sept. 11 on its own terms.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after the towers fell, Jennifer Bartlett started painting. She had watched them collapse from her roof that September, and in her studio in the West Village she began depicting what almost no one wanted to depict, in her style of solid dots daubed into a grid of little squares. Toward the edges the dots are that distinctive cloudless blue, but most squares she overlaid with two dots, or three, the gray of the smoke superimposed on the red or saffron of the fireball. The dots became embers of exploded airplanes, or TV screen pixels (we had no smartphones then); they were papers raining down on the financial district and the Battery. Across two squares Bartlett placed a figure, stylized like in a cave painting, feet over head. A diver.

headline: At U.S. Open, Teen Spirit Rules and It’s Contagious
abstract: Doubles partners Coco Gauff and Caty McNally credit fellow teenagers Leylah Fernandez and Emma Radacanu for motivating them as they’ve advanced to the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: As Emma Raducanu and Leylah Fernandez have put themselves one match away from an improbable all-teenage U.S. Open women’s singles final, an even younger duo is just as close to taking the trophy in tandem.

headline: The Trumpeter Adam O’Farrill’s Art of Avoiding the Obvious
abstract: The son and grandson of Latin jazz royalty is releasing a new album with his quartet Stranger Days, and it’s their most melodically engaging yet.
lead_paragraph: If you pay close enough attention to jazz, Adam O’Farrill might have landed on your radar about a decade ago, when he was still an adolescent. His last name is immediately recognizable — his father and grandfather are Latin jazz royalty — but he stood apart even then, mostly by hanging back and letting his trumpet speak for itself.

headline: A.I. Can Now Write Its Own Computer Code. That’s Good News for Humans.
abstract: A new technology called Codex generates programs in 12 coding languages and even translates between them. But it is not a threat to professional programmers.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Tom Smith got his hands on Codex — a new artificial intelligence technology that writes its own computer programs — he gave it a job interview.

headline: Courtroom Reporting When You’re Not Quite in Court
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Human Trafficking', 'Sex Crimes', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Blurry sights, muffled sound. Covering the R. Kelly trial on a monitor in another room of the courthouse isn’t exactly ideal access, but we make do.
lead_paragraph: One day during R. Kelly’s trial in Brooklyn federal court, the priest who officiated the 1994 wedding of the R&B superstar and the 15-year-old singer Aaliyah was called to testify as a witness. He did so without stepping foot in New York.

headline: ‘Reversing Gears’: China Increasingly Rejects English, and the World
keywords: ['Chinese Language', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Propaganda', 'Education (K-12)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Language and Languages', 'Books and Literature', 'English Language']
abstract: A movement against Western influence threatens to close off a nation that succeeded in part by welcoming new ideas.
lead_paragraph: As a student at Peking University law school in 1978, Li Keqiang kept both pockets of his jacket stuffed with handwritten paper slips. An English word was written on one side, a former classmate recalled, and the matching Chinese version was written on the other.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Music', 'Dancing', 'Theater', 'Classical Music', "Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival", 'MTV Video Music Awards', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Labyrinths and Mazes', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
lead_paragraph: An artist who turned soup cans into Pop Art icons would probably be amused to see one of his other works reimagined in thousands of stalks of corn.

headline: Brazil’s President Bans Social Networks From Removing Some Posts
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Censorship']
abstract: The new rules in Brazil appear to be the first national policy that restricts how tech companies can control their sites, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil is temporarily banning social media companies from removing certain content, including his claims that the only way he’ll lose next year’s elections is if the vote is rigged — one of the most significant steps by a democratically elected leader to control what can be said on the internet.

headline: Olaf Scholz Is Running as the Next Angela Merkel, and It Seems to Be Working
abstract: Mr. Scholz, a Social Democrat who is modeling himself as the candidate of continuity, has a fair shot at being Germany’s next chancellor.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Olaf Scholz asked his fellow Social Democrats to nominate him as their candidate for chancellor, some inside his own camp publicly wondered if the party should bother fielding a candidate at all.

headline: House panels begin writing the $3.5 trillion social policy and climate bill.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Tuition', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Vocational Training', 'Global Warming', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Education (Pre-School)']
abstract: Five committees started drafting the components of Democrats’ far-reaching legislation in an arduous process that could take several days.
lead_paragraph: Five House committees on Thursday began formally drafting their pieces of Democrats’ far-reaching social policy and climate change bill that would spend as much as $3.5 trillion over the next decade — and raise as much in taxes and other revenue boosters — to reweave the social safety net and move the country away from fossil fuels.

headline: Dragon Boat Racing, Booming in Popularity, Confronts Abuse Case
keywords: ['Boats and Boating', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Asian-Americans']
abstract: The on-again, off-again prosecution of a leading coach has divided the racing community and raised questions about safeguards in the sport.
lead_paragraph: For the last three decades, dragon boat racing has surged in popularity around the world. Former rowers have switched to paddling and represented their countries in international races. Corporate and government employees have participated in community races. Young Asian Americans, buoyed by cultural pride, have dominated some rosters, especially in New York.

headline: Inside Missouri’s ‘2nd Amendment Sanctuary’ Fight
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Sheriffs', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A new law puts Missouri at the vanguard of states challenging federal authority on guns. It began as a backlash, and it has set off another.
lead_paragraph: OZARK, Mo. — Brad Cole is a fiery defender of the Second Amendment, a set-jawed lawman with a lacquered alligator head on his desk, a Smith & Wesson .357 Magnum on his hip and a signed picture of himself with former President Donald J. Trump on his office wall.

headline: How a TV Ad Enticed Broadway Crowds Right After 9/11
abstract: Rudy Giuliani was meant to appear; Elaine Stritch arrived just in time. Recalling the “I Love New York” spot that helped dispel the fear in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Broadway suspended performances for just two days, reopening on Sept. 13, 2001. But audiences were hesitant to return, and many shows performed to near-empty houses for weeks.

headline: Air Travel After 9/11: Just Get Through It
abstract: Before the terrorist attacks, airplane passengers weren’t seen as security risks, and flying was an enjoyable extension of the vacation experience — not something merely to anxiously endure.
lead_paragraph: To understand how very different the experience of flying was before Sep. 11, 2001, consider this story from Felix Hernandez about ordering pizza. In 1999, Mr. Hernandez was the pilot on a Trans World Airlines flight from New York’s Kennedy International Airport to Chicago that was nearing takeoff when it was called back because of weather. The gate that the Boeing 727 had left from was already filled, so Mr. Hernandez was told to taxi the plane to a parking area to wait out the delay.

headline: 7 True Stories From Virtual School
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Teachers, administrators and service providers talk about what remote teaching is really like.
lead_paragraph: Teachers started reporting that students were in class on Zoom while, for example, moving boxes at a warehouse. The norm was that the camera be on, but especially as time went on, the kids often had it pointed at the ceiling. Teachers could tell when kids were at work because it’s a higher ceiling than their bedrooms’.

headline: ‘Muhammad Ali’ Explores the Many Layers of ‘the Greatest’
keywords: ['Television', 'Boxing', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A new four-part documentary series by Ken Burns paints a sweeping portrait of a man whose life intersected with many of modern America’s most profound changes.
lead_paragraph: One day in the mid-1990s, Ken Burns had a cold while he was in Los Angeles to raise money for his next documentary. He ducked into a coffee shop for some hot tea, and after paying, one of the 20th century’s most ardent historians turned from the counter and locked eyes with perhaps its most towering icon. Muhammad Ali was sitting in a booth nearby. The two men stared at each other silently for longer than most strangers would — celebrities or not.

headline: Which Values Should Guide America’s Laws?
abstract: Reflections on Texas’ abortion law.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: The Potential Future of Gifted Programs in N.Y.C. Schools
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is poised to  overhaul how students are admitted to the classes, which have become a stark symbol of segregation.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: ‘I’m Part of Something That’s Really Evil’
abstract: The story of Terry Albury, an F.B.I. agent so disillusioned by the war on terror that he was willing to leak classified documents.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: N.F.L. Week 1 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Dueling Alabama quarterbacks and a rematch of January’s Browns-Chiefs playoff game make for a compelling start to the regular season.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our NFL Week 4 picks against the spread and predictions.

headline: Building a More Sustainable Car, From Headlamp to Tailpipe
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Vehicle makers shy away from traditional materials that are hard to recycle, like leather and plastics, and look to repurpose alternatives that still convey quality.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, Chrysler’s TV commercials played up its vehicles’ “rich Corinthian leather.” That meaningless phrase, dreamed up by marketers and cooed by the actor Ricardo Montalbán, became emblematic of what defined a luxury vehicle.

headline: A fire at a coronavirus hospital in North Macedonia kills at least 14.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hospitals', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Twelve others, all patients, were being treated for injuries in what the country’s health minister called a “terrible accident.”
lead_paragraph: A fire at a temporary hospital where coronavirus patients were being treated in North Macedonia has left at least 14 people dead, the country’s health minister said.

headline: A Big Delta Unknown
abstract: Is the variant more severe than earlier versions of the virus? We look at the latest data.
lead_paragraph: It remains perhaps the most important unanswered question about the Delta variant: Does it cause more severe illness than earlier versions of the Covid virus — or equally severe symptoms in the average infected person (while clearly being more contagious)?

headline: ‘Dating & New York’ Review: Texts and the City
abstract: A winning cast helps sell a too-familiar premise about commitment-phobic millennials.
lead_paragraph: “Dating & New York” is consciously framed as a modern fairy tale: It opens with a set of watercolor paintings that portray the city in clean, soft textures and a voice-over informing us that “once upon a time” there, two millennials were cursed with the “paradox of choice.” Wendy (Francesca Reale) and Milo (Jaboukie Young-White) connect through a dating app, meet once and then ghost each other. When they finally rendezvous again, Wendy has drawn up a written contract for a “best friends with benefits” arrangement. The two embark on a relationship they refuse to acknowledge as such.

headline: ‘Queenpins’ Review: Suburban Scammers
abstract: Two cash-strapped neighbors devise a multimillion-dollar coupon swindle in this mildly entertaining comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Queenpins” might have been a snappy little comedy had it lost 20 minutes and found a point beyond glorifying grand larceny. Erasing the lead character’s smug-perky narration wouldn’t have hurt, either.

headline: ‘No Responders Left Behind’ Review: Heroes Need Heroes Too
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Rescues', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: John Feal works tirelessly as an advocate for rescuers injured or sickened in the events of Sept. 11, 2001, and their aftermath.
lead_paragraph: In “No Responders Left Behind,” John Feal is a kind of action hero — political action, that is. This documentary by Rob Lindsay follows Feal’s tenacious efforts to obtain government health benefits and compensation for the thousands of rescuers with illnesses and injuries from working on Sept. 11, 2001, and beyond.

headline: ‘Dogs’ Review: Fish Out of Water
abstract: A city boy inherits land used by the Mafia in this unoriginal neo-western crime thriller from Romania.
lead_paragraph: The city boy Roman (Dragos Bucur) is lured into the Romanian outback when he inherits 550 hectares of land from his recently deceased grandfather, a local “godfather” figure not terribly unlike those popularized by Mario Puzo. Though Roman arrives with the intention of quickly selling the miserable property for some extra cash, his sojourn is upended when a group of thugs headed by the smug, sinister Samir (Vlad Ivanov) come to play.

headline: ‘Kate’ Review: Lost in Assassination
abstract: Mary Elizabeth Winstead plays a vengeful contract killer in this predictable thriller.
lead_paragraph: The thriller “Kate” is an undistinguished action film that makes a hero of a hit woman. Kate (Mary Elizabeth Winstead), guided by her wily handler, Varrick (Woody Harrelson), has been a professional since adolescence. Her only rule is to never kill in front of a child. Naturally — this being a relatively unimaginative plot — Kate betrays her principles within the first five minutes of the movie, murdering a yakuza gang member in front of his daughter.

headline: ‘The Capote Tapes’ Review: New Narratives and Unanswered Prayers
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: This documentary adds some material to the tragic tale of a great American writer, but also teases at what it can’t deliver.
lead_paragraph: There’s some fascinating and provocative material in “The Capote Tapes” that is diluted by the director Ebs Burnough’s insistence on teasing a question that, arguably, has a self-evident answer.

headline: ‘The Alpinist’ Review: Dizzying Heights
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Mountaineering', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: This documentary tries to shed light on the attitude of a Canadian rock climber it describes as “elusive.”
lead_paragraph: In a podcast excerpted at the start of “The Alpinist,” the rock climber Alex Honnold, from the Oscar-winning documentary “Free Solo,” is asked to name a climber who impresses him. He cites Marc-André Leclerc, a Canadian whom Honnold says takes on some of the sport’s most difficult challenges in “such a pure style.” Honnold’s remarks suggest Leclerc would happily ascend in obscurity, keeping his accomplishments between him and the mountains.

headline: ‘Fire Music’ Review: An Impassioned Case for Free Jazz
abstract: The beautiful souls that created free jazz — including Ornette Coleman, Cecil Taylor, Don Cherry and Carla Bley — light up this new documentary from Tom Surgal.
lead_paragraph: One default reaction to the musical form called “free jazz” — Ornette Coleman’s phrase for this improvised, experimental style of jazz — has long been that it’s “not music.” This concise but cogent documentary directed by Tom Surgal is crammed with exhilarating sounds, moving reminiscences and stimulating arguments that it is not just music, but vital music.

headline: For Fall, a New American Gothic
abstract: With long, layered silhouettes and raw textures like wool and denim, this season’s fashion revives — and reimagines — the pastoral looks of eras past.

headline: Was That Bunt Weird or Is Your Manager Mike Matheny?
abstract: A treasure trove of sortable statistics for managers gives fans the ability to track their team’s tendencies on things like stolen bases, intentional walks, ejections and, yes, bunts.
lead_paragraph: Baseball is a sport of numbers: 762 home runs, 511 wins, a 56-game hitting streak.

headline: France to Offer Free Contraception for Women Up to 25
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The government, responding to what it said was a decline in the use of contraceptives among some young women because of the cost, will pay for contraception starting next year.
lead_paragraph: France will begin offering free contraceptives for women up to the age of 25 starting next year to help young women with the financial costs of protecting against pregnancy, the country’s top health official said on Thursday.

headline: You Are Invited to Our Wedding. Kindly Tell Us Your Vaccination Status.
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: As the busy fall wedding season arrives, the Delta variant is forcing guests and couples to conform to new rules of etiquette.
lead_paragraph: Asking wedding guests to leave their children at home used to be among the thornier requests a couple could make.

headline: Nearly all power has been restored in New Orleans, where at least 10 people died of excess heat after Ida.
abstract: The progress comes amid a rising death toll from the hurricane. Follow here for news on extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world.
lead_paragraph: With the vast majority of lights now on in New Orleans, city officials on Thursday were prepared for the next phase in navigating the aftermath of Hurricane Ida: recovery.

headline: A family has been trying to get back to Hong Kong for a year. Is this the moment?
abstract: The Bordias have been trying to return to Hong Kong, their home of 13 years, from India, where they traveled early in the pandemic. But their journey has become a game of transoceanic Whac-A-Mole.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Ankur and Priyanka Bordia unpacked their family’s eight suitcases for the fourth time in 40 days.

headline: Pinball Museum Will Auction 1,700 Arcade Games After Closing Its Doors
abstract: The Museum of Pinball in Banning, Calif., is closing because of financial difficulties, augmented by the pandemic. Its collection could be worth as much as $7 million.
lead_paragraph: Inside an unremarkable warehouse near Palm Springs, Calif., hundreds of pinball machines once beckoned arcade game aficionados from far and wide, their blinking lights and coin slots a throwback to a time long before Xbox.

headline: The Black Recovery Stories Speaking to Individual and Collective Wellness
abstract: Long sidelined, these narratives are ascendant in the culture, and offer an elastic yet demanding view of what it might take for Americans — and their nation — to heal.
lead_paragraph: FOR ALL THAT was emotionally sobering about the last year, it was literally sobering, too. Many Americans, drinking more than ever during Covid-19 lockdowns and with plenty of time to reflect on it, began to wonder if alcohol was more hindrance than help. The question had been popularized by the sober-curious movement, based on a term coined by the British author Ruby Warrington, and supported by online recovery programs such as Tempest, founded in 2014. But it became especially acute as the incoherent national response to the Covid-19 pandemic conspired with a failing health care system to prove once again that the state could not be trusted to ensure its citizens’ wellness. This was particularly true, the reanimated Black Lives Matter movement announced, when those citizens were brown or Black.

headline: U.S. states with low vaccination rates see sharp spikes in children with Covid-19.
abstract: The number of children admitted to the hospital in the United States with Covid-19 has risen to the highest levels reported to date. Nearly 30,000 of them entered hospitals in August.
lead_paragraph: The number of children admitted to the hospital in the United States with Covid-19 has risen to the highest levels reported to date. Nearly 30,000 of them entered hospitals in August.

headline: ‘Football Is Like Food’: Afghan Female Soccer Players Find a Home in Italy
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Politics and Government', 'Soccer', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Members of a team from Herat left behind the lives they had built in Afghanistan in hopes that they can build a future where they can play, and thrive.
lead_paragraph: AVEZZANO, Italy — Two days after Taliban fighters seized Herat, Afghanistan’s third-largest city, the Italian journalist Stefano Liberti received a message via Facebook: “Hi sir, we are in trouble. Can you help us?”

headline: What the Texas Abortion Law Means for California
abstract: Exploring the future of abortion access in the state.
lead_paragraph: The near-total ban on abortions in Texas that began last week has reverberated across the nation, with abortion rights advocates fearful of what’s to come as lawmakers in some states pledge to follow suit.

headline: 10 Ways to Teach About 9/11 With The New York Times
abstract: Ideas for helping students think about how the Sept. 11 attacks have changed our nation and world.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 11, 2001, is one of those rare days that, if you ask most adults what they remember, they can tell you exactly where they were, whom they were with and what they were thinking. It is a day seared in memory. But for students who were born in a post-9/11 world and have grown up in the aftermath, it is complex history that needs to be remembered, taught and analyzed like any other historical event.

headline: A Vermeer Restoration Reveals a God of Desire
abstract: An image of Cupid was covered over in “Girl Reading a Letter at an Open Window” for nearly 300 years. Now that he’s back on show, the famous painting looks quite different.
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — After nearly three centuries behind a layer of paint, a naked Cupid has surfaced in one of the world’s best-loved artworks, drastically altering the background of a quiet interior scene.

headline: I Wrote the Lead Times Article on 9/11. Here’s What Still Grips Me.
abstract: After 20 years of war, a correspondent looks back.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, an English teacher in central Washington State assigned her eighth and ninth graders to write poems based on the lead article in The Times. The teacher, Tammy Grubb, said her intention was to give the students a way to process their feelings. The poems were posted in the school hallway and then, since my byline was on the article, Ms. Grubb sent them to me, 77 of them.

headline: Covid has disrupted learning for more than 400 million children in South Asia, the U.N. says.
abstract: A UNICEF report warned that the pandemic had forced a premature transition to remote learning in a region where many lack reliable internet access.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic is causing lasting damage to the education of children across South Asia, more than 400 million of whom are still facing school closures and limited access to remote learning, the United Nations said on Thursday.

headline: Dear Colleagues, Will You Please Mask Up?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Content Type: Service', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: A reader asks about navigating an office where vaccination is not required.
lead_paragraph: My employer doesn’t require masks in the office, and most people don’t wear them — even in meeting rooms where social distancing is impossible. Still, I wear a mask, and I’d feel better if my colleagues did too. We returned to the office in June, before the Delta variant became widespread in my state and Covid infection rates were low. I’m vaccinated, but the vaccination rate is low in my area. (And our employer says we shouldn’t ask co-workers if they are vaccinated.) Is there a way to ask co-workers to wear masks in the office? I have young children who aren’t eligible for vaccination, and I want to keep them safe.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A Marcel Breuer doc, a purse that’s a pouch — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Bold, Fall-Friendly Timepieces in Shades of Green
abstract: This batch of fresh-feeling options features emerald, juniper and pistachio dials, some with bands to match.
lead_paragraph: Green may usually be associated with spring but has lately been popping up on timepieces perfect for fall. It’s an unexpected flourish that adds a bit of freshness, whether you prefer a clean and unadorned look — see the Nomos Club Automatic — or a more embellished finish, as with the diamond-studded bezel of Patek Philippe’s Aquanaut Luce. The latter carries the shade through from its dial to its band, just like Hublot’s Big Bang Unico SORAI, while Omega’s Seamaster Aqua Terra sticks with a classic steel bracelet and H. Moser’s Pioneer Centre Seconds features a black textile strap.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in White Plains, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Holmdel, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in White Plains, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Holmdel, N.J.

abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in White Plains, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Holmdel, N.J.
