abstract: U.S. officials said a Reaper drone followed a car for hours and then fired based on evidence it was carrying explosives. But in-depth video analysis and interviews at the site cast doubt on that account.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was the last known missile fired by the United States in its 20-year war in Afghanistan, and the military called it a “righteous strike” — a drone attack after hours of surveillance on Aug. 29 against a vehicle that American officials thought contained an ISIS bomb and posed an imminent threat to troops at Kabul’s airport.

headline: It’s a ‘Brawl in Beantown,’ as Progressive Allies Clash in the Boston Mayor’s Race
abstract: For years, they were “sisters in service,” taking on the old guard and boosting one another’s careers. A rare open mayoral seat changed that.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Not so long ago, Boston’s leading progressives called themselves “sisters in service,” linking arms to take on this city’s overwhelmingly white, overwhelmingly male old guard.

headline: In Colson Whitehead’s New Novel, a Crime Grows in Harlem
abstract: A hotel heist is at the center of “Harlem Shuffle,” but the deeper sin is America’s handling of race and the decline of a thriving midcentury community.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes he slipped and his mind went thataway,” Colson Whitehead writes about Ray Carney, the crime-adjacent Harlem furniture salesman at the center of his new novel, “Harlem Shuffle.” Whitehead’s own mind has famously gone thataway through nine other books that don’t much resemble one another, but this time he’s hit upon a setup that will stick. He has said he may keep Ray going into another book, and it won’t take you long to figure out why.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Consider 9/11’s effects on American culture.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Tomorrow morning I’m going to meet my friend Daniel for breakfast in the East Village, and then we’re going to walk over to the west side, roughly following the route I traveled to work on Sept. 11, 2001, when Daniel and I were colleagues at the then-brand-new cable network Oxygen. The office had a bank of about eight televisions in its lobby, each regularly tuned to a different news channel. That day, as we entered, each showed the exact same images.

headline: Say Hello to the Tortizza, a Dinner Life Raft
abstract: These tortilla pizzas, topped with crunchy vegetables and salty feta, couldn’t be easier to make.
lead_paragraph: When it first opened in 2018, the Manhattan bar and vodka distillery Our/New York would serve makeshift tortilla pizzas that had been quickly burnished in a toaster oven behind the bar. The founder and partner, Dave Ortiz, got the idea from his friend, the chef Ilan Hall. “Long story short: A celebrity chef hooked me up,” he said.

headline: A New Podcast Rekindles a Box-Office Bomb
abstract: Julie Salamon, the author of a 1991 book about the filming of “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” returns to Hollywood history — and her own.
lead_paragraph: One day last December, Julie Salamon was sorting through stacks of old plastic boxes at a storage unit in Lower Manhattan. Salamon, 68, is a journalist, author and self-described pack rat. The boxes were accidental galleries in the museum of a life’s work, filled with relics — notebooks, clippings, photos and tapes — accumulated for the dozen books Salamon has published since 1988.

headline: ‘What’s Going on With Our Black Girls?’ Experts Warn of Rising Suicide Rates.
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Discrimination', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Researchers have uncovered worrisome trends among Black youth.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, suicide rates have been increasing in Black children and adolescents, and a new study says the sharpest rise occurred among young girls.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Will Biden’s mandates work?
lead_paragraph: The sweeping vaccine mandates that President Biden announced yesterday will affect almost every aspect of society in the United States. Our colleague Apoorva Mandavilli, who covers science for The Times, had a simple question: Will the mandates slow the surging pandemic?

headline: Carl Bean, Gay Singer Who Turned to Preaching, Dies at 77
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: After recording “I Was Born This Way,” a club favorite, he entered the ministry and founded a church for the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
lead_paragraph: Carl Bean, who in 1977 recorded “I Was Born This Way,” a disco song of L.G.B.T.Q. pride that became a much-remixed club favorite — and who then became a minister and AIDS activist, founding a church in Los Angeles that sought to serve the spiritual needs of gay people and others who were marginalized — died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 77.

headline: Top National Security Posts Sit Empty, Mired in Senate ‘Purgatory’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: Two decades after the Sept. 11 attacks, there are again dozens of unfilled Senate-confirmed national security positions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, nearly half of the federal government’s Senate-confirmed top national security jobs sat empty, making the United States more vulnerable, the 9/11 Commission found. Two decades later, the situation — by at least one measure — is worse.

headline: Sept. 11, Vaccines, the Met Opera: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Israel Captures 4 of 6 Palestinian Fugitives Who Escaped Prison
abstract: The escape on Monday was seen as a rare humiliation of Israel’s security establishment, and was celebrated by Palestinians. The other two inmates were still at large on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli police said on Saturday that they had captured four of the six Palestinian fugitives who escaped a maximum-security prison this week, in a case seen as a rare humiliation of the country’s security establishment.

headline: A Sept. 11 Conundrum
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Social Media', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: What we leave behind.
lead_paragraph: A lot of important words are being written about the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on America, marking that major and tragic turning point in history.

headline: U.S. Forces Were Training the Guinean Soldiers Who Took Off to Stage a Coup
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American military officials have denounced the ouster of a president in West Africa, and said they had no warning of what their students were planning.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — American Green Berets were training local forces in the West African nation of Guinea last weekend when their charges peeled away for a mission not listed in any military training manual: They mounted a coup.

headline: Debate Over Guns Is Muted as Canada’s Election Nears
abstract: The Conservative Party leader, Erin O’Toole, rolled back a promise to end a ban on assault weapons, giving his opponents less room to maneuver.
lead_paragraph: With the debates now over, we have come to the final days of the high-speed election campaign that was called last month by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

headline: Food Delivery Apps Sue New York Over Fee Limits
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Mobile Applications', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Restaurants', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Grubhub, Uber Eats and Door Dash have characterized a 15 percent cap on fees charged to restaurants as an unconstitutional measure that will hurt consumers.
lead_paragraph: The three largest food delivery platforms have filed a lawsuit seeking to overturn New York City’s cap on the fees they can charge to restaurants.

headline: Bank of America Revamps Leadership, but C.E.O. Plans to Stick Around
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The nation’s second-largest bank promoted several executives, although it’s unlikely that any of them will replace Brian Moynihan, the chief executive, anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America made sweeping changes to the company’s leadership Friday that elevated several executives, including three women, to senior jobs and all but guaranteed that Brian Moynihan, the chief executive, would remain at the helm of the nation’s second-largest bank for years to come.

headline: The Afghan War Took an Awful Toll. I Would Still Serve Again.
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: It’s not a surprise that many American veterans are highly cynical about these wars. We are also conflicted about our own service.
lead_paragraph: Was it worth it?

headline: Two People Injured in Fire at a Queens Hospital
abstract: A rooftop blaze produced an enormous cloud of black smoke, but officials said the flames were extinguished within an hour.
lead_paragraph: Two people suffered minor injuries after a fire erupted on the roof of St. John’s Episcopal Hospital in Queens on Friday, fire officials said.

headline: Daniil Medvedev Easily Advances to U.S. Open Final
abstract: The No. 2 seed booked a spot in his second Open final, beating the 12th-seeded Felix Auger-Aliassime, 6-4, 7-5, 6-2. Medvedev will play either Novak Djokovic or Alexander Zverev.
lead_paragraph: When Daniil Medvedev made his first U.S. Open final two years ago, he did it to a soundtrack of frequent boos, leaning into a villain role he acquired during a contentious third-round match and goading the crowd before ultimately winning it over with his valorous losing effort in the final against Rafael Nadal.

headline: The Taliban Are Telling Us They Haven’t Changed at All
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The West must not mistake tactical flexibility for real change.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the Taliban promised to unveil an “inclusive” government: one that would respect women’s rights, albeit within the confines of Shariah; represent different ethnicities; and bar terrorist groups from Afghanistan.

headline: Federal Research Bolsters the Case for Vaccine Mandates
keywords: ['Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Disease Rates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Scientists believe the administration’s new measures may tamp down the pandemic, although the effects will not immediately be obvious.
lead_paragraph: Just a day after President Biden issued broad mandates aimed at encouraging American workers to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, federal health officials released new data showing that unvaccinated Americans are 11 times as likely as vaccinated people to die of Covid-19.

headline: Video Shows Fire at New York City Hospital
abstract: The blaze erupted on the roof of St. John’s Episcopal Hospital in Queens. Officials said that the flames were extinguished within an hour and that two people suffered minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: The blaze erupted on the roof of St. John’s Episcopal Hospital in Queens. Officials said that the flames were extinguished within an hour and that two people suffered minor injuries.

headline: Biden’s Vaccine Push Aligns Him With a Fed-Up, Vaccinated Majority
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Government Employees', 'States (US)', 'Governors (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As the president took forceful new steps to pressure Americans to get inoculated, he argued that they were urgently needed health measures. In his allies’ view, they were also good politics.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va. — Terry Orie, a 61-year-old real estate agent, has skipped vacations because of the pandemic. She has canceled plans with friends. She has bristled at the frustrations of communicating with clients when everybody is wearing masks.

headline: The Overlooked Costs of Counterterrorism
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Terrorism']
abstract: On policing, jobs and the climate.
lead_paragraph: The consequences of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the decades of war that followed can in some ways be quantified: nearly a million lives lost, 38 million people displaced as a result of conflict, an estimated $8 trillion in expenditures and 85 countries affected to varying degrees by American counterterrorism operations.

headline: Biden Is Right: Vaccine Refusal ‘Has Cost All of Us’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Government Employees', 'United States Economy', 'Disease Rates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Requiring Covid vaccines is necessary to safeguard the country.
lead_paragraph: As Americans contemplate the prospect of a second winter trapped in the grip of Covid-19, remember that it didn’t need to be this way. Vaccines were developed in record time, and have proved to be both incredibly safe and stunningly effective. Nearly two-thirds of eligible Americans have accepted these facts and done their part by getting fully vaccinated.

headline: Biden’s Sweeping Vaccine Mandates Infuriate Republican Governors
keywords: ['Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Governors (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Disease Rates', 'States (US)']
abstract: Some employers and business groups welcomed the new coronavirus requirements, but many G.O.P. leaders issued outright condemnations.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s orders pushing millions of workers to get vaccinated were aimed at turning the tide on a pandemic that has killed 650,000 Americans. But on Friday, the mandates immediately deepened the nation’s political divisions over coronavirus vaccinations and government power.

headline: Measles Cases Bring Temporary Halt to Afghans’ Arrival in U.S.
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Measles']
abstract: The C.D.C. asked that the evacuation flights from overseas bases be suspended after four Afghans were found to be infected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration halted flights carrying Afghan evacuees to the United States from military bases overseas after discovering a few of the new arrivals had measles, the latest hurdle in a haphazard effort to assist allies hoping to flee the Taliban.

headline: 20 Years On, the War on Terror Grinds Along, With No End in Sight
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: The failures in Iraq and Afghanistan obscure what experts say is the striking success of a multilateral effort that extends to as many as 85 countries.

headline: Biden Doubled Mask Fines. What Does It Mean for Air Passengers?
abstract: Battles over mask-wearing in airports and on planes have become common, but how many people actually end up getting fined? And who’s in charge of the process?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, in a wide-ranging speech outlining aggressive steps to curb the spread of the coronavirus, President Biden announced that the Transportation Security Administration would double fines for travelers who refuse to wear masks in airports and on commercial airplanes.

headline: Cause for Alarm?
abstract: Sid Sivakumar makes us think for days in his latest Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The last time we solved a Sid Sivakumar grid in The New York Times, it was a collaboration with Matthew Stock back in May, another challenging fanned-out construction. This kind of geometric pattern, combined with Saturday cluing, means that a solver has four isolated propellers to flail away at; the momentum I built in the southwest quadrant did nothing for me in the northwest, which was by far my weakest spot.

headline: Novak Djokovic Reaches U.S. Open Final, One Victory From a Grand Slam
abstract: Djokovic beat Alexander Zverev, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2, and has a chance to become the first man since 1969 to win a calendar-year Grand Slam. He will play Daniil Medvedev in the final on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven down, one to go.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Buffalo Soldiers Get Statue at West Point
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 11, 2021
lead_paragraph: “When I was coming up we had no role models that we could talk to. We didn’t know we had Buffalo Soldiers. If we had known about that it would have made a difference. Now they have a historical, tangible reference point.”

headline: His Basketball Camp Made Hall of Famers. Now He’s One, Too.
abstract: Howard Garfinkel co-founded the Five Star Basketball Camp, which trained big-name stars like Michael Jordan, Patrick Ewing and Grant Hill.
lead_paragraph: Grant Hill was introduced to the Five Star Basketball Camp in the form of a Sports Illustrated article that was published in 1984, when he was 11 years old. As Hill flipped through the pages of the magazine, he found himself transfixed. To him, Five Star sounded like basketball nirvana, an exclusive destination where promising players could consume the game.

headline: ‘Looking Back, I Am Glad We Played’
abstract: Stuyvesant High, blocks from the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, finished its football season in 2001 under dour circumstances. Was the attempt at normalcy worth it?
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 11, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 11, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about security trading in 2020 by Federal Reserve officials misstated the timing of stock disclosures by Randal K. Quarles and Jerome H. Powell. Mr. Quarles’s disclosure was made in 2020, for 2019 transactions. His transactions were not made last summer. And Mr. Powell’s disclosures of 41 transactions were for 2019, not 2020.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Remembering 9/11
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The weeks and months that followed the attacks were a defining time for many, including on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Always Pay the Rent? It May Help Your Mortgage Application.
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Credit Scores', 'Content Type: Service', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: For decades, regular payments to a landlord haven’t counted for much for many tenants trying to get a mortgage. Fannie Mae aims to change that.
lead_paragraph: Later this month, a group of renters in the United States will get a new break when they try to become homeowners: Their history of consistently paying their landlords will count toward qualifying for a mortgage.

headline: In Shanksville, Preserving the Memory of 9/11 and the Wars That Followed
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

headline: Meeting Hungary’s Strongman, Pope Treads a Fine Line With an Embattled Leader
abstract: Pope Francis’ meeting with Viktor Orban could help, or hurt, the prime minister’s efforts to curry favor with voters ahead of coming elections in Hungary, which is predominantly Catholic.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary portrays himself as the defender of Christian Europe against migrants and multiculturalism. After years of his weakening of democratic institutions, the far-right strongman has prepared for coming elections in Catholic-majority Hungary by strengthening his links to Catholic traditionalists in Europe and the United States.

headline: How 9/11 Changed a 13-Year-Old Girl in Harlem
abstract: As a middle school student on Sept. 11, 2001, I didn’t realize how much the terror attacks would affect me and my family.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.

headline: Newsom’s Strategy for California Recall: It’s Me or the Abyss
abstract: Ahead of the vote on Tuesday, the governor is running not so much on his own policies as against the influence of a certain former president.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — As the campaign to oust him heads into its final weekend, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California is hammering home the choice he has presented to voters since the start of the recall — Donald J. Trump or him.

headline: To Survive the Pandemic, a Secret Nintendo Cafe Is Secret No Longer
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Toru Hashimoto’s Tokyo spot is a showcase for items he kept while working for the video game company. It used to be a members-only hideaway, but financial strain has forced him to open up.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toru Hashimoto ran a cafe he hoped almost nobody could find.

headline: Mountain of Money Fuels Gavin Newsom’s Surge to Recall Finish Line
abstract: The California governor has taken full advantage of the state’s loose financing rules for recall elections, overpowering Republican challengers for whom the cavalry never arrived.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s bid to fend off a recall in California has been bolstered by an infusion of tens of millions of dollars from big donors in recent months that delivered him an enormous financial advantage over his Republican rivals in the race’s final stretch.

headline: Berlin Clubs Return With a Vengeance
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Dancing', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: A discothèque successfully sued the city over its ban on indoor dancing, and clubs have reopened. But if there’s a spike in coronavirus cases, the local government has explored a backup plan.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The beats were pumping inside Salon zur wilden Renate long after the sun had risen. Hundreds of euphoric, maskless revelers crammed onto the dance floor, the only social distancing created in temporary pockets by the rhythmic moving of the crowd.

headline: How Math Solved the Case of the Volcanic Bombs That Didn’t Explode
abstract: Scientists have long been puzzled by flying blobs of magma that remained intact, but didn’t have a good way to study them.
lead_paragraph: It would be reasonable to hear the term “volcanic bomb” and presuppose that such an object tends to explode. But a specific type of volcanic bomb rarely lives up to the second half of its name: These objects get blasted into the air, crash into the ground and disappointingly fail to detonate.

headline: ‘Everything Changed Overnight’: Afghan Reporters Face an Intolerant Regime
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Censorship', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Taliban promised to respect press freedoms, but the new government has already showed signs of repression, and has even physically assaulted Afghan journalists.
lead_paragraph: Beloved shows removed from the airwaves. A television station cutting from a news report a story about a pregnant police officer who was reportedly fatally shot by the Taliban. A radio editor telling his colleagues to edit out anti-Taliban cheers from coverage of demonstrations in the capital.

headline: Vaccine Resisters Seek Religious Exemptions. But What Counts as Religious?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Government Employees', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Major denominations are essentially unanimous in their support of the vaccines against Covid-19, but individuals who object are citing their personal faith for support.
lead_paragraph: When Crisann Holmes’s employer announced last month that it would require all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19 by Nov. 1, she knew she had to find a way out.

headline: Trump May Be Gone, But the Fight Against His Border Wall Goes On
keywords: ['Border Barriers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Eminent Domain', 'Land Use Policies', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Residents in Los Ebanos, Texas, on the Rio Grande thought Joe Biden’s victory would end their fears of losing their property for a wall. It hasn’t worked out that way.
lead_paragraph: LOS EBANOS, Texas — The men showed up unannounced, but it didn’t take long for Aleida Flores Garcia to figure out why they were measuring portions of her backyard. “We are here to mark where a border wall would go,” they told her last summer as they surveyed the ranch her family has owned for five generations.

headline: The Photographs of 9/11
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Photography', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Photographers reflect on shooting the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and their aftermath.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, The New York Times won the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography for its coverage of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath. Two decades later, we asked our photographers to return to their work from that time and reflect on the images they created, and what it took to capture them. Their answers have been edited for length and clarity.

headline: ‘It’s a Godsend’: 9-Cent Taxi Rides in Rural South Korea
abstract: One county’s plan to help older, carless citizens stuck in remote villages proved wildly popular and has been copied across South Korea, revolutionizing public transportation in the countryside.
lead_paragraph: SEOCHEON, South Korea — On a recent overcast morning, a village on South Korea’s west coast showed no sign of human stirring until five older residents slowly emerged through the fog that shrouded lush, green rice paddies.

headline: Special Episode: What Does It Mean to ‘Never Forget’?
abstract: Twenty years after Sept. 11, a look at what we hold on to and what we choose to let go.
lead_paragraph: Two planes hijacked by Al Qaeda pierced the north and south towers of the World Trade Center. A third slammed into the Pentagon in Arlington, Va. A fourth crashed in an open field outside Shanksville, Pa. All in less than 90 minutes.

headline: History on the Line at the U.S. Open Finals 🎾
abstract: There’s an unexpected all-teenage women’s final, and the men’s top seeds meet with a Grand Slam on the line.

headline: Quandary at U.N.: Who Speaks for Myanmar and Afghanistan?
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'International Relations', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s brutal military coup and the Taliban’s triumphal return to power in Afghanistan are among the crises confronting the United Nations as it convenes its annual General Assembly this coming week.

headline: For a Fractured Israel, a Film Offers Ominous Lessons From Ancient Past
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Movies', 'Jews and Judaism', 'War and Armed Conflicts']
abstract: An animated epic depicting a Jewish civil war and the destruction of the Second Temple 2,000 years ago is being seen as a warning in a deeply divided country.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A gripping political thriller swept across cinema screens in Israel this summer, with the movie prompting impassioned debate and striking a particularly resonant chord with Israel’s precarious new government.

headline: Unearthed at a British Golf Course: A Log Coffin From the Bronze Age
abstract: Workers digging in a pond at the Tetney Golf Club discovered a waterlogged coffin containing the remains of a man who archaeologists said was buried about 4,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In July 2018, Hugh Willmott was overseeing the excavation of an Anglo-Saxon burial site in northeast England when a regional preservation official told him about a potentially more exciting find.

headline: The pandemic is a key issue in the recall, and that bodes well for Newsom.
abstract: A new poll found that most likely voters disagreed with the idea that the governor overstepped his authority in his response to the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months ago, when it seemed as though the worst of the coronavirus pandemic was behind us, Republican supporters of the recall felt vindicated and optimistic. The fact that so many people were out and about would only embolden the argument that Gov. Gavin Newsom had been too tough in his lockdown orders last year.

headline: At 9/11 museum, site of today’s memorial, controversies past and present.
abstract: At the official memorial site, rough spots over a board trustee, a recent documentary, and canceled exhibits.
lead_paragraph: The 9/11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan, the host of this morning’s ceremony, is no stranger to controversy, whether before its 2014 opening or in recent days.

headline: Nickolas Davatzes, Force Behind A&E and the History Channel, Dies at 79
abstract: He led the cable giant, whose eclectic mix of shows would include collaborations with the BBC and documentary-style series like “Hoarders.”
lead_paragraph: Nickolas Davatzes, who was instrumental in creating the cable television networks A&E and the History Channel, which now reach into 335 million households around the world, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 79.

headline: How Can I Figure Out What Repairs a Building Might Need in the Future?
abstract: You can, and should, find out what problems the board knows about before you agree to buy an apartment. But you can’t foresee everything.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m considering buying a new place, and I want to know how a prospective buyer of a co-op or condo in New York can find out what repairs the building might need in the next four or five years. I’d hate to be hit with a huge assessment for repairs shortly after I move in, and I certainly don’t want to unknowingly move into a building with structural problems.

headline: The C.D.C. reports that unvaccinated Americans are 11 times more likely to die if infected: The week in Covid news.
abstract: Unvaccinated Americans were 4.5 times more likely than vaccinated individuals to become infected with the coronavirus, and they were 10 times more likely to be hospitalized and 11 times more likely to die from it, according to one among a handful of studies highlighting the effectiveness of the shots.
lead_paragraph: Unvaccinated Americans were 4.5 times more likely than vaccinated individuals to become infected with the coronavirus, and they were 10 times more likely to be hospitalized and 11 times more likely to die from it, according to one among a handful of studies highlighting the effectiveness of the shots.

headline: A Nick to Apple’s Profits Could Be a Windfall for App Developers
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'iPhone', 'Decisions and Verdicts']

lead_paragraph: Apple has taken to calling its iPhone App Store an “economic miracle,” and it has pointed to developers like Zach Shakked as proof.

headline: Tributes to Sept. 11 victims, survivors, and families from around the world
abstract: As the United States marks the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, memorials have been held around the world, and tributes have been paid by global leaders.
lead_paragraph: As the United States marks the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, memorials have been held around the world, and tributes have been paid by global leaders, in memory of the victims, survivors and families affected.

headline: Manning Up, Letting Us Down
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Overdosing on macho after 9/11 led America astray.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I’m not one of those people who think women make naturally better leaders than men, more collegial and collaborative. I’ve covered enough women in the upper ranks, and worked for and with enough women, to know that it depends on the individual.

headline: Venus Williams: The Thing That Has Really Made Me Tough
abstract: I used to think that winning depended on my physical health. Then my mother taught me that that was only the half of it.
lead_paragraph: I’m sitting at my desk after having to pull out of this year’s U.S. Open with a leg injury. Managing physical ailments is always difficult, but it’s part of a professional athlete’s job. I have always understood this.

headline: The Unnecessary Cruelty of America’s Immigration System
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We can protect human rights, lower  costs and ensure that people show up to immigration proceedings, without detaining thousands.
lead_paragraph: One day in the spring of 2019, a young Honduran man in a detention center in Ferriday, La., began to feel strange. He’d recently heard from his lawyers that his request to be released on humanitarian parole while his asylum case was pending had been denied. As he swayed on his feet, his skin breaking out into hives, he suspected that the stress of facing more time in a prison cell had brought on a panic attack.

headline: The Sacklers Are Walking Off Into the Sunset. Reform the System.
keywords: ['Opioids and Opiates', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Bankruptcies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Purdue Pharma bankruptcy case settlement protected the wealthy and ignored those who suffered.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 26, 2019, the Department of Justice appointed me to serve on the Official Unsecured Creditors Committee in the bankruptcy case against Purdue Pharma, the company that helped fuel the opioid overdose crisis through the misbranding and reckless marketing of the powerful painkiller OxyContin. The committee acted as a mega-plaintiff, with broad powers to subpoena records, take depositions and cross-examine witnesses. For nearly two years, I attended countless negotiations, depositions and chambers meetings. I read thousands of pages of confidential documents revealing the true nature and depth of Purdue’s liability in the crisis.

headline: At 9/11 Ceremonies, Moments of Silence, Tributes and Tears
abstract: Twenty years after the worst attack on American soil, the loss of nearly 3,000 people was remembered in events across the country.
lead_paragraph: The loved ones gathered again in Lower Manhattan for moments of silence and the peals of the bells. They paid tribute to those they lost 20 years earlier and listened as Bruce Springsteen sang about memory and loss.

headline: Violent extremists at home and abroad ‘are children of the same foul spirit,’ George W. Bush says in Pennsylvania.
abstract: Former President George W. Bush commemorated the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Saturday by speaking at the Flight 93 National Memorial near Shanksville, Pa.
lead_paragraph: Former President George W. Bush commemorated the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Saturday at the Flight 93 National Memorial in Pennsylvania, recalling a time of American unity and drawing a sharp contrast with the present-day divisiveness of the country’s politics.

headline: What Can Sports Teach Us?
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'College Athletics', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Sports matter, even if you don’t identify as a fan.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, and welcome to the first issue of my newsletter (you are reading the web version), a place where I hope to discuss the obsessions, ideas and thought processes that have shaped and guided my career.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Day 4
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Dyes and Dyestuffs', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Tie-dye never dies.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. Every day we’ll spotlight one thing we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.

headline: In Chicago, people climb steps to remember emergency workers lost on 9/11.
abstract: More than 500 people, many of them firefighters in full uniforms, climbed 2,200 steps at Chicago’s Soldier Field on Saturday to remember the victims of Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: More than 500 people, many of them firefighters in full uniforms, climbed 2,200 steps at Chicago’s Soldier Field on Saturday to remember the victims of Sept. 11.

headline: As Democrats Push a $3.5 Trillion Bill, a Top Lawmaker Stays Mum on Tax Increases
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The silence from Representative Richard Neal of Massachusetts has some liberal Democrats worried that he could thwart the scope of their economic ambitions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Republicans sought to pass a giant tax cut along party lines in 2017, Representative Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, led his party’s effort to brand the legislation as a tax break for the rich, helping erode public support for the bill.

headline: Abimael Guzmán, Leader of Guerrilla Group That Terrorized Peru, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Guzmán’s Maoist movement, Shining Path, killed tens of thousands in the 1980s and ’90s. He sought to bring the world to a “higher stage of Marxism.”
lead_paragraph: Abimael Guzmán, the founder and leader of the Shining Path guerrilla movement, which spread terror across much of Peru in the 1980s and ’90s, died on Saturday in Peru. He was 86.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are sturdy features in the landscape.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Once again, Team Cox-Rathvon presents a passage that speaks to me personally: I have a scar on my right leg from one of the evil, evil plants that we read about today, and the author of the passage doesn’t sound too fond of them, either. That author is Mary Hunter Austin, a naturalist who wandered alone through the Southwest in the 19th century, encountering all manner of desert fauna and flora (in heavy skirts, and hopefully unscathed). The passage comes from a book called “The Land of Little Rain,” published in 1903; Austin meets with adversity but also expresses admiration for yuccas, coyotes, cactuses and everything that scratches out a life in such harsh environs.

headline: Parents of Young Children Desperately Seek Vaccine Trials
abstract: Schools have reopened around the country, and families with those under 12 are finding ways to get their kids inoculated, even though they’re not officially eligible yet.
lead_paragraph: Leng Vong Reiff had just received her second dose of a Covid vaccine and thought guiltily of her two young, unvaccinated sons. So she began banging away at her keyboard.

abstract: At least 21 percent of nursing home residents are on antipsychotic drugs, a Times investigation found.

headline: Kamala Harris: 9/11 shows how ‘fear can be used to sow division.’
abstract: Speaking at a memorial service for the victims of Flight 93, the vice president emphasized the importance of unity and said the nation’s greatest strength was its diversity.
lead_paragraph: At a memorial for the passengers who fought back against terrorists aboard United Airlines Flight 93, Vice President Kamala Harris warned that the tragedy of the Sept. 11 attacks had shown how “fear can be used to sow division,” and stressed that America’s diversity was its greatest asset.

headline: On the Scene: 9/11 at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: At Guantánamo Bay, the memory of Sept. 11 is never far away. And not just because the men who are accused of plotting the terrorist attacks are held prisoner here.
lead_paragraph: At Guantánamo Bay, the memory of Sept. 11 is never far away. And not just because the men who are accused of plotting the terrorist attacks are held prisoner here.

headline: At Selfridges, Weddings Are on the Fourth Floor
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Department stores are broadening their offerings to survive online sales. A London landmark will host your wedding.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Carlene Noel and Danny Sains exchanged vows on Saturday they weren’t just merging their two families into one, they were also marking an unusual expansion of the offerings of a British department store. The new Mr. and Ms. Sains got married on the fourth floor of the stately flagship of Selfridges, on London’s Oxford Street.

headline: Teresa Zylis-Gara, Plush-Voiced Polish Soprano, Is Dead at 91
abstract: She took on a wide range of roles in her long international career, which included a stretch as a stalwart of the Metropolitan Opera in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Teresa Zylis-Gara, a Polish soprano who displayed a plush voice, impressive versatility and beguiling stage presence during a three-decade international career that included a stretch at the Metropolitan Opera during her prime in the 1970s, died on Aug. 28 in Lodz, Poland. She was 91.

headline: What Comes After the 9/11 Era?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: The battle to define the next American grand strategy.
lead_paragraph: When I moved to Washington, D.C., in 2002 we all lived in 9/11’s shadow. We waited for bombs in the Metro, for more anthrax envelopes, for a sequel to the previous autumn’s terror. We watched planes headed for Reagan Airport fly low over the Potomac, always half-expecting them to veer.

headline: Painful memory for Muslims: Outrage over a proposed Islamic center in Manhattan.
abstract: The downtown project was scuttled amid anti-Muslim sentiment. The head of the Anti-Defamation League recently apologized for opposing the plan.
lead_paragraph: To the two men who envisioned it, an Egyptian-American real estate developer and an imam long involved in interfaith initiatives, Park51 was a simple but necessary project: a Muslim community center, modeled on the Jewish Community Center on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, with spaces for worship, athletics and cultural programs, open to the public.

headline: Teen Participant in ‘Slender Man’ Stabbing to Be Released From Mental Hospital
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Anissa Weier, 19, requested her release in a letter this March. “If I am to become a productive member of society, I need to be a part of society,” she wrote.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old woman who participated in the nearly fatal stabbing of a friend, a crime she said was carried out to gain the favor of a sinister fictional character called Slender Man, will be released from a psychiatric hospital on Monday, a Wisconsin judge ruled on Friday.

headline: An astronaut marks the 20th anniversary of 9/11 from space.

lead_paragraph: An astronaut paid tribute from space on the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.

headline: In Shanksville, Biden says the future of democracy is on the line.
abstract: The president honored the passengers and crew members who confronted terrorists on 9/11 and addressed an existential battle underway in America.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after former President George W. Bush spoke at the Flight 93 memorial in Shanksville, Pa., on Saturday, President Biden arrived to observe a wreath-laying ceremony at the place where, 20 years ago, a plane crashed after brave passengers and crew members confronted the terrorists who had hijacked it.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo Is Back and So Is Manchester United
abstract: A star returns with two goals in a resounding victory, restoring a sense of confidence to a club accustomed to sure things.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — And just like that, everything was exactly as it used to be, as if nothing had ever changed, as if he had never been away. Cristiano Ronaldo had scored, again. Manchester United was winning, again. The fans were exulting, again. He was home, at last, and so were they.

headline: The U.S. is falling to the lowest vaccination rates of the world’s wealthiest democracies.
abstract: The United States has the lowest rate of partial vaccination among the Group of 7 nations, and is all but certain to rank last in full vaccination shortly, as Japan rapidly increases its pace while the U.S.’s slows.
lead_paragraph: Japan initially struggled to get its Covid-19 vaccination program into full gear, but now that it has, the percentage of its population that has received at least one dose has edged past the level achieved in the United States — leaving Americans last for that category among the world’s seven wealthiest large democracies.

headline: At Army Football Game, Sept. 11 Anniversary Lends Tone of Solemnity
abstract: The context of the moment — with respect to 20 years ago and recent events in Afghanistan — was not lost on players, alumni and recruits.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — At 8:46 on Saturday morning, the unmistakable aroma of grilled sausages and just-cracked-open beer wafted through parking lot E above Michie Stadium, the quaint football field nestled on the banks of the Hudson River.

headline: Gilbert Seltzer, Soldier in the World War II ‘Ghost Army,’ Dies at 106
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: He was one of the last survivors of a band of Army con artists who duped German forces with their arsenal of fakery, including inflatable tanks and scripted radio transmissions.
lead_paragraph: Gilbert Seltzer, who served with a secret Army unit in World War II that fooled German forces with inflatable tanks, dummy airplanes, fake radio transmissions and sound effects that mimicked troop movements, died on Aug. 14 at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 106.

headline: Hochul, in first 9/11 as governor, emphasizes the human cost of the attacks.

lead_paragraph: During her first commemoration of the Sept. 11 attacks as governor, Kathy Hochul spent time with the families of victims at the 9/11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan, attended a Fire Department Mass and paid tribute to the New York National Guard.

headline: Biden and Bush Urge Unity as Nation Remembers Sept. 11
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Pentagon Building', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Both President Biden and former President George W. Bush acknowledged that what has happened in the years since has only challenged the notion that Americans found strength in coming together.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As they traveled the country laying wreaths, strolling through crash sites in pastoral meadows and comforting families whose wounds are ripped open anew each year, two living presidents used the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks to urge Americans to come together in an effort to weather deep political and cultural divisions.

headline: Windows on the World employees are remembered amid calls for better pay for service workers.

headline: Denmark lifts the last of its coronavirus restrictions.

lead_paragraph: Denmark has lifted the last of its coronavirus restrictions, effectively declaring that the virus was no longer a “critical threat to society” and allowing the country to get back to a semblance of prepandemic normal.

headline: Raducanu wins a stirring first set, 6-4.
abstract: The 18-year-old from Britain was one set away from becoming the first qualifier to win a grand slam singles title.

headline: What a Character!
abstract: Alex Rosen’s puzzle has that look.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There’s a great deal of personality in this first Sunday grid from Alex Rosen, who has constructed two daily puzzles so far for The Times, on a Tuesday and a Wednesday. Sunday’s fairly leaps off the page, and there’s even a little choreography. Mr. Rosen is a software engineer living in London; according to the puzzle’s print introduction, his focus is helping computer users avoid email-related security mistakes like clicking on a bad link or accidentally sending an email to the wrong person.

headline: Emma Raducanu wins the U.S. Open to complete a miraculous run.
abstract: Raducanu, ranked 150th in the world and barely known two weeks ago, became the first player to win a Grand Slam title after surviving the qualifying tournament.
lead_paragraph: Emma Raducanu, the 18-year-old British phenom, completed a shocking run through the U.S. Open with a straight-sets victory over Leylah Fernandez of Canada on Saturday for a title that will surely go down as one of the great underdog journeys in the history of sports.

headline: Going Back Twenty Years to Look Forward

headline: On a Difficult Day for New York, Leylah Fernandez Moves a Tennis Crowd
abstract: After losing the women’s final at the U.S. Open on the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Fernandez said, “I hope I can be as strong and resilient as New York has been the last 20 years.”
lead_paragraph: Leylah Fernandez stood on the podium, fighting back tears. She had finished an eloquent runner-up speech, looking as if all she wanted was to disappear underneath the stands of Arthur Ashe Stadium and get a hug from her family. But she prolonged her anguish for a few more minutes.

headline: F.B.I. Releases Newly Declassified Document Related to Sept. 11 Attacks
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Families of the Sept. 11 victims have long pushed for a deeper investigation into any possible role the Saudi government had in the attacks, but the document offered no conclusive evidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. released a newly declassified document late Saturday describing connections that the agency examined between the hijackers and the Saudi government in the years since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, although it contained no conclusive evidence about whether the kingdom played a role in the attacks.

abstract: To capture the first Grand Slam in men’s tennis in 52 years, Djokovic must beat Daniil Medvedev in the U.S. Open final. “Mentally, he’s the best player to ever play the game,” Djokovic’s semifinal opponent said.

headline: Trump Talked as Holyfield Got Pummeled. Just Another Day in Boxing’s Absurd Summer.
abstract: Of course it was a circus — the kind that makes sense in boxing these days.
lead_paragraph: In a single zany sentence, this is how the once-promising summer of boxing ended: Triller, a social video app that is a much less popular version of TikTok, put on a pay-per-view fight between a 58-year-old Evander Holyfield (who hasn’t fought in a decade) and a 44-year-old mixed martial artist, Vitor Belfort — and paid former President Donald J. Trump and Donald Trump Jr. to serve as live commentators, all on the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: If the Police Lie, Should They Be Held Liable? Often the Answer Is No.

abstract: Federal agents and police officers who work with them are often immune from lawsuits, even for serious rights violations. The Supreme Court is being asked to re-evaluate that.

Thirty people, almost all of them Somali refugees, were charged and sent to jail, many of them for years.

keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Politics and Government', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']

headline: Behind the Texas Abortion Law, a Persevering Conservative Lawyer
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Legal Profession', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Jonathan Mitchell has never had a high profile in the anti-abortion movement, but he developed and promoted the legal approach that has flummoxed the courts and enraged abortion rights supporters.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan F. Mitchell grew increasingly dismayed as he read the Supreme Court’s decision in June 2016 striking down major portions of a Texas anti-abortion bill he had helped write.

headline: After the 9/11 Attacks, Boston Found a Focus for Its Anger
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Airport Security', 'Airports', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Terrorists boarded two planes in Boston and flew them into the World Trade Center. Massachusetts zeroed in on its top airport official, who has never quite recovered.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Virginia Buckingham remembers the moment when she realized that she had been singled out. She had stopped at Dunkin’ Donuts on her way into Logan International Airport, which she oversaw as the top official at the Massachusetts Port Authority. As she stood in line, a man behind her whispered to his friend, “That’s her.”

headline: ‘Black Capitalism’ Promised a Better City for Everyone. What Happened?
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Corporations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In the wake of nationwide protests, corporate America has pledged to fight racism and support Black Americans. But a similar initiative started decades ago in Rochester shows it is a promise that is difficult to sustain.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — The Panther Graphics printing plant sits along a row of red brick buildings and empty parking lots on the edge of a circular highway that separates this city’s downtown from a largely Black neighborhood to the north. Nearby, there is a warehouse, a Baptist Church and a billboard that warns “A Shot from A Gun Can’t Be Undone,” a reference to Rochester’s soaring murder rate.

headline: Germany’s Election Was His to Lose, and He Might Just Do That
abstract: Armin Laschet, Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union party’s candidate for chancellor, is flagging in the polls, and he seems to be dragging the party down with him.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT AN DER ODER, Germany — His party is the biggest in Germany. It has won all but three elections since 1950, including the past four. Its departing chancellor is more popular than any politician in the country. And German voters crave stability and continuity.

headline: When Sadness Is Transformative and Grief Gets Complicated
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Azareen Van der Vliet Oloomi talks about her new novel, “Savage Tongues,” in which two friends help each other deal with personal and political traumas.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “Savage Tongues,” Azareen Van der Vliet Oloomi’s third novel, the Iranian American narrator, Arezu, is arriving in Marbella, Spain. It’s her first time back in 20 years, since she was 17 and met Omar, her stepmother’s nephew, who was then 40. He would become “my lover, my torturer, my confidant and enemy,” she tells us.

headline: The Nuns of Fiction: Experts in Affliction and Awe
abstract: From Chaucer to Don DeLillo and Lauren Groff, nuns in literature have served a variety of functions — not least, Claire Luchette writes, as the authors’ stays against mortal agony.
lead_paragraph: A group of crows is a murder; pandas, an embarrassment; nuns, a superfluity — a term that dates to the Middle Ages, when nunneries were overcrowded, lice-ridden and destitute. Today, there’s no such thing as too many nuns, as few women are taking vows. But the nuns who are among us remain ecclesiastical workhorses. Ordained men can stand in persona Christi, allowing them, for example, the superpower of transubstantiation. But if priests stand at the front of the church as middlemen between God and the faithful, nuns are at the front lines of suffering: They bring God to the meek, poor, sick, imprisoned — those, in other words, whom society has deemed superfluous and disposable.

headline: Liane Moriarty’s New Novel Is a Family Saga and a Mystery
abstract: In “Apples Never Fall,” the author of “Nine Perfect Strangers” and “Big Little Lies” serves readers the tale of a missing mother and tennis pro.
lead_paragraph: APPLES NEVER FALLBy Liane Moriarty

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.

abstract: After a decades-long standoff with the last resident of a communal apartment, a private museum has finally opened in Brodsky’s shared home in St. Petersburg, a rare grass-roots victory in Russia.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Until he fled the Soviet Union in 1972, the Russian poet Joseph Brodsky lived in a drab communal apartment in St. Petersburg, sharing a bathroom and kitchen with three other families.

headline: The Week in Business: A Strong Push to Vaccinate
abstract: The government is going to require businesses with more than 100 employees to require vaccinations or weekly Covid tests.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration released a blueprint for how solar energy, which contributed less than 4 percent of the country’s electricity last year, could move toward producing almost half of the country’s electricity by 2050. This is in line with what most climate scientists say is necessary to prevent the worst effects of global warming, but it would require vast upgrades to the electric grid. Though the cost of solar panels has fallen steeply over the last decade, the plan would require trillions of dollars in investments by homeowners, businesses and the government to remake an energy infrastructure built for coal, natural gas and nuclear power plants.

headline: Nino Castelnuovo, ‘The Umbrellas of Cherbourg’ Star, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Castelnuovo, who brought an incandescent charm to the screen, became famous during a golden age of Italian cinema. But his breakthrough role was in a French film.
lead_paragraph: Nino Castelnuovo, a popular Italian film and television actor who found success beyond his home country when he starred alongside Catherine Deneuve in the soaringly sentimental French New Wave musical “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg,” died on Sept. 6 in Rome. He was 84.

headline: In Orban’s Hungary, Pope Urges Bishops to Embrace Diversity
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: On a quick trip to the country, Francis met with Prime Minister Viktor Orban, Hungary’s hard-right leader, before celebrating a public Mass.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Pope Francis used his short time in Budapest on Sunday to urge his bishops to embrace diversity and send a message to the country’s hard-right, anti-migrant leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban, that God is not a strongman who silences enemies and that religious roots, while vital for a country, also allow it to open up and extend “its arms toward everyone.”

headline: The Question Michael K. Williams Asked Me Before Every Season of ‘The Wire’
abstract: As Omar Little, the actor bent his beautiful mind to a task that even the best writers and showrunners often avoid.
lead_paragraph: The second season of our fledgling HBO drama in Baltimore did not shoot its first frame of film before one key cast member was in the writers’ offices, scripts in hand, showing his disappointment.

headline: Even Texas Allows Abortions to Protect a Woman’s Life. Or Does It?
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Abortion', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Doctors']
abstract: History shows us that what counts as a threat to a womans life isn't always clear-cut.
lead_paragraph: Join us, if you will, in a thought experiment. It’s the fall of 2022. Dr. H., an obstetrician-gynecologist, practices in a red state. Much has changed in the reproductive rights landscape by then: In the spring, her state rushed to pass a law similar to the notorious 2021 Texas law that bans a large majority of abortions and incentivizes private citizens to sue anyone helping someone get an abortion. The Supreme Court also overturned Roe v. Wade in the Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization case that year, leaving the issue of abortion regulation to individual states; a few years before, Dr. H.’s state passed a trigger ban that automatically banned the few abortions that were still legal in the state when Roe fell. In her state, the law now allows an abortion only when a pregnancy threatens the life of a pregnant person.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In a last-minute deal before Iran was likely to be censured for violating its agreements with the International Atomic Energy Agency, the new government in Tehran agreed on Sunday to let the organization reset monitoring devices that help measure the progress of the country’s nuclear program.

headline: Hear That? It’s Your Voice Being Taken for Profit.
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Advertising and Marketing']
abstract: 'When she recognizes you’re frustrated with her, Alexa can now try to adjust, just like you or I would do.'
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever dialed an 800 number to ask or complain about something you bought or to make an inquiry about something you’re thinking of buying, there is a decent chance you were profiled — by the arrangement of your words and the tone of your voice — without knowing it. My research suggests many customer contact centers now approach and manage callers based on what they think the person’s voice or syntax reveal about the individual’s emotions, sentiments and personality, often in real time.

headline: A Rabbi’s Guide on Making Amends and Letting Those Grudges Go
abstract: A rabbi’s advice for those who have done wrong and those who can’t forgive.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine was publicly canceled. He deserved it and he knew it. He spent a year working with a rabbi and a therapist, during which time he tried to track down those he had hurt and apologize to them, often more than once. We can’t see inside one another’s hearts, but I believe in the sincerity of his change.

headline: Health Care in Afghanistan Is Crumbling, Aid Groups Warn

lead_paragraph: The health care system in Afghanistan is teetering on the edge of collapse, endangering the lives of millions and compounding a deepening humanitarian crisis, public health experts warn.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Get inspired by our newest recipes, including tortilla pizzas and blackened fish with quick grits.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I like the looks of Melissa Clark’s new recipe for roasted lemony fish with crispy caper brown butter and nori (above) and might make it tonight if I can find good fish at the market. But I’ll tell you this about these mid-September days of high pressure and low humidity, bluebird skies where I stay and a kind of promise in the atmosphere that everything’s copacetic: They make me want to cook up some projects, too.

Declaring the move “terrifying,” he wrote on Twitter: “This is still America, and we still believe in freedom from tyrants.”

The Mets began August in first place and ended it in third place, out of the playoff picture and apologetic that some of their stars had been flashing thumbs-down gestures to their own fans.

headline: A Deep Dive Into Matisse’s ‘The Red Studio’
abstract: In a coming exhibition, MoMA will feature the artworks within this famed painting. Two of them will be on public view for the first time in 50 years.
lead_paragraph: When Henri Matisse painted “The Red Studio” in the Paris suburb of Issy-les-Moulineaux in 1911, he not only let the viewer into his work space, with its box of crayons, ceramic plate and grandfather clock. He also captured tiny versions of his own paintings propped against the walls, and his sculptures perched on stools.

headline: Israel threatens to charge scores who returned from a Ukraine pilgrimage using faked coronavirus test results.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — More than 150 Israelis suspected of using fake negative coronavirus test results to board flights home after a pilgrimage to Uman, Ukraine, have been summoned for questioning by the Israeli police in accordance with a strict, new government directive.

lead_paragraph: Having lashed Texas with powerful wind gusts and heavy rain as a tropical storm, Nicholas weakened to a tropical depression on Tuesday night after sweeping across the Houston metropolitan area on a path toward Louisiana, battered just over two weeks ago by Hurricane Ida.

headline: Why I Write
abstract: A paper’s columnists should be like an orchestra, each playing a different instrument. I decided that  I was going to play the banjo.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite aunts was desperately poor, like many people I knew in rural north Louisiana. I don’t know how much money she had or made. I only know the shadow of need that stalked her. She seemed, like many members of my family, one paycheck or severe injury away from insolvency.

headline: Venice: Women’s Stories
abstract: Films by or about women stood out at this year’s Venice International Film Festival, though they represented only a fraction of the titles showcased.
lead_paragraph: There is a moment that happens every time I am lucky enough to attend the Venice International Film Festival, just before it all begins, when overloaded screening schedules still seem perfectly doable, and deadlines are distant and abstract, almost pretty, like far-off flocks of birds. Freewheeling down the Lido (the barrier island in the Venetian lagoon where the festival takes place) on a newly rented bike, the weather reliably gorgeous, the breeze warm and the tiniest bit savory with centuries of sea-salted history, I think I am more predictably, straightforwardly happy than on any other day of the year.

headline: With a Win in Portland, Alex Palou Reclaims His IndyCar Lead
abstract: Palou overcame a pileup during the first turn that cost him his pole position advantage, and he worked his way up the field to win the Grand Prix of Portland.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Despite a multicar pileup on the opening lap that sent the pole winner Alex Palou to the back of the pack, Palou managed to cleverly work his way back into the IndyCar championship lead and place first on Sunday at the Grand Prix of Portland.

headline: Why Our Monsters Talk to Michael Wolff
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: In his new book, the author of “Fire and Fury” continues his specialty: teasing out stories from men in power.
lead_paragraph: It’s early 2019, a few months before Jeffrey Epstein will be arrested on sex charges, and he is sitting in the vast study of his New York mansion with a camera pointed at him as he practices for a big “60 Minutes” interview that would never take place.

headline: With Crowds Back at the U.S. Open, Young Stars Give Them a Show
abstract: Novak Djokovic failed to win a Grand Slam, but there was a sense of renewal, exciting new players named Raducanu and Fernandez, and a sense that tennis is in capable hands.
lead_paragraph: To fully appreciate the unmasked roars of 2021 at the U.S. Open, it was best to have experienced the silence and vast empty spaces of 2020.

headline: Saquon Barkley (and Fans) Returned. But So Did Last Season’s Giants.
abstract: Despite the return of the Pro Bowl running back, a ballyhooed defense and a readmitted home crowd, the Giants looked listless in a loss to the Denver Broncos.
lead_paragraph: Running back Saquon Barkley dodged and bulled his way to a 5-yard gain on the first play from scrimmage in Sunday’s game between the Giants and Denver Broncos. Barkley, the cynosure of the Giants’ offense until a torn knee ligament kept him out of 14 games last season, seemed whole again, and the home fans at a packed MetLife Stadium leapt to their feet in response.

headline: Afghan Pilots Who Sought Safety in Uzbekistan Transfer to U.S. Base
abstract: Taliban leaders have been pressuring the Uzbek government to turn over the pilots, who fear for the safety of themselves and their families.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An initial group of Afghan pilots who flew themselves and their family members to safety in Uzbekistan aboard Afghan Air Force aircraft were transferred to a U.S. military base in the United Arab Emirates on Sunday, according to the office of Representative August Pfluger, which has been in contact with one of the pilots and his wife.

headline: On a Rerouted Road Trip, Aaron Rodgers Looked Disoriented
abstract: The Packers quarterback was intercepted twice in a lackluster showing, while the Saints’ Jameis Winston threw five touchdown passes to take down the Packers.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Saints’ home game that was scheduled to be held Sunday amid climate-controlled pandemonium in New Orleans was instead staged in dryer-vent conditions in north Florida before hordes of fans wearing foam blocks of cheese on their heads — and yet somehow all that seemed downright normal compared to what was transpiring on the field.

headline: House Democrats Outline Tax Increases for Wealthy Businesses and Individuals

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior House Democrats are coalescing around a draft proposal that could raise as much as $2.9 trillion to pay for most of President Biden’s sweeping expansion of the social safety net by increasing taxes on the wealthiest corporations and individuals.

abstract: Axe continues to let his emotions lead his decisions. And now the consequences are teaming up to take him down.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea said on Monday it​ had successfully launched newly developed long-range cruise missiles, its first missile test in six months and a new indication that an arms race between North and South Korea was heating up on the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Lagging vaccinations in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: As of Thursday, the U.S. ranks last among the Group of 7 nations for the percentage of its population that has received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, just behind Japan. Some 62.16 percent of Japanese people were at least partly vaccinated, compared to 61.94 percent of Americans. Canada leads the rankings.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 13, 2021.

headline: Union Veteran Takes Over at Emily’s List as Abortion Fights Loom

lead_paragraph: Emily’s List, the fund-raising powerhouse that has helped elect hundreds of women who support abortion rights, has chosen Laphonza Butler, a former union leader and well-connected Democratic strategist in California, as its next president.

keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'Ethanol', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: At first glance, it’s a big step forward in curbing climate change. In a deal announced Thursday, the Biden administration and the airline industry agreed to an ambitious goal of replacing all jet fuel with sustainable alternatives by 2050, a target meant to drive down flying’s environmental toll.

headline: Abortion Is No Longer a Crime in Mexico. But Will Doctors Object?

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — As soon as the nurse found out that she had an abortion at home, Fernanda García knew she was in danger. The nurse began yelling that she was a criminal, that what she had done was wrong, that she would be sent to jail.

keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Building (Construction)', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Automobiles', 'Restoration and Renovation']

lead_paragraph: NORMAL, Ill. — When he bought a construction contractor called Weber Electric in 2018, Josh Mosier inherited about 20 employees. By the end of the next year, he was up to about 100 employees. By the spring of 2021, the number was over 225.

headline: Biden’s Bet on Vaccine Mandates
abstract: A look at the administration’s decision to require shots for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: As recently as a month ago, President Biden appeared to be skeptical about imposing coronavirus vaccine mandates. Now that skepticism has given way to a suite of policies that aim to force the hands of the unvaccinated.

headline: Should Students Be Allowed to Miss School for Mental Health Reasons?
abstract: New laws in several states allow children and adolescents to declare a mental health day. Is this a good trend? Do you wish your school gave you the option?
lead_paragraph: Several states, including Arizona, Oregon and Virginia, have recently passed bills that allow students to miss school to take care of their mental health, efforts that were often supported or led by students.

headline: Schools in New York City fully reopen after 18 months of pandemic restrictions.
abstract: Almost all of the nearly one million students in the public system are returning to class on Monday.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s classrooms reopened on Monday to roughly a million children, most of whom were returning for the first time since the United States’ largest school system closed in March 2020.
