headline: Jane Powell, Hollywood’s Girl Next Door, Is Dead at 92
abstract: Typecast from the outset, she was a star of movie musicals before she was out of her teens. But her big-screen career peaked when she was in her 20s.
lead_paragraph: Jane Powell, whose pert good looks and lyrical soprano voice brought her Hollywood stardom before she was out of her teens — but whose movie career peaked when she was still in her 20s with a starring role in one of the last great MGM musicals, the 1954 extravaganza “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers” — died on Thursday at her home in Wilton, Conn. She was 92.

headline: Is Self-Awareness a Mirage?
abstract: We know what we’re feeling, just not how and why we got here.
lead_paragraph: One of the most unsettling findings of modern psychology is that we often don’t know why we do what we do. You can ask somebody: Why’d you choose that house? Or why’d you marry that person? Or why’d you go to graduate school? People will concoct some plausible story, but often they really have no idea why they chose what they did.

headline: I Am Serving 28 Years to Life. Why Does One Person Decide if I Deserve Mercy?
abstract: Gov. Hochul has a rare opportunity to transform the clemency process.
lead_paragraph: FALLSBURG, N.Y. — Bobby Ehrenberg knew he would probably die in prison.

headline: Sondheim Is Writing a New Musical, and Hopes to Stage It Next Year
abstract: The actor Nathan Lane said he had recently participated in a reading of the show, titled “Square One.”
lead_paragraph: Stephen Sondheim, the 91-year-old composer and lyricist widely regarded as among the greatest musical theater artists in history, is writing another show and said he hopes that a production will be staged next year.

headline: For Some, Afghanistan Outcome Affirms a Warning: Beware the Blob
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan exposed the shortcomings of views within the foreign policy establishment, also known as ‘The Blob.’
lead_paragraph: First there was the Biden administration’s withdrawal from Afghanistan. Then there was the chorus of disapproval. And then, as is so often the case in American foreign policy, there was the Blob.

headline: Sian Proctor is the first Black woman to pilot a spacecraft.
abstract: The community college professor has long pursued her dream of being an astronaut.
lead_paragraph: Sian Proctor, 51, is a community college professor from Tempe, Ariz.

headline: Don’t Let Hunters Kill Bison Inside a National Park
keywords: ['Bison', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The park service should stop a planned cull of these animals in Grand Canyon National Park.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In politics, issues of true importance aren’t always the ones that consume our attention. My candidate for the most underrated of all public concerns is the treatment of animals, an issue as revealing as any about our character and sense of fairness. If you want hard evidence to track the moral progress of humanity, watch how we deal with other creatures who are defenseless against our power and will.

headline: Is Bad Indoor Air Dulling Your Brain?
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'internal-sub-only', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Heating, Ventilation and Cooling (HVAC)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: While we tend to worry about inhaling viral particles like the coronavirus, new research shows the air quality at work may have subtle effects on cognitive function.
lead_paragraph: How healthy is the air in your workplace?

headline: Thousands of Migrants Huddle in Squalid Conditions Under Texas Bridge
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The temporary camp in Del Rio has grown with staggering speed in recent days during a massive surge in migration that has overwhelmed the authorities.
lead_paragraph: DEL RIO, Texas — Thousands of migrants were crowded under a bridge outside the border community of Del Rio on Thursday, part of a massive surge in migration across the Rio Grande this week that has overwhelmed the authorities and caused significant delays in processing the arrivals.

headline: T.I. and Tiny Will Not Be Charged in Los Angeles Sexual Assault Investigation
abstract: The district attorney’s office in Los Angeles cited the statute of limitations, which expires after 10 years, in declining to pursue criminal charges regarding an alleged 2005 incident.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Los Angeles have declined to pursue criminal charges against the rapper T.I. and his wife, Tameka Cottle Harris, following an investigation into whether the couple drugged and sexually assaulted a woman in 2005, citing the statute of limitations, according to a document from the district attorney’s office.

headline: Ohio House Republican, Calling Trump ‘a Cancer,’ Bows Out of 2022
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2022)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Representative Anthony Gonzalez, one of the 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach Donald Trump, is the first of the group to retire rather than face a stiff primary challenge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Calling former President Donald J. Trump “a cancer for the country,” Representative Anthony Gonzalez, Republican of Ohio, said in an interview on Thursday that he would not run for re-election in 2022, ceding his seat after just two terms in Congress rather than compete against a Trump-backed primary opponent.

headline: From ‘Jeff who?’ to ‘Thank you.’
abstract: The rivalry between Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos over spaceflight is well known, but the two made nice on Twitter over the Inspiration4 launch.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk are two of the world’s wealthiest men. Both own private rocket companies. And in public, their relationship has been characterized by conflict.

headline: Who Gets Sick in Space? Orbital Tourists May Offer Better Clues.
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Medicine and Health', 'Research', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Emotions', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Motion Sickness']
abstract: Commercial spaceflight brings a more diverse cross section of humanity beyond Earth, helping medical researchers collect data.
lead_paragraph: Doctors have poked and prodded NASA astronauts for years, and the astronauts, as government employees, have largely acceded to their roles as test animals in studying how an alien environment — outer space — affects the human body.

headline: Vaccination Is Required at U.N. Meeting, N.Y.C. Mayor Says
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said he had told António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, that the city’s vaccination requirement for entering convention centers would apply to participants in the annual General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said he had told António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, that the city’s vaccination requirement for entering convention centers would apply to participants in the annual General Assembly.

headline: Big Game
abstract: Matthew Stock brings us an all-star puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Some of you will be pleased, while others may be dismayed, to learn that this is not a sports-themed puzzle. (I’ll admit I went a little heavy with the baseball when choosing the headline and the photo.) It’s Friday, and we’ve got a Matthew Stock themeless to entertain us.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Tensions over a U.S.-Australia submarine deal.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s announcement that the U.S. and Britain would help Australia deploy nuclear-powered submarines in the South China Sea has infuriated France, foreshadowing how conflicting American and European responses to confrontations with China may redraw the global strategic map.

headline: Hearing His Voice Changed Everything
abstract: I never knew my father. Did he know me?
lead_paragraph: The first time I heard my father’s voice he had been dead for 53 years. It all started when my cousin, who lives in Jerusalem, gave me 25 audio reels in round metal cans. She had found them while cleaning out her parents’ home there.

headline: Brian Selznick’s Lockdown Masterpiece
abstract: “Kaleidoscope” is the stuff of dreams — glittering shards of a wondrously ungraspable story.
lead_paragraph: KALEIDOSCOPEBy Brian Selznick

headline: Kate DiCamillo’s New Novel, About a Girl Who Would Be King
abstract: In “The Beatryce Prophecy,” a young girl is hunted by the king because of a prophecy that she will unseat him.
lead_paragraph: THE BEATRYCE PROPHECYBy Kate DiCamilloIllustrated by Sophie Blackall

headline: Why Reviving the Right to Picnic Offers Hope in Melbourne
abstract: The lockdown isn’t over. But at least we can gather on the grass.
lead_paragraph: I used to joke that someone in Melbourne ought to make a song to the tune of the 2 Pac song “California Love,” but instead of the line “California knows how to party,” the words would be “Victoria knows how to picnic.” Because man, Victoria really knows how to picnic.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Plant-Based Foods Expand and Chase Flexitarians
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 17, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “I like to view my cheese as a canvas. It’s my form of art. I want my product to be a feast for the eyes as well as the mouth.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 17, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 17, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article about the Inspiration4 mission misstated the distance of the Inspiration4 crew from Earth. They are farther from Earth than anyone since space shuttle crews visited the Hubble telescope in the 1990s, not farther than anyone since the Apollo missions ended in the 1970s.

headline: ‘Shang-Chi’ Wins a Warm Asia Greeting. Then There’s China.
abstract: Marvel’s first Asian superhero movie has yet to be released in the mainland amid fierce debate over its back story and star.
lead_paragraph: Marvel released “Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings” with China in mind. Simu Liu, the film’s Canadian lead actor, was born in China. Much of its dialogue is in Mandarin. The cast includes Tony Leung, one of the biggest Chinese-speaking movie stars in history.

headline: Word of the Day: efficacious
abstract: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Makes an Intriguing Offer to Logan Paul
abstract: The YouTube personality called Kimmel out for referring to him as one of the worst people in the world — alongside Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Two Men Charged in Killing of Journalist in Northern Ireland
abstract: Lyra McKee was fatally shot while covering rioting in Derry two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Two men have been charged with murder in the death of the journalist Lyra McKee, who was shot and killed in 2019 while observing riots in the city of Derry in Northern Ireland.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Fake Parties and Cloned Candidates: How the Kremlin ‘Manages’ Democracy
abstract: The Russian authorities have used a variety of deceitful tactics to try to manufacture a big victory in parliamentary elections this weekend. Here’s how they do it.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia stages local and national elections like clockwork in accordance with its post-Soviet Constitution, but the results are nearly always the same: sweeping victories for President Vladimir V. Putin and the politicians and parties loyal to him.

headline: Retailers Rethink Pandemic-Battered Manhattan
abstract: Starbucks has closed more than 40 stores, while adding mobile-order pickup counters in others. Other chains like Sonic are taking advantage of vacancies to establish themselves in New York.
lead_paragraph: In the heart of Manhattan’s garment district, a once-busy Starbucks on a corner of Eighth Avenue and 39th Street sits empty. Just down the block, a Dos Toros Taqueria that opened just three years ago is now closed. And Wok to Walk, which once served steaming containers of noodles mixed with chicken and vegetables to a bustling lunch crowd, is also shuttered.

headline: Merkel Leaves the German Economy With Trouble Under the Hood
keywords: ['Elections', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Automobiles', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'International Relations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel steered Europe through crises, and Germany has boomed during her tenure. But she has ducked changes needed to ensure the success lasts, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: During her 16 years as Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel has become an international avatar of calm, reason and democratic values for the way she handled crises that included a near financial meltdown of the eurozone, the arrival of more than a million migrants and a pandemic.

headline: The U.S. virus surge appears to be declining in some states, but deaths are still increasing.
abstract: Many officials have taken to calling the current wave, fueled by the more contagious Delta variant, a “pandemic of the unvaccinated.”
lead_paragraph: New coronavirus cases and Covid hospitalizations across the United States have started to show signs of decline, although they remain far higher than they were earlier in the summer, and the number of new deaths is still increasing.

headline: South African Court Rejects Former President’s Plea to Overturn Prison Sentence
abstract: The arrest of Jacob Zuma set off days of violent unrest and exposed deep rifts in his party, the African National Congress. But some hailed it as a victory for democracy.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s highest court on Friday rejected an appeal to throw out the prison sentence of Jacob Zuma, the former president who was jailed for refusing to appear before a commission investigating corruption accusations that tainted his tenure as the nation’s leader.

headline: Afghanistan, a Double Bind and Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Red Comet: The Short Life and Blazing Art of Sylvia Plath’ and ‘Sisters’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: HIS VERY BEST: Jimmy Carter, A Life, by Jonathan Alter. (Simon & Schuster, 800 pp., $20.) Alter’s “important, fair-minded” biography, David Greenberg wrote in his review, renders his subject with “a depth rarely achieved by political journalism.” The book “exposes Carter’s weaknesses as well as his undervalued strengths, his reverberating failures as well as his unsung triumphs,” and shows how the qualities that propelled him to the presidency “also kept him from rising to his historical moment.”

headline: Thomas Mann on the Artist vs. the State
abstract: Thomas Mann spent the years during World War I composing “Reflections of a Nonpolitical Man,” an idiosyncratic assault on democracy and reason that was recently reissued. The book’s political ideas are of little use, Christopher Beha writes, but Mann’s critique of how democracies enlist writers to serve as their social conscience resonates forcefully today.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Mann was just 26 years old when the publication of his first novel, “Buddenbrooks,” placed him in the front rank of German writers. He relished this position, but over the next decade produced little else to justify it. He was nearing 40 before he completed another great work, “Death in Venice,” a novella about an aging writer whose fascination with a beautiful young Polish boy keeps him on vacation even as a cholera epidemic descends. Mann started almost immediately on a second novella that would reproduce “Death in Venice”’s theme — the strange allure of “decadence,” illness and death — in a comic mode. He was working on this companion piece in 1914, when the assassination of the Austrian archduke Franz Ferdinand set into motion the events that would begin World War I.

headline: What Things Remind You of Your Childhood?
abstract: Are there toys, games, foods or places that make you think of life when you were younger?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever smelled something that reminded you of a meal your grandparent cooked when you were younger? Or seen the cover of a book that you used to read and suddenly missed being a little kid? Heard a song that reminded you of a lullaby someone would sing to you?

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 17, 2021
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2 Episode 9: Beard Has a Late Night
abstract: A lot happened last week. This week, pretty much all of it was put on hold.
lead_paragraph: And now for something completely different.

headline: A Sunset Farewell to Summer
abstract: The Untermyer Gardens in Yonkers held an outdoor celebration for its conservancy.
lead_paragraph: The Untermyer Gardens Conservancy, which restores and maintains the 43-acre former estate in Yonkers, N.Y., celebrated its 10th anniversary on Sept. 14 with a sunset party. The event honored Stephen F. Byrns, the conservancy’s longtime president, and Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the majority leader of the New York State Senate. A garden tour was followed by a reception and dessert under the stars.

headline: The U.S. Needs to Stop the Confusion Over Booster Shots
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Infighting over boosters is undermining Americans’ already fragile trust in the public health system.
lead_paragraph: This guest essay has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Biden implores world leaders to take action on climate change: ‘We don’t have a lot of time.’
abstract: The president urged nations to take on more ambitious climate targets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday announced that the United States and Europe have pledged to work to cut global methane emissions by a third in the coming decade and urged other nations to join their effort to curb a potent greenhouse gas that is warming the planet.

headline: Covid Showed Us What Keynes Always Knew
abstract: How the pandemic and events of the last decade upended economic policy.
lead_paragraph: “The world discovered that John Maynard Keynes was right when he declared during World War II that ‘anything we can actually do, we can afford,’” writes Adam Tooze. “Budget constraints don’t seem to exist; money is a mere technicality. The hard limits of financial sustainability, policed, we used to think, by ferocious bond markets, were blurred by the 2008 financial crisis. In 2020, they were erased.”

headline: Pulling at a Reflection
abstract: What do you think this image is saying?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Robert Gates on Org Charts at N.C.A.A. and Pentagon: They’re ‘Incomprehensible’
abstract: “They look like an AT&T wiring diagram,” said the former defense secretary, who now leads a committee that is rewriting the N.C.A.A.’s constitution.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Gates, the former defense secretary, agreed this summer to lead a committee to rewrite the constitution of the perpetually embattled N.C.A.A.

headline: Why This Superstar Pitcher for the Mets Started a Book Club
abstract: ‘I just think that’s what being a New Yorker is all about, being hungry for more,’ said Noah Syndergaard, an avid reader.
lead_paragraph: At a private party this summer at Little Prince, a French restaurant in SoHo, New Yorkers danced under disco lights and lined up at the bar.

headline: Fall Preview: The Thrill Is Back. So Is the Anxiety.
abstract: This new cultural season promised the most triumphant of returns, but the vagaries of the virus have ushered in nervousness, too.
lead_paragraph: The fall season! It’s a time of Broadway debuts, opera openings, Oscar bait, triumphant television returns and fat special issues heralding the sumptuous delights of “the fall season” — packages like the one you are reading right now.

headline: A Bond Built in Brooklyn
abstract: Justin Cooke and Erik Wallin gave their guests a tour around their favorite borough after their wedding ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Justin Cooke and Erik Wallin couldn’t get married without showing their 194 guests around Brooklyn. It wasn’t a long trek, only about a mile along the Brooklyn Heights promenade from St. Ann and the Holy Trinity Church, the site of their wedding ceremony, to St. Ann’s Warehouse, the performing arts center in Dumbo. But it was crucial, the couple came to realize, that their Aug. 28 nuptials showcase the city where they met and are building a home, especially amid the pandemic.

headline: Emmys 2021: The List of Nominees
abstract: The 73rd Emmy Awards will be held on Sunday. Several winners were announced earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live updates of the Emmys 2021 and winners list.]

headline: An ‘Accident of Geography’ Was the Start of Forever
abstract: Though Valeria Dueñas and John Garfinkel come from very different parts of the country, they bonded instantly at a Washington bar — and plan to name their dog after one, too.
lead_paragraph: It all started at a bar on St. Patrick’s Day in 2014.

headline: In Love Thanks to Politics — and Transparency
abstract: “Electric” early conversations grew into deeply honest ones in the relationship of Hannah Smith and Varun Anand.
lead_paragraph: In November 2017, Varun Anand sat next to Hannah Smith at a bar in Manhattan’s West Village. They were attending the going-away party of a friend who Mr. Anand had worked with in 2016 on the Clinton presidential campaign, and who Ms. Smith worked with in 2012 on the Obama campaign.

headline: A Courtship Built on Adventure
abstract: “When I am with Mike, I feel invincible,” Dana Rhoden said of her relationship with Michael Baran. The two were married atop a mountain in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: The first time Dana Rhoden spent time with Michael Baran was in 2010 at a mutual friend’s wedding in Coral Gables, Fla. “We danced all night and innocently kissed,” said Ms. Rhoden, now 43, and the owner of The Dana Agency, a public relations firm in Miami. “Nothing else happened because I was in a relationship.”

headline: 5 Pros in the Concert Trenches on Getting (Carefully) Back to Work
keywords: ['Music', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Vaccination Proof and Immunization Records']
abstract: What’s it like mixing sound, building sets and taking care of artists’ health as the music industry hits pause and play?
lead_paragraph: As live music revs back up, we spoke to five professionals around the industry about their experiences with fans, safety protocols, volume levels and tour plans. These are edited excerpts from the conversations.

headline: There Are Three Versions of Bruckner’s Fourth. Why Choose?
abstract: Jakub Hrusa and the Bamberg Symphony have released a new recording of them all.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian composer Anton Bruckner died in 1896, but his Fourth Symphony remains something of a work in progress.

headline: Don’t Let Trump Steal the Show With ‘Stop the Steal’
keywords: ['Elections', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The ideological belief in voter fraud is driving actual efforts to delegitimize Democratic Party victories.
lead_paragraph: You cannot actually debunk Republican accusations of voter fraud. You can show they aren’t true (and they aren’t), but that has no bearing on the belief itself.

headline: What’s Changing in the New FAFSA and What’s Not
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Content Type: Service', 'Personal Finances', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Pell Grants']
abstract: The latest version of the federal form for college aid will be available on Oct. 1 for the 2022-23 academic year. But a planned major overhaul of the form may not take effect for several years.
lead_paragraph: Big changes are coming to a notoriously complex form that students need to submit to qualify for college financial aid — but the changes will mostly appear gradually, over the next few years.

headline: All-Inclusive Resorts Make Staying Put More Appealing
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Cruises']
abstract: Business is booming at all-inclusive resorts, where travelers can enjoy multiday stays without complicated logistics — plus in-house dining, outdoor diversions and, in many cases, on-site virus testing.
lead_paragraph: After Amanda Stephens, a doctor in North Florida, had two cruises canceled last year, she turned to the next-best thing: eight days at Ambergris Cay, an all-inclusive luxury resort on a private island in Turks and Caicos, a British overseas territory. The family’s November trip was filled with white-sand beaches, water sports, on-site dining, complimentary spa treatments, and games and activities for the children, 7 and 11.

headline: Three Years Later, the Two Ran Off Together
abstract: Mariama Rose Diallo and Benjamin Gerrish Dickinson, both screenwriters and directors, met in 2018 at a Brooklyn bar. Their attraction was immediate.
lead_paragraph: When Mariama Rose Diallo and Benjamin Gerrish Dickinson, both screenwriters and directors, met in July 2018 at a Brooklyn bar, they became locked in a deep conversation. Ms. Diallo said she became so intrigued that she thought about “how close I had come to upending my life by running off with a handsome stranger.”

headline: Nashville Didn’t Make Room for Mickey Guyton. So She Made Her Own.
keywords: ['Country Music', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: She was failed by the country music industry until the emotional song “Black Like Me” changed her career. Now comes a debut album that proved therapeutic.
lead_paragraph: Six and a half years ago, Mickey Guyton released her breakout major label single, a grand, sweeping ballad called “Better Than You Left Me.” She sang it with heft and feeling, and the melody was reminiscent of the weepy country ballads of the 1960s. It was a loud, assured knock on Nashville’s door.

headline: Debunking the Pro-Trump Right’s Claims About the Jan. 6 Riot
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Attacks on Police', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A rally scheduled for Saturday in Washington is intended to continue a Republican effort to rewrite the narrative of the assault on the Capitol. The facts undercut their assertions.
lead_paragraph: In the eight months since a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol, some Republicans have tried to build a case — belied by the facts — that the vast federal investigation of the riot has been essentially unfair, its targets the victims of political persecution.

headline: Love at First Slice
abstract: Lauren Annunziata and Gabriel Piscione thought they met in high school, until her relative unearthed a photo of them eating pizza together at a children’s birthday party 10 years earlier.
lead_paragraph: When Lauren Annunziata sat down to eat pizza at her cousin’s birthday party in October 1995 at Kids N’ Action, a children’s entertainment center in Brooklyn, she had no idea that her future husband was at the same table as her. In fact, the only evidence that remains of Ms. Annunziata and Gabriel Vincent Piscione’s first meeting is a photo taken by Ms. Annunziata’s relative, Terry Cartusciello, where the future couple sat only a few feet away from each other.

headline: Robert Gates Ran the Pentagon. Can He Help Save the N.C.A.A.?
abstract: The former defense secretary now leads a committee that could remake college sports — or, as often happens with the N.C.A.A., that has little to show after many meetings.
lead_paragraph: The Washington State home of Robert M. Gates — closer to Canada than to Seattle, adorned with a mounted elk head and occupied by one of America’s semiretired spymasters — would seem an improbable place to try to reshape college sports in less than six months.

headline: First Came Lightning, Then Marriage
abstract: Neither Jamie Drucker nor Scott Huber had ever had a serious relationship before they met, at age 27. These days, their lives revolve around sailing, and each other.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Drucker and Scott Huber met on a party bus on the way to Virginia’s Gold Cup horse race, in 2014. “A mutual friend introduced us,” Ms. Drucker said. “I looked for him on Facebook the next day and couldn’t find him. Later that day, I got a Facebook message from Scott asking me out.”

headline: Theater Majors Unite at the Altar
abstract: After seven years together — and time living as far apart as Germany and Texas—Victoria Lee and Benjamin Bratcher pulled off a “euphoric” wedding at a Spanish-inspired villa.
lead_paragraph: It all started with a headshot. Benjamin Bratcher saw Victoria Lee’s photo when he was a junior and she was an incoming freshman at Abilene Christian University, in Texas. Both theater majors, they met at a department party in August of 2013.

headline: How a Barber and Journaling Expert Spends His Sundays
abstract: John Casey bears witness to New Yorkers’ stories, whether they are in his chair or taking his writing workshops.
lead_paragraph: When John Casey couldn’t work at Jack’s Barber Shop in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, which closed for several months in early 2020 because of the pandemic, he created The Sustainable Journaling Project, a four-session Zoom workshop. The thrust of it? Be simple. Write every day. Mr. Casey is a shining example of the practice; he has written every day for the last seven years.

headline: Parents of Students With Disabilities Try to Make Up for Lost Year
abstract: In New York City, the shift to remote learning “exacerbated pre-existing achievement gaps” for the 200,000 students with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Caleb Bell is deaf, blind and nonverbal. When classes at his Manhattan school moved online last year, Mr. Bell needed his mother’s help to answer direct questions. She’d often reach over and lift a block with a raised green circle, signifying “yes,” or a raised red X signifying “no.”

headline: How Old Is This Old House?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Carbon Dating']
abstract: Property records don’t go back far enough to date some houses. But experts can pinpoint a house’s age by studying tree-ring patterns in the house’s timber.
lead_paragraph: The first time a real estate agent took Ian Stewart to see the old saltbox farmhouse on a rocky hillside in Ghent, N.Y., he knew he wanted to buy it.

headline: First Came Friendship for an Activist and a Single Father of Five
abstract: Kassie Edwards and Michael Ruxsaksriskul both had childhood trauma. When they met at an AIDS awareness event in Washington, neither was interested in the other romantically.
lead_paragraph: Before Michael Ruxsaksriskul figured out that Kassie Edwards didn’t want to date him because of his personality, he assumed his personal baggage was to blame. As a newly divorced father of five on the verge of bankruptcy, the former Marine knew he was carrying a lot. What he didn’t know was that Ms. Edwards was experienced in unpacking.

headline: They Couldn’t Drink Their Water. And Still, They Stayed Quiet.
abstract: In a Pennsylvania town, fracking, contamination and a community unbound.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered Tom Crawley eight years ago, when I attended a town hall hosted by a Republican state representative, Garth Everett, in the cavernous volunteer fire hall of Hughesville, a hamlet nestled in the Appalachian foothills of north central Pennsylvania.

headline: A ‘Sopranos’ Family Tree
abstract: A guide to the many mobsters of “The Many Saints of Newark” and how they prefigure the characters in the beloved series about New Jersey wiseguys.
lead_paragraph: In the world of “The Sopranos,” there’s family, and then there’s “family” — those hard-won, deep-seated mob ties that make spiritual relations of every member of the Italian American mafia. Over the course of six seasons, that acclaimed HBO drama introduced us to several dozen members of New Jersey’s powerful DiMeo crime family, including its brilliant and fascinating kingpin, Tony Soprano, and the various uncles, cousins, rivals and lovers who fill out the engrossing drama of the character’s fraught, volatile life.

headline: A Flooded Stadium Went Viral, but the Home Team Didn’t Quit
abstract: The Somerset Patriots lost cars and equipment to Hurricane Ida’s aftermath — and had fish swimming in the on-deck circle — but the Yankees affiliate returned home a week later.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEWATER, N.J. — Shortly past sunrise on the day after Hurricane Ida’s remnants brought torrential rains, Dan Purner, the groundskeeper for the Somerset Patriots, drove his pickup around vehicles that had been abandoned on main roads.

headline: Fall Brings a Bounty of New Albums. Watch for These 3.
abstract: A long-running indie band (Parquet Courts), a star-in-waiting (Remi Wolf) and a producer stepping into the spotlight (Illuminati Hotties) are ones to watch this season, our critic says.
lead_paragraph: At last, the music industry is — sort of? kind of? maybe? — beginning its post-2020 reawakening. Bands that had been waiting to release new albums until they could realistically envision touring them are now tentatively re-emerging from extended hiatuses. Rising stars whose ascents were delayed by the pandemic are finally lifting off. After a long fallow period, this fall’s album-release harvest is once again looking abundant.

headline: The Changing Midtown Cityscape
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES (ATV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: When you return to the office, you may not find your favorite coffee place.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at how retailers — especially chain stores in Midtown — are rethinking things as they adapt to what they hope will be a post-Covid existence.

headline: Colson Whitehead’s New Novel and the Secret to Raising a Resilient Child: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: A pilot program hints at an eventual end to Australia’s hotel quarantine system.
abstract: New South Wales will allow some returning international travelers to quarantine at home starting at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: The Australian state of New South Wales will allow some returning international travelers to quarantine at home starting at the end of the month, possibly signaling the beginning of the end for the country’s strict hotel quarantine system.

headline: Fake Rock Nearly Crushes Opera Star: Accident or Sabotage?
abstract: Feuding stagehands, falling props: It might sound like the plot of an opera, but in France it has been the subject of a court case.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The tenor Robert Dean Smith was lying onstage — eyes closed, pretending to be dead — when he felt something very close above him.

headline: How to Learn More About the History of Your Home
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Genealogy']
abstract: Tracking down property records and researching other documents can shed light on the life of a house.
lead_paragraph: Houses are secret keepers, witnesses to history, be it everyday milestones like the spot a baby takes first steps to significant historical events like the porch, which provided shelter so we could wave to neighbors during a pandemic.

headline: A Broadway Show Comes Back to Life
abstract: One theater production’s journey back to the stage after the longest and costliest shutdown in New York theater’s history.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado Marries His Longtime Partner, Marlon Reis
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Politics and Government', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Mr. Polis is the first sitting governor to have a same-sex wedding.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado married his longtime partner, Marlon Reis, in a traditional Jewish ceremony on Wednesday, the first time a sitting governor has had a same-sex wedding.

headline: Google and Apple, Under Pressure From Russia, Remove Voting App
keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Political Prisoners', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The app, created by allies of the opposition leader Aleksei Navalny, vanished from online stores, reflecting a new level of pressure against U.S. technology companies in the country.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Apple and Google removed an app meant to coordinate protest voting in this weekend’s Russian elections from the country on Friday, a blow to the opponents of President Vladimir V. Putin and a display of Silicon Valley’s limits when it comes to resisting crackdowns on dissent around the world.

headline: Valorizing Jan. 6
abstract: Capitol Hill is bracing for another pro-Trump rally.
lead_paragraph: In the months since the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, videos and investigations have underscored how violent it was.

headline: Where Did It All Go So Wrong for Juul?
abstract: A new documentary by The New York Times traces the e-cigarette maker on its path from fledgling start-up to Silicon Valley juggernaut and, eventually, public health villain.
lead_paragraph: Our new documentary is now streaming on FX on Hulu.

headline: It’s That Time of Year, Experts Warn: Get a Flu Shot
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Influenza', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Public health experts recommend an annual flu shot, and are worried a “twindemic” with Covid-19 could further burden health care facilities this year.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, as coronavirus cases climbed and the world hoped for vaccines, health experts feared influenza and Covid-19 would combine for a devastating “twindemic.”

headline: He Was Swept Down a Sewer Pipe: ‘I Just Let the Water Take Me’
abstract: Devastation from Hurricane Ida’s remnants stretched deep into New Jersey, forcing residents and officials to address “a new reality.”
lead_paragraph: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J. — Kevin Rivera owes his life to a man he will never meet.

headline: What Facebook Knows
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Greeting Gestures', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Social Media', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Internal company documents suggest that the company plays down awareness of its flaws.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Wall Street Journal published a bombshell investigation about how Facebook responds to the flaws in its platform. The four-part report, which is largely based on internal documents, suggests that the company often plays down what it knows about these problems. According to The Journal, at least some of the documents have been turned over to the S.E.C. and Congress by a whistle-blower.

headline: Lesson of the Day: The Forgotten History of Indigenous Boarding Schools
abstract: In this lesson, you will learn more about residential schools for Native American children, hear from survivors, and consider the importance of history, memory and justice.
lead_paragraph: Featured Resources: For this lesson, students can read the article “Lost Lives, Lost Culture: The Forgotten History of Indigenous Boarding Schools” or listen to The Daily episode “State-Sponsored Abuse in Canada” from the beginning until 11:40.

headline: United Airlines briefly stops all of its U.S. and Canadian flights.
abstract: The airline had paused flights on Friday morning, saying it had “experienced technical system issues.”
lead_paragraph: United Airlines briefly paused flights nationwide on Friday morning amid reports of a system outage.

headline: TS Madison Steals the Spotlight
abstract: Her role in the summer movie “Zola” was brief, but getting there was years in the making.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen minutes into the film “Zola,” the actress TS Madison delivers a devotion that becomes a kind of mantra for the rest of the film.

headline: The F.D.A.’s day of lively debate revealed key questions about the evidence on boosters.
abstract: New research indicated the booster shots were not now necessary for everyone, a view that prevailed at the agency’s advisory committee meeting.
lead_paragraph: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration on Friday questioned a key assertion by researchers in Israel and by the drug company Pfizer: that its coronavirus vaccine is waning in protection not just against infection, but against severe illness and hospitalization.

headline: Hong Kong Forces Tiananmen Vigil Group to Delete Online Presence
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'Social Media', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The deletions were the most high-profile instance of internet censorship under the national security law.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police have forced one of the city’s best-known activist groups to scrub its online presence, in the latest sign of how officials may use a powerful national security law to restrict online speech and impose mainland Chinese-style internet censorship.

headline: From TV to the French Presidency? A Right-Wing Star Is Inspired by Trump
abstract: Éric Zemmour, a writer and TV celebrity known for his far-right nationalism, dominates political talk in France as he weighs a run for president.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s election season began in force this week, with candidates for the presidency launching their bids or holding campaign-style events. But the person who stole the show was not a candidate, or even a politician, but a right-wing writer and TV star channeling Donald J. Trump.

headline: Black Irish, Mariah Carey’s New Liquor, Can’t Be Sold in Ireland
abstract: A trademark dispute with an Irish company has prevented the singer’s new line of Irish cream liqueur from reaching customers in Ireland or the rest of the European Union.
lead_paragraph: The singer Mariah Carey, announcing her new liquor brand last month, said it was called Black Irish in a nod to her father, who was Black, and her mother’s Irish heritage.

headline: Giants, Leaving Points on the Board, Come Up One Short
abstract: Washington won a thriller on a last-second field goal, sending Daniel Jones and the Giants to another 0-2 start.
lead_paragraph: The Giants moved the ball sharply, at times impressively. Then they settled for a field goal.

headline: Security Memo on the Sept. 18 Rally
abstract: Read the memo prepared by the Department of Homeland Security assessing the possibility of violence at a rally in Washington Saturday, protesting the charges against members of the mob that attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: Read the memo prepared by the Department of Homeland Security assessing the possibility of violence at a rally in Washington Saturday, protesting the charges against members of the mob that attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6.

headline: I Have Seen the Future of Car Shows. Maybe.
abstract: I’ve been to a lot of car shows, and they look pretty much the same, but one car show this month tried something different.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been to a lot of car shows, and they look pretty much the same, but one car show this month tried something different.

headline: How to Hold Onto Post-Lockdown Joy: Practice Gratitude
abstract: It’s proven to make you happier.
lead_paragraph: When pandemic rules began to loosen earlier this year, I felt a small burst of joy each time I did something that had been off-limits for months. With the rollout of the vaccines, once-mundane activities became almost wondrous.

headline: Biden Threatens New Sanctions Against Ethiopia War Leaders
keywords: ['War and Armed Conflicts', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'Tigrayans (Ethnic Group)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: In an executive order, President Biden targeted all sides of the widening conflict in Africa’s second most populous country, demanding an end to fighting and safe passage for aid.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — President Biden signed an executive order on Friday threatening sweeping new sanctions that aim to stop the escalating war in northern Ethiopia and allow urgently needed humanitarian aid to flow into the region.

headline: Know Your ‘NCIS’ From Your ‘CSI’?
abstract: And don’t forget “FBI.” Test your network TV knowledge in this quiz about the new fall season.
lead_paragraph: And don’t forget “FBI.” Test your network TV knowledge in this quiz about the new fall season.

headline: How Jessica Chastain Became Tammy Faye
abstract: To transform the actress into the title televangelist of “The Eyes of Tammy Faye,” it took a little faith and a lot of artists.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Chastain spent years pursuing the opportunity to play Tammy Faye Messner, the indefatigable star of Christian broadcasting. Better known to an audience of millions as Tammy Faye Bakker, she and Jim Bakker, her husband at the time, presided over the popular PTL television ministry until they were brought down in the late 1980s by financial and sex scandals.

headline: Proposed Tax Changes Focus on the Wealthy
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Content Type: Service', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: How is that defined? The tax plans in Congress essentially say a wealthy individual earns $400,000 a year. But that figure, a financial psychologist says, is “arbitrary.”
lead_paragraph: So how do you define who’s wealthy?

headline: All the Ways to Fall for Dance Again Onstage and Beyond
abstract: This season’s highlights? A new festival at Little Island, a birthday celebration for Twyla Tharp — and the return of all the things you’ve missed.
lead_paragraph: When the world shut down last year, whole slates of professional dance programming evaporated overnight. Yet suddenly everyone was dancing: at virtual dance parties and in TikTok challenges, in the swelling crowds at social justice protests, in the streets as election results rolled in. This fall dance is back onstage, with theaters and companies (optimistically) planning busy seasons. Much of the programming feels like business as usual, but some artists are channeling the energy of the moment, reimagining dances created online during shutdowns as live pieces, or bringing the cathartic power of protest dance to the stage. (Theaters may require audience members to show proof of vaccination, and live performances are still subject to change because of Covid; check websites for updated information.)

headline: New Fall Movies 2021: Here Are More Than 125 Coming Soon
abstract: Look for would-be blockbusters (“Dune,” “No Time to Die”), art-house hopefuls (“Spencer,” “Flee”) and everything in between (“The Many Saints of Newark”).
lead_paragraph: Movies continue to return to theaters, and some of our most popular heroes — James Bond; Neo and Trinity; a new group of Ghostbusters — are set to return with them this fall. The backlog from the pandemic means we’re getting not one but two films from Ridley Scott. Chloé Zhao will apply her Oscar-winning eye to a comic book movie. Some major titles, like “The Tragedy of Macbeth,” starring Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand — and directed by Joel Coen without his brother, Ethan — hadn’t settled on dates by press time, but expect to see them soon.

headline: Fall TV 2021: The 31 Shows to Watch
abstract: Television returns in earnest after last year’s pandemic wipeout, bringing new high-minded adaptations, new seasons of beloved shows and new versions of things you’ve seen many times before.
lead_paragraph: Fall television returns to normal this year after the pandemic wipeout of 2020, with the broadcast networks presenting their usual full schedules. But what’s normal these days?

headline: These Are the Art Shows and Events to See This Season
abstract: From an enormous roundup of Black American portraits to a two-city retrospective of Jasper Johns, the new art season is buzzing again — and as busy as it ever was.
lead_paragraph: After the pandemic brought museum and gallery shows to a dead stop, last year’s racial justice protests lent new urgency to demands that institutions become more transparent, more representative and more diverse. While there’s certainly an uptick of shows featuring women and artists of color in this fall preview, there are also many, delayed by Covid-19, that were planned several years ago. For the moment, at least, it feels as if we are picking up just where we left off — with solo blockbusters (like Jasper Johns’s, stretching over two cities), art fairs (nearly all in person, again) and ancient treasures (rare ceramics, from Thailand to Mesopotamia). Check museums and fairs for health-related updates: Museums may require proof of vaccination, and fairs may yet migrate back online.

headline: 66 Pop and Jazz Albums, Shows and Festivals Coming This Fall
keywords: ['Rhythm and Blues (Music)', 'Jazz', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Blues Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: Anticipated returns (Abba, Diana Ross), intergenerational collaborations (Lady Gaga and Tony Bennett) and hotly tipped follow-ups (Brandi Carlile, Makaya McCraven) are coming in the new season.
lead_paragraph: When pandemic lockdowns shut down the concert industry last year, some artists forged ahead with planned album releases and answered a question loaded with risk: What would a rollout look like without the regular promotional cycle of in-person interviews, late-night performances and live shows? Many musicians pivoted to streaming; others buckled down on their songwriting and hit the studio. The results of these experiments are largely emerging now.

headline: Theater to See This Season After a Very Long Intermission
abstract: Timely plays tackle tough subjects, while musicals get the royal treatment, thanks to a princess (“Diana”), queens (“Six”) and the King of Pop (“MJ”).
lead_paragraph: In another season, the chance to see “Wicked” or “The Lion King” again after so long wouldn’t be such thrilling news. But this isn’t any other theater season. So while in these listings we detail plenty of world premieres (“Flying Over Sunset,” “The Bedwetter”); inventive revivals (a gender-swapped “Company”); and at least seven plays by Black writers on Broadway, we might also take a look at the old reliables. Welcome back.

headline: Police Search Florida Wilderness for ‘Person of Interest’ in Van Mystery
abstract: The parents of Brian Laundrie, whose fiancée, Gabrielle Petito, disappeared on a cross-country trip, say they haven’t seen their son in days, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The authorities on Saturday began scouring a vast Florida wildlife reserve for a man declared a “person of interest” in the disappearance of his fiancée, one day after his parents disclosed that they hadn’t seen him since Tuesday.

headline: Stocks decline for a second week as September’s slow retreat continues.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Government Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Quantitative Easing', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: Wall Street seems to be in a funk, with the S&P 500 declining about 2.3 percent since its latest high.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street tumbled again on Friday, with the S&P 500 marking a second consecutive weekly drop and extending a slow decline that has been weighing on the stock market all month.

headline: The Pain Wouldn’t Stop — Because Her Medication Had Been Stolen
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Home Health Care', 'Elderly', 'your-feed-health', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Too often, seniors who use opioids become targets for exploitation and abuse.
lead_paragraph: LaVonne Borsheim’s family could not understand why she was suffering such intense pain.

headline: A Professor Plots to Seduce His Student. She Has Other Plans.
abstract: In Katie Lattari’s unnerving suspense novel, “Dark Things I Adore,” a scheming thesis adviser proves no match for his young protégé.
lead_paragraph: The publication of another novel by Jean-Patrick Manchette, the French noir writer who died in 1995, is a reason to rejoice. His association with the Surrealists, his mordant sense of humor and his profound familiarity with the genre’s masters — many of whom he translated — produced masterpieces like “The Prone Gunman,” “Fatale” and “Three to Kill.” I’d rather read Manchette than many contemporary noir writers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Clint Eastwood's latest film, an opera installation and Colson Whitehead's new book are among the cultural events to see and do this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Clint Eastwood's latest film, an opera installation and Colson Whitehead's new book are among the cultural events to see and do this weekend.

headline: Utah Is a Destination Wedding Hot Spot, No Travel Required
abstract: Thousands of international couples, separated by Covid-19 travel restrictions, have found a surprising lifeboat in Provo, Utah, where the wedding process has been fully virtualized.
lead_paragraph: PROVO, Utah — Five days a week, in a small beige room in a plain office building here, couples all over the world are granted a golden ticket: the ability to reunite after being separated by Covid-19 travel restrictions, in some cases for more than a year and a half.

headline: At Barcelona, a Feeling Worse Than Sorrow: Pity
abstract: The Camp Nou’s reaction to a humbling defeat in the Champions League was a measure of how far and how fast a mighty team has fallen.
lead_paragraph: They would have expected anger. As Barcelona’s players chased shadows on Tuesday night, as Bayern Munich toyed with them and teased them and tore through them, time and time again, they would almost have been waiting for the fury to come, for the Camp Nou to bare its teeth.

headline: National Book Awards Announces Its 2021 Nominees
keywords: ['National Book Awards', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: This year’s fiction longlist includes Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, a 2020 nominee in the poetry category, as well as Richard Powers, who also made the Booker Prize shortlist this week.

headline: Giraffes Prefer a Fair Fight
abstract: Researchers found that the long-necked mammals spar with partners of similar stature.
lead_paragraph: Giraffes don’t fight much, says Jessica Granweiler, a master’s student at the University of Manchester in England who studies nature’s tallest mammals. When they do, look out.

headline: How Much Water Do You Actually Need?
abstract: Here’s how to know when you truly need to hydrate.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve spent any time on social media or visited an athletic event lately, you’ve surely been bombarded with encouragements to drink more water. Celebrity influencers lug around gallon-sized water bottles as the hot new accessory. Twitter bots constantly remind us to make more time to hydrate. Some reusable water bottles even come emblazoned with motivational phrases — “Remember your goal,” “Keep drinking,” “Almost finished” — to encourage more drinking throughout the day.

headline: U.S. officials warn of potential violence at the Sept. 18 rally, but see no ‘specific or credible plot.’
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: An internal report by the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence office cited concerning internet chatter ahead of the rally supporting the suspects in the Jan. 6 riot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is deploying scores of National Guard troops to secure a fenced-off Capitol during a rally on Saturday for defendants charged in connection with the Jan. 6 riot, bracing for violence as the authorities toil to correct the security failures that led to the deadly assault eight months ago.

headline: The Harvard Professor Scam Gets Even Weirder
abstract: Six other men describe their encounters with the same mysterious Frenchwoman.
lead_paragraph: Six other men describe their encounters with the same mysterious Frenchwoman.

headline: A Rare Look at Bob Dylan in the Studio, and 13 More New Songs
keywords: ['Rhythm and Blues (Music)', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Jazz']
abstract: Hear tracks by Tems, Adia Victoria, Cuco and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Finally, a Lot of Classical Music and Opera to Hear This Season
abstract: Among the highlights: the Metropolitan Opera’s first work by a Black composer, Carnegie Hall’s reopened doors and more.
lead_paragraph: The coming classical music season has an unsettled quality, a sense of a culture trying to orient itself in the midst of crisis. You can detect in the offerings bottled-up energy from a long dormancy; wariness about the continuing health and financial effects of the pandemic; pressure, in the wake of protests against racial injustice, to demonstrate that a hidebound art form can become truly more diverse.

headline: ‘The Eyes of Tammy Faye’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Michael Showalter narrates a scene from his film featuring Jessica Chastain and Andrew Garfield.
lead_paragraph: The director Michael Showalter narrates a scene from his film featuring Jessica Chastain and Andrew Garfield.

headline: Watch Jessica Chastain Take a Stand in ‘The Eyes of Tammy Faye’
abstract: The director Michael Showalter narrates a sequence featuring the actress as Tammy Faye Bakker and Andrew Garfield as Jim Bakker.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make use of the fresh beans at the market with Gabrielle Hamilton’s braised black-eyed peas with baby turnips.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Black-eyed peas play a big role in celebrations of the calendar New Year, where they’re used for good-luck stew and hoppin’ John and gumbo. But as Gabrielle Hamilton points out in The New York Times Magazine this week, fresh black-eyed peas can bring fortune to this new academic year as well, along with all the other shell beans we’re finding at the market in this harvest season.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a home-sharing horror comedy, a slow-burn study of a nightmarish friendship and a love letter to scary drag queens.
lead_paragraph: Rowan (Lee Marshall) is an odd girl who becomes an odd girl out when she takes a trip to a remote cabin in the woods with her friend Emily (Lauren Beatty) and Emily’s boyfriend, Brendan (Aris Tyros). On the first night, the three enjoy drinks and lighthearted conversation. But things quickly take an ominous turn as Rowan has waking nightmares that Emily is slicing into her arms and stealing her blood.

headline: Pandemic-related illness forces cancellation of Sept. 11 hearing at Guantánamo.
abstract: The judge scrapped the hearing “in an abundance of caution” on the last day of the first session of hearings for the Sept. 11, 2001 case during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — A military judge overseeing the Sept. 11, 2001, case abruptly canceled a hearing on Friday at Guantánamo Bay because of illness related to the coronavirus pandemic, ending this month’s pretrial session a day early.

headline: Tourists Attack N.Y.C. Restaurant Hostess Over Vaccine Proof, Police Say

lead_paragraph: Update: Security camera footage revealed new details about the altercation at Carmine’s.

headline: ‘A Treasure in a Tree!’: Birders on Their (Expensive) Habit
abstract: Six birders on their bird-watching gear: “Last year I spent $2,300 on Swarovski binoculars. But that wasn’t enough.”

headline: The Biden administration is negotiating to buy another 500 million Pfizer doses to donate overseas.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Shortages', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The talks come just in time for a global Covid-19 summit that President Biden will host on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly meeting next week.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is negotiating with Pfizer to buy another 500 million doses of Covid-19 vaccine to donate overseas, which would bring the total number of planned donations to 1.15 billion doses — about a tenth of the world’s need — according to two people familiar with the plan. It was not immediately clear over what time period the donation would be.

headline: Hochul Orders Release of 191 Detainees as Rikers Crisis Deepens
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Shortages', 'Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Friday ordered the release of nearly 200 detainees from New York City’s Rikers Island jail complex, underscoring the growing alarm about violence and unbridled disorder at the notorious facility.

headline: Biden Urges World Leaders to Accelerate Action on Climate Crisis

lead_paragraph: At a virtual forum, President Biden pressed for a global allegiance in fighting climate change less than two months before a United Nations conference where nearly 200 nations are expected to announce new emissions-cutting targets.

headline: In Panjshir, Few Signs of an Active Resistance, or Any Fight at All
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: On a recent visit, few civilians were about and signs of heavy fighting were scarce. What remained were opposing narratives and claims of massacres, ethnic cleansing and false charges.
lead_paragraph: PANJSHIR, Afghanistan — In this lush strip of land — walled off from potential invaders by high mountain peaks and narrow, ambush-prone passes — former mujahedeen fighters and Afghan commandos regrouped in the days after the Taliban toppled the Afghan government, vowing to fight to the last man. With its history of resistance and its reputation for impenetrability, the Panjshir Valley seemed an ideal place for a determined force of renegades to base an insurgency.

headline: The Mythology of Racial Progress
abstract: Americans are determined to believe in Black progress — whether it's happening or not.
lead_paragraph: Americans are determined to believe in Black progress — whether it's happening or not.

headline: Bob Woodward Extends His Trump Chronicles With the Chaotic Transfer of Power
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: In “Peril,” Woodward and his co-writer Robert Costa take readers up to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot and the early days of the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: The titles of Bob Woodward’s three books about the Trump administration — “Fear,” “Rage” and now “Peril” — are appropriately blunt. The books, about the staccato stream of events that accompanied Donald Trump’s time in office, are written at a mostly staccato clip.

headline: Richard Branson’s Virgin Voyages starts U.S. cruises as the industry bounces back.
abstract: Mr. Branson wants to bring to cruises the same sensibility that he brought to his airlines: younger and slightly edgy. (There is a tattoo parlor onboard.)
lead_paragraph: Virgin Voyages, a joint venture between Bain Capital and Richard Branson’s Virgin Group, made its United States debut this week, more than a year later than scheduled.

headline: Why Louisiana’s Electric Grid Failed in Hurricane Ida
keywords: ['Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Machinery and Equipment', 'Hurricane Laura (2020)', 'Wind']
abstract: Much of the state, including New Orleans, lost power for days because many of Entergy’s electrical poles and towers were not built to withstand a major hurricane, energy experts said.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks before Hurricane Ida knocked out power to much of Louisiana, leaving its residents exposed to extreme heat and humidity, the chief executive of Entergy, the state’s biggest utility company, told Wall Street that it had been upgrading power lines and equipment to withstand big storms.

headline: ‘Everybody’s Talking About Jamie’ Review: Drag Queen Dreams
abstract: Despite its clichés, this musical about an aspiring teenage drag queen is a charmer.
lead_paragraph: You have to credit “Everybody’s Talking About Jamie” for boldness: This new British musical is not afraid to be predictable. Characters who are all archetypes leave no cliché unturned as they navigate plot turns we have seen a hundred times before.

headline: The Most Adaptable Pesto Pasta
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi’s recipe absolutely delivers with whatever substitutions you throw in.
lead_paragraph: Hello! I’m Krysten, filling in for Em this week. I’ve edited this newsletter since the very start, and it’s one of my greatest joys. I love knowing that the recipes in this space are making it onto your tables — and hopefully making dinner a little easier for you and your families. It’s almost like getting to eat with you all. (Is that too earnest? I’m very earnest.)

headline: What Is Drama? The Bungled Plan at ‘Jeopardy!’ to Choose a New Host
abstract: Replacing the late Alex Trebek has been an ongoing saga for the game show. Here’s how it unfolded.
lead_paragraph: When Alex Trebek, the beloved host of “Jeopardy!,” died in November from pancreatic cancer, the game show had to face a grim reality: How would it move on without the man who was the heart of the show? Mr. Trebek, with his calm and steadying voice, had been a fixture in American living rooms for 37 years.

headline: Pasta Aglio e Olio Gets a Plus One

headline: A Celebrated Virtuoso on an Instrument She Wasn’t Meant to Play
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Music', 'Musical Instruments', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The hallowed tradition of kora playing in Sona Jobarteh’s family passed down the male line. One of her teachers dismissed it as “an ethnic thing.” But it has brought her international acclaim.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The ethereal sound of the kora, a centuries-old West African instrument, reverberated as Sona Jobarteh, a virtuoso from one of Gambia’s most celebrated musical families, plucked its strings with her forefingers and thumbs.

headline: Great Oregon Wines Beyond the Willamette Valley

lead_paragraph: UNDERWOOD, Wash. — Laura Brennan Bissell was already making wine under her own label, Inconnu, in Northern California when she visited the Columbia River Gorge for the first time.

headline: India boosts its Covid vaccine drive with 25 million shots given on Modi’s birthday.
abstract: After early setbacks, the inoculation push in the world’s second most populous country has gained momentum. India now counts more than 793 million administered shots.
lead_paragraph: India’s far-reaching effort to vaccinate its vast population against Covid-19 hit another milestone on Friday: Its health ministry said that a record 25 million shots had been administered over the course of the day, a special push to mark the birthday of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and celebrate his 20 years in public office.

headline: Britain Signals Intent to Revert to the Imperial System
keywords: ['Weights and Measures', 'Metric System', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The government announced plans to allow shops to sell produce in pounds and ounces, rather than using the metric system, as part of an effort to “capitalize on new Brexit freedoms.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said it was taking steps to return to its traditional system of imperial weights and measures, allowing shops and market stalls to sell fruits and vegetables labeled in pounds and ounces alone, rather than in the metric system’s grams and kilograms, a move it hailed as an example of the country’s new post-Brexit freedoms.

headline: Wrapped Arc de Triomphe Is Christo’s Fleeting Gift to Paris
abstract: Planned by the conceptual artist 60 years ago, the posthumous work transforms a great monument with a glistening cloak. It feels like a liberating moment for the city.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For almost 60 years, the artist known as Christo dreamed of wrapping the Arc de Triomphe. As a young man, having fled communist Bulgaria, he would gaze at the monument from his tiny garret apartment. A photomontage dated 1962 shows the 164-foot-high arch crudely bundled up. Freedom trumped the sacred. He always wanted people to look again at what perhaps they did not see.

It’s a relatively lighthearted novel, certainly compared to “The Underground Railroad” and “The Nickel Boys,” Whitehead’s two previous novels, each of which won the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: A Wedding Dish Worthy of Weeknight

lead_paragraph: At a wedding function in Lahore, Pakistan, shimmering fabrics, bright colors, maximalist jewelry and glittering makeup form a dazzling display of aesthetic maximalism. Old grudges are set aside or permanently forgotten in favor of love and blessings. Everyone knows newlyweds will need both, and so everyone is invited — and fed.

The “pledge trainer,” a junior who reeked of whiskey, yelled out the rules. The final, most important one? No Black people at the frat house. He did not use the words “Black people.”

headline: North Carolina court strikes down a voter ID law, citing racial discrimination.

headline: 14 Classic Recipes You Should Know by Heart
abstract: Commit a few — or all — of these dishes to memory, and you’ll always have a delicious meal at the ready.
lead_paragraph: We all have one — a dish we don’t need a recipe for. The prepping, cooking and serving has become second nature, like a dance you’ve danced a million times before. When you whip it together from memory on a busy weeknight or at a vacation rental, it makes you feel a little accomplished, like you’ve figured it all out. (Even if it’s just for that brief shining moment.) The collection of recipes below, which is by no means a definitive list, includes those that you might want to work on memorizing next. They are back-pocket dishes that will never do you wrong.

headline: Furious Over Sub Deal, France Recalls Ambassadors to U.S. and Australia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: It is the first time in the long history of the French-U.S. alliance that a top diplomat has been recalled, illustrating the depth of France’s anger.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Calling American and Australian behavior “unacceptable between allies and partners,” France announced on Friday that it was recalling its ambassadors to both countries in protest over President Biden’s decision to provide nuclear-powered submarines to Australia.

The effort was intended to increase the value of personal injury claims against the manufacturers of the medical devices.

headline: ‘The Most Important Number You’ve Never Heard Of’

abstract: A new study aims to help the Biden administration determine the social cost of greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: There’s a good reason climate change is called the policy problem from hell. Several good reasons, actually, but let’s start with a big one: Fighting climate change forces society to spend real money today to reap benefits that will occur over hundreds or even thousands of years. We’re not set up to be that farsighted, either financially or mentally.

headline: Some Asked, ‘Does Chattanooga Need a Lynching Memorial?’
