headline: Taliban Seize Women’s Ministry Building for Use by Religious Police
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)']
abstract: Taliban leaders have turned the Kabul building that housed Afghanistan’s Ministry of Women’s Affairs into the offices for the religious police, an ominous portent for women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have converted the Ministry of Women’s Affairs building into offices for the religious morality police, who once instilled dread in Afghanistan for their suppression of women and brutal enforcement of the militant government’s interpretation of Shariah law when it ruled two decades ago.

headline: Ralph Irizarry, Innovative Latin Percussionist, Dies at 67
abstract: A colleague said Mr. Irizarry, who played timbales with Ray Barretto and Rubén Blades and led his own bands, expanded the instrument’s possibilities “to the nth degree.”
lead_paragraph: Ralph Irizarry, a master of the timbales who played in groups led by the conga player Ray Barretto and the singer Rubén Blades before forming his own well-regarded bands, died on Sept. 5 in a hospital in Brooklyn. He was 67.

headline: New York Public Library to Keep Picture Collection Browsable
abstract: A plan to archive the resource, used by many artists, including Warhol, has been shelved.
lead_paragraph: The New York Public Library on Thursday reversed course and announced that it would continue to maintain its venerable Picture Collection as circulating and browsable. The collection will be transferred to another room on the same floor in the main branch at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue, with the move tentatively scheduled for early 2022.

headline: On the Scene: An E.V. Boom Town
abstract: Normal, Ill., is hoping the upstart electric vehicle maker Rivian can help the town become thriving once again.
lead_paragraph: Normal, Ill., is hoping the upstart electric vehicle maker Rivian can help the town become thriving once again.

headline: Glimpses of How Pandemic America Went Back to School
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Education (Secondary)', 'Principals (School)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'E-Learning', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Across the country, students are returning to classes. We connected with hundreds of them to see how they — along with teachers, administrators and parents — are coping.
lead_paragraph: This fall, after 18 months of classroom closures, seemingly endless screen time, child-care emergencies and nasty political wrangling over whether and how to reopen, schools are back.

headline: As Populists Decline, the Center-Left Sees Hints of a Comeback
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: A long-struggling political faction has seen surprising gains this year, in part because of changes wrought by the pandemic. Can it hold on to them?
lead_paragraph: A style of politics long considered in decline is experiencing something of a reprieve, even seeing glimmers of a possible return.

headline: Can I Still Dress All in Black?
abstract: A reader asks for guidance on their achromatic wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: In art, where black was the first pigment used, black is an achromatic color — one without a dominant hue but containing all hues in equal measure. Historically, that has led to it being considered, in the decorative arts and, to a certain extent, in fashion, a neutral, like white or beige — a tone used as a base against which other colors can be displayed.

headline: Seeing New York Fashion Week
abstract: After a long pause, it feels (a little) like old times.
lead_paragraph: Despite an uncertain summer, New York Fashion Week came roaring back, bringing with it a beautiful blur of shows that were staged all around the city, with the Met Gala acting as the splashy grand finale. As the fashion crowd travels east to London for the next round of shows, we look at some of our favorite photos from a week that felt familiar and reinvented.

headline: The Bureau of Land Management is moving back to Washington.
abstract: The Trump administration had moved the agency’s headquarters to Colorado. Interior Secretary Deb Haaland said that office would become the agency’s ‘Western headquarters.’
lead_paragraph: Interior Secretary Deb Haaland announced Friday that the Bureau of Land Management will move its headquarters back to Washington, a reversal of a heavily criticized Trump administration decision to relocate the public lands agency to Grand Junction, Colo.

headline: Odette Downgraded to Post-Tropical Cyclone on Its Way to Newfoundland
abstract: The storm is expected to unleash strong winds and heavy rains in Newfoundland, in Canada, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Odette, which formed on Friday off the Mid-Atlantic coast as a tropical storm, was downgraded to a post-tropical cyclone on Saturday afternoon as it barreled toward Newfoundland, in Canada, forecasters said.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Adam Tooze
abstract: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Adam Tooze. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Adam Tooze. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: SpaceX’s large cupola gave the astronauts, and us, a new window on planet Earth.
abstract: The Inspiration4 mission was able to test out a big window to see back to Earth and out into space.
lead_paragraph: The astronauts on the Inspiration4 mission finally gave people on Earth a good look through their cupola on Friday. That’s a fancy word for dome.

headline: She Changed Black Literature Forever. Then She Disappeared.
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In search of Gayl Jones, whose new novel breaks 22 years of silence.
lead_paragraph: I knew from the beginning that I would not meet Gayl Jones.

headline: Afghanistan, Pfizer, Arc de Triomphe: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Endless Facebook Apology
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Wearable Computing', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Computers and the Internet', 'internal-sub-only']
abstract: It’s shocking but hardly surprising.
lead_paragraph: In March of 2018, I interviewed Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce, at the top of the company’s San Francisco tower. He offered up an astonishing metaphor when I asked him for his take on the impact of social media companies.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The F.D.A. rules on boosters
lead_paragraph: After weeks of heated debate, an F.D.A. advisory panel voted against approving a booster shot for people 16 and older who received the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The panel did recommend a booster for Pfizer-BioNTech recipients who are 65 or older, or are at high risk of severe Covid-19.

headline: Memorial Along National Mall Offers Stark Reminder of Virus’s Toll
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of white flags honor the more than 670,000 people in the United States who have died from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Peering at a sea of white flags blanketing the National Mall, Dr. Laura A. Valleni recalled the scores of pregnant women who had contracted the coronavirus at her hospital in South Carolina. Babies have been born prematurely, mothers have died and a surge of children has overwhelmed the pediatric unit for the past two months, she said.

headline: Tim Cook Faces Surprising Employee Unrest at Apple
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Discrimination', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Hundreds of current and former Apple workers are complaining about their work environment, a rarity for the once tight-lipped company.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, known among its Silicon Valley peers for a secretive corporate culture in which workers are expected to be in lock step with management, is suddenly facing an issue that would have been unthinkable a few years ago: employee unrest.

headline: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Recommends Pfizer Boosters for Older People and Others at High Risk
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Preventive Medicine', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The committee said there was insufficient evidence to recommend third shots for all adult recipients of the vaccine, as Pfizer had requested.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A key advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration overwhelmingly rejected recommending Pfizer booster shots for most recipients of the company’s coronavirus vaccine, instead endorsing them only for people who are 65 or older or at high risk of severe Covid-19, and received their second dose at least six months ago.

headline: And Then There Were 9: The Road Ahead for Pro-Impeachment House Republicans
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: The 10 G.O.P. lawmakers who voted to impeach Donald Trump face angry primary voters and challengers inspired or endorsed by the former president. So far, only one has given up on re-election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Representative Anthony Gonzalez of Ohio looked into his political future, he saw a brutal primary contest against a Trump-backed opponent for the chance to return to a Trump-dominated House Republican caucus.

headline: Robert Durst Found Guilty of Murder After Decades of Suspicion
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Mr. Durst, the onetime heir to a Manhattan real estate empire, was convicted of killing a close confidante in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 2000.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robert A. Durst, the enigmatic real estate scion who evaded criminal suspicion for half his life only to become a national sensation after damaging admissions were aired in a 2015 documentary on HBO, was convicted on Friday in the execution-style murder of a close confidante more than 20 years ago.

headline: Indigenous Issues Are Sidelined in Canada’s Election
abstract: The discovery of over 1,000 remains in unmarked graves at former residential schools started a dialogue that hardly surfaced in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: As the 36-day snap election called by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau staggers toward Monday’s vote, the Liberals and the Conservatives remain locked in a statistical tie in the polls.

headline: Sidelined on Jan. 6, Walker Has Top Job Securing Capitol Against a Repeat
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: William J. Walker has testified about how his requests for approval to deploy the National Guard on Jan. 6 went unanswered. Now it falls to him to prevent another rampage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a mob of President Donald J. Trump’s supporters rampaged through the Capitol on Jan. 6, William J. Walker, who was commanding the District of Columbia National Guard, watched helplessly, waiting for hours for approval to deploy his troops to help a badly overrun police force put down the deadly riot.

headline: Secret Talks and a Hidden Agenda: Behind the U.S. Defense Deal That France Called a ‘Betrayal’
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Contracts', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'International Relations', 'Arms Trade', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: In meeting after meeting with their French counterparts, U.S. officials gave no heads-up about their plans to upend France’s largest defense contract.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Australia went to extraordinary lengths to keep Paris in the dark as they secretly negotiated a plan to build nuclear submarines, scuttling France’s largest defense contract and so enraging President Emmanuel Macron that on Friday he ordered the withdrawal of France’s ambassadors to both nations.

headline: How Hope, Fear and Misinformation Led Thousands of Haitians to the U.S. Border
abstract: Some left to find work. Others to escape violence or racial discrimination in other countries. But many believe ‘there is nothing to go back to.’
lead_paragraph: DEL RIO, Texas — They have arrived this week by the thousands, Haitians who had heard of an easy way into the United States. In what appeared to be an endless procession across the shallow waters of the Rio Grande, they carried mattresses, fruit, diapers and blankets, provisions to tide them over while they awaited their turn to plead for entry into America.

headline: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Algeria’s Longest-Serving President, Dies at 84
abstract: He joined the country’s fight for independence in the 1950s and helped lead it out of a brutal civil war in the 1990s. He was ousted in 2019 after 20 years in office,
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who joined his country’s fight against French colonial rule in the 1950s, rose to foreign minister at 26, went into exile over corruption charges and then returned to help lead the nation out of civil war, has died, He was 84.

headline: Home of a Massive Flock
abstract: Ryan McCarty takes some risks, but ends up pleasing the crowd.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Am I preaching to the choir when I say, “phew”? It feels like weeks since I’ve seen a Saturday grid I can actually break into, instead of breaking into a cold sweat. Maybe we’ve paid our penance. Ryan McCarty has constructed a positively fearless puzzle with a big, splashy set of debuts that are bound to evoke a strong reaction of one kind or another.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘It’s Always Going to Haunt Me’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 18, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no manual on how to deal with an insurrection.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 18, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 18, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about an appeal by the Justice Department to block a bankruptcy plan that would grant broad legal immunity to Purdue Pharma misstated the timing of OxyContin’s introduction to the market. It was 25 years ago, not 15 years ago.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Unconventional Weapon Against Future Wildfires: Goats
keywords: ['Goats', 'Wildfires', 'Sustainable Living', 'Livestock', 'Weeds', 'Grass', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Lani Malmberg travels with a few hundred goats, which eat the tall brush and grasses that power Western wildfires.
lead_paragraph: When megafires burn in unison and harsh droughts parch the West, local governments, utilities and companies struggle with how to prevent outbreaks, especially as each year brings record destruction.

headline: Was Occupy Wall Street the ‘Beginning of the Beginning’?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: In “Generation Occupy,” Michael Levitin argues that the 2011 protest against income inequality shaped both the substance and style of American politics.
lead_paragraph: GENERATION OCCUPYReawakening American DemocracyBy Michael Levitin

headline: When 7 Psychopaths Enroll at the Same School, Terror Ensues
abstract: In her latest column, Sarah Lyall weighs in on Vera Kurian’s twisted tale, “Never Saw Me Coming,” and two other new thrillers.
lead_paragraph: For a psychopath, Chloe Sevre is unusually astute about what social media can say about a person. “Will Bachman drinks too much and hangs out with people who don’t look after him,” she notes, analyzing the Instagram account of a fellow college student she intends to murder in Vera Kurian’s NEVER SAW ME COMING (Park Row, 400 pp., $27.99). “Will Bachman has 60 days to live.”

headline: Some Rich People Are Counting Their Antibodies ‘Like Calories’
abstract: Medical concierge services are offering coronavirus antibody tests as a perk, despite caveats about their usefulness.
lead_paragraph: Before Juhi Singh, 46, who owns a high-end wellness center on the Upper East Side, jetted off to the Amalfi Coast last month, she packed her bathing suits and left her 10-year-old son with his grandmother.

headline: Harassed and Harangued, Poll Workers Now Have a New Form of Defense
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)']
abstract: Threatened by extremists and under fire by politicians, election workers now have their own legal defense network. It’s a perk they never expected to need.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is perhaps a metaphor for the times that even the volunteer who checked you into the polls in November now has a legal defense committee.

headline: Having Trouble Finding Your Soul Mate? Let Mom Do It for You.
abstract: As vaccine rollout continues, the pressures of online dating are back. So is the idea of outsourcing the matchmaking to your Jewish parents.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that online dating can be a stultifying, painful and sometimes traumatizing experience.

headline: A Multifaceted Designer Gets a New Platform
abstract: Emmanuel Olunkwa is named editor of Pin-Up, the fashionable architectural and design magazine.
lead_paragraph: Name: Emmanuel Olunkwa

headline: In Portraits, Seared Memories of the Capitol Riot
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Photography']
abstract: In an interview, the photographer Jason  Andrew described the inspiration behind the portraits published in The Times this week and recalled his experience covering the violence of Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Times published interviews with six people — two lawmakers, two congressional staff members and two Capitol Police officers — who were inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. when rioters broke into the building. Accompanying those interviews are portraits taken this summer by the photographer Jason Andrew, who covered the violence in Washington that day for The Times. Below, he talks about his pictures, filming video portraits at 125 frames per second and his experience photographing the riot. This interview, the result of two conversations, has been condensed and edited.

headline: 100 Isn’t a Magic Number, So Why Is It Part of the Vaccine Mandate?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Small Business', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The threshold of 100 employees adds to a patchwork of small-business rules. It shows up in no other major small-business laws. The reasoning behind the number is a mystery.
lead_paragraph: When the Biden administration announced an upcoming mandate that employees be vaccinated or tested regularly at companies with 100 or more employees, business leaders responded with a barrage of questions. Among smaller companies, one loomed especially large: Why 100?

headline: As Climate Change Fears Grow, a Real Fight Over Fake Turf
keywords: ['Grass', 'Politics and Government', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Playgrounds', 'Chemicals']
abstract: A city’s decision to replace actual grass with a synthetic version sets off a conflict over the possible environmental and health risks of the move.
lead_paragraph: EAST ORANGE, N.J. — Residents near a small neighborhood park in New Jersey awoke early this month to the roaring sound of heavy machinery: A grassy field they had been begging officials to fix for years was finally getting a face-lift.

headline: They Shunned Covid Vaccines but Embraced Antibody Treatment
keywords: ['Antibodies', 'Shortages', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Hospitals', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Championed by doctors and conservative radio hosts alike, monoclonal antibodies for Covid are in high demand — even from those who don’t want a vaccine.
lead_paragraph: Lanson Jones did not think that the coronavirus would come for him. An avid tennis player in Houston who had not caught so much as a cold during the pandemic, he had refused a vaccine because he worried that it would spoil his streak of good health.

headline: The Scientist and the A.I.-Assisted, Remote-Control Killing Machine
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Firearms', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Remote Control Systems', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Israeli agents had wanted to kill Iran’s top nuclear scientist for years. Then they came up with a way to do it with no operatives present.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s top nuclear scientist woke up an hour before dawn, as he did most days, to study Islamic philosophy before his day began.

headline: The Covid Crisis Is Now a Garbage Crisis, Too
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Recycling of Waste Materials']
abstract: Overblown fears that the coronavirus could be transmitted through surfaces have created a stigma around handling nonhazardous trash, experts say. Some recyclable waste has been junked or burned.
lead_paragraph: Across Brazil, recycling plants stopped running for months. In Uganda, a junkyard is short on reusable plastics. And in Indonesia’s capital, disposable gloves and face shields are piling up at a river mouth.

headline: Why Taxing Stock Buybacks Is the Wrong Fix for Executive Pay
abstract: The supposed link between buybacks and inequality is unproven.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. This week, the financial journalist Roger Lowenstein weighs in on a plan by Senate Democrats to tax stock buybacks. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Jeff Probst Is the Ultimate ‘Survivor’
abstract: Despite many changes to the reality show over the last 21 years, he has been a constant.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Probst was halfway to Fiji when he got the call. It was mid-March 2020, days before “Survivor” was scheduled to begin filming, and he was on vacation with his family in Hawaii when he learned that months of work and preparation would have to be suspended immediately. The show’s crew — around 400 people — were suddenly out of work. Plans to shoot the show domestically were investigated and scrapped.

headline: Despite Censorship and Poor Internet, Cuban Podcasts Are Booming
abstract: New audio shows made in Cuba are finding a rapt audience and upending the island’s hyperpartisan media landscape.
lead_paragraph: There has been little to laugh about in Cuba lately. But on a recent episode of El Enjambre, a weekly podcast produced on the island, the three hosts were howling at the latest form of censorship by the state-run telecommunications company.

headline: In Senegal, Demand for Covid Vaccines Grows, but They’re Hard to Get
abstract: As rumors and misinformation about coronavirus vaccines gradually subside and the West African country emerges from a third wave, Senegalese are less reluctant to take a shot.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — When Mbaye Ndiaye, a science teacher in Senegal, arrived in his classroom after getting his first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine in April, his pupils burst into a round of applause. Surprised, he asked them what they were congratulating him for.

headline: Sparse Right-Wing Protest of Jan. 6 Arrests Draws Huge Police Response
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Organizers said the police response had dampened turnout for the “Justice for J6” rally, which served as a platform for pro-Trump politicians seeking House seats next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fewer than 100 right-wing demonstrators, sharply outnumbered by an overwhelming police presence and even by reporters, gathered at the foot of the Capitol on Saturday to denounce what they called the mistreatment of “political prisoners” who had stormed the building on Jan. 6.

headline: A Metronome of Power Keeps the White Sox Humming
abstract: Jose Abreu is known for picking up checks, crowding the plate and driving in runs — a lot of runs. He is quiet in the news media, but his teammates have plenty to say about him.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Going out to dinner with Jose Abreu, the reigning winner of the American League Most Valuable Player Award, can be a challenge. At least it is for his teammates on the Chicago White Sox who try to pay their fair share.

headline: Do I Need to Clean Up My Attic Before I List My House?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Sellers should focus on the rooms where people spend the most time, but if you have the budget and time, staging the attic can offer a bonus for buyers.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am about to put my house on the market, and would like to feature the large, open, unfinished attic for potential finishing and use. Presently, it has unpainted plywood flooring. Do you have any suggestions for how to best stage this space, with minimal cost and work?

headline: Never Complain, Never Explain
abstract: Drop the Identity Cloak when identity is not the issue. (And tax the rich!)
lead_paragraph: What ever happened to the good old-fashioned art of Owning It?

headline: An F.D.A. panel’s vote deals the Biden administration’s push for universal booster shots a setback.
abstract: The panel recommended against blanket access to Pfizer boosters for those 16 and older, but urged offering them to those 65 and older and “at high risk,” a term that offers the White House some room to expand access.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s push to make Covid-19 booster shots available to most fully vaccinated adults has been stymied for now by a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel’s recommendation that Pfizer-BioNTech boosters be made available only to those 65 and over and those at high risk of severe Covid.

headline: A Political Road Not Taken in America
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'History (Academic Subject)']
abstract: A brief look at the Confederate Constitution.
lead_paragraph: I have recently spent a lot of time reading about the Confederate government and the Confederate Constitution for a small project I’m participating in. It’s been a fascinating exercise in large part because I did not actually know that much about either. I have a strong working knowledge of the secession crisis, the Civil War and many of the personalities involved in both, but I was not as knowledgeable about the structure of the Confederate government itself or the particular provisions of its constitution.

headline: Religious Beliefs and Abortion Laws
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Abortion', 'Christians and Christianity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: How religious belief affect abortion laws and vaccination.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Our Drug Supply Is Sick. How Can We Fix It?
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Shortages', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Competition for market share at rock-bottom prices has led to shortages, price spikes, allegations of price-fixing and substandard and even dangerous practices.
lead_paragraph: The American health care system is built on the idea that a pill is a pill. Generic drugs are considered equal to and interchangeable with one another — and also with the name brand. This gospel has existed since 1984, when a law known as Hatch-Waxman was passed, allowing companies to make drugs that had gone off patent without having to replicate the same expensive clinical trials. For the most part, all they had to do was prove that the generic was manufactured using good practices and worked in the body in a similar way, within an acceptable range.

headline: The Deeper Problem Behind General Milley’s ‘Secret Phone Calls’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A story about the Joint Chiefs chairman near the end of  Trump’s presidency may not be as bad as it sounds. But there’s still cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: A new book reports that Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, improperly restricted the president of the United States’ ability to use military force and committed to warning China, an American adversary, of any impending U.S. military action against it. If the book, “Peril,” by Bob Woodward and Robert Costa, accurately recounts General Milley’s behavior, his actions could be an egregious series of violations of the norms that govern civil-military relations in the United States.

headline: First Tied to ISIS, Then to U.S.: Family in Drone Strike Is Tarnished Twice
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Apologies', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The U.S. admission that a drone strike that killed 10 civilians was a “tragic mistake” did nothing to ease the sense of vulnerability among surviving family members and co-workers living under Taliban rule.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Pentagon’s admission of having made a “tragic mistake” in the killing of an Afghan aid worker, and seven children from his extended family in a drone strike, added one more incident to the long, grievous list of U.S. military mistakes in Afghanistan.

headline: Variety: Takeaway Crossword
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners resurrects a fu* diversio*.
lead_paragraph: TAKEAWAY CROSSWORD — Today we have a real novelty, a puzzle that puts our deductive ability to the test in a way that looks simple but develops into satisfying complexity. I went to the archives to see if it was new, and found that The New York Times has run three of them before, all by Matt Ginsburg, between 2009 and 2015. Alex Eaton-Salners constructed today’s grid; variety connoisseurs may be reminded of another of his specialties, the “Going Too Far” puzzles. Easy directions lead to a creative workout and a challenging solve.

headline: The N.F.L. Bets on Betting
abstract: Gambling on football has come out of the shadows.
lead_paragraph: If you watched the N.F.L.’s first weekend of action, there is a good chance you saw more ads for BetMGM, FanDuel and Caesars Sportsbook than you had ever seen in your life. The N.F.L. now has an official casino sponsor (Caesars) and partnerships with seven sports books. Nearly 60 million football bets were processed online in the United States last weekend — likely an all-time high — and the N.F.L. was probably thrilled about every single one of them.

headline: Biden’s Entire Presidential Agenda Rests on Expansive Spending Bill
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'American Families Plan (2021)', 'American Jobs Plan (2021)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A plan for the economy, education, immigration, climate and more binds disparate Democratic lawmakers, but the proposal risks sinking under its own weight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No president has ever packed as much of his agenda, domestic and foreign, into a single piece of legislation as President Biden has with the $3.5 trillion spending plan that Democrats are trying to wrangle through Congress over the next six weeks.

headline: Texas Lawmakers, After a Rightward Shift, Plan for More of the Same
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Voting Rights, Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The state recently completed one of its most conservative legislative sessions, widening a divide among many residents.
lead_paragraph: WALLER COUNTY, Texas — At a roadside bar on farm road 359, where the sprawl of Houston gives way to horse stables and hay rolls, Cindy Schmid and her friend Gail Mikeska gather every Thursday to eat, drink and talk about everything: family, country music, the hard right turn of Texas politics.

headline: Three Weeks After Hurricane Ida, Parts of Southeast Louisiana Are Still Dark
keywords: ['Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: As businesses and schools have reopened in New Orleans, ongoing power outages in communities just beyond the city put recovery out of reach.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — For Tiffany Brown, the drive home from New Orleans begins as usual: She can see the lights on in the city’s central business district and people gathering in bars and restaurants. But as she drives west along Interstate 10, signs of Hurricane Ida’s destruction emerge. Trees with missing limbs fill the swamp on either side of the highway. With each passing mile, more blue tarps appear on rooftops, and more electric poles lay fallen by the road, some snapped in half.

headline: Trudeau Seeks a Fresh Start, but Many Voters See a Power Grab
abstract: A snap election that was supposed to be a show of strength has instead allowed opponents to highlight the prime minister’s weak points.
lead_paragraph: BURNABY, British Columbia — Outside a TV studio in a Vancouver suburb where Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada was recording an interview days ahead of the country’s election, a man shouted insults, mostly obscene, about Mr. Trudeau and his family while blasting Twisted Sister’s “We’re Not Gonna Take It” from a stereo on a cart.

headline: ‘There Is Chaos’: Iran-Backed Militias Battle Activists in a Holy Iraqi City
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Militia violence has driven antigovernment protesters underground and shaken Karbala, a city of gold-domed Shiite shrines.
lead_paragraph: KARBALA, Iraq — One night in May, Samira Abbas Kadhim was up late, waiting for her son. She poked her head out of the gate of their small house, looking for him down the narrow street.

headline: Biden Administration to Deport Haitians in South Texas
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The U.S. will begin flying migrants back to Haiti and other countries on Sunday as President Biden struggles to manage an immigration system already buckling under record migration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Saturday that it would swiftly begin deporting Haitians who have gathered in the thousands at the southern border in the past week after illegally entering the United States, as it struggled to manage an escalating crisis.

headline: Submarine Deal Gives Post-Brexit Britain Its Moment on the Global Stage
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The British government played an early role in brokering the alliance with the U.S. and Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines in the Pacific, officials in London and Washington said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As relations between France and the United States sink to their lowest depths in decades, Britain has emerged as the unlikely winner in a maritime security alliance that has sowed anger and recrimination across three continents.

headline: Health experts voice support for opening booster access to older and at-risk Americans.
abstract: Some, however, wondered why the cutoff age is 65, and not 60.
lead_paragraph: American health experts spoke out on social media and other platforms on Friday and Saturday to applaud the likelihood that federal regulators could soon make Pfizer-BioNTech booster shots available for those 65 and older or at high risk of severe Covid-19, though some argued that the cutoff age should be lower.

headline: In Orange County, the Recall’s Defeat Echoes Years of G.O.P. Erosion
abstract: Voters struck down the effort to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom, continuing the political seesawing that has defined the former Republican stronghold.
lead_paragraph: LADERA RANCH, Calif. — When Gail Grigaux first moved to Ladera Ranch in Orange County from the East Coast more than 15 years ago, she knew she had arrived in the conservative heart of Southern California.

headline: Joe Manchin Got the Voting Bill He Wanted. Time to Pass It.
keywords: ['Voting Rights, Registration and Requirements', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Congress needs to protect voting rights. Now.
lead_paragraph: Far too many Republicans are players in a cynical pantomime: They say that the new voting restrictions being passed across the nation are designed solely to thwart widespread voting fraud, when the reality is that widespread fraud does not exist and the new restrictions’ purpose is to frustrate and disadvantage voters who lean Democratic — especially minority, young and lower-income voters.

headline: What if Covid Were 10 Times Deadlier?
abstract: Would a deadlier pandemic have yielded different political divides?
lead_paragraph: “I think I’ve come to believe that even if the Covid death toll was 10 times what it currently is,” the MSNBC host Chris Hayes wrote a few days ago on Twitter, “the politics of all of it wouldn’t be appreciably different.”

headline: A Week After the Open, Championship Tennis Continues in Queens
abstract: A Davis Cup tie between South Africa and Venezuela is being held in front of a small group of fans at the West Side Tennis Club — the first Davis Cup action there since 1959.
lead_paragraph: A week has passed since the United States Open electrified the tennis world with its enchanting unpredictability and rejuvenated fan base. But unknown to many, top flight tennis lingered in New York City as the Davis Cup made a quiet and unusual return to the West Side Tennis Club.

headline: Coming up soon: The astronauts return to Earth.
abstract: Barring issues with the weather, the crew will splash down near sun down.
lead_paragraph: After three days in orbit, the crew of the Inspiration4 mission — the first trip to orbit where no one aboard is a professional astronaut — is headed home to Earth.

headline: The Delta variant is detected in 99% of U.S. cases, according to C.D.C.
abstract: The highly infectious variant of Covid-19 has contributed to a rise in cases, hospitalizations and deaths in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The extremely transmissible Delta variant of the coronavirus, which overtook all other variants in the United States just a few months ago, now represents more than 99 percent of cases tracked in the country, according to the data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Bennie Pete, Bandleader Who Kept the Beat After Katrina, Dies at 45
abstract: A tuba player and the leader of the Hot 8, one of New Orleans’s high-profile brass bands, he brought music to his fellow citizens in the difficult days after the storm.
lead_paragraph: Bennie Pete, a New Orleans tuba player who co-founded and led the Hot 8, one of the city’s high-profile brass bands, and dedicated himself to preserving the musical traditions of the Big Easy after Hurricane Katrina, died on Sept. 6 at a hospital there. He was 45.

headline: Rep. Lee Zeldin Confirms Leukemia Diagnosis
abstract: Mr. Zeldin, a conservative Republican, says the disease is in remission, and that his bid for governor of New York will be unaffected.
lead_paragraph: Representative Lee Zeldin, a staunch conservative from Long Island and the leading Republican candidate in next year’s race for governor in New York, revealed that he was diagnosed with leukemia last year and has been receiving treatment.

headline: Covid-stricken Alabama had more deaths than births last year, a first in its recorded history.
abstract: “Our state literally shrunk in 2020,” said Dr. Scott Harris, the state’s health officer.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in Alabama’s known history, the state had more deaths than births in 2020 — a grim milestone that underscores the pandemic’s calamitous toll.

headline: Adalberto Álvarez, Latin Dance Music Maestro, Is Dead at 72
abstract: He was known as the “Gentleman of Son” because of his infectious enthusiasm for repopularizing the genre considered the bedrock of the Cuban sound.
lead_paragraph: Adalberto Álvarez, one of Cuba’s most celebrated musicians, who as a bandleader helped revive and refashion Cuban son, a fusion of European and African styles and instruments that was vital to Latin dance music, died on Sept. 1 in a hospital in Havana. He was 72.

headline: California’s governor says two of his children have tested positive for the coronavirus.
abstract: Gavin Newsom’s office said the state’s first family was “following all Covid protocols.”
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, who four days ago beat back a pandemic-fueled attempt to recall him, is “following all Covid protocols” with his family after two of his four children tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: New Look
abstract: Peter Gordon’s grid requires one’s full focus.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Peter Gordon has been contributing puzzles to The Times like clockwork for over three decades. Most have been themed, and the ones that I remember the best have involved the elegant manipulation of letters to turn something ordinary into something surprising. This grid falls neatly into that category.

headline: Lions and tigers at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo test positive for the virus.
abstract: It is unclear how the animals were infected.
lead_paragraph: Lions and tigers and Covid? Oh my. Some of the lions and tigers of the Smithsonian’s National Zoo & Conservation Biology Institute in Washington, D.C., have tested positive for the virus that causes Covid-19.

headline: Yolanda López, Artist Who Celebrated Working-Class Women, Dies at 78
abstract: She was celebrated for recasting the Virgin of Guadalupe in her own image as a feminist superhero — a young, strong, brown woman in running shoes.
lead_paragraph: Yolanda López, an artist and activist who created one of the most famous artworks in Chicano history by boldly recasting the Virgin of Guadalupe in her own image — as a young, strong, brown woman wearing running shoes and a wide grin — died on Sept. 3 at her home in San Francisco. She was 78.

headline: Are water landings from space safe?
abstract: SpaceX has completed two successful earlier water landings, one at night.
lead_paragraph: Returning from the free-fall environment of orbit to the normal forces of gravity on Earth is often disorienting for astronauts. A water landing adds the possibility of seasickness.

headline: The Inspiration4 flight showed space tourism’s potential and limitations.
abstract: A crew of everypersons showed what space tourism could become in the future.
lead_paragraph: When NASA owned and operated its own spacecraft, there was no chance it would rent out a Saturn 5 rocket or a space shuttle to someone else. But during the Obama administration, NASA decided to hire private companies to take its astronauts to the space station. One of the program’s secondary goals was to spur more commercial use of low-Earth orbit.

headline: Peter Williams, 69, Dies; His Art Evoked Black Lives, Including His
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Art', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: His colorful works could be quite personal, or they could be blunt responses to police brutality or other news of the day.
lead_paragraph: Peter Williams, whose colorful paintings — sometimes humorous, sometimes disturbing, often both — reflected his own history, Black history and contemporary issues like police brutality and mass incarceration, died on Aug. 19 in Wilmington, Del. He was 69.

headline: Stabilized Notre-Dame Cathedral Is on Track for 2024 Reopening, Officials Say
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The restoration effort is seeking to meet President Emmanuel Macron’s ambitious plan to reopen the cathedral five years after it was ravaged by a fire — just in time for the 2024 Olympics in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Two and a half years after a fire ravaged the centuries-old Cathedral of Notre-Dame in the heart of Paris, the building has been secured enough to start the rebuilding process, which is expected to be completed in 2024, according to the French authorities.

headline: SpaceX astronauts will get a health check after splashdown.
abstract: While the Inspiration4 crew was only in orbit for three days, doctors will performing screenings to make sure they are well.
lead_paragraph: When astronauts return to Earth from space, they can experience a number of health and physical issues after they land — a result of living without gravity.

headline: Texas Doctor Says He Performed an Abortion in Defiance of New State Law
keywords: ['Abortion', "Women's Rights", 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: In an opinion essay in The Washington Post titled “Why I violated Texas’s extreme abortion ban,” Dr. Alan Braid wrote, “I am taking a personal risk, but it’s something I believe in strongly.”
lead_paragraph: A Texas doctor disclosed on Saturday that he had performed an abortion in defiance of a new state law that bans most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, setting up a potential test case of one of the most restrictive abortion measures in the nation.

headline: Footage Reveals New Details in Tourist Melee at N.Y.C. Restaurant
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Restaurants', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Vaccination Proof and Immunization Records', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Three Black women from Texas were arrested, but a lawyer for one called it “mutual combat” after they were called a racial slur.
lead_paragraph: New information emerged on Saturday about a brawl outside a popular Italian restaurant in Manhattan that raises questions about initial accounts of the altercation, in which the police said they arrested three women from Texas after they attacked a hostess who had asked them to provide proof of their vaccination status.

headline: Inspiration4 Astronauts Beam After Return From 3-Day Journey to Orbit
keywords: ['Private Spaceflight', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Travel and Vacations', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The mission hinted at what space travel could look like in a more accessible future, while remaining in reach now to only the richest of the rich.
lead_paragraph: After three days in orbit, a physician assistant, a community college professor, a data engineer and the billionaire who financed their trip arrived back on Earth, heralding a new era of space travel with a dramatic and successful Saturday evening landing in the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Israel Captures Last 2 Palestinian Inmates Still Free After Prison Break
abstract: Six prisoners had tunneled out of a maximum-security facility on Sept. 6, in an embarrassment for Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel on Sunday captured the last of the six Palestinian inmates who escaped a maximum-security prison nearly two weeks ago, ending an episode that Israelis saw as a humiliation of their security establishment and Palestinians celebrated as a rare black eye for the Israeli occupation.

headline: Carl Nassib Made History, but Also a Big Play
abstract: Last week Nassib, 28, became the first openly gay player to compete in an N.F.L. game. Teammates, the news media and observers casually noted the feat, then cheered his game-changing play.
lead_paragraph: One of the most significant cultural milestones in the recent history of North American sports occurred with about as much pomp and circumstance as a shrug of the shoulders.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Texas Lawmakers, After Shift to Right, Plan More of Same
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 19, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “Texans are watching their state government that is consumed with these partisan debates over abortion and election reform, but they’re actually living in a state where schools can’t give clear safety guidance on Covid. The concern is that the conservative faction has gone too far and is damaging our state’s reputation.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 19, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 19, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 44 this weekend about dance events this fall misstates the last name of a founder of FLOCK. He is Florian Lochner, not Lockner.

headline: Evergrande Gave Workers a Choice: Lend Us Cash or Lose Your Bonus
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The Chinese property giant owes $300 billion and is on the hook for as many as 1.6 million apartments. It may owe tens of thousands of its employees money, too.
lead_paragraph: When the troubled Chinese property giant Evergrande was starved for cash earlier this year, it turned to its own employees with a strong-arm pitch: Those who wanted to keep their bonuses would have to give Evergrande a short-term loan.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘My Heart Started Pounding When I Realized I Was That Someone’
abstract: Distressed on the Dumbo pier, meeting a college basketball legend and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Life After Proclaiming a Trump Re-election as Divinely Ordained
keywords: ['Pentecostal Churches', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'audio-neutral-informative']
abstract: When you are in the business of prophecy, what do you do when prophecy fails?
lead_paragraph: This spring, the media mogul Stephen E. Strang made an unusual apology to readers in the pages of his glossy magazine.

headline: In the Heart of Nashville, Rolling Parties Rage at Every Stoplight
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Buses', 'Parties (Social)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Noise', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: As Nashville’s popularity has grown, so has the “transportainment” business — a motley assortment including old buses, farm tractors and a truck with a hot tub. Many think it has gotten out of hand.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The John Deere tractor pulled onto Broadway and rumbled into the madness.

headline: Ruth Ozeki’s Borgesian, Zen Buddhist Parable of Consumerism
abstract: In “The Book of Form and Emptiness,” the characters are so preoccupied with material possessions that objects come to life all around them.
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF FORM AND EMPTINESS By Ruth Ozeki

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Biden Administration Seeks to Expand Telehealth in Rural America
keywords: ['Telemedicine', 'Rural Areas', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'American Rescue Plan (2021)']
abstract: New funding will allow more medical appointments to take place via video in rural communities, where some of the nation’s oldest and sickest patients live.
lead_paragraph: The roughly 15 percent of the population living in rural America includes some of the oldest and sickest patients in the country — a disparity that has grown more stark during the coronavirus pandemic. The Biden administration is investing more in telemedicine, whose use has grown sharply during the pandemic, as a way to improve their access to care.

headline: The ‘Murdaugh Murders’: What to Know About the South Carolina Mystery
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Falls', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Legal Profession', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Embezzlement', 'Insurance', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The unsolved killings of a lawyer’s wife and son have brought new scrutiny to three other deaths in recent years.
lead_paragraph: ISLANDTON, S.C. — The unsolved killing of a mother and son. Millions of dollars in stolen funds. Fresh investigations into a fatal boat crash and a housekeeper’s deadly fall.

headline: A New Covid Testing Model Aims to Spare Students From Quarantine
abstract: More school districts are embracing “test-to-stay” protocols that allow uninfected close contacts to remain in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: When the schools in Marietta, Ga., opened their doors on Aug. 3, the highly contagious Delta variant was sweeping across the South, and children were not being spared.

headline: Alabama Begins Removing Racist Language From Its Constitution
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'Voting Rights, Registration and Requirements', 'Discrimination', 'Politics and Government', 'Constitutions', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Many outdated provisions have long since been invalidated, but the language that was specifically intended to enshrine white supremacy has remained.
lead_paragraph: The last time Alabama politicians rewrote their State Constitution, back in 1901, their aspirations were explicitly racist: “to establish white supremacy in this state.”

headline: How Accounting Giants Craft Favorable Tax Rules From Inside Government
keywords: ['Tax Shelters', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Taxation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Lawyers from top accounting firms do brief stints in the Treasury Department, with the expectation of big raises when they return.
lead_paragraph: For six years, Audrey Ellis and Adam Feuerstein worked together at PwC, the giant accounting firm, helping the world’s biggest companies avoid taxes.

headline: Alabama Barely Edges Out Florida in SEC Opener
abstract: Florida’s second-half surge took the Crimson Tide by surprise but was not enough to topple No. 1 Alabama.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — Ben Hill Griffin Stadium has quieted down. A game that was much closer than many expected had the Gators’ fans permeating the air with deafening chants as they made one last effort to will their team past the Alabama Crimson Tide.

headline: Booster Shots, France, Fall Books: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Composer at the Frontier of Movie Music’
abstract: Nicholas Britell’s scores — for “Succession,” “Moonlight” and “The Underground Railroad,” among others — suggest whole new ways of writing for film and television.
lead_paragraph: You have almost certainly heard Nicholas Britell’s music, even if you don’t know his name. More than any other contemporary composer, he appears to have the whole of music history at his command, shifting easily between vocabularies, often in the same film.

headline: The Week in Business: A Milestone in Space Tourism
abstract: Plus, a tax plan is proposed and the government will weigh in on booster shots.
lead_paragraph: A SpaceX rocket carrying four Americans blasted off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Wednesday. The orbital spaceflight was the first to carry only passengers who weren’t professional astronauts, a milestone for the space tourism industry. In addition to SpaceX, which Elon Musk founded, Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin and Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic plan to offer commercial spaceflights. But the latest flight differed from the short jaunts that Mr. Bezos and Mr. Branson took to space in July. The crew orbited the planet for three days.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 20, 2021
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: For a TikTok Running Star, It’s All Uphill From Here
abstract: Erin Azar, a.k.a. Mrs. Space Cadet on TikTok, invited followers to join her, “a slightly overweight person who drinks too much beer,” as she trains for a marathon. She didn’t anticipate millions would respond.
lead_paragraph: Every one of Erin Azar’s runs from her home in central Pennsylvania starts with an uphill. And it makes her want to die.

headline: Madrid is set to remove most of its restrictions on Monday.
abstract: The 14-day infection rate in Spain has fallen to its lowest level since August 2020.
lead_paragraph: Madrid will remove most of its pandemic restrictions on Monday amid a general easing of lockdown rules in Spain after the country’s coronavirus infection rate fell to its lowest level in more than a year.

headline: JoJo Siwa Wants to Be ‘a Role Model for People Who Love Love’
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: At 18, the “Dance Moms” and internet star is returning to reality TV as half of the first same-sex partnership on “Dancing With the Stars.”
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, JoJo Siwa emerged as a tween wonder on the reality show “Dance Moms,” known for her brassy one-liners, rapid-fire pirouettes and rainbow-hued ensembles topped with huge hair bows.

headline: The Economic Mistake the Left Is Finally Confronting
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Welfare (US)', 'Income', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: The left needs to think as much about supply as it does about demand.
lead_paragraph: The words “supply side” are coded, in American politics, as right wing. They summon the memory of Arthur Laffer’s curve, the history of Republicans promising that cutting taxes on the rich will encourage the nation’s dispirited John Galts to work both smarter and harder, leading economies to boom and revenues to rise. This has made it vaguely disreputable to worry about the supply side of the economy. It’s as if the nonsense of phrenology had made it sordid for doctors to treat disorders of the brain.

headline: The Dangerous Politics of ‘We Will Not Forgive’
abstract: America has spent 20 years vowing revenge for terrorism. There’s a better path.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, in the somber tone and muted dress indicative of responding to tragedy, addressed the nation late last month. The Kabul airport attack had just claimed the lives of 13 American troops and over 60 Afghan civilians. He spoke movingly of the ultimate sacrifice made by our servicemen and -women. Then he turned his attention to our enemies. He said, “We will not forgive. We will not forget. We will hunt you down and make you pay.”

headline: Peter Weakens to a Tropical Depression
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Weather', 'Heat and Heat Waves', 'Global Warming', 'Cyclones']
abstract: The storm is not expected to affect the mainland United States, a meteorologist said.
lead_paragraph: Peter, now weakened to tropical depression status, was expected to bring one to two more inches of rain to parts of the Caribbean, including Puerto Rico, through Wednesday, but was otherwise not expected to affect the mainland United States directly, forecasters said.

headline: There’s a Reason Putin Keeps Winning
abstract: The Kremlin’s propaganda system, lurid and spurious, is central to the president’s power.
lead_paragraph: Elections in Russia are always tricky for the Kremlin. Offer too much choice, and citizens may pick the wrong candidates. Offer too little, and the underlying authoritarianism of the regime becomes grimly apparent.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Start with a Times classic: Marian Burros’s recipe for a delicious plum torte.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The New York Times published Marian Burros’s recipe for plum torte (above) in 1983, and did so again every September for six years. Requests for copies of that recipe continued to flood in through the 1990s, but it wasn’t until the birth of New York Times Cooking in the fall of 2014 that we could give it a permanent home. It’s a true taste of the shoulder season between summer and fall, and one of the greatest easy desserts of all time, a perfect Sunday project. Please make it with whatever fruit you can manage today, and raise a glass to Marian when you do. We walk in her footsteps every day.

headline: How Silence Became a Luxury Product
abstract: Our lives are loud — and too often it costs money to escape the noise.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I wanted to find a moment to journal, pray, and simply be still, so I went to a riverbank near my home. I sat listening to birds, eyeing the languid joy of sunbathing turtles, charting fallen leaves eddying in the green current. A roar broke the silence. A leaf blower. I tried to find a quieter spot, but leaf blowers seemed to follow me. Everywhere. It was like some secret society of leaf blowers conspired against me. I kept looking, but quiet was elusive. Wherever I went I found the whooshes of road noise, the clack-clack-clacking of construction, or the blare of televisions.

headline: When Professors Have Affairs With Students
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Medicare']
abstract: Professors and a recent college graduate respond to a guest essay. Also: Vaccine mandates; erosion of democracy; dental benefits.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Cabaret Star and an Opera Star Walk Onto a Stage …
abstract: The punchline is “Only an Octave Apart,” featuring the unlikely collaborators Justin Vivian Bond and Anthony Roth Costanzo at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: “This show has been 10 years in the making,” the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo said recently.

headline: When Covid-19 Stole Their Smell, These Experts Lost Much More
keywords: ['Smell (Olfaction)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Wines', 'Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Senses and Sensation', 'Smells and Odors']
abstract: French perfumers, sommeliers and winemakers with coronavirus infections are sometimes deprived of a crucial tool: their high-performing noses.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hélène Barre, 35, lost her sense of smell when she fell ill with Covid-19 in November, a condition known as anosmia. Her slow recovery was plagued by disturbing distortions: Peanuts smelled like shrimp, raw ham like butter, rice like Nutella. The phantom scent of something burning still bothers her for hours at a time.

headline: The New York Philharmonic Returns, in the Midst of Transitions
abstract: As the orchestra’s season opens, its music director announced he would step down, its hall is under renovation and it’s still trying to diversify.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s concert on Friday was not just a heartening return to Lincoln Center for America’s oldest orchestra, 556 days after its last performance there.

headline: Fighting a Pandemic, While Launching Africa’s Health Revolution
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Epidemics', 'Ebola Virus', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Public health in Africa has been a story of neglect and dependency, says John Nkengasong, the first director of the Africa Centers for Disease Control. But he’s on a mission to turn things around.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. John Nkengasong took the job as the first head of Africa’s new Centers for Disease Control in 2017, part of the continent had just emerged from a devastating Ebola outbreak. Less than three years later, Covid-19 hit.

headline: John Shelby Spong, 90, Dies; Sought to Open Up the Episcopal Church
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Episcopal Church', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Anglican Churches', 'Clergy']
abstract: Bishop Spong pushed for women in the clergy and same-sex marriage, and he called on his followers to reject “supernatural” aspects of Christianity.
lead_paragraph: John Shelby Spong, a charismatic Episcopal bishop who pushed his followers to accept women and L.G.B.T.Q. clergy, and who later called on them to reject sacrosanct ideas like Jesus’ virgin birth and the existence of heaven and hell, died on Sept. 12 at his home in Richmond, Va. He was 90.

headline: Fauci urges Americans not to get booster shots until they are eligible.
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Dr. Fauci is also defending President Biden’s decision to release a plan for Covid boosters before regulators had given their recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease doctor, defended President Biden’s decision last month to announce the availability of Covid booster shots before regulators had weighed in, and he urged vaccinated Americans to wait until they were eligible for an extra shot before getting one.

headline: Chris Rock says he has Covid.

headline: Mississippi’s governor plays down state’s high death rate.

headline: Haiti Protests Mass U.S. Deportation of Migrants to Country in Crisis
abstract: Haiti migration officials have asked the United States for a “humanitarian moratorium” even as they receive the first returnees from Texas. “Will we have enough to feed these people?”
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The first Haitians deported from a makeshift camp in Texas landed in their home country Sunday amid sweltering heat, anger and confusion, as Haitian officials beseeched the United States to stop the flights because the country is in crisis and cannot handle thousands of homeless deportees.

headline: Rich Countries Worry About Booster Shots. They Should Be Worried About Africa.
keywords: ['Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shortages', 'Stockpiling', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Just 20 percent of people in low- and lower-middle-income countries have had a Covid-19 vaccine dose — versus 80 percent in richer countries.
lead_paragraph: As the rich world rolls out Covid-19 booster shots, hundreds of millions of Africans remain dangerously exposed, still awaiting their first vaccine dose. This not only adds to the litany of harsh disparities we’ve seen around this virus, but it is also a scandalous injury to global solidarity and vaccine equity.

headline: This Powerful Democrat Linked to Fossil Fuels Will Craft the U.S. Climate Plan
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Coal', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Senator Joe Manchin is already a crucial swing vote in the Democrats’ sweeping budget bill. But he will also write the details of its climate change program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joe Manchin, the powerful West Virginia Democrat who chairs the Senate energy panel and earned half a million dollars last year from coal production, is preparing to remake President Biden’s climate legislation in a way that tosses a lifeline to the fossil fuel industry — despite urgent calls from scientists that countries need to quickly pivot away from coal, gas and oil to avoid a climate catastrophe.

headline: Nabisco Workers End Weekslong Strike After Reaching New Contract
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'Bonuses', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries']

lead_paragraph: A weekslong strike by Nabisco employees in five states ended on Saturday, as their union announced that its members had overwhelmingly approved a four-year contract with the parent company of the maker of Oreos, Ritz Crackers and other snacks.

headline: A Giant Violin Floats Down Venice’s Grand Canal
abstract: This 39-foot-long instrument, built by local artisans and carrying musicians performing a live concert, sets a course for the future.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — In its 1,600-odd years, any number of phantasmagorical vessels have floated down Venice’s Grand Canal, often during regattas or elaborate ceremonies dedicated to the sea. On Saturday morning, a decidedly unusual head-turner took a spin: a gigantic violin, carrying a string quartet playing Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons.”

headline: Military Jet Crashes in Texas Backyard, Injuring 2 Pilots
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']

headline: Here’s how to watch the Emmy Awards tonight.
abstract: The ceremony begins at 8 p.m. Eastern on CBS and you can watch online via cbs.com, or if you’re a CBS subscriber, via the CBS app with a cable login.
lead_paragraph: There’s sure to be both drama and comedy at the 73rd annual Primetime Emmy Awards, which will be mostly an in-person edition of the show. Hosted by Cedric the Entertainer, the comedian and star of CBS’s “The Neighborhood,” the awards will be handed out Sunday night in Los Angeles before a limited audience, and will honor the pandemic-era television programs that got us through lockdown.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: France recalls its U.S. and Australian ambassadors.
lead_paragraph: Relations between France and the U.S. have sunk to their lowest level in decades, after the U.S. and Australia secretly negotiated a plan to build nuclear submarines.

headline: Inspiration4 Civilian Crew Returns to Earth After 3 Days in Orbit

headline: Solving a Mystery

headline: Bills Offense Cruises in Low Gear to Win in Miami
abstract: In a rout of Miami, the Bills offense did not even need Josh Allen’s best. He still finished 17 of 33 passing for 179 yards and two touchdowns to take the lead in the A.F.C. East.
lead_paragraph: Every starting quarterback in the A.F.C. East was chosen in the top half of the first round within the last four N.F.L. drafts, infusing a bonanza of dynamic young talent into a division that could be — emphasis on could — sneaky competitive this season.

headline: Michael K. Williams could win an acting award posthumously.
abstract: The actor, who was found dead on Sept. 6, is nominated for best supporting actor in a drama for “Lovecraft Country,” and is a slight favorite to win.
lead_paragraph: Michael K. Williams, the beloved star of “The Wire” who was found dead on Sept. 6, is nominated for best supporting actor in a drama for the recently canceled HBO series “Lovecraft Country.” If he does win — and he is a slight favorite over Tobias Menzies from “The Crown” — it will not be because Emmys voters wanted to give him the award posthumously. The Emmy voting period ended before Williams’s death.

headline: Remains Believed to Be Missing Woman in Van Mystery Are Found
abstract: The authorities said remains found in Wyoming were consistent with a description of Gabrielle Petito, 22. She was reported missing after her fiancé returned alone from a cross-country van trip.
lead_paragraph: Human remains believed to be a Florida woman reported missing after her fiancé returned home from a monthslong van trip without her were found in a national park in Wyoming on Sunday, the F.B.I. said at a news conference.

Those teams have losing records and no hope of the playoffs. The Yankees, in the more rugged American League East, are part of the pennant race.

headline: Who is Gabrielle Petito?
abstract: Gabrielle Petito had worked as a pharmacy technician to save money for a crosscountry trip with her boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, the family of Gabrielle Petito reported her missing to the North Port, Fla., police department. She seemed to have disappeared in the western United States during a cross-country trip with her fiancé, Brian Laundrie, who returned to his home in North Port without Ms. Petito, 22, on Sept. 1.

headline: ‘Mare of Easttown’ takes both supporting actor awards for limited series.

Thus far Sunday night,  the HBO crime drama has already claimed both supporting acting awards for a limited or anthology series or movie.

headline: How the U.S. Helped, and Hampered, the Escape of Afghan Journalists

headline: With ‘The Crown,’ Netflix Finally Takes the Emmys Throne
abstract: The lush Netflix series chronicling the British royal family took home the four major acting awards as well as best drama. “Ted Lasso,” on Apple TV+, and “Mare of Easttown,” on HBO, also scored numerous wins.
lead_paragraph: At long last, the streaming platforms were triumphant at the Emmys, with Netflix and AppleTV+ taking major awards in drama, comedy and limited series as Television Academy voters acknowledged a profound shift in entertainment, from the channel-flipping days of traditional TV to the 21st-century mode of click-and-watch binge viewing.

headline: Word of the Day: proffer
abstract: This word has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Review: At the Emmy Awards, TV Celebrates Its Own Survival
abstract: The telecast felt like a very private party — people seemed to be having fun, but the jollity didn’t really come through the screen.
lead_paragraph: As the positivity-signaling shows “Ted Lasso” and “Hacks” traded off comedy awards at the 73rd Primetime Emmy Awards on Sunday night, it was indicative of a past year that tried our souls and put us in the mood for a shared national tummy scratch. The traditional television industry, buffeted by the pandemic and endlessly losing ground to streaming video, has had it as bad as anyone, and the theme of the show — unremarkable, more or less efficient but still overly long — appeared to be, “Hey, we’ve all got jobs!”

headline: The Mannings Give TV Sports Yet Another Alternate Viewing Option
abstract: ESPN has the quarterbacks Peyton and Eli Manning. CBS has the slime and SpongeBob allure of Nickelodeon. A boxing upstart even got Trump. For viewers, it’s ever more options beyond just watching the game.

headline: Cuomo Ally Resigns From Post as State Watchdog
abstract: Letizia Tagliafierro, the former inspector general, is the latest in a string of high-profile departures, as allies and appointees of the former governor leave state government.
lead_paragraph: The New York State inspector general resigned on Friday, becoming the latest in a string of high-profile departures from state government as allies and appointees of former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo follow him into private life.
