headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Broadway is back and so too are the Tony Awards. Here’s more on the ceremony and other recommendations for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Broadway is back and so too are the Tony Awards. Here’s more on the ceremony and other recommendations for the weekend.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Devil You Know’ and ‘The Lying Life of Adults’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: MAGIC LESSONS, by Alice Hoffman. (Simon & Schuster, 416 pp., $17.) “Hoffman’s book swept me away during a time I most needed it,” our reviewer, Edan Lepucki, wrote of the third installment (and second prequel) in the Practical Magic fantasy series. While the plot here is darker than in the other novels, the storytelling, Lepucki enthused, is “(forgive me) bewitching.”

headline: The Ecstasy of Scientific Discovery, and Its Agonizing Price

headline: From Anthony Doerr, an Ode to Storytelling That Shows How It’s Done
abstract: “Cloud Cuckoo Land,” Doerr’s first novel since “All the Light We Cannot See,” unites five characters over a millennium in a tribute to books and those who love them.
lead_paragraph: CLOUD CUCKOO LANDBy Anthony Doerr

headline: Giving Love a Second Chance
abstract: Marissa Arnold and Joseph Deaux dated for a few months in 2014, but broke up to care for their mothers, both of whom were diagnosed with cancer. When they reconnected in 2017, they fell for each other again.
lead_paragraph: In September 2017, Joseph Ernest Glisson Deaux checked his phone during work and saw a text from a woman he had barely spoken to over the last few years, Marissa Beth Arnold. He and Ms. Arnold had met in April 2014 at a work event and dated for a few months, but before their relationship could get serious, Ms. Arnold’s mother was diagnosed with terminal cancer. Mr. Deaux’s mother also had late-stage cancer, and although they both had feelings for one another, they decided to stop seeing each other to focus on taking care of their families.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2, Episode 10: The Naked and the Dead
abstract: This week brings Ted’s origin story, and other tales of the damage fathers can do.
lead_paragraph: We now return to our regularly scheduled programming.

headline: Amber Tamblyn Goes Dancing With Bowling Shoes
abstract: The star of “Y: The Last Man” hits Brooklyn Bowl for a girls’ night out.
lead_paragraph: Amber Tamblyn strode confidently toward the foul line and unleashed a sparkly pink bowling ball toward the waiting pins. Almost immediately, the ball plopped into the right gutter. Another ball, another assured approach. That ball guttered, too.

headline: Should We Bring Back Animals From Extinction?
abstract: A new company hopes to genetically resurrect the woolly mammoth thousands of years after it went extinct. Should these efforts be applauded or feared?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever seen the movie “Jurassic Park” or one of its sequels? It tells the story of an eccentric businessman who creates a theme park of cloned dinosaurs from prehistoric DNA, only to have his dreams ruined when the resurrected Tyrannosaurus rex and other ferocious predators escape and endanger the lives of the no-longer-thrilled human visitors.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 24, 2021
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: A Wedding 18 Years in the Making for Colorado Governor
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When Colorado Gov. Jared Polis and Marlon Reis met in 2003 neither imagined they would one day be married.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado gets one question a lot about his Sept. 15 wedding to Marlon Reis. “People say, ‘You know, it took you a while to get married,’” Mr. Polis, a Democrat, said. “But what’s important to remember is that Obergefell v. Hodges wasn’t until 2015. So we really only waited six years.”

headline: Why Sex-Positive Feminism Is Falling Out of Fashion
abstract: For some, a porn-soaked culture is oppressive, not liberating.
lead_paragraph: In her new book, “The Right to Sex: Feminism in the Twenty-First Century,” the philosopher Amia Srinivasan, who is quickly becoming one of the most high-profile feminist thinkers in the English-speaking world, describes teaching Oxford students about second-wave anti-porn activism. She assumes her students, for whom porn is ubiquitous, will “find the anti-porn position prudish and passé.” They do not. Rather, they’re in complete agreement with assertions that could come straight from Andrea Dworkin.

headline: Reporting on the Issues That Set Our Brains on Fire
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Michael Powell, a Times journalist, discusses his job writing about free speech, intellectual life and campus politics.
lead_paragraph: From the years of his youth when he worked as a New York City cabdriver, the Times reporter Michael Powell has retained a mastery at switching lanes. A reporter and columnist at several newspapers, he joined The Times in 2007 and has covered national political campaigns and reported for the Business desk. He wrote the Gotham column for the Metropolitan section and was the Sports of The Times columnist for six years.

headline: Twin ‘Love Lamps’ Kept Them Close Even When They Weren’t
abstract: Raquel Begleiter and David Godow talked about the Byzantine Empire when they met in Washington in 2015. Their relationship became “a long-distance Odyssey.”
lead_paragraph: On an early September afternoon in 2015, Raquel Begleiter and David Godow met while eating pizza at a mutual friend’s place in Washington. Initially, Ms. Begleiter’s focus was on her best friend, Rachel, who was about to move to San Francisco. But then the Byzantine Empire came into the conversation, a topic of particular interest to Ms. Begleiter, and she and Mr. Godow began, in his words, “nerding out” over medieval history.

headline: A Bond That Began With Football
abstract: Natalie Wengroff and Paul Wiley met during their first year of law school at Washington & Lee University.
lead_paragraph: When Natalie Wengroff and Paul Wiley met during their first year at Washington & Lee University’s law school, they found an easy conversation opener in the University of Michigan gear she regularly wore from her alma mater.

headline: ‘The Most Beautiful Proposal’
abstract: Samir Doshi popped the question to Leslie Arffa after filling their home with wall-to-wall flowers and candles. He hid the living room and kitchen furniture in the bedroom.
lead_paragraph: When Leslie Arffa was asked what she thought were Samir Doshi’s best qualities, she cleared her throat, and hesitated with evident emotion. “He’s incredibly kind and thoughtful,” she said. “I never met anyone before that I never got tired of spending time with.”

headline: What Happens Inside a Broadway Theater Can Help Us Heal
abstract: It is church for the heart and mind. It is shul for the intellect. A mosque celebrating mankind.
lead_paragraph: For 18 months, theater all but disappeared in New York City. For those of us who work on and around stages, our lifeblood came to a full stop. The theater district was a ghost town. My wife, Rebecca Luker, and I made our living on Broadway from a combined 27 shows in 30 years. We knew how lucky we were and pinched ourselves daily. And then suddenly it all ended.

headline: Making the Jump From ‘Girlfriends’ to Spouses
abstract: Claire Conroy Brown and Karin Gist met on the set of the TV show “Girlfriends.” They remained good friends for several years, though neither could deny a certain chemistry.
lead_paragraph: Claire Conroy Brown and Karin Gist didn’t think they would become girlfriends in anything but the platonic sense when they met on the set of the TV show “Girlfriends” in 2003. Ms. Brown, then an assistant to the showrunner, and Ms. Gist, a first-time TV writer, were focused on establishing themselves in Hollywood. Both remember a certain chemistry, though.

headline: After a Few First ‘Dates’ the Relationship Turned Serious
abstract: Matthew Sipe and Ryan Watzel met in 2012 at Yale Law School and became fast friends.
lead_paragraph: On what they considered their first official date — a Halloween party in 2012 at a pub in New Haven, Conn. — Matthew Sipe and Ryan Watzel were in costume.

headline: A Hawaiian Wedding, Complete With Tractors and Cattle
abstract: Alexa Wilhelm and Ikaika Sarme, who met at a Halloween party five years ago, were married on a ranch on the Big Island.
lead_paragraph: A wedding in Hawaii usually conjures images of sandy white beaches and clear blue waters. But Alexa Wilhelm and Ikaika Sarme opted to marry at Kahua Ranch, a working cattle ranch on the Big Island, instead.

headline: Why Is Rikers Island Still Open?
abstract: A spate of deaths and a mounting culture of violence at New York City’s largest jail renew calls for an emergency solution.
lead_paragraph: During the past few months, Rikers Island has been the site of sequential atrocities so stark that this week four members of New York’s congressional delegation called for its immediate closure. Among the most recent was the death, a few weeks ago, of 24-year old Esias “Izzy” Johnson, who had spent the previous month trying and failing to be released on bail and his final hours, his family claims, screaming for medical help in vain.

headline: Chris Cuomo Sexually Harassed Me. I Hope He’ll Use His Power to Make Change.
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: His former boss wants harassers and enablers held accountable.
lead_paragraph: I was Chris Cuomo’s boss at ABC News nearly two decades ago, and I am a regular viewer of CNN today, so I’ve long watched how he communicates on camera and witnessed at times how he behaved behind the scenes. This year, as he escaped accountability for advising former Gov. Andrew Cuomo during his sexual harassment scandal, two moments crystallized for me how Mr. Cuomo performs.

headline: Telling Fashion’s Fortune
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Psychics and Fortune Tellers', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: For years Cesare Badoglio was the go-to prognosticator of Italian designers.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, Cesare Badoglio, who puts his age at “between 80 and 99,” was the spirit whisperer for some of the brightest talents in Italian fashion.

headline: Ron DeSantis Was a Slam Dunk. Until He Wasn’t.
abstract: By following a G.O.P. base strategy on pandemic issues in a state hard hit by Covid, he may have left himself vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Among the possible contenders for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination not named Donald Trump, one governor has captured more than his share of attention: Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: In Oak Bluffs, Strangers Become Family
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A first-time visitor to this Martha’s Vineyard town, long cherished by generations of Black travelers, finds that after a devastating year, warm welcomes, a strong sense of pride and the spirit of family remain constants.
lead_paragraph: Approaching Inkwell Beach on Martha’s Vineyard on a midsummer day, you feel a magnetic energy in the air. Before you can even see the ocean, familiar melodies waft through a set of speakers, everything from Beyoncé to Earth, Wind & Fire. Once on the small beach, steps from the main strip of Oak Bluffs, you are surrounded by Black beachgoers proudly wearing the insignia of Shaw University, Morgan State University and other historically Black colleges and universities. Members of the “Divine 9” — historically Black sororities and fraternities — glide about in their respective paraphernalia, and revelers of all ages socialize and take photos in the spirit of unfettered kinship. I feel and see Black joy everywhere.

headline: A Music Obsession That’s Adventurous and Soothing
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Music', 'Rhythm and Blues (Music)', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: ‘The trick to crate digging is to simply go at it: Dive into the sections, flip through the jackets and trust your gut.’
lead_paragraph: I was stuck trying to write in my Brooklyn apartment, overthinking a sentence as usual.

headline: Partners in Business and Adventure
abstract: Caroline Matthews and Connor McCarthy met during graduate school at Stanford, while both were on a Buddhist meditation retreat in the Himalayas.
lead_paragraph: When Caroline Matthews is asked where she first met Connor McCarthy, she says simply, “We met in graduate school.”

headline: Trump Had a Mob. He Also Had a Plan.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2024', 'Constitution (US)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: The storming of the Capitol closed the door on one era of American politics and opened the door to another.
lead_paragraph: You can understand a revolution as a time when the unthinkable becomes, suddenly, thinkable. It is a time when the rules that ordinarily govern political life lose their force and conflict takes the place of consensus, a time when the struggle for power is a struggle to define the political order itself.

headline: Democrats Consider Adding Carbon Tax to Budget Bill
keywords: ['Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Global Warming', 'American Jobs Plan (2021)', 'American Families Plan (2021)']
abstract: A tax on carbon dioxide pollution could be the single most effective policy to tackle climate change. It could also be politically explosive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Opposition from a single moderate Democrat to corporate and income tax rate increases has revived efforts in the Senate to draft a tax on carbon dioxide pollution as a way to pay for the Democrats’ proposed $3.5 trillion budget bill.

headline: Their Produce Is Pristine Enough for Picky Chefs. But They Give It Away.
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Philanthropy', 'Food Insecurity', 'Soup Kitchens', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The couple behind Carversville Farm believe that everyone deserves high-quality food, so they donate most of theirs to kitchens feeding the neediest in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: MECHANICSVILLE, Pa. — Steve Tomlinson takes pride in the details at Carversville Farm, the 388-acre certified-organic spread he manages here in bucolic Bucks County.

headline: Does Building Better Jails Go Far Enough?
abstract: As New York looks to replace Rikers Island, some say a focus on more humane jail design is largely beside the point.
lead_paragraph: Darren Mack remembers August 1992. It was so hot that the metal walls of his jail cell on Rikers Island were “sweating.” Safety guards on windows blocked ventilation. An industrial fan on each tier of cellblocks was meant to cool the place, but they hardly worked, recalled Mr. Mack, who served 19 months on Rikers Island on a charge of accomplice to armed robbery.

headline: Behind the Trees, a Brooklyn Artists’ Collective
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Art', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: A historic house in Clinton Hill South has been colonized by painters, designers, poets, architects and activists, living and working together.
lead_paragraph: Hidden by overgrown trees and flowering shrubs in need of a haircut, 70 Lefferts Place, in Brooklyn’s Clinton Hill, can be hard to find amid its neighboring rowhouses of brick and brownstone.

headline: ‘I’m So Tired’: Readers Respond to Schools Reopening
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Parenting', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Following a collection of vignettes from schools around the country, readers weighed in. Here is a selection of their comments.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a special feature on schools reopening around the country — and how students, teachers, administrators and parents are faring. Reader response, mostly from teachers and parents, was passionate and heartfelt. A selection is below.

headline: Finding Common Ground in the South, San Francisco and South India
abstract: Sree Arimilli and Sandheep Surendran lived nearby in San Francisco and shared striking similarities. But they didn’t come together until they called on astrological forces (and a dating app).
lead_paragraph: It was ultimately a dating app that introduced Sree Arimilli and Sandheep Surendran of San Francisco. But more traditional and spiritual elements, as well as a bit of self help, also played a part.

headline: A Dangerous Scramble to Evacuate Afghan Nonprofit Workers
abstract: Women who steered programs to empower girls are fleeing the country. But unlike people who worked for the U.S. military, they have no clear path to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Roya was the face of the modern young Afghan woman. As leader of a girls’ club funded by the U.S. government, she gave her troops a script for their lives that their mothers could not pursue: They were just as powerful as boys in their ability to change their communities, she taught them. Working for another small nonprofit, she helped build connections between American and Afghan girls.

headline: That Comment Someone Left on Facebook? It Can Get You Sued.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Australia’s top court has said media companies can be held liable for replies to their posts, prompting some to step back from the platform.
lead_paragraph: Dylan Voller was already a polarizing figure in Australia when the disturbing, violent and demonstrably false accusations against him began to appear on Facebook.

headline: The Cost of Insuring Expensive Waterfront Homes Is About to Skyrocket
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Flood Insurance', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coastal Areas', 'Global Warming', 'Floods', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: New federal flood insurance rates that better reflect the real risks of climate change are coming. For some, premiums will rise sharply.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s version of the American dream, which holds that even people of relatively modest means can aspire to live near the water, depends on a few crucial components: sugar white beaches, soft ocean breezes and federal flood insurance that is heavily subsidized.

headline: Ferries in Alaska. Rail in Oregon. States Dream Big on Infrastructure Funds.
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'States (US)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Transit Systems', 'Transportation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'American Jobs Plan (2021)']
abstract: The infrastructure bill could reshape priorities across the country, jump-starting critical projects that stalled over funding. These are some of the possibilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the Pacific Northwest, the aging Interstate 5 bridge, a main artery between Oregon and Washington, is at risk of collapsing in a major earthquake. Across Appalachia, abandoned coal mines leaking toxic pollutants are a threat to public health. And along the Gulf Coast, states like Louisiana are forced to consider novel evacuation routes to ease traffic on inland highways that often become clogged before powerful hurricanes.

headline: How an Olympic Skateboarder Spends Her Sundays
abstract: With the Tokyo Games behind her, Alexis Sablone is enjoying Brooklyn — and street skating — again.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Sablone doesn’t really have weekends. “It’s never like, ‘Oh, I’ve got to get back to work tomorrow,’” she said.

headline: Saving the Artwork of the South: Deep Investment, and a Drone
abstract: From Birmingham to Gee’s Bend, the Souls Grown Deep Foundation is directly investing in Alabama communities where artists and quilters live, work — and struggle.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — “I’m the conjurer of all my ancestors, 400 years of African people in America,” said Joe Minter, surveying the dense outdoor environment of artworks he has forged from refuse over the past 32 years across his half-acre yard, facing two of the largest African-American cemeteries in the south. Nodding to the tombstones, he added, “they have given me the privilege of being their spokesman.”

headline: Chris Cuomo, Andrew Cuomo and the Need for Accountability
abstract: “I see another way forward.”
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: For Food Deliverers, the Promise of Better Pay
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Tips and Tipping']
abstract: The City Council passed a bill mandating minimum-pay standards for delivery workers, who were a lifeline for New Yorkers during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday. We’ll look at steps New York City is taking to improve conditions for low-wage food deliverers, who became lifelines during the pandemic. We’ll also fly into the New York Public Library for a glimpse of holdings you can’t borrow.

headline: Another Murder of a Woman in London Intensifies Calls for Safer Streets
abstract: The case of Sabina Nessa, 28, whose body was found in a London park, has renewed national outrage over violence against women in Britain. A suspect has been arrested on suspicion of murder.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The name of the murdered young woman was slowly intoned by the crowd who gathered in the southeast London neighborhood on Friday evening: Sabina Nessa. Sabina Nessa. Sabina Nessa.

headline: Jen Psaki’s Turn at the Lectern and Richard Powers’s ‘Bewilderment’: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Germany, and Europe, After Merkel
abstract: When Germans head to polls this weekend, they face an unusually difficult question: Who can replace Angela Merkel as a leader, for their country and for Europe?
lead_paragraph: After 16 years in power, Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany, is walking out of office one of the most popular politicians in the country.

headline: Why Reparations Are Needed to Close the Racial Wealth Gap
abstract: The U.S. government’s debt to emancipated slaves and their descendants is more than 155 years overdue, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: The wealth gap between Black and white Americans is too enormous to be remedied through incremental programs. What’s needed are federal reparations.

headline: Germany After Angela Merkel
abstract: The chancellor’s long tenure is nearly over. Who’s next?
lead_paragraph: American voters tend to like change. It’s rare for either major political party to hold the White House for more than two straight terms, and the president’s party often struggles in midterm elections.

headline: ‘Every Single Pitch, Everyone’s Staring’
abstract: As the Phillies make a late push for the playoffs, Bryce Harper is providing nightly reminders of his game-changing talent. It just might get him a second M.V.P. Award.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — With the Philadelphia Phillies clinging to their playoff hopes and a one-run lead in the eighth inning on Wednesday night, the moment fell, of course, to the best player on the team, the one who had helped carry them this far.

headline: In a Fading Portuguese Village, the Gardens Bloom Again
abstract: A landscape designer has transformed the town of Santar with a series of lush, connected plots where everyone is free to roam.
lead_paragraph: IN 2013, JOSE Luís Vasconcellos e Sousa, a now-62-year-old retired private bank executive living in Estoril, Portugal, cold-called the legendary Madrid-based landscape designer Fernando Caruncho with a proposal. Perhaps Caruncho, whose minimalist works evoke the monumental quality of 1970s land art, could create a contemporary extension to complement the 400-year-old formal garden of his ancestral estate in Santar, a village in Dão’s wine region, 90 minutes south of Porto.

headline: The U.S. could run out of cash to pay its bills as early as Oct. 15, analysts say.
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The analysis showed a narrower window during which the United States could default on its debt. The Treasury has said it has no official contingency plan if the debt limit is breached.
lead_paragraph: The federal government could run out of cash and start missing payments on things as diverse as Social Security and military pay sometime between Oct. 15 and Nov. 4, according to a new analysis from the Bipartisan Policy Center.

headline: ‘Controlling Britney Spears’ Reveals New Details of Her Life Under Conservatorship
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A new documentary by The New York Times features interviews with key insiders and people with firsthand information about how the conservatorship controlled the pop star’s life.
lead_paragraph: Our documentary is now streaming on Hulu.

headline: China Cracks Down Harder on Cryptocurrency With New Ban
keywords: ['Virtual Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bitcoin (Currency)']
abstract: The clampdown comes as China’s central bank has been testing its own digital currency. The price of Bitcoin dropped on the news.
lead_paragraph: China intensified its crackdown on cryptocurrency on Friday, declaring all financial transactions involving cryptocurrencies illegal and issuing a nationwide ban on cryptocurrency mining, the power-hungry process in which vast computer networks compete for newly created crypto tokens.

headline: Here Come the Crypto Rules
keywords: ['Virtual Currency', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The urgency among regulators to rein in the crypto industry has generated a flurry of lobbying all over Washington.
lead_paragraph: Financial regulators are racing to regulate stablecoins. These digital currencies pegged to a stable asset like the dollar are used in crypto trading, banking and decentralized finance, addressing the problem of price volatility that plagues Bitcoin and others. Stablecoins have become an important bridge between digital currencies and the traditional financial system.

headline: Holding Back the Floodwaters
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Floods', 'Weather', 'Basements and Cellars', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Homeowners who faced flooded basements after Hurricane Ida are pondering how to deal with the possibility of fiercer and more frequent storms.
lead_paragraph: How do you keep the water out when it seems unstoppable? That is the question that keeps Carrie Moore glued to her phone whenever it rains, scanning weather radar apps to try to determine whether the basement of her Sunset Park rowhouse will flood.

headline: Iowa’s Grassley will seek an eighth term in the Senate.
abstract: The Republican senator, 88, is the former head of two high-profile Senate committees and will spare his party a bitter primary fight to succeed him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican in the Senate, announced on Friday on Twitter that he would seek an eighth term, relieving Republicans worried about a bitter primary fight that could put the seat at risk.

headline: In Biden’s foreign policy, friends and foes see echoes of the Trump administration.
abstract: At the United Nations’ annual gathering of world leaders this week, President Biden and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke ambitiously about international cooperation and a new diplomatic approach for a post-Trump America.
lead_paragraph: At the United Nations’ annual gathering of world leaders this week, President Biden and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke ambitiously about international cooperation and a new diplomatic approach for a post-Trump America.

headline: How Did Californians Spend Their Second Summer of the Pandemic?
abstract: Finding joy even in bleak moments.
lead_paragraph: This summer in California was not what we signed up for.

headline: Fashion Is Not Only for the Young and Skinny
abstract: Consider Missoni, Tod’s and even Emporio Armani. Time for designers to get with the program.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The news of Linda Evangelista’s cosmetic procedure trauma has been the talk not only of the internet, where the former supermodel’s Instagram post about what she said were the negative effects of a CoolSculpting treatment has sparked vociferous response, but also at the shows in Milan, where Ms. Evangelista once reigned and where her tale has passed from one socially distanced chair to another like a fashion horror story.

headline: A Push for Social Security to Resume Mailing Annual Updates
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Social Security (US)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Personal Finances', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: The government has been urging people to create online accounts. But most haven’t, which means they can’t regularly check for errors.
lead_paragraph: With so much financial information available online, who needs paperwork cluttering your desk? But some members of Congress want Americans to get at least one financial document on paper: their annual Social Security statement.

headline: Jared Harris Is (and Isn’t) His Father’s Son
abstract: The actor has emerged from the shadow of his father, Richard Harris, with memorable performances in series like “Mad Men” and “Chernobyl.” Next up is the sci-fi epic “Foundation.”
lead_paragraph: Ask David S. Goyer, the creator of “Foundation,” why Jared Harris was his first choice to star in this ambitious new Apple TV+ series, and he will point to one small, meaningful moment during filming.

headline: Pandemic Changes the World of Horse Auctions
keywords: ['Horses', 'Horse Racing', 'Auctions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Breeding of Animals', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Traditional speculators, known as pinhookers, are now vying with online buyers looking to invest in something new. The new bidders are driving up prices.
lead_paragraph: Thoroughbred horses are always a bet on the future, whether you’re at the track and wagering on which one will win that day or an owner deciding which mares and sires will produce the best offspring — with no proof for years.

headline: Stream an Operatic Rarity by a Black Composer (While You Can)
abstract: William Grant Still’s “Highway 1, U.S.A.,” staged by Opera Theater of St. Louis, is available online until Sept. 30.
lead_paragraph: Want a break from prestige TV for an evening? Good news: An important 20th-century American opera is newly available to stream, after a rare live staging this summer. And it’s about 50 minutes long, just like an episode of “The Crown.”

headline: After a Choreographer’s Suicide, Ballet Confronts Tough Questions
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Liam Scarlett killed himself after he was accused of misconduct. Now the dance world is grappling with the aftermath.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The choreographer Liam Scarlett’s “With a Chance of Rain,” a lush, expansive ballet set to a melodic Rachmaninoff piano score, would hardly seem a risky piece of programming. But it was still notable when the Bayerisches Staatsballett performed it last weekend at the Cuvilliés Theater in Munich.

headline: 20 Mentor Texts by Teenagers for Documenting and Reflecting on Your Life
abstract: If you are participating in our Coming of Age in 2021 contest, here is more work across mediums to inspire you.
lead_paragraph: Over 5,500 entries came in to our inaugural Coming of Age Contest last year, and, after multiple rounds of judging, we honored 245 finalists. A small selection of those were then chosen by The New York Times to be featured in special digital and print presentations in the spring.

headline: A Backpack That Asks: What Is a Backpack?
abstract: On the second day of Milan Fashion Week, a tongue-in-cheek collaboration between MM6 Maison Margiela and Eastpak.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.

headline: Paranormal Play in Denver From Meow Wolf
abstract: “Convergence Station,” the company’s third installation, may be good business. But is it good art?
lead_paragraph: DENVER —   Meow Wolf trades on the dark side of American popular culture, in cults and conspiracies, in supernatural beings, extraterrestrials and unsolvable conundrums. The chain of oversized, immersive art installations teases visitors who wander through its dimly-lit environments by dropping hints about nefarious mysteries they could spend a lifetime — not to mention multiple $45 admission charges — trying to work out.

headline: As a potential debt default looms, Yellen faces her biggest test yet.
abstract: When Janet L. Yellen was Federal Reserve chair in 2014, she faced a grilling from Republicans about whether the federal government had a plan if the nation’s borrowing limit was breached and measures to keep paying the country’s bills were exhausted.
lead_paragraph: When Janet L. Yellen was Federal Reserve chair in 2014, she faced a grilling from Republicans about whether the federal government had a plan if the nation’s borrowing limit was breached and measures to keep paying the country’s bills were exhausted.

headline: China Detains Business Chiefs as Its Corporate Crusade Expands
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The seizure of the top two leaders of HNA Group comes as speculation swirls over whether Beijing will bail out another troubled giant, Evergrande.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has kicked up its campaign to tame its free-spending, debt-laden companies, as the authorities punished the corporate chiefs of two troubled companies while letting a troubled property giant continue to struggle under the weight of more than $300 billion in debt.

headline: Watch Live: Biden Delivers Remarks on Covid Response
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Biden gives an update on the U.S. vaccination program and the nation’s handling of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: President Biden gives an update on the U.S. vaccination program and the nation’s handling of the coronavirus.

headline: Janty Yates on Dressing the ‘House of Gucci’
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Suits (Apparel)', 'Seamstresses and Tailors', 'Dresses', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: The Oscar-winning British costume designer on delving into the archives and working with Lady Gaga for the hotly anticipated biopic.
lead_paragraph: In seasons past, Gucci held a runway show on the first day of Milan Fashion Week. This season, however, the new collection is scheduled to debut in Los Angeles on Nov. 3 — not long before the Thanksgiving weekend release in movie theaters of “House of Gucci,” a film based on the true story of the killing of the former chief of the Italian fashion house, Maurizio Gucci, by his ex-wife, Patrizia Reggiani.

headline: ‘Andy,’ Gus Van Sant’s Warhol Musical, Is a Surprise but Not a Miracle
abstract: The film director set himself a steep challenge in his debut stage work. At least for now, he hasn’t quite met it.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Gus Van Sant is no stranger to experimental biopics: “Last Days,” his lyrical, nearly dialogue-free meditation on the end of Kurt Cobain’s life, shunned every convention of the genre. Yet “Andy,” his Andy Warhol-inspired stage debut, which had its world premiere at the Teatro Nacional D. Maria II in Lisbon this week, may be Van Sant’s oddest tribute to date.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Couple With Opposing Tastes Strike a Balance
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Brownstones', 'Antiques', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Following a period of editing and rediscovery, austerity and abundance — and a wide range of objects — live side by side in this Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment.
lead_paragraph: AS A CHILD in Virginia, Michael Brown collected birds’ nests, stamps and mounted beetles and butterflies. By the age of 10, he had graduated to Goofus glass vases — cold-painted trinkets produced in the early 20th century that were often given as fairground prizes — and old-fashioned spectacle frames he’d find at local flea markets. His first job, at 18, was dressing windows at the Richmond department store Thalhimers, and on the weekends he began collecting antique furniture and curiosities, a habit that continued into adulthood, as he worked as an interior stylist and retail art director, picking up treasures wherever he went: a 1920s lacquered gold Japanese screen from a stint living in Portland, Ore.; sun-bleached sea turtle shells from a vacation in Maine. By the time the 59-year-old found his current home in 2013, a 1,000-square-foot, one-bedroom rental on the top floor of a brownstone in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, he needed a 20-foot truck to transport the goods he’d accumulated. “I wish I could be one of those people who could buy a thing, live with it, throw it out and move on,” he says. “But I can’t.”

headline: Hurricane Forecasters Aren’t Tweeting About Your Personal Life, They Swear
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Social Media', 'Hurricane Ida (2021)', 'Cyclones', 'Weather', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Kate was a “poorly organized depression.” The National Hurricane Center says it wasn’t personal.
lead_paragraph: “I can relate to that hurricane” is not a thought anyone wants to think.

headline: In 2021, the Mendoza Line Isn’t So Scary
abstract: Once a death knell, hitting below .200 isn’t all that unusual anymore, provided you have discernible value elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Even baseball fans who aren’t into statistics are familiar with batting average. If it starts with a 4, that’s historically good. Starting with a 3 is good, a 2 is OK, and if it starts with a 1 … well, even a casual fan knows it’s time to send that player to the minors.

headline: The C.E.O. Other C.E.O.s Turn to for Advice
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Rich Lesser, who has run Boston Consulting Group for eight years, is stepping down at a moment of enormous change.
lead_paragraph: When chief executives face thorny challenges that they feel their companies are unprepared to handle, they often turn to consulting firms. McKinsey and Bain & Company are among the best known, often drawing headlines for some of their more controversial work and prominent alumni. But just as influential in the business world, albeit with a lower profile, is Boston Consulting Group.

headline: He Taught Ancient Texts at Oxford. Now He Is Accused of Stealing Some.
keywords: ['Manuscripts', 'Museums', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Bible', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: Hobby Lobby, the craft chain that helped build a collection for the Museum of the Bible, has sued a former Oxford lecturer, asserting he sold its stolen artifacts.
lead_paragraph: He had impeccable credentials. No one disputes that.

headline: In Race for 5G, Alarm and Security Services Get Stuck in the Middle
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Wireless Communications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shortages', 'Computer Chips', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Covid-19 shutdowns and chip shortages have made it more difficult to upgrade devices and meet a deadline set by AT&T.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Brinkman’s troubles are threatening to slow down AT&T’s multibillion-dollar rollout of ultrafast 5G wireless technology.

headline: As Biden hails Pfizer boosters, the C.D.C. director defends her move to include frontline workers.
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant']
abstract: Remarks by President Biden and the C.D.C. director, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, came after Dr. Walensky overruled a recommendation by her agency’s panel of scientific advisers against booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine for frontline workers.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden cheered moves by federal regulators to allow for millions of Americans to get booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defended her decision on Friday to recommend the shots for frontline workers, a highly unusual move because it overruled her agency’s scientific advisers.

headline: For India’s Military, a Juggling Act on Two Hostile Fronts
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Territorial Disputes', 'International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Tensions with China and Pakistan stretch a cash-starved military, while the fall of Afghanistan to the Taliban removes a potential ally.
lead_paragraph: CHANDIGARH, India — After the deadliest clashes in half a century with China, India’s military has taken emergency measures to reinforce a 500-mile stretch of the border high in the Himalayas.

headline: Former Louisiana Trooper Faces Federal Civil Rights Charge
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Body-camera footage shows the ex-trooper, Jacob Brown, repeatedly pummeling a Black man, Aaron Larry Bowman, with a flashlight during a traffic stop in 2019.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury indicted a former Louisiana state trooper on Thursday on a federal civil rights violation, finding that he repeatedly clubbed a Black man with a flashlight during a traffic stop that was recorded by his body camera.

headline: At Art Basel, Everyone’s Playing It Safe
abstract: Dealers brought familiar works to the flagship Swiss fair, and the event’s organizers soothed nervous exhibitors with reassuring gestures.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — Psychologists call it the “mere exposure effect”: Humans like what they already know, whether people, places, products — or works of art.

headline: ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Stephen Chbosky narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Ben Platt.
lead_paragraph: The director Stephen Chbosky narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Ben Platt.

headline: Watch Ben Platt Perform in ‘Dear Evan Hansen’
abstract: Stephen Chbosky, the director of the film adaptation of the Broadway musical, narrates a sequence with the song “Waving Through a Window.”
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Comedians Turn Their Attention to Abortion
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Movies', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Alison Leiby has an hourlong set looking at the experience of an unwanted pregnancy. She’s among a spate of female artists finding humor in the issue.
lead_paragraph: A stand-up show about abortion sounds like a bad idea. The comic Alison Leiby knows that. Just look at her title: “Oh God, an Hour About Abortion.”

headline: Biden Condemns Border Patrol Treatment of Haitian Migrants as Expulsions Continue
abstract: Several members of the administration said that an inquiry into what happened was still open and that officials would continue deporting migrants under a Trump-era public health rule.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden vowed on Friday that Border Patrol agents who rounded up Haitian migrants crossing the Rio Grande would “pay,” calling the scene at the southwestern border “horrible to see,” even as several members of his administration stressed that an investigation into what happened was still open.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Check out our latest special section, “Fast Flavor,” for 24 low-fuss recipes we know you’ll love.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I know our relationship relies most heavily on digital communication, with me dropping into your inbox a few times a week to offer up recipes and articles. But today I’d like to urge you to buy our newspaper on Sunday, and to enjoy the analog pleasures of a print special section: “Fast Flavor,” with two dozen unfussy recipes from recipe developers and reporters across our shop. That’ll pay off in a big way.

headline: Stream These Five International Films Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a slow-burn Romanian drama, a documentary about baseball in Japan, an experimental Chilean film-memoir and more.
lead_paragraph: Following an intelligence officer whose son goes missing on a blizzard-stricken mountain, this slow-burning Romanian film deepens familiar Hollywood templates — a father’s relentless quest to save his child; a battle of man against nature — into a complex ethical drama about the blurred lines between desperation and hubris. When Mircea Jianu (Adrian Titieni) first learns of his son’s disappearance, his reactions are what one would expect from any parent in his shoes: panic, despair, anger. He insists on following the rescue team up the slopes, despite the inclement weather, and lashes out at their seeming slowness.

headline: Trump, Duterte, and the Authoritarian War on Women
abstract: Donald Trump’s ideological cousins around the world want to reverse the feminist gains of recent decades.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s ideological cousins around the world want to reverse the feminist gains of recent decades.

headline: Marcos Alonso and the Genius of Thomas Tuchel
abstract: There is no such thing as a good or a bad player, only one in the right (or wrong) system.
lead_paragraph: Things got so bad, at one point, that even Marcos Alonso’s father was telling him to go. His fallout with his coach at Chelsea, Frank Lampard, had been spectacular and it had been total. Alonso had been substituted at halftime during a game at West Bromwich Albion, but instead of dutifully filing out to support his teammates, he had instead skulked off to wait on the team bus, stewing at the injustice of it all.

headline: This Weeknight Chicken Recipe Has Mass Appeal
abstract: Delicate boneless, skinless thighs cook quickly, aren’t prone to drying out and pair beautifully with a garlicky cucumber yogurt.
lead_paragraph: Jack Sprat may eat no fat, but I wonder how he’d weigh in on boneless, skinless chicken thighs.

headline: Don't Call Me LGBTQ
abstract: The case for a new term that describes all sexual minorities.
lead_paragraph: The case for a new term that describes all sexual minorities.

headline: Italy Frees Catalan Separatist Leader From Jail. Here’s How the Case Has Gone.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Secession and Independence Movements', 'Fugitives', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Extradition', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Treason and Sedition', 'Territorial Disputes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Carles Puigdemont, a former leader of Catalonia, faces trial in Spain and was detained briefly in Italy. It is not clear if he will appear when the court considers whether to return him to Spain.
lead_paragraph: An Italian court released a former leader of Spain’s Catalonia region from jail on Friday, a day after his arrest on a warrant seeking his return to Spain for trial over a failed independence bid he led four years ago.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic Tries Out Another Temporary Home
abstract: After opening its season at Alice Tully Hall, the orchestra found more congenial surroundings at the Rose Theater.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the surge of adrenaline that the New York Philharmonic felt at finally returning to live concerts at Lincoln Center after a year and a half. Maybe sizing down symphonic power for a temporary venue — Alice Tully Hall, with just over a third of the seats of the orchestra’s usual theater across the street — was a work in progress on opening night.

headline: The Haunting Last Letters of Sylvia Plath
abstract: As tragedy approaches, she is stricken, broken — and at the height of her artistic powers.
lead_paragraph: As tragedy approaches, she is stricken, broken — and at the height of her artistic powers.

headline: The Highs and Lows of the ‘Cheer Mom’
abstract: As a sport grows more competitive and demanding, an archetype has emerged.
lead_paragraph: By mid-January of this year, Kristen Wheeler, a self-described “cheer mom,” was exhausted. She was spending most of her days in the cheer gym or in the car with her bottomless cup of coffee while her 17-year-old daughter, Abby, a high school varsity and All Star cheerleader, practiced for major competitions.

abstract: Covid vaccines around the world; Afghanistan's envoy, and education of women and girls; Haitian migrants; the voting bill; France's global stature.

headline: Members of Congress Urge Biden to Intervene at Rikers as de Blasio Plans Visit
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Absenteeism and Truancy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a letter to President Biden on Friday, several Democrats said New York City “cannot be trusted” to manage the jail complex, which has descended into chaos.
lead_paragraph: A group of congressional Democrats from New York called on President Biden on Friday to use federal resources to address the crisis at Rikers Island, expressing a lack of confidence in the city’s ability to restore order to the jail complex.

headline: To His Surprise, His Play About 2 Dead U.K. Politicians Struck a Chord
keywords: ['Theater', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: After decades in the political sphere, Michael McManus turned to theater. His play, “Maggie & Ted,” explores the tensions that would pave the way for Brexit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A play about two long-dead British politicians might not be an obvious winner in London’s West End. But this summer a brief run of “Maggie & Ted, the Birth of Brexit” attracted a sellout theater crowd, including a former prime minister, Theresa May, and its success seems to have surprised the playwright, Michael McManus, as much as anyone.

headline: Can Macron Lead the European Union After Merkel Retires?
abstract: Emmanuel Macron, the French president, would love to fill the German chancellor’s shoes. But a Europe with no single, central figure may be more likely.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After Germans vote on Sunday and a new government is formed, Chancellor Angela Merkel will leave office after 16 years as the dominant figure in European politics. It is the moment that Emmanuel Macron, the French president, has been waiting for.

headline: A Nervy Trip to Kabul: How Ukraine Negotiated With the Taliban and Rescued 96 Afghans
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: Few countries have been willing to fly rescue missions into Afghanistan since the Americans left. Ukraine is an exception. It says it has a different definition of danger.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Before departing for Afghanistan, an elite team of Ukrainian troops gathered in a circle outside the airport and passed around a bottle of whiskey, a ritual meant to calm the nerves.

headline: Two hosts of ‘The View’ test positive for the virus minutes ahead of an interview with the vice president.
abstract: Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin were abruptly pulled from the set on live television after testing positive before an in-studio interview with Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Two co-hosts of “The View,” Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin, were abruptly pulled from the set on live television on Friday morning after testing positive for the coronavirus, minutes ahead of a live in-studio interview with Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Rochester Officer Faces Discipline in Daniel Prude’s Death
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: The departmental charges are the first to be filed against any of the seven officers suspended in the case of Mr. Prude, a Black man who died after the police placed a mesh hood over his head and pinned him down.
lead_paragraph: Police officials in Rochester, N.Y., said on Thursday that they had filed departmental charges against an officer who took part in arresting Daniel Prude, a Black man who died in March 2020 after the police pinned him face down on the ground and put a mesh hood over his head.

headline: Could This Covid Wave Reverse the Recovery? Here’s What to Watch.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Coronavirus Delta Variant', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Some businesses are still hurting, and federal aid has wound down. But economists see sources of resilience and signs of strength.
lead_paragraph: The spread of the Delta variant has delayed office reopenings, disrupted the start of school and generally dashed hopes for a return to normal after Labor Day. But it has not pushed the U.S. economic recovery into reverse.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Times editors have handpicked 11 stories for you to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Times editors have handpicked 11 stories for you to enjoy.

headline: Two Covid vaccine pioneers win 2021 Lasker Awards in medicine.
lead_paragraph: Among this year’s recipients of the Lasker awards, announced Friday, were two scientists whose work was crucial in the development of Covid-19 vaccines.

headline: The Best One-Bowl Cookie Recipe You’ve Probably Never Heard Of
abstract: These old-fashioned butter cookies promise to become your new favorite.
lead_paragraph: Brown-edge cookies may not look like much — and their no-nonsense name certainly doesn’t do them any favors — but don’t let appearances fool you. In the great Venn diagram of cookies, this little wafer lies at the intersection of Christmas sugar cookie, vanilla wafer and French tuile. They are absurdly buttery, crisp at the edges, just barely chewy in the center, and they go with everything. It’s a bold statement, but as far as cookies go, these golden rounds are practically flawless.

headline: Covid Vaccine Pioneers and Others Win 2021 Lasker Awards in Medicine
keywords: ['Lasker Awards', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'RNA (Ribonucleic Acid)', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Research']
abstract: The prizes are given annually, and many winners often go on to be awarded the Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: The Lasker awards for 2021, announced Friday, were given to scientists whose work was crucial for Covid-19 vaccines, scientists who discovered how to control the firing of neurons with beams of light, and to a researcher whose influential work and leadership changed medical science.

headline: House approves measure to protect abortion rights amid threats from states and the courts.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Abortion']
abstract: The Women’s Health Protection Act is unlikely to advance in the Senate, but its passage reflected a sense of urgency by Democrats to maintain abortion access nationwide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House narrowly approved a measure on Friday intended to enact abortion rights into federal law, as Democrats sought to counter efforts at the state level to restrict abortions and growing hostility to abortion rights from the conservative-leaning Supreme Court.

headline: The Restaurant Host Is Suddenly at the Front of the Covid Wars
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Vaccination Proof and Immunization Records', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Forget the powerful maître d’ of old. Today’s hosts are mostly young, inexperienced women who have to enforce health rules and deal with the sometimes violent response.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Young was thrilled to be hired two years ago as a host at Café Poêtes in Houston. She was pursuing an undergraduate degree in hospitality, so she thought the experience in fine dining would be invaluable. She wanted to be the first person to greet arriving diners.

headline: Daily Covid deaths rise to a new high in Russia, where vaccine hesitancy remains common.
abstract: The government’s numbers are widely regarded with suspicion, but Russian officials appear to be issuing more urgent warnings about the virus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia reported its worst-ever single-day Covid-19 death toll on Friday as coronavirus cases rise in some areas and vaccine hesitancy remains widespread.

headline: Black-Tie Season Returns
abstract: Benefits were held for the Public Theater, the Museum at F.I.T. and the Central Park Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater held its annual gala in Central Park on Sept. 20. The gala celebrated the final performance of “Merry Wives” at the Delacorte Theater, and what would have been the 100th birthday of its founder, Joe Papp. The Museum at F.I.T. raised $700,000 at its couture council luncheon honoring Wes Gordon at Cipriani South Street on Sept. 22.

headline: A federal program aimed at halting evictions is showing signs of improvement.
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: The Treasury Department disbursed more than $2.3 billion in rental assistance in August, the most of any month since the cash was allocated by Congress.
lead_paragraph: The number of low-income renters at immediate risk of losing shelter remained relatively low in the month since the Supreme Court struck down a national eviction moratorium, as a troubled $46.5 billion federal rental aid program showed signs of kicking into high gear.

headline: A W.H.O. panel recommends treating high-risk Covid patients with monoclonal antibodies.
abstract: The expensive treatment, developed by the U.S. drug maker Regeneron and the Swiss biotech company Roche, has garnered attention as backstop for those who shun vaccines.
lead_paragraph: A World Health Organization panel has endorsed the use of a monoclonal antibody treatment for Covid patients at the greatest risk of being hospitalized or those who are not producing antibodies to fight off the disease.

headline: Alessia Cara’s Bouncy Ode to Single Life, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Coldplay and BTS, J. Cole, Arturo O’Farrill and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Man Convicted in Thefts of a van Gogh and a Hals From Dutch Museums
abstract: DNA evidence found at the two museums after the burglaries led investigators to the suspect, who has now been sentenced to eight years in prison by a Dutch court.
lead_paragraph: A three-judge panel in the Netherlands on Friday found a man guilty of stealing paintings by van Gogh and Frans Hals from museums in separate thefts and sentenced him to eight years in prison and a hefty fine.

headline: The C.I.A. recalls its station chief to Vienna amid criticism of his handling of mysterious illnesses.
keywords: ['Havana Syndrome', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Frustration is growing about the treatment of an increasing number of intelligence officers and diplomats with symptoms of so-called Havana syndrome.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. recalled its Vienna chief of station this month, after agency leaders concluded he failed to take adequate steps to address a series of mysterious health episodes in Austria in which intelligence officers and diplomats fell ill with symptoms similar to Havana syndrome, according to current and former officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss personnel movements. The names of agency station chiefs are highly classified.

headline: Weeknight Greatest Hits
abstract: We’ve collected some of our best quick recipes in our new special section. We hope you love them as much as we do.
lead_paragraph: Here at Five Weeknight Dishes we are always striving to give you delicious and interesting ideas for dinner that won’t take too much time to make — time you may hardly have in the first place. (You’re busy!) I’m talking about the recipes with the brilliant twist, the sharp shortcut, the technique that elevates something from just OK to truly good.

headline: House Democrats say they plan action next week on the infrastructure bill and their social safety net plan.
abstract: An infrastructure vote had already been planned for Monday, and top Democrats said they also intended to take up their larger social policy and climate package.
lead_paragraph: House Democratic leaders on Friday said they would take up both a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill and a far-reaching, multitrillion-dollar social safety net plan next week, as they worked feverishly to bridge deep divisions within their ranks that are holding up President Biden’s top two domestic priorities.

headline: Let’s Ignore Each Other in the Same Room
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Friendship']
abstract: Why parallel play is good for grown-ups, too.
lead_paragraph: “Want to read quietly next to each other in Riverside Park?” I texted a friend one Sunday afternoon in July. I was exhausted from staying out too late the night before and filled with the dread that clings to those final hours of the weekend — but I didn’t want to be alone. “Meet there at 1?” she wrote back and I packed my backpack, excited to spend another afternoon both alone and together with a friend.

headline: Wonking Out: This Might Be China’s ‘Babaru’ Moment
abstract: Evergrande may not be another Lehman, but so what?
lead_paragraph: OK, who ordered that? You’d think that between Covid-19, climate change and U.S. democracy under siege, we would already have enough crises on our plate. A potential Chinese financial meltdown is the last thing we need. Yet here we are.

headline: Remembering Richard Buckley
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'News and News Media', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Mr. Buckley was a well known fashion journalist who, despite being married to Tom Ford, largely avoided being the story.
lead_paragraph: There’s a photograph in Tom Ford’s house in Beverly Hills, a Polaroid of him with his husband, Richard Buckley, who died last weekend at 72 after more than 30 years of health issues resulting from cancer.

abstract: A map showing the storm’s route as it moved across the Atlantic Ocean.

lead_paragraph: A new lawsuit claims the social media giant allows bias based on gender and age.

abstract: In the 1950s, and ’60s, she depicted women, artists and thinkers in intricate dreamlike canvases that now fetch high prices.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Doris Diether, Guardian of Greenwich Village, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Zoning', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: She challenged Robert Moses to preserve Washington Square Park and helped save Shakespeare in the Park. In the process, she became a zoning expert.
lead_paragraph: Doris Diether, a full-time public citizen who by sheer gumption became a self-taught guardian of Washington Square Park and a Greenwich Village preservationist, died on Sept. 16 in the Waverly Place apartment she had occupied since 1958. She was 92.

headline: How Matt Gaetz Used Daddy’s Money to Become Trump’s Favorite Congressman
abstract: Like the president, the Florida Republican rode family connections, unorthodox real estate deals, and trolling to political fame.
lead_paragraph: Like the president, the Florida Republican rode family connections, unorthodox real estate deals, and trolling to political fame.

headline: Liberty Season Begins and Ends With Thrills
abstract: Sabrina Ionescu’s game-winner that opened the season had everyone thinking playoffs. Nothing from that point went as expected, including the team’s postseason run.
lead_paragraph: The dramatic ending of the Liberty’s first trip to the playoffs since 2017 evoked memories of the start of this season.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: This week, seven late-night hosts took part in Climate Night. Otherwise, they focused on news about BTS, the Pfizer vaccine and Donald Trump suing his niece.
lead_paragraph: This week, seven late-night hosts took part in Climate Night. Otherwise, they focused on news about BTS, the Pfizer vaccine and Donald Trump suing his niece.

headline: When a President Wrote for the Book Review
abstract: For the 125th anniversary of the Book Review, we revisit the time Teddy Roosevelt gushed on our front cover about a book he loved.
lead_paragraph: Past presidents and soon-to-be presidents have long written for the Book Review — Herbert Hoover, Bill Clinton, John F. Kennedy. The very first one to do so, though, was Theodore Roosevelt, on Oct. 13, 1918. It was clearly quite a coup for the Book Review, then just over two decades old, to persuade the former president to review “Jungle Peace,” a new volume from the explorer and naturalist William Beebe about the jungles of Guyana.

headline: How to Pack an Emergency ‘Go Bag’
abstract: Climate-related emergencies are becoming more frequent. Here’s how to prepare.
lead_paragraph: Climate-related emergencies are becoming more frequent. Here’s how to prepare.

headline: Randall Kennedy on ‘Say It Loud!’
abstract: Kennedy discusses his new essay collection, and Mary Roach talks about “Fuzz: When Nature Breaks the Law.”
lead_paragraph: The Harvard law professor Randall Kennedy’s new book, “Say It Loud!,” collects 29 of his essays. Kennedy’s opinions about the subjects listed in the book’s subtitle — race, law, history and culture — tend to be complex, and he’s not afraid to change his mind. He says on the podcast that there’s “no shame” in admitting you’re wrong, and that he does just that in the book when he finds it appropriate.

headline: My Mission to Ferret Out a Lost Broadway Score
abstract: The music is a missing piece of the Fats Waller story.
lead_paragraph: It’s not hard to know that Fats Waller was a jazz pianist and entertainer who wrote great songs like “Ain’t Misbehavin’.” You can see him do what he did, in all facets, in the film “Stormy Weather” from 1943.

headline: No, California Isn’t Doomed
keywords: ['internal-sub-only', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Taxation', 'Homeless Persons', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Elections, California Gubernatorial Recall (2021)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: With a budget surplus and plans for fixing its biggest problems, the Golden State is looking a bit more golden.
lead_paragraph: California has been struggling. It has stumbled through the Covid-19 pandemic and recession, afflicted by wildfires, an epidemic of homelessness and stratospheric housing prices. Last year it experienced its first population decline in records going back to 1900. Its latest mess was a costly and unsuccessful campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom.

headline: 5 Food Shows to Watch Right Now
abstract: Feel like you're in a food TV rut? Here are some great shows you can sink your teeth into.
lead_paragraph: Feel like you're in a food TV rut? Here are some great shows you can sink your teeth into.

headline: A Journey Along the River That Separates Russia From China
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Rivers', 'Cold War Era']
