lead_paragraph: THE AMUR RIVERBetween Russia and ChinaBy Colin Thubron

headline: Love Letter: A New Life Together, Thanks to Quarantine
abstract: And: Finding love close to home.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has reshaped many of our relationships in significant ways. For Meaghen Brown, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, an office shutdown meant finally being able to share a life with her long-distance boyfriend.

headline: In Louisiana, a Haunting Landscape
abstract: In a break from portraiture, Dawoud Bey photographed plantations on the west bank of the Mississippi River, drawing a line between past and present.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a photograph by Dawoud Bey, whose latest exhibition, “In This Here Place,” opened at Sean Kelly Gallery in New York on Sept. 10.

headline: Ahead of German Election, Hundreds of Thousands Demand Climate Action
keywords: ['Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Politics and Government', 'Youth', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Protests took place worldwide, but those in Germany had heightened urgency amid calls for the next government to do something about climate change.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Hundreds of thousands of young people around the world on Friday returned to the streets in the first global climate protest since the coronavirus pandemic forced them into lockdowns.

headline: Michael K. Williams Died of a Drug Overdose, Authorities Say
abstract: The actor known for “The Wire,” who was found dead in his apartment earlier this month, died of intoxication by a mixture of heroin, cocaine and fentanyl. He had been open about his struggle with addiction.
lead_paragraph: The death this month of Michael K. Williams, the Brooklyn actor most famous for his memorable portrayal of a gay stickup man in “The Wire,” was caused by an accidental drug overdose involving fentanyl, New York City’s medical examiner said on Friday.

headline: Meng’s release could eliminate a source of friction between China and the Biden administration.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Since coming to office, President Biden has taken a tough position on China but has also sought common ground.
lead_paragraph: The deal to release Meng Wanzhou could reduce a nettlesome conflict in U.S.-China relations.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Take an audio trip.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. You know those albums or songs that you so profoundly associate with a moment in your life that just the opening bars, maybe even just a couple of notes, function as a sort of time machine? You hear a song and you’re transported to that room in that house — maybe it’s your childhood bedroom, or your college dorm room. Maybe you’re 11 years old again, or you’re dating that person again, or you’re walking that very specific route to school again, the one on which you listened to this same album, over and over, on your Walkman (or Discman or iPod Nano).

headline: After weeks of planning, U.S. pharmacies and states are making Pfizer boosters available.
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tens of millions of Americans woke up eligible for booster shots.
lead_paragraph: On the heels of federal officials’ endorsement of booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine for many fully inoculated Americans, some states announced plans for getting even more shots in arms.

headline: Who are the Canadians detained after Ms. Meng’s arrest?
abstract: For more than 1,000 days, two Canadian men held in China have been in separate prisons. They have been accused of espionage, without evidence, and forced to go months without visits from diplomats. They have waited as their cases meander through China’s opaque legal system, despite calls around the world for their release.
lead_paragraph: For more than 1,000 days, two Canadian men held in China have been in separate prisons. They have been accused of espionage, without evidence, and forced to go months without visits from diplomats. They have waited as their cases meander through China’s opaque legal system, despite calls around the world for their release.

headline: In Britain, Rising Prices and Shortages Evoke 1970s-Style Jitters
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Shortages', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Taxation', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The nation’s economy is very different from the bleak days of the 70s, but certain parallels are unnerving Britons and loom as a potential headache for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Long lines at gas stations, rising fuel prices, empty shelves in supermarkets and worries about runaway inflation.

headline: U.S. schools with mask requirements are seeing fewer outbreaks, the C.D.C. finds.
abstract: Arizona schools that did not require masks had 3.5 times as many outbreaks as those that mandated them.
lead_paragraph: School mask mandates have generated controversy in many parts of the country. Now, two studies, published on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, provide additional evidence that masks protect children from the coronavirus, even when community rates are high and the contagious Delta variant is circulating.

headline: Senators say they pulled out of a Boston Globe conference to back a union.
abstract: Senators Edward J. Markey and Elizabeth Warren said they had declined to participate in solidarity with journalists who are in a contract dispute.
lead_paragraph: Senators Edward J. Markey and Elizabeth Warren, Democrats from Massachusetts, said Friday that they had backed out of a virtual conference hosted by The Boston Globe earlier in the week in solidarity with the journalists’ union there, which is in a yearslong dispute over a new labor contract.

headline: New York Hospitals Face Possible Mass Firings as Workers Spurn Vaccines
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Nursing Homes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: With a Monday deadline looming, thousands of health care workers in the state are risking their jobs by not getting a coronavirus vaccine.
lead_paragraph: In Buffalo, the Erie County Medical Center plans to suspend elective in-patient surgeries and not take intensive-care patients from other hospitals because it may soon fire about 400 employees who have chosen not to get vaccinated against the coronavirus.

headline: The Score of Final Fantasy Gets Its Due at the Concert Hall
abstract: The beloved music for this video game and others have been covered on YouTube for years. Now some are performed at classical music’s grandest venues.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At a recent concert here, the bows of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra rose and fell like the mighty sword of Sephiroth, the silver-haired villain of Final Fantasy VII. Onstage, a 32-person choir thundered the antagonist’s name: “Sephiroth!”

headline: Pakistan Says U.N. Envoy of Old Afghan Government Should Vacate Seat
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Stopping short of urging that a Taliban envoy to the U.N. be accepted, Pakistan’s foreign minister suggested that stability had improved in Taliban-ruled Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s foreign minister said Friday that the United Nations ambassador from Afghanistan’s toppled government had no standing and that its seat at the 193-member organization should remain vacant for now.

headline: Why Some People Stay Behind in a Wildfire
abstract: And why we decided to cover their choices.
lead_paragraph: This week on The Daily, Annie Correal, a staff reporter for The Times, introduced us to some members of her family who had made a difficult and controversial choice. Despite mandatory evacuation orders in parts of California that were threatened by a huge wildfire this summer, they chose to stay behind and try to fight the blaze. Many of you wrote in with thoughts about the episode, and with questions for Annie. Here are some of her answers, which have been edited and condensed for clarity.

headline: What Is the Ultimate Pair of Forever Jeans?
abstract: A reader, tired of chasing the latest fad in denim, asks for guidance in finding jeans that will last a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: The fact is, we are living in the era of everything-goes jeans. They are skinny, wide, boyfriend, flared, distressed, stovepipe, acid-washed, upcycled, jegging. Whatever you want, there’s a jeans style for that.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Boosters begin, and how to persuade the vaccine hesitant.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said today that coronavirus booster shots for certain categories of people who received the Pfizer vaccine will begin immediately. He urged those eligible to get one quickly to fortify their protection from the dangerous Delta variant.

headline: ‘Better to wait your turn in line,’ Biden says to those not yet eligible for Covid booster shots.
abstract: The authorization for boosters applies to groups of people in the United States fully vaccinated with the Pfizer vaccine, but about 45 percent of the country’s fully inoculated people received Moderna or Johnson & Johnson doses.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday urged people who are not yet eligible for coronavirus booster shots to be patient, while suggesting eligibility could expand rapidly.

headline: Faith vs. a Full Week of Work
abstract: You shouldn’t have to forgo religious observance to do your job.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Mike Flanagan Explores His Private Horrors in ‘Midnight Mass’
keywords: ['Television', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: In the new Netflix series, the acclaimed adapter of works by Shirley Jackson and Stephen King tells a more personal story.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Mike Flanagan has become best known for his adaptations of works by Shirley Jackson (“The Haunting of Hill House”), Henry James (“The Haunting of Bly Manor”) and Stephen King (“Gerald’s Game,” “Doctor Sleep”). The horrors in his latest project, “Midnight Mass,” a seven-episode limited series that premiered Friday on Netflix, are homegrown.

headline: PG&E Faces Criminal Charges Over Fatal 2020 Wildfire in California
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Charges including manslaughter arise from a blaze that killed four last year. A state inquiry said the utility’s power lines were involved.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Northern California filed criminal charges against Pacific Gas & Electric on Friday in connection with the deaths of four people last year in a wildfire that was linked to the utility’s equipment.

headline: When ‘It Could Never Possibly Happen Here’ Isn’t an Option
keywords: ['Mass Shootings', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: A mass shooting inside a suburban Memphis grocery store was called “the most horrific event that has occurred in Collierville history.” But it was one the town had prepared for.
lead_paragraph: COLLIERVILLE, Tenn. — A gunman opened fire in a suburban supermarket, and employees and customers immediately sought cover, barricading themselves in freezers and behind pallets of merchandise. Police officers swept in, employing lessons still fresh from training in June. Firefighters followed, shielding themselves in ballistic gear their department bought three years ago in anticipation of a moment like this.

headline: Huawei, Booster Shots, Britney Spears: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Education Doesn’t Inoculate Us from Vaccine Hesitancy
keywords: ['internal-sub-only', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Parenting', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Sociology', 'Medicine and Health', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: What we learn is filtered through our identities.
lead_paragraph: I got in a bit of a dust-up online recently for concluding that vaccine hesitance and resistance to masking were not uncommon among health care workers — and that it wasn’t surprising. I based my conclusion on vaccine hesitancy on some personal experience — a nurse at my vaccine site was very vocal about refusing the vaccine — and on various surveys showing that not all health care workers are willing to get vaccinated.

headline: An Exit Interview With a School Superintendent Who Defied Texas’ Governor
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Pedro Martinez is leaving San Antonio to become Chicago’s schools chief. He weighs in on his battles with Gov. Greg Abbott and why a student vaccine mandate should be “on the table.”
lead_paragraph: For months, Pedro Martinez has been locked in a political battle over the safety of schools in Texas. As the superintendent in San Antonio, he defied Gov. Greg Abbott by issuing a mask mandate in schools. He was the only superintendent of a major Texas school district to require school employees to be vaccinated, prompting a lawsuit from the Texas attorney general.

headline: Biden Promised to Follow the Science. But Sometimes, He Gets Ahead of the Experts.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: White House officials dismiss criticism that President Biden’s comments on booster shots amount to undue pressure on public health experts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he announced on Friday that booster shots would be available to some Americans, President Biden made a prediction: His administration was likely to soon provide third doses of the vaccine “across the board” to anyone who wanted one.

headline: Canadians weigh in on the Meng deal: ‘What about the two Michaels?’
abstract: While Meng Wanzhou contemplates flying to freedom to her home country, China, many Canadians on Friday lashed out at the continued imprisonment of two Canadians, known across the country as “the two Michaels.”
lead_paragraph: While Meng Wanzhou contemplates flying to freedom to her home country, China, many Canadians on Friday lashed out at the continued imprisonment of two Canadians, known across the country as “the two Michaels.”

headline: Pennsylvania Prosecutor Charged in Rape at Woman’s Home, Police Say
abstract: Jeffrey L. Thomas, the district attorney in Somerset County, Pa., was charged with rape, indecent and simple assault, strangulation and criminal trespass.
lead_paragraph: An elected county prosecutor in Pennsylvania who was charged on Wednesday with rape in connection with an attack on a woman in her home left the residence only after she promised not to call the police, the authorities said.

headline: Charles Sellers, 98, Historian Who Upset the Postwar Consensus, Dies
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A Southerner who became a radical at Berkeley, he argued that democracy developed in America as a response to the emergence of industrial capitalism.
lead_paragraph: Charles Sellers, a historian whose work on early-19th-century America helped overturn the postwar consensus that democracy and capitalism developed in tandem by showing that in fact they were more often at odds, died on Thursday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 98.

headline: Cliff Freeman, Adman Who Asked, ‘Where’s the Beef?,’ Dies at 80
abstract: His humorous touch was evident in commercials for Wendy’s, Little Caesars, Fox Sports and many other clients. “We have to win with wit,” he once said.
lead_paragraph: Cliff Freeman, the award-winning copywriter and creative director behind many witty television commercials, most memorably the one for Wendy’s in which a gravelly-voiced old woman shouts, “Where’s the beef?,” at the sight of a puny hamburger patty in an oversized bun, died on Sept. 5 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: How Democrats Could Shrink Their $3.5 Trillion Budget Bill
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'American Rescue Plan (2021)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Child Tax Credits and Stipends', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Here are three options to shrink down the Democrats’ climate change and social welfare bill as moderates demand less spending and smaller tax hikes to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Democratic leaders struggle to unite their caucus behind a sprawling domestic policy package, it is increasingly clear the $3.5 trillion in spending and tax increases will have to be pared back, possibly by a lot, to make it to President Biden’s desk.

headline: States Begin a Complex Booster Shot Rollout for Pfizer Recipients
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Elderly', 'Drugstores', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Health officials were preparing on Friday to start giving booster shots to older and at-risk Americans, trying to make sense of new and broad eligibility guidelines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — State health officials rushed on Friday to roll out campaigns to provide coronavirus booster shots for millions of vulnerable people who got the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and to help a confused public understand who qualifies for the extra shots.

headline: This Is How America’s Richest Families Stay That Way
keywords: ['Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Inequality', 'American Families Plan (2021)']
abstract: The longer we fail to constrain inherited wealth, the sooner the dream of a democratic society dies.
lead_paragraph: Most people have probably never heard of a stepped-up basis, but it might just be the most important tax loophole in America — one that billionaires use to pass vast sums of wealth down to their heirs by avoiding capital gains taxes.

headline: Penny Harrington, Who Broke a Blue Ceiling, Dies at 79
abstract: Overcoming bias, she became the first woman to head a major city police department in the nation, in Portland, Ore. But a rocky tenure led her to resign 17 months later.
lead_paragraph: Penny Harrington, who, after years of fighting gender discrimination in the Portland, Ore., Police Bureau, became its first female police chief — and the first woman to head a major city police department in the country — died on Sept. 15 at her home in Morro Bay, Calif. She was 79.

headline: Subtropical Storm Teresa Becomes the 19th Named Storm of the Season
abstract: Teresa, which is not expected to threaten land, will likely dissipate by Sunday forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Subtropical Storm Teresa formed on Friday north of Bermuda and became the 19th named storm of the busy 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, but forecasters said they expected it to dissipate by Sunday.

headline: Alberta’s ‘Best Summer Ever’ Ends With an Overwhelmed Medical System
abstract: A surge of Covid-19 cases has forced the province to ask for military assistance in airlifting patients to hospitals across the country.
lead_paragraph: Premier Jason Kenney was roundly criticized by public health experts in June when he declared victory over the coronavirus and made Alberta the first province to largely lift pandemic restrictions.

headline: Rebuking Biden, Iran’s Chief Diplomat Demands More Sanctions Relief
abstract: The foreign minister for Iran’s new hard-line government said it would demand a higher price for limiting its nuclear program than it did in the 2015 deal.
lead_paragraph: Accusing President Biden of continuing “the thick file of the Trump sanctions against Iran,’’ the new, hard-line Iranian foreign minister said on Friday that in return for agreeing to limits on its nuclear program, his country would demand far more sanctions relief than it received under the 2015 nuclear deal.

headline: Matt Amodio, the Latest ‘Jeopardy!’ Star, Breaks $1 Million
abstract: The Ph.D. student in computer science at Yale is only the third contestant to reach that level of winnings.
lead_paragraph: “Jeopardy!” has another seemingly unstoppable sensation.

headline: New Guidance on Booster Shots Gets Ahead of the Science
abstract: The responsibility for making decisions about getting boosters in some cases has shifted onto individuals and their doctors.
lead_paragraph: There’s finally a decision on which Americans should get booster shots against Covid-19. Unfortunately, some of the new federal recommendations go well beyond the data and foist the decision of appropriateness onto individuals and their doctors. And by expanding booster eligibility to a huge swath of the population, the Biden administration risks undermining confidence in vaccines.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez apologizes for her ‘present’ vote on Iron Dome funding.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation', 'Palestinians']
abstract: In a letter to constituents, the New York congresswoman suggested she had changed her “no” vote because she had been subjected to “hateful targeting” for opposing the aid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York and the highest-profile progressive in the House, apologized on Friday to her constituents for an abrupt decision to pull back her vote against providing $1 billion in new funding for Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system, suggesting she had done so after being subjected to “hateful targeting” for opposing it.

headline: Vigil Held for Slain Teacher Sabina Nessa
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Mourners gathered in southeast London to remember Sabina Nessa, a 28-year-old elementary school teacher who was killed in a park near her home. Her death has reignited outrage over violence against women in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Mourners gathered in southeast London to remember Sabina Nessa, a 28-year-old elementary school teacher who was killed in a park near her home. Her death has reignited outrage over violence against women in Britain.

headline: U.S. Agrees to Release Huawei Executive in Case That Strained Ties With China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: China reciprocated within hours, freeing two Canadians, a notable resolution in a relationship that has been spiraling downward.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department reached an agreement on Friday clearing the way for a senior executive of Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecommunications giant, to return to China after admitting some wrongdoing in a sanctions violation case, removing one major irritant between the two superpowers.

headline: ‘Stop the Steal’ Movement Races Forward, Ignoring Arizona Humiliation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'States (US)']
abstract: As a Republican review of 2020 votes in Arizona sputtered to a close, Donald Trump and his allies signaled that their attack on the election, and their drive to reshape future elections, were far from over.
lead_paragraph: After all the scurrying, searching, sifting, speculating, hand-counting and bamboo-hunting had ended, Republicans’ post-mortem review of election results in Arizona’s largest county wound up only adding to President Biden’s margin of victory there.

headline: Woman Charged With Arson in Starting California Wildfire, Officials Say
abstract: The Fawn fire, which has burned nearly 10,000 acres, was spreading quickly on Friday, a day after the authorities accused a Palo Alto woman of igniting the blaze.
lead_paragraph: A woman from Palo Alto, Calif., was charged with arson in connection with a wildfire that has burned about 9,850 acres and damaged more than 25 buildings in Shasta County, worsening the toll of an already brutal fire season in the state, the authorities said.

headline: Will Lawmakers Finally Act Against Big Tech?
keywords: ['internal-sub-only', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Virtual Currency', 'Social Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Child Pornography']
abstract: Facebook may have crossed the line.
lead_paragraph: Kids and whistle-blowers. This is the heart of the recent Wall Street Journal series of investigations about how Facebook runs its business. And it’s why the articles landed with such force.

headline: China frees 2 jailed Canadians after the U.S. agrees to release a Huawei executive.
abstract: Two Canadians imprisoned in China since 2018 were free and on their way home, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Two Canadians imprisoned in China since 2018 were free and on their way home, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced Friday night.

headline: U.S. Ryder Cup Team Seizes Big Lead on a Wild Opening Day
abstract: The action included some harrowing moments for a couple of golfers, and the gallery included Michael Jordan.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — A snapshot panorama from the first day of the Ryder Cup would start with a crowd of 40,000 — 90 percent of it American fans because of pandemic-related travel restrictions — noisily arriving before sunrise on Friday to roar unabated for 12 hours and through eight matches that concluded in the gloaming. Patriotic costumes were in vogue, though not among the most prominent spectators in the mix: Michael Jordan and Stephen Curry.

headline: How to Build Roller Skates
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Roller Skating', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Photography']

headline: Greek Goddess of Memory
abstract: Adam Simon Levine’s debut puzzle speaks to us, in words we can’t pronounce.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Capping off a week of daily grids from brand- or almost-new constructors is this debut poser from Adam Simon Levine, with a dramatic centerpiece. I really needed the success jingle to know that I’d finished, at which point I unapologetically went to the internet to learn something new. When this happens on a Saturday, I consider the knowledge gained to be value added, especially when it’s something fascinating and important that slipped through the cracks of my experience and education.

keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Discrimination', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Income Inequality', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Minorities', 'Hispanic-Americans']

lead_paragraph: Anita Hill still speaks in the measured tones she did while being questioned before an all-white, all-male panel before the Senate in 1991 — a young law professor in a blue linen suit who would give the nation an overnight education in workplace sexual harassment.

lead_paragraph: Bushwig, the end-of-summer drag weekend extravaganza held each year in New York, was born of a simple desire.

headline: Whales So Close You Can Touch Them: A Family Adventure in Canada
abstract: Recalling a prepandemic trip to a watery landscape in Quebec province: “The adventure we had feels like one plucked from a world I can no longer reach, not unlike watching the water, waiting for a whale to crest.”
lead_paragraph: The trail to our yurt was narrow, muddy and peppered with tiny ceramic and plastic gnomes, fairies and bears. My 8-year-old daughter, clutching her stuffed giraffe and gingerly avoiding the knotty roots, spotted a miniature tiger, crouched at the base of a pine tree.

headline: Long Hours, Low Pay, Loneliness and a Booming Industry
keywords: ['Home Health Care', 'Elder Care', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Working Hours', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: The ranks of home health aides are expected to grow more than any other job in the next decade. What kind of work are they being asked to do?
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, Yvette Dessin spent long work days with her elderly patients, accompanying them on walks, cooking them meals and bathing those who needed that most intimate kind of care. If a patient died, Ms. Dessin and her adult daughter attended the funeral services to pay their respects.

headline: U.K.’s Migrant Boat Dispute Has Eyes Fixed on the Channel
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The southeastern coast of England is increasingly the focal point of Britain’s migration debate as the government advocates more extreme measures to halt asylum seekers arriving by boat.
lead_paragraph: FOLKESTONE, England — Using high-powered binoculars and a telescope, three volunteers from a humanitarian monitoring group stood on the Kent coast, peering across the English Channel. The looming clock tower of the French town of Calais was visible on this clear morning, but so was the distinctive outline of a small rubber dinghy.

headline: Affluent, Anxious and Almost Normal: A Journey Through Merkel’s Germany
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: As Angela Merkel prepares to step down after 16 years as chancellor of Germany, she leaves behind a country profoundly changed — and anxious about changing more.
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — The small silver star at the tip of Aleksandar Djordjevic’s Mercedes shines bright. He polishes it every week.

headline: One Solution to a Shortage of Skilled Workers? Diversify the Construction Industry.
abstract: President Biden’s infrastructure plan would create a hiring challenge, but also an opportunity to recruit from communities that the industry has long ignored.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: To Get Back Arrested Executive, China Uses a Hardball Tactic: Seizing Foreigners
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Politics and Government', 'Extradition', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The speed at which Beijing returned two Canadians held seemingly tit-for-tat in exchange may signal comfort with the tactic.
lead_paragraph: In a rapid-fire climax to a 1,030-day standoff, China welcomed home a company executive whose arrest in Canada and possible extradition to the United States made her a focus of superpower friction. In getting her back, Beijing brandished a formidable political tool: using detained foreign citizens as bargaining chips in disputes with other countries.

headline: ‘I Need an Army’: Across America, Schools Cram for Their Covid Tests
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Children and Childhood', 'your-feed-health', 'your-feed-education']
abstract: Some districts have established robust virus testing programs, but many others are struggling.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — One recent Thursday, Ciara Brown, a junior at Fox Tech High School in San Antonio, stepped up to a small white table, pulled down her face mask and took a test that is still far from standard in American schools: a cotton swab up the nose.

headline: Review: Sounds and Styles Playfully Collide in ‘Only an Octave Apart’
abstract: This show brings together two convention-inverting artists: the cabaret star Justin Vivian Bond and the opera singer Anthony Roth Costanzo.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever wondered what it’s like to be normal?” Justin Vivian Bond, the doyenne of downtown cabaret, asks the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo a few songs into their show, “Only an Octave Apart,” at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: Can You Break the Lease if Your Apartment Might Flood?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Floods', 'Content Type: Service', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords']
abstract: Maintaining a rental property — including making sure water drains properly — is the responsibility of the landlord, not the tenant.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a Park Slope garden apartment with ongoing drainage issues. During hurricanes Henri and Ida, I was bucketing water away from the door, which leads to my bedroom. I bought a raised drain guard and a sump pump that hooks up to a garden hose, but the pump couldn’t keep up. Because I was home, the damage was limited. But what if a big storm hits when I’m not home? The management company told me to deduct the cost of the pump from the rent. But shouldn’t the landlord address the larger drainage issues?

headline: Pfizer boosters are recommended for many Americans, and Alaska faces its worst surge: The week in Covid news.
abstract: Millions of Americans became eligible for booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine this week, after federal regulators recommended it for people inoculated with that vaccine more than six months ago and who fall into one of three categories:  over 65; having underlying medical conditions; or working that put them at risk for infections.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans became eligible for booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine this week, after federal regulators recommended it for people inoculated with that vaccine more than six months ago and who fall into one of three categories:  over 65; having underlying medical conditions; or working that put them at risk for infections.

keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Politics and Government']

headline: Democrats’ Spending Fight Carries High Stakes for Their Candidates

headline: The World Lost a Great Philosopher This Week
keywords: ['internal-sub-only', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Philosophy', 'Whites', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A tribute to Charles W. Mills.
lead_paragraph: This has been a sad week for those of us who read, study and care about political philosophy. That’s because Charles W. Mills, a U.K.-born and Jamaica-raised philosopher whose life’s work was the interrogation and critique of the foundations of liberalism, died on Monday.

headline: How Do I Tell the Story of Robert E. Lee?
abstract: Exposing the complicated truth of America's past is the real work of historians.
lead_paragraph: This month in Virginia, the most famous statue of Robert E. Lee — a 21-foot-tall bronze equestrian sculpture — was swung down from its granite base on Richmond’s Monument Avenue and cut in two at the waist so that it could fit under highway overpasses on its final journey to an undisclosed state facility. Hundreds gathered to cheer the event as a victory for racial justice.

headline: This Is No Way to End a Pandemic
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Getting first shots in arms, globally, is more important than any booster program.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, before any Covid vaccine had been authorized for use, former President Donald Trump all but promised that a shot would be available before Election Day. When Food and Drug Administration regulators suggested that he was mistaken, he accused them of deliberately slow-walking their authorizations in an attempt to influence the coming election — and threatened to override them.

headline: 7 Gadgets to Make You Less Weird When You Go Back to the Office
abstract: Has returning to your workplace got you down? These inventions can help.
lead_paragraph: After 18 months of isolation, it’s time to dust off your favorite Dockers. We put in 130 hours of research and testing to offer you seven gadgets that will help you ease back into the daily grind. Strap on your lanyard; we’re going in.

headline: How Record Rain and Officials’ Mistakes Led to Drownings on a Subway
abstract: The deluge in the city of Zhengzhou revealed how China’s years of go-go construction had left its cities vulnerable to climate change.
lead_paragraph: ZHENGZHOU, China — The heaviest hour of rainfall ever reliably recorded in China crashed like a miles-wide waterfall over the city of Zhengzhou on July 20, killing at least 300 people, including 14 who drowned in a subway tunnel.

headline: A 3-D Model Built With Public Records and Phone Calls
abstract: For an interactive article on business inside the Empire State Building, a New York Times team turned to interviews with tenants, vacancy listings, promotional materials and real estate data.
lead_paragraph: In late May, when the New York Times journalists Keith Collins and Matthew Haag sent their first email to the company that owns the Empire State Building, New York was expected to fully reopen within six to eight weeks — and they had an ambitious idea for how to cover it.

headline: They Investigate Police Killings. Their Record Is Wanting.

abstract: After the murder of George Floyd, some states looked to independent agencies to examine deaths in police custody. But dozens of cases handled by the Texas Rangers show the approach has flaws.

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Income Inequality', 'Paid Time Off', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Readers disagree with a guest essay that argued that America cannot afford the $3.5 trillion bill now before Congress.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox cooks, and Henry Rathvon is a wraith this week.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today we have a passage that preys on those of us who like to rely on the limitations of one- and two-letter words to help us fill in a letter or 10 in an acrostic grid. It sometimes happens that we get a reference to someone’s initials, or a special term that includes a single character, but we can usually rely on “a” and “i” as single words. There are a several exceptions today, and they’re integral to the excerpt’s topic, which is all those vowels that we actually have in the English language.

headline: Two more federal judges rule against the Tennessee governor’s ban on mask mandates.
abstract: The rulings were the second and third the last two weeks to suspend Gov. Bill Lee’s executive order after parents sued, charging that it violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.
lead_paragraph: Two federal judges in Tennessee have dealt blows to Gov. Bill Lee’s executive order that allows families to opt out of school mask mandates, ruling in separate cases on Friday that local districts could require face coverings to protect disabled children while legal challenges progress through the courts.

headline: Norway lifts coronavirus restrictions after 561 days.
abstract: “Now the time has come to return to a normal daily life,” the prime minister, Erna Solberg, said.
lead_paragraph: Norway on Saturday lifted social distancing rules, capacity limits on businesses and other pandemic-era restrictions that have been in place for more than a year.

headline: What Is CoolSculpting?
abstract: The fat-freezing procedure left supermodel Linda Evangelista “disfigured.” Here’s what experts say it is supposed to do and what the most common side effects are.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Linda Evangelista, the ’90s-era supermodel, shared on Instagram that she had been disfigured by a fat-reducing procedure called CoolSculpting that did the opposite of what it promised: Instead of reducing the amount of fat she had, CoolSculpting increased it, she said.

headline: North Korea Dangles Hopes for Summit and End-of-War Declaration
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Kim Jong-un’s sister responds to the South Korean leader’s last attempt to put the peace process back on track, but skepticism abounds.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — ​North Korea would consider holding a summit meeting with South Korea and declaring an official end to the Korean War if the South can restore trust with it, the North’s official news agency reported on Saturday, citing the sister of its leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: ‘No Time to Be a Child’
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: During the pandemic, teenage girls took on more caregiving at home, extra shifts at work and the burden of organizing racial justice protests. In many instances, it upended their lives.
lead_paragraph: — A poem by Azariah Baker, a high school student in Chicago

headline: Can Joe Biden Recover?
abstract: Biden can definitely float his way back up. Clawing his way up might be a different story.
lead_paragraph: This was a good week for anyone enthused about relitigating the 2020 election. First there was new evidence, reported in a new book about the Biden family from the Politico writer Ben Schreckinger and in an Insider story on an abortive Libya-related influence operation, suggesting the famous Hunter Biden emails were real and indicating how much Hunter’s influence-peddling depended on proximity to his father. The Twitter and Facebook decisions to censor The New York Post’s election-season version of the Hunter Biden story looked partisan and illiberal at the time; now they look worse.

headline: Angela Merkel Was Underestimated, and It Became Her Superpower
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Her 16-year reign is evidence that effective politics doesn't require losing your humanity.
lead_paragraph: Almost every article written about Angela Merkel’s tenure as Germany’s chancellor notes that one of her greatest political strengths has been that she is so often underestimated. In this, she is not unique: Helmut Kohl, who launched Ms. Merkel into politics and spent even more time in the chancellor’s office, once declared, “I make my living by being underestimated.”

headline: Cloyd Boyer, Last of a Three-Brother Baseball Rarity, Dies at 94
abstract: His pitching career was cut short, but at one time he and his brothers Ken and Clete were all on the major league stage together. He ended up outliving them.
lead_paragraph: Cloyd Boyer pitched for the St. Louis Cardinals and the Kansas City Athletics and, in a baseball career of nearly a half century, later worked as a pitching coach for the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves and as a minor league manager, a roving pitching instructor and a scout.

headline: A Quarterback Duel Fizzles, but the Irish Explode
abstract: Jack Coan, who transferred to Notre Dame from Wisconsin, looked more solid than his Badger replacement, though he left the game in the third quarter with an injury.
lead_paragraph: Saturday’s college football game between Notre Dame and Wisconsin had an air of suspense before the two teams even took the field. Did Wisconsin Coach Paul Chryst make the right decision in sticking with quarterback Graham Mertz over Jack Coan? How would Coan, now Notre Dame’s quarterback, fare against his former team? Would this game add Coan to a growing list of quarterback transfers who elevated their new programs upon arrival?

headline: George Mraz, Consummate Jazz Bassist, Dies at 77
abstract: For half a century, he was in constant demand, backing big names like Oscar Peterson as well as countless up-and-coming performers.
lead_paragraph: George Mraz, a sought-after jazz bassist whose deft, versatile work anchored the recordings and performances of generations of artists, from Oscar Peterson and Dizzy Gillespie more than 50 years ago to Cyrus Chestnut and Joe Lovano in this century, died on Sept. 16 in Prague. He was 77.

headline: Icelanders Vote in Volatile Election With Climate in Mind
abstract: Icelanders voted Saturday in a general election dominated by climate change, with an unprecedented number of political parties likely to win parliamentary seats.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Icelanders were voting Saturday in a general election dominated by climate change, with an unprecedented number of political parties likely to win parliamentary seats.

headline: New York weighs using the National Guard to replace unvaccinated health care workers.
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul has plans to use National Guard members and out-of-state professionals to cover staff shortages if thousands of health care workers fail to meet a state vaccination deadline on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is considering calling in the National Guard and recruiting medical professionals from other states to cover looming staff shortages at hospitals and other facilities as the likelihood grows that tens of thousands of health care workers will not meet the state’s deadlines for mandated vaccinations.

headline: Study Breaks
abstract: Priyanka Sethy and Matthew Stock put us to the test.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s back-to-school season, no matter how long ago we last went back to school; this grid is a reminder of that, but it’s a fun one. It’s a collaboration between Matthew Stock, who has made two Sunday grids and several daily puzzles for The Times, and Priyanka Sethy, who makes her constructing debut. Ms. Sethy is a bicoastal management consultant, and Mr. Stock works for a math education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill.; they met via the Crossword Puzzle Collaboration Directory on Facebook and worked together (from Ms. Sethy’s theme idea) over video.

headline: Oleksandr Usyk Upsets Anthony Joshua to Upend Heavyweight Boxing Picture
abstract: Usyk beat Joshua in a unanimous decision as Joshua had been openly looking toward the winner of a forthcoming Tyson Fury-Deontay Wilder bout.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Joshua needed a knockout.

headline: 11 Arrested in Fraternity Pledge’s Alcohol-Poisoning Death, Police Say
abstract: Adam Oakes, a 19-year-old student at Virginia Commonwealth University, died in February after being told to drink a bottle of Jack Daniel’s whiskey, family members say.
lead_paragraph: Eight people were arrested on Friday and three others on Monday after an investigation into the death of Adam Oakes, a student at Virginia Commonwealth University who died in February from alcohol poisoning at a fraternity party, the authorities said.

headline: Tensions Flare in Ryder Cup as the U.S. Team Takes a Commanding Lead
abstract: The Americans were calmly overpowering the European side, but then things got testy.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Golf is a game of decorum.

headline: At Least 3 Killed and 50 Hurt in Amtrak Derailment in Montana, Officials Say
abstract: The derailment, involving eight cars of the Empire Builder train, happened near Joplin, Mont., on Saturday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: At least three people were killed and 50 others were injured after an Amtrak train derailed in Montana on Saturday afternoon, setting off a frantic response by rescuers who scrambled to extricate passengers from cars, the authorities said.

headline: Yankees Pull Even With the Red Sox as Stanton Leads the Way
abstract: A pair of wins in Boston, both powered by Giancarlo Stanton, has the rival teams tied for the A.L.’s top wild-card spot.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — After meandering through most of September, the Yankees’ season has reached a make-or-break point. Over the final week and a half of the regular season, they have six games scheduled against two of the teams — the Boston Red Sox and Toronto Blue Jays — they are fighting with for the final two postseason spots in the American League.

headline: With 2 Losses, Clemson Is a Far Cry From Its Enduring Playoff Standards
abstract: Clemson has had some tight moments. But before this season, the Tigers would usually come through.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — For more than a decade, it has been hard to imagine the Clemson Tigers being uncomfortable in the position they were in Saturday night: trailing North Carolina State in double overtime, fourth-and-5 at the 20-yard line in front of a frothy, capacity crowd on the road.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 26, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 26, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 11 about Mo Abudu, the head of EbonyLife Media, describes incorrectly the status of more than 30 deals between Abudu’s media company and others. Some of those deals have been made public; they were not all unreported.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Eyes on the English Channel as a Migrant Crisis Brews.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 26, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “There is this history of welcome and also of defense. Both are ingrained — it just depends on which buttons are pressed.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘Slipping Into the Cool Water Always Feels Like Slipping Back in Time’
abstract: A bittersweet last day of summer, a late-night song in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: She Bought Her Dream Home. Then a ‘Sovereign Citizen’ Changed the Locks.
abstract: A New Jersey woman was preyed upon by a fast-growing extremist group that claims its members are sovereign Moors, not bound by U.S. laws.
lead_paragraph: The official-looking letters started arriving soon after Shanetta Little bought the cute Tudor house on Ivy Street in Newark. Bearing a golden seal, in aureate legalistic language, the documents claimed that an obscure 18th-century treaty gave the sender rights to claim her new house as his own.

headline: The Marines Reluctantly Let a Sikh Officer Wear a Turban. He Says It’s Not Enough.
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Uniforms', 'Turbans', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: While other armed services allow some religion-based exceptions to dress standards without problems, the Marines insist that even small deviations can threaten the force’s effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: Almost every morning for five years, First Lt. Sukhbir Toor has pulled on the uniform of the United States Marine Corps. On Thursday, he also got to put on the turban of a faithful Sikh.

headline: A British Men’s Wear Designer With Jamaican Roots
abstract: Bianca Saunders started her namesake fashion label when she was 24.
lead_paragraph: Name: Bianca Saunders

headline: Ancient Greece Through the Lens of the Camera Obscura
abstract: Vera Lutter evaded wildfires and sacrificed meals and sleep to produce beguiling photographs with an archaic form of image-making.
lead_paragraph: In early August, when The Times Magazine reached out to the photographer Vera Lutter about documenting ancient Athenian ruins, she was in her native Germany mourning her father, who died this summer. At the time, European news had been dominated by reports of wildfires in Greece — an ill omen for the clear skies and uphill hikes required to shoot atop the Acropolis.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: New Limits Give Chinese Video Gamers Whiplash
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'E-Sports']
abstract: China has a complex relationship with video games. New government rules for minors have made it even more so.
lead_paragraph: China’s video game industry is booming. But it sure doesn’t feel that way to Stone Shi, a game designer in China.

headline: With Abortion Largely Banned in Texas, an Oklahoma Clinic Is Inundated
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Abortion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: The new law prohibits abortions after about six weeks, a very early stage of pregnancy. Many women are now traveling out of state for the procedure.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — On a windy Tuesday morning, the parking lot outside a small brick building on the Southside of Oklahoma City was filling up fast. The first to arrive, a red truck shortly before 8 a.m., was from Texas. So was the second and the third.

headline: This Lab Charges $380 for a Covid Test. Is That What Congress Had in Mind?
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Price Gouging', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Insurers say it’s price-gouging, but a law left an opening for some labs to charge any price they wished.
lead_paragraph: At the drugstore, a rapid Covid test usually costs less than $20.

headline: For Schumer and Pelosi, the Challenge of a Career With No Margin for Error
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'American Jobs Plan (2021)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Global Warming', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'American Families Plan (2021)']
abstract: The top two Democrats in Congress face a daunting pile of legislative imperatives. With President Biden’s agenda hanging in the balance and few votes to spare, can they get it done?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last week, as all outward appearances suggested gridlock on Capitol Hill, Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, and Speaker Nancy Pelosi were in perpetual motion, grasping to salvage their $3.5 trillion social policy and climate change bill.

headline: Five Years After Peace Deal, Colombia Is Running Out of Time, Experts Say
keywords: ['Peace Process', 'Coca (Plant)', 'Rural Areas', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Income Inequality', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: A treaty with rebels in 2016 called for the end of a decades-long war. But that is not the same as achieving peace, and the window for doing so may be closing.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Colombia — On a coca farm hidden in the jungle, a half-dozen day laborers slip out of hammocks and head to work, harvesting the shiny green leaves that will become cocaine.

headline: Known for Feuding With Immigrants, a TV Star Wants to Run a Town Many Call Home
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A mayoral bid by a TV commentator known for her inflammatory messaging on race raises a larger question: How should Portugal address its colonial legacy?
lead_paragraph: AMADORA, Portugal — She is a former TV commentator whose penchant for provocation has won her fame, or at least notoriety, in Portugal: for instance, by describing calls for racial justice traitorous, and by referring to Black Portuguese by an old-fashioned term that translates to something like “Negro.”

headline: Labour’s Leader Struggles to Emerge From Boris Johnson’s Shadow
abstract: Competent but low on charisma, Keir Starmer has yet to give British voters a clear reason to support the main opposition party, critics say.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If Prime Minister Boris Johnson went to one extreme with his pithy 2019 election slogan — “get Brexit done” — the leader of the opposition Labour Party, Keir Starmer, has gone to the other.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Why Was Vicha Ratanapakdee Killed?’
abstract: His death helped awaken the nation to a rise in anti-Asian violence. For his grieving family, the reckoning hasn’t gone far enough.
lead_paragraph: Throughout 2020, multiple strangers came at Monthanus Ratanapakdee seemingly out of nowhere. An old man yelled at her in Golden Gate Park — something about a virus and going back to her country. When she discussed these incidents, her father would ask, “Is it really that bad?”

headline: Booster Shots, Germany, Britney Spears: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: A Debt Deadline Looms
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: The Fed indicated it was planning to slow down its purchases of government bonds as soon as November. And food delivery workers in New York gained protections.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve indicated on Wednesday that it might soon ease measures it put in place to support the economy since the depths of the pandemic downturn. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said the central bank’s monthly purchases of $120 billion in government-backed bonds “still have a use, but it’s time for us to begin to taper them,” and indicated that it might slow the program as early as November. Meanwhile, half the Fed’s policymakers said they expected to raise interest rates next year.

headline: Women Enslaved by ISIS Say They Did Not Consent to a Film About Them
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Privacy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The acclaimed documentary “Sabaya” portrays the rescue of Yazidi women sexually enslaved by the Islamic State terrorist group. But many of the traumatized women said they never agreed to be in the film.
lead_paragraph: In a critically acclaimed documentary on the rescue of women and girls sexually enslaved by ISIS, tension-filled scenes play out in a Syrian detention camp and later in a safe house where victims are faced with agonizing choices.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 27, 2021
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Can a Mantra Make You Run Faster? This Olympic Medalist Has No Doubt.
abstract: “I love these words and phrases because usually they start in practice or in conversation,” Courtney Frerichs said. Those words and phrases helped her win a silver medal.
lead_paragraph: This is a story about Courtney Frerichs, who turned in one of the surprise performances of the Tokyo Olympics. But really it is a story about mantras, because who Frerichs is and what she managed to accomplish this summer are all about the words she has been repeating to herself for years.

headline: Germany chooses a new Parliament.
abstract: On Sunday, Germans will choose a new Parliament, which will ultimately determine who succeeds Chancellor Angela Merkel at the helm of the European Union’s most populous democracy. More than 60 million people are eligible to vote in this election.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Germans will choose a new Parliament, which will ultimately determine who succeeds Chancellor Angela Merkel at the helm of the European Union’s most populous democracy. More than 60 million people are eligible to vote in this election.

headline: What to watch for on Sunday.
abstract: Sixty million people are eligible to vote in the German national election on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Sixty million people are eligible to vote in the German national election on Sunday. There won’t be a new government that night, or the next day — it could take the rival parties weeks or even months to settle on a coalition with a parliamentary majority. But the ballots are tallied quickly, and the new shape of Germany’s political landscape is likely to be visible within hours.

headline: Are These the Next Cool Sunglasses?
abstract: The emerging brand Sunnei went all-in on goggles on Milan Fashion Week’s third day.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.

headline: German officials expect record mail-in ballots.
abstract: BERLIN — German election officials are expecting mail-in ballots to break records in Sunday’s federal election. At least 40 percent and possibly a majority of ballots will arrive by mail, according to Georg Thiel, head of the agency in charge of counting the votes.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German election officials are expecting mail-in ballots to break records in Sunday’s federal election. At least 40 percent and possibly a majority of ballots will arrive by mail, according to Georg Thiel, head of the agency in charge of counting the votes.

headline: Francesco Risso on Rethinking the Fashion Show
abstract: After almost two years of social distancing, the Marni creative director had had enough. So he dressed all 500 of his guests in Milan this week.
lead_paragraph: Francesco Risso has been creative director at Marni since 2016, mixing the Milanese fashion house’s explosive prints and prim but off-kilter silhouettes with his own bold and often playful aesthetic. On Saturday, 18 months after Marni’s last physical runway show, the onetime protégé of Miuccia Prada upped the ante yet again with an experimental live event. Here, he explains why.

headline: At Black-owned funeral homes, many staffers are burying their own colleagues.
abstract: “We mourn, we comfort, we are in pain, too,” said Hari P. Close, the president of the National Funeral Directors & Morticians Association.
lead_paragraph: For Black-owned funeral businesses, the pain of the coronavirus pandemic has been two-pronged: Many funeral workers are mourning their own colleagues who have died from the virus, all while experiencing burnout from having to preside over countless services for their Black patrons and neighbors who have died at disproportionate rates from Covid.

headline: An Immersive, Absurdist Show to Remember
abstract: Takeaways from a Marni experience that brought new life to Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Finally, a kind of catharsis. An event that — like the 150th-ranked Emma Raducanu winning the U.S. Open or Chloé Zhao getting to direct a Marvel movie — kicked open the door after months of mostly isolation to shake us out of complacency.

headline: These are the leading candidates for the chancellery.
abstract: In Germany, political parties name their candidates for chancellor before campaigning begins.
lead_paragraph: In Germany, political parties name their candidates for chancellor before campaigning begins, and most of the focus falls on the selections who have a realistic chance of winning.

headline: Swiss Voters Approve Law Allowing Same-Sex Marriages
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Referendums', 'Politics and Government', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Adoptions']
abstract: The legislation, endorsed in a referendum, will also allow same-sex couples to use sperm banks and to adopt children for the first time.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Voters in Switzerland overwhelmingly decided on Sunday to legalize same-sex marriage, making the country one of the last in Western Europe to do so.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Melissa Clark’s pepperoni pasta with lemon and garlic is a perfect weeknight meal or Sunday dinner.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Time was, Sundays were so different from the other days: long and relaxed and contemplative, a chance to recuperate from the toil of the week, hopefully in the kitchen. I’d make like Marcella Hazan and simmer a Bolognese for the better part of an afternoon, make yogurt for the week to come, roast a chicken or a turkey breast for sandwiches, bake a visiting cake to take to co-workers on Monday morning.

headline: Republicans Are Playing a Dangerous Game With Debt
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Taxation', 'United States Economy', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: They know the borrowing limit must be raised, one way or another.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans say they believe the nation’s borrowing limit should be raised, and don’t want the United States to default on its financial obligations — they just don’t want any part in helping Democrats get it done. “This could not be simpler,” the minority leader, Mitch McConnell, said on Thursday. If the Democrats “want to tax, borrow and spend historic sums of money without our input, they’ll have to raise the debt limit without our help.”

headline: We Did the Research: Masks Work, and You Should Choose a High Quality Mask if Possible
keywords: ['Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Research', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: One of the largest studies to date shows masks work.
lead_paragraph: Masks, especially surgical ones, substantially reduce the risk of getting Covid-19. Getting more people to wear them — through mandates or strategies like handing out masks at churches and other public events — could save thousands of lives each day globally and hundreds each day in the United States.

headline: The Limits of ‘My Body, My Choice’
keywords: ['internal-sub-only', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Abortion', 'Christians and Christianity', "Women's Rights", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Prioritizing individual freedom is not enough to bring about a just society.
lead_paragraph: At a protest against vaccine mandates, a hospital worker told New York’s Livingston County newspaper: “If you want it? Great. If you don’t? Great.” She continued: “Choice is where we stand. If you want it, we’re not against it. That’s your choice.” Those I know who have refused to get vaccinated or wear masks have echoed this same idea. They assure me that they aren’t telling anyone else what to do but that this is a matter of personal choice. They are doing what they think is best for themselves and their families.

headline: The N.B.A. denies Andrew Wiggins’s request for a religious exemption from the vaccine.
abstract: Unless he gets vaccinated, Mr. Wiggins will be barred from attending home games in San Francisco, where his team is based.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. has denied the request of Andrew Wiggins, a Golden State Warriors player, for a religious exemption from the coronavirus vaccine, which is required in San Francisco to attend large indoor events, including Warriors home games.

headline: The Maps That Steer Us Wrong
abstract: Misleading maps are leading us astray.
lead_paragraph: Too many of our digital maps are sellouts.

headline: In-person turnout is lower than in 2017, but mail-in ballots may boost overall numbers.
abstract: Voter turnout in Germany  — as a measure of the  people visiting polling stations — was down on Sunday when compared to the last election in 2017, officials said. But the number is misleading. Participation could be extraordinarily high once mail-in ballots are counted.
lead_paragraph: Voter turnout in Germany  — as a measure of the  people visiting polling stations — was down on Sunday when compared to the last election in 2017, officials said. But the number is misleading. Participation could be extraordinarily high once mail-in ballots are counted.

headline: Amtrak Derailment in Montana Leaves At Least 3 Dead
abstract: The authorities said at least three people were killed and 50 others were injured in a derailment involving eight cars of an Empire Builder train near Joplin, Mont.
lead_paragraph: The authorities said at least three people were killed and 50 others were injured in a derailment involving eight cars of an Empire Builder train near Joplin, Mont.

headline: How China Plans to Avert an Evergrande Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Control of the banking system gives Beijing the tools to stop a broader collapse, officials believe, while censorship and police powers can stifle protests.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In any other country, the sudden collapse of a corporate titan with more than $300 billion in debt would send shock waves across the economy. Headlines would blare. Banks would shudder. Investors would panic.

headline: South Korea will start giving vaccine boosters amid a surge in Covid cases.
abstract: The country has seen a spike in infections after Chuseok, a three-day holiday celebrating the fall harvest.
lead_paragraph: The Prime Minister of South Korea said on Sunday that the nation would soon start administering booster shots to medical workers and people in their 60s and older, as the country battled a new wave of infections after a national holiday.

headline: Bobby Zarem, ‘Superflack’ and Maker of Stars, Dies at 84
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Movies', 'Theater', 'News and News Media']
abstract: As a spirited impresario of public relations, he promoted entertainers, films and the “I Love New York” tourism campaign.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Zarem, the exuberant press agent who fulfilled his childhood fantasies by catching rising stars and promoting them to stellar careers, died on Sunday at his home in Savannah, Ga. He was 84.

headline: Théoneste Bagosora, a Mastermind of Rwanda Genocide, Dies at 80
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mr. Bagosora was convicted of genocide for ordering a massacre in the capital and the killing of top officials, including the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Théoneste Bagosora, a senior Rwandan military figure who was one of the masterminds of the Rwandan genocide, died on Saturday in a prison in Mali. He was 80.

headline: Antibody Treatments: Paying for Anti-Vaxxers’ Irresponsibility
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Antibodies', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Abortion', 'Wildlife Trade and Poaching', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Elderly', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Antivaxxers and antibodies; a false health care choice; recalling an abortion; wild animals in national parks; whitewashing Jan. 6.
